[[Zana (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 drama movies, Kosovan movies

Zana is a 2019 Kosovan drama movie directed by Antoneta Kastrati. It was selected as the Kosovan entry for the Best International Feature Film at the 92nd Academy Awards, but it was not nominated.

[[Fringed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs, Animals of Oceania

The fringed tree frog, Lönnberg's tree frog or green-eyed frog (Ranoidea eucnemis) is a frog from New Guinea and Australia. Scientists saw it on the Huon Peninsula and parts of the Cape York Peninsula in Queensland.

This frog lives in rainforests.  It lives near streams with many rocks in them.  It lays eggs during the spring and summer, 800-900 at a time.  The female frog lays eggs in clumps.  The tadpoles can swim well in the fast water.  They become frogs after 60-80 days.

This frog is not endangered now, but some of the things that humans do are bad for it.  Years ago, taking trees for wood meant there was less forest for the frogs to live in.  Now, the biggest dangers to the frogs are things that make their water worse, like grazing.

[[Unwanted (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 movies, Kosovan movies, Albanian-language movies, Dutch-language movies

Unwanted (Albanian: T'padashtun) is a 2017 Kosovan movie drama directed by Edon Rizvanolli. It was selected as the Kosovan entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 90th Academy Awards, but it was not nominated.

[[Agon (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 movies, 2012 drama movies, Albanian movies, Albanian-language movies

Agon is a 2012 Albanian movie drama directed by Robert Budina. The film was selected as the Albanian entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 86th Academy Awards, but it was not nominated.

[[Roberta Stewart]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, New Zealand water polo players

Roberta Stewart (born 16 June 1981) is a New Zealand water polo player. She competed for the New Zealand women's national water polo team in the 2007 World Aquatics Championships.

She played for Marist club in Auckland, and Long Beach State University.

[[Revision (demoparty)]]

CATEGORIES: Events in Europe, Germany

Revision is a demoparty that happens in Saarbrücken, Germany. As with its predecessors, it happens every Easter weekend. It is the successor of the Breakpoint demoparty, and still has much of its organizing staff. The event started in 2011, after Breakpoint had announced its end in 2010.

Around 800 people from around the world go to Revision every year. It is currently the biggest pure demoscene event in the world.

[[Rebecca Donoghue]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, New Zealand sportspeople, Water polo players

Rebecca Donoghue (born 24 December 1981) is a New Zealand water polo player. She competed for the New Zealand women's national water polo team in the 2005 World Aquatics Championships, 2006 Commonwealth Games, and 2007 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Olivia Colebourne]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, New Zealand water polo players

Olivia Colebourne (born 27 June 1983) is a New Zealand water polo player. She competed for the New Zealand women's national water polo team in the 2007 World Aquatics Championships.

She played for Hartwick University.

[[Federica Lavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Italian water polo players

Federica Eugenia Lavi (born 22 February 1994) is an Italian water polo player. She competed for the Italy women's national water polo team in the 2017 World Aquatics Championships, 2018 Women's European Water Polo Championship, and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Gje]]

CATEGORIES: Cyrillic letters

Gje (Ѓ ѓ) is the 5th letter of the Macedonian alphabet.

Gje is derived from the Cyrillic letter Ge.

[[Patrizia Giancotti]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, European anthropologists, Italian photographers, Italian journalists, Italian radio personalities, People from Turin

Patrizia Giancotti (born 26 June 1958 in Turin) is an Italian anthropologist, photographer, journalist, author, and radio presenter.

She teaches anthropology at Sigmund Freud University Milano , and at the Academy of Fine Arts in Reggio Calabria. She is the author and presenter of  the Wikiradio, Passioni, Tre Soldi programs on Rai Radio 3.  

She carried out his research in visual anthropology in Italy and abroad, particularly in Brazil, where she lived for over ten years, collaborating with the writer Jorge Amado. She studied the priestesses of the Bahia, to worship of the Siren, and  Amazonian shamanism; and in Benin, where she carried out research on African religious traditions.  For her work in cultural broadcasting, she received the "Abèbè of Oxum" Award from the Mayor of Salvador da Bahia, Lidice da Mata, and the  High Honor of the Cruzeiro do Sul, from the government of Brazil.

She carried out surveys of visual anthropology in Southern Italy. For the Brazilian Embassy, ​​with the help of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Brasil Telecom, and Banco do Brasil, she has conceived and edited Musica Brasileira na Sala Palestrina, two volumes containing audio and video recordings of music concerts held in the historic hall of Palazzo Pamphilj. She has worked with Ennio Morricone, and José Carreras. She worked with Luigi Ontani at the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art of Trento and Rovereto.

She holds courses and seminars in various Italian universities. Since 2003, she worked for national radio, as a host in the programs  "Wikiradio" and "Passioni", on Rai Radio 3.  

[[Mod Archive]]

CATEGORIES: Music, Websites

The Mod Archive is a website that is an archive and index of music module files. Anyone can upload music module files to the website, and the community makes charts, reviews and ratings of them.

The website covers these formats: MOD, IT, XM, AHX, MED, STM, S3M, MO3, MTM, 669, AMF, AMS, DBM, DIGI, DMF, DSM, FAR, GDM, IMF, J2B, MDL, MPTM, MT2, OKT, PLM, PTM, STM, ULT and HVL.

[[Angeliki Chadzimichali]]

CATEGORIES: 1895 births, 1965 deaths, Historians, Greek people

Angeliki Chadzimichali (Greek: Αγγελική Χατζημιχάλη; 1895 – 1965) was a Greek historian and folklore researcher. She won the 1959 Purfina Prize.

[[TraxWeekly]]

CATEGORIES: Music magazines, Music

TraxWeekly was one of the main PC demoscene e-zines (electronic magazines) of 1990s. The other one was DemoNews.

TraxWeekly only focused on music and used to be the most important source of news on tracker music and major releases in the music industry. It ran for 119 issues from March 12, 1995 to February 16, 1998. When it ended, over eleven hundred subscribers were getting it. It used a strong format that included interviews, reviews, and on-the-spot reports from major demo parties from all over the world. After it ended, it was largely replaced by Static Line, another e-zine, which was created by Coplan/SceneSpot.

[[Helen Antoniadis-Bibicou]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2017 deaths, People from Athens, Historians

Helen Antoniadis-Bibicou  (21 July 1923 – 12 or 13 June 2017) was a Greek Marxist Byzantine scholar. She studied Byzantine history, and modern Greek studies. She was an active member of the Greek Communist Party in France.

A horror story is a story made to scare people. It is like a horror movie but in a book or told by others.

[[Antonella Lattanzi]]

Antonella Lattanzi (born 1979 in Bari) is an Italian novelist and screenwriter. She was a finalist at the 2013 Stresa Prize. She won the 2017 Cortina d'Ampezzo Prize.

[[Boris Klyuyev]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian stage actors, Russian educators, Actors from Moscow

Boris Vladimirovich Klyuyev (Бори́с Влади́мирович Клю́ев; 13 July 1944 — 1 September 2020) was a Soviet and Russian actor and teacher. He was named a People's Artist of Russia in 2002. He was born in Moscow. Klyuyev D'Artagnan and Three Musketeers, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson and TASS Is Authorized to Declare....

Klyuyev died on 1 September 2020 in Moscow from lung cancer, aged 76.

[[People's Artist of Russia]]

CATEGORIES: Russia

People's Artist of the Russian Federation (Народный артист Российской Федерации, Narodnyy artist Rossiyskoy Federatsii), also sometimes translated as National Artist of the Russian Federation, is an honorary and the highest title awarded to citizens of the Russian Federation. They honor people who are important in performing arts (theatre, music, dance, circus, cinema, etc.).

[[Erick Morillo]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2020 deaths, People who committed suicide, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Colombian people, American DJs, Record producers, Musicians from Miami, Florida

Erick Morillo (March 26, 1971 – September 1, 2020) was a Colombian-American disc jockey, music producer, and record label owner. Morillo was best known for his international work in house music for the label Strictly Rhythm. He helped produce the 1993 hit "I Like to Move It".

He won the Muzik magazine "Remixer of the Year" award in 1999. 

On August 6, 2020, Morillo was arrested and charged with sexual battery upon a woman.

Morillo was found dead at his home in Miami Beach, Florida from a possible suicide on September 1, 2020 at the age of 49.

[[Fondation Louis-Vuitton]]

CATEGORIES: Art museums in France, Buildings and structures in Paris

The Fondation Louis-Vuitton is a modern art museum in Paris, France, on 8 Avenue du Mahatma Gandhi. It has been created in 2014.

Some of the artists featured at the museum include Jean-Michel Basquiat, Gilbert & George and Jeff Koons.

[[Kang Kek Iew]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Cambodian people, Military people, Criminals

Kang Kek Iew or Kaing Kek Iev, also romanized as Kaing Guek Eav (កាំង ហ្គេកអ៊ាវ), nom de guerre Comrade Duch or Deuch (មិត្តឌុច); or Hang Pin, (17 November 1942 – 2 September 2020) was a Cambodian war criminal. He was leader in the Khmer Rouge movement, which ruled Democratic Kampuchea from 1975 to 1979. 

He was responsible for the Tuol Sleng (S-21) prison camp where thousands were held for interrogation and torture, after which many of these prisoners were eventually executed.

Kek Iew died at the age of 77 at a hospital in Phnom Penh on 2 September 2020. The cause of death was lung disease.

[[Hans A. Linde]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, German politicians, German lawyers, American educators, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Berlin, Politicians from Portland, Oregon

Hans Arthur Linde (April 15, 1924 – August 31, 2020) was a German-born American legal scholar and lawyer. He was born in Berlin. He was nominated by Governor Robert W. Straub to be the 79th Associate Justice of the Oregon Supreme Court in 1977. He retired in 1990.

Linde died on August 31, 2020 in Portland, Oregon at the age of 96.

[[Pascal Kané]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, French movie actors, French movie directors, French screenwriters, French educators

Pascal Kané (January 21, 1946 – August 31, 2020) was a French movie director, screenwriter and actor. He was on the editorial staff of Cahiers du Cinéma from 1969 to 1979. He taught cinema at Université Paris III.

He was known for directing and writing Liberty Belle. He starred in India Song and The Suspended Vocation. He was born in Angoulême, Charente.

Kané died on August 31, 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Lance Finch]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian lawyers, Canadian judges, Politicians from Alberta, Politicians from British Columbia, People from Edmonton

Lance Sydney George Finch, CAN (16 June 1938 – 31 August 2020) was a Canadian lawyer and politician. He was the Chief Justice of the British Columbia Court of Appeal from June 6, 2011 until his retirement on June 16, 2013. Finch was born in Edmonton, Alberta.

Finch died on 31 August 2020 in Vancouver, British Columbia at the age of 82.

[[Virginia Bosler]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, American stage actors, American dancers, Actors from Massachusetts, People from Newton, Massachusetts, 1926 births

Virginia Bosler (September 23, 1926 – August 30, 2020) was an American actress and dancer. She was born in Newton, Massachusetts. She was known for being an original cast member for the Broadway classics Oklahoma! and Brigadoon.

Bosler died on August 30, 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Martin O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of Clackmannan]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United Kingdom, UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997, UK MPs 1997–2001, UK MPs 2001–2005, Politicians from Edinburgh, Former Labour MPs (UK)

Martin John O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of Clackmannan (6 January 1945 – 26 August 2020) was a Scottish Labour politician. He was a Member of Parliament from 1979 until 2005 and as a member of the House of Lords from 2005 until his death in 2020. He was in the Neil Kinnock Shadow Government between 1988 to 1992. O'Neill was born in Edinburgh.

O'Neill died on 26 August 2020 in Edinburgh from cancer, aged 75.

[[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of the United Kingdom

In British parliamentary practice, the Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (usually known simply as the shadow cabinet) is made up of senior members of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition who criticize the current government ministers and create alternative policies.

Since 11 May 2010, the Labour Party has been Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition, and its leadership therefore forms the current shadow cabinet.

[[Maz Jobrani]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Iranian actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Comedians from California, Actors from California, People from Tehran

Maziyar Jobrani (مازیار جبرانی; born February 26, 1972) is an Iranian-American comedian and actor. He was born in Tehran. He is known for being part of the "Axis of Evil" comedy group. 

His best known movies are The Interpreter, Friday After Next, Dragonfly, and Jimmy Vestvood: Amerikan Hero. He appeared as a regular character on the 2017 CBS sitcom Superior Donuts.

[[Great Malvern]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Worcestershire

Great Malvern is an area of the spa town of Malvern, Worcestershire, England. It lies at the foot of the Malvern Hills. It is on the eastern flanks of the Worcestershire Beacon and North Hill, and is the historic centre of Malvern and includes its town centre.

[[Sign of the Times (Harry Styles song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 songs

"Sign of the Times" is the debut single by English singer Harry Styles from his self-titled debut studio album. 

It was released on 7 April 2017 by Columbia Records. It was written by Styles, Jeff Bhasker, Mitch Rowland, Ryan Nasci, Alex Salibian, and Tyler Johnson, and produced by Bhasker, Salibian, and Johnson.

It is a pop rock and soft rock ballad. Its music video was released on 8 May.

[[Yulian Semyonov]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 1993 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Russian novelists, Russian screenwriters, Russian poets, Soviet writers, Writers from Moscow

Yulian Semyonovich Semyonov (Юлиа́н Семёнович Семёнов, jʉlʲɪˈan sʲɪˈmʲɵnəvʲɪtɕ sʲɪˈmʲɵnəf), pen-name of Yulian Semyonovich Lyandres (Ля́ндрес) (October 8, 1931 – September 15, 1993), was a Soviet and Russian novelist, screenwriter and poet. His works were mainly spy fiction and detective fiction. He was born in Moscow. His best known novel was Seventeen Moments of Spring.

Semyonov died on September 15, 1993 from a stroke in Moscow, aged 61.

[[The Jackal (2010 movie)]]

The Jackal (Çakal) is a 2010 Turkish action movie directed by Erhan Kozan and starring İsmail Hacıoğlu, Erkan Can, Uğur Polat, Haldun Boysan, Turgay Tanülkü, Damla Sönmez.

[[Children of Men]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 movies, 2000s science fiction movies, 2000s action movies, American science fiction movies, American action movies, British science fiction movies, British action movies, Japanese movies, Movies directed by Alfonso Cuarón, Post-apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

Children of Men is a 2006 American British Japanese science fiction action movie directed by Alfonso Cuarón and was based on the 1992 novel of the same name by P.D. James. It stars Clive Owen, Michael Caine, Julianne Moore, Pam Ferris, Danny Huston, Clare-Hope Ashitey, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Oana Pellea and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 2007.

[[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 establishments in New York (state), Companies based in New York City, Finance

KKR & Co. Inc. (formerly known as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and KKR & Co. L.P.) is an American global investment company. It manages many assets, including private equity, energy, infrastructure, real estate, credit, and, through its strategic partners, hedge funds. 

The firm has completed more than 280 private equity investments in portfolio companies with about $545 billion of total enterprise value as of June 30, 2017. As of September 30, 2017, Assets Under Management ("AUM") and Fee Paying Assets Under Management ("FPAUM") were $153 billion and $114 billion, respectively.

[[Neshat Jahandari]]

CATEGORIES: Iranian people

Neshat Jahandari is the first female Captain flying the MD80 based in Tehran, Iran. She is the second Iranian woman to qualify as a commercial airline pilot. 

She has flown 3000 thousand hours and is the youngest and only MD80 female captain of the Iranian airline. After qualifying as an airline captain, the company's video went viral.  

Another fame wave came when she made history being the Captain of the first all-female-crew operating a flight from Tehran to the northeastern city of Mashhad.

The departing flight from the capital Tehran to Mashhad in northeast Iran was done with 160 passengers on Monday, and the return flight carried 171 passengers.

Captain Jahandari posted about the news on her Instagram page, describing it as a “historic event” in Iran’s aviation industry.

[[Assia Erramy]]

Assia Erramy (born 1 January 1990) is a Moroccan volleyball player. She is a member of the Moroccan women's volley-ball team. She won a bronze medal at the 2019 African Games.

[[Sharon Chepchumba Kiprono]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Kenyan volleyball players

Sharon Chepchumba Kiprono (born 26 October 1998) is a Kenyan female volleyball player. She is part of the Kenya women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2018 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix. She won a gold medal at the 2019 African Games.

At the club level, she plays for KCB.

[[Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum]]

CATEGORIES: Cambodia, Museums in Asia

The Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum (សារមន្ទីរឧក្រិដ្ឋកម្មប្រល័យពូជសាសន៍ទួលស្លែង) is a museum in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. It talks about the Cambodian genocide. The site is a former secondary school which was used as Security Prison 21 (S-21) by the Khmer Rouge regime from its rise to power in 1975 to its fall in 1979. 

From 1976 to 1979, about 20,000 people were imprisoned at Tuol Sleng (the real number is unknown). Tuol Sleng (ទួលស្លែង tuəl slaeŋ) means "Hill of the Poisonous Trees" or "Strychnine Hill". 

Tuol Sleng was just one of at least 150 torture and execution centers created by the Khmer Rouge. 

On July 26, 2010, the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia convicted the chief of Tuol Sleng Prison, Kang Kek Iew (alias Duch), for crimes against humanity and grave breaches of the 1949 Geneva Conventions and sentenced him to life imprisonment.

[[Cambodian genocide]]

CATEGORIES: Cambodia, Genocide

The Cambodian genocide (ហាយនភាពខ្មែរ or ការប្រល័យពូជសាសន៍ខ្មែរ, Génocide cambodgien) was the mass killing of Cambodians by the Khmer Rouge under the leadership of Pol Pot who pushed Cambodia towards communism. It resulted in the deaths of 1.5 to 2 million people from 1975 to 1979. This was a quarter of Cambodia's 1975 population (circa 7.8 million).

To push  its goals, the Khmer Rouge emptied the cities and forced Cambodians to relocate to labor camps in the countryside, where mass executions, forced labor, physical abuse, malnutrition, and disease happened. 

[[Park Man Bok]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2019 deaths, South Korean volleyball players, Volleyball coaches

Park Man Bok (30 August 1936 in Seoul - 26 September 2019 in Lima) was a South Korean volleyball player and coach. He was elected to the Volleyball Hall of Fame.

He studied at Kyung Hee University. From 1960 to 1964, he served in the Korean Army. From 1965 to 1968, he coached Soong Eui Women’s College. From 1969 to 1972, he coached the Korean Air team. He coached the South Korea women's national volleyball team at the 1973 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Cup.

He coached the Peru national women’s volleyball team, at the 1974 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 1978 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 1982 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 1986 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 1990 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 1976 Summer Olympics, 1980 Summer Olympics, 1984 Summer Olympics, 1988 Summer Olympics, and 2000 Summer Olympics.

[[Philippe Daverio]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, French writers, French politicians, French educators, French television personalities, Italian television personalities, Italian politicians, Italian writers, People from Milan

Philippe Daverio (17 October 1949 – 2 September 2020) was a French-born Italian art critic, teacher, writer, author, politician, and television personality. He was the official cultural officer of Milan during the 1990s. He was born in Mulhouse, France.

Daverio organized many exhibitions, including Andy Warhol's Last Supper at Galleria del Credito Valtellinese in Milan. He also edited a book on Giorgio De Chirico's work between 1924 and 1929.

From 2002 to 2012 he hosted Passepartout, a series on art and culture on Rai 3.

In 2009, he became a city councilor of Milan.

Daverio died on 2 September 2020 in Milan from brain cancer, aged 70.

[[Ranoidea exophthalmia]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Ranoidea exophthalmia (also known as the big-eyed tree frog) is a tree frog from New Guinea.  Scientists found it between 730 and 850 meters above sea level.

[[Ieng Sary]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from bowel obstruction, Cambodian people, Criminals

Ieng Sary (អៀង សារី; 24 October 1925 – 14 March 2013) was a senior member of the Khmer Rouge. He was a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Kampuchea led by Pol Pot. He worked in the Democratic Kampuchea as foreign minister and deputy prime minister. 

His wife, Ieng Thirith also was part in the Khmer Rouge government as social affairs minister. 

Ieng Sary was arrested in 2007 and was charged with crimes against humanity just like Pol Pot & Nuon Cheahttp://vodenglish.news/nuon-cheas-genocide-conviction-stands-but-final-judgement-left-unsaid. He died of heart failure and intestinal blockage before trial commenced.

[[Anni Lanz]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Swiss activists, Human rights activists

Anni Lanz (born 1945) is a Swiss human rights activist, with a focus on refugee policy in Switzerland. She was head of the refugee aid organization Solidarité sans frontières. She was nominated as one of five Swiss women in the 1000 Women project for the 2005 Nobel Peace Prize. In 2007, she was awarded the Fischhof Prize, which is awarded by the Foundation Against Racism and Anti-Semitism (GRA) and the Society for Minorities in Switzerland (GMS).

[[James Mayer de Rothschild]]

CATEGORIES: 1792 births, 1868 deaths, French philanthropists, French businesspeople, German businesspeople, German philanthropists, Bankers, Legion of Honour, French Jews, German Jews

James Mayer de Rothschild, Baron de Rothschild  (15 May 1792 – 15 November 1868), born Jakob Mayer Rothschild, was a German-French banker. He was the founder of the French branch of the Rothschild family.

[[Elisabeth Decrey-Warner]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Swiss activists, Swiss politicians

Elisabeth Decrey-Warner (born Elisabeth Reusse-Decrey on 16 October 1953) is a Swiss psychotherapist and peace activist. She was president of World Organisation Against Torture. She founded Geneva Call. In 2000, she was President of Swiss Parliament. She was 2005 Nobel Peace Prize nominee.

From 1989 to 2001, she was a member of the Parliament of the Republic and Canton of Geneva. She has supported humanitarian aid work, despite the interference of counter-terror laws.

[[Big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Africa, Frogs

The big-eyed tree frog, Amani Forest tree frog, vermiculated tree frog (Leptopelis vermiculatus) is a frog from the Eastern Arc Mountains and a few other places in Tanzania. Scientists saw it on between 900 and 1800 meters above sea level.

The adult male frog is 3.9 to 5.0 cm long and the female is 6.1 to 8.5 cm long.  It lives in forests.  It likes to sit on tree limbs hanging over the water.

All young frogs and some adult males are bright green with a black pattern.  Adult females and many adult males are gold-brown in color, with patterns on their backs and dark marks behind their eyes. This frog has discs at the ends of its toes.  These discs help it climb.

This frog is endangered because humans like to cut down its forests to build farms.  These are mostly small farms, not large corporate farms.  In many of the places where this frog lives, there are no laws against doing this.

[[Tayfun Gönül]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2012 deaths, Turkish people, Nonviolence advocates, Anarchists

Tayfun Gönül (1958, Izmit - July 30 2012 in Istanbul) was a Turkish writer, doctor, Turkey's 'first conscientious objector,' and anarchist.

[[Niihau Incident]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century in Hawaii, World War II

The Niʻihau incident occurred on December 7–13, 1941, when Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service pilot Shigenori Nishikaichi crash-landed his Zero (aircraft) on the Hawaiian island of Niʻihau after participating in the attack on Pearl Harbor.

[[Hélène Monastier]]

CATEGORIES: 1882 births, 1976 deaths, Swiss teachers

Hélène Monastier (2 December 1882 in Payerne - 7 March 1976 in Lausanne) was a Swiss teacher. She was a well-known person of the Christian Socialists, the International Civil Service and the Religious Society of Friends in French-speaking Switzerland.

[[Dhanial]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in Pakistan, Pakistani tribes, Punjabi people

Dhanial is one of the largest tribe living in Potohar plateau and Lower Himalayas for the last eight centuries Most of the Dhanyals are settled in the cities of Rawalpindi, Islamabad and in Kotli Sattian and Murree Hills.

[[Scottish Parliament (Constituencies) Act 2004]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Scotland

The Scottish Parliament (Constituencies) Act 2004 (c 13) is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom that amends the Scotland Act 1998. The 1998 Act originally created the Scottish Parliament.

[[Adventure game]]

CATEGORIES: Types of video games, Video game genres

An adventure game is a type of video game or computer game.  Gameplay in adventure games is mostly exploration, solving puzzles and finishing stories.  Some adventure games also have combat systems so the player can fight enemies like in an action game, beat 'em up or role-playing game, but many adventure games have no fighting in them at all.  The first adventure game was Colossal Cave Adventure in 1975.

In adventure games, the player usually acts through a character in the story.  This character sometimes has a history. For example Roger Sams in Bad Mojo is a sad insect scientist and Alexander in King's Quest VI is a prince trying to rescue a princess.  Other player characters have almost no history.  In Myst and Zork, the game does not even give the player character a name.  Other characters and the game's voice call the player "you."

Adventure games can be played on computers, for example PCs and Macs.  Adventure games can be played on consoles, for example Playstations and Xboxes.

Many adventure games are called point-and-click adventure games because the player uses a computer mouse to click on things on the screen.  Not all adventure games do this.  In the 1996 game Bad Mojo, the player can only use the computer's arrow keys.  In the 1977 game Zork, the player must write commands using the keyboard.

Because they are about exploration, adventure games usually have an interesting world setting.  Some games have art with painted graphics.  Others show off the newest image-making technology, for example Myst.  Other games, like the early Zork games, had no graphics at all.  The Zork games told the player what was happening using words.

Some famous adventure game series are Myst by Brøderbund, Monkey Island by LucasArts, and the King's Quest and Quest for Glory series by Sierra on-line.

[[Fish fry]]

CATEGORIES: Seafood

A fish fry is a meal of battered or breaded fish, which is fried. With the fish, there are French fries, hot sauce, dessert, tartar sauce and/or hush puppies. 

Fish is often served on Friday nights during Lent as a restaurant special or under church fundraisers.

Fish fries are very common in the Midwest and Northeastern United States.

[[Seres Produções]]

CATEGORIES: Record labels

[[Batter (cooking)]]

CATEGORIES: Doughs

Batter is thin dough that can be easily poured into a pan. Batter is used mainly for pancakes, light cakes and as the coating for some fried foods. The word batter comes from a French word battre. Battre means beat. Many batters require vigorous beating or whisking in their preparation.

A number of batters are made by combining dry flour with liquids, like eggs, milk and water. Often, a leavening agent such as baking powder is included to fluff up the batter while it cooks. The mixture may be naturally fermented for this actual purpose, as well as to add flavor.

The viscosity of batter may be from very 'heavy" to "thin". Heat is applied to the batter, often by frying, baking or steaming in order to cook the ingredients and to "set" the batter in a solid form.

[[Treehouse of Horror III]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 4) episodes, 1992 television episodes, Treehouse of Horror

"Treehouse of Horror III" is the 5th episode of The Simpsons' fourth season. It was first shown on television on October 29, 1992.  It is the third episode of the Treehouse of Horror series. In the episode, Bart gets an evil talking doll, King Homer is taken by Mr. Burns, and Bart and Lisa start a zombie apocalypse.

The episode was written by Al Jean, Mike Reiss, Jay Kogen, Wallace Wolodarsky, Sam Simon, and Jon Vitti. Carlos Baeza is the director for the episode.

[[Ivy Bethune]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2019 deaths, American actors

Ivy Bethune (1 June 1918 – 19 July 2019) was the actress who played Duana in the Star Trek: The Next Generation first season episode "When The Bough Breaks." Bethune also played Ma Peabody in the 1985 movie Back to the Future. 

In 2019 when she died, Bethune was the second-oldest living female Star Trek performer, after Marsha Hunt. She was the third oldest overall Star Trek performer after Hunt and Norman Lloyd. She was the sixth Star Trek performer to reach the age of 100, after Viola Stimpson, Ellen Albertini Dow, Olaf Pooley, Lloyd, and Hunt.

She died of natural causes in Woodland Hills, California.

[[Agustín Roberto Radrizzani]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine people, Roman Catholic bishops, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina

Agustín Roberto Radrizzani, SDB (September 22, 1944 – September 2, 2020) was an Argentine prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Mercedes-Luján from 2007 until 2019.

Radrizzani became a priest on March 25, 1972.

On May 14, 1991, he became the Bishop of Neuquén by Pope John Paul II. 

He was later named Bishop of Lomas de Zamora on April 24, 2001. He was promoted by Pope Benedict XVI to Archbishop of Mercedes-Luján on December 27, 2007. 

He died on September 2, 2020 from COVID-19, aged 75.

[[David Capel]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, English cricketers, People from Northampton

David John Capel (6 February 1963 – 2 September 2020) was an English cricketer. He played for Northamptonshire and England.

He was part of the Northamptonshire County Cricket Club both as a player as well as coach for 32 years. 

He became the assistant coach of the England women's cricket team in 2013, staying in the role until 2015. 

In October 2016, he was appointed by the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB) as the head coach of the Bangladesh women's cricket team. 

In 2018, he was diagnosed with brain cancer. He died from the disease on 2 September 2020, aged 57.

[[The Killing Game (1967 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 comedy movies, French comedy movies, Movies directed by Alain Jessua

The Killing Game (Jeu de massacre) is a 1967 French comedy movie directed by Alain Jessua and starring Jean-Pierre Cassel, Claudine Auger, Michel Duchaussoy, Nancy Holloway.

[[Yellow-bellied weasel]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of Asia, Mustelids

The yellow-bellied weasel (Mustela kathiah) is a type of weasel. It lives in pine forests in central and eastern Asia.

Céline Ferer (born 21 June 1991) is a French rugby union player. She played for the France women's national rugby union team. She played in the 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup, and 2020 Women's Six Nations Championship.

She played with Stade Toulousain.

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Russian sportspeople, Rugby union players, Rugby sevens players

Yulia Vitalievna Rudenko (born Yulia Guzeva on 26 May 1990 in Krasnodar) is a Russian rugby union player, and 2014 rugby sevens champion. She participated at the 2014 Rugby Europe Women's Sevens Grand Prix Series, and 2016 Rugby Europe Women's Sevens Grand Prix Series, and 2016 European Rugby Championship, and 2019–20 Rugby Europe Championships.

She plays for Krasny Yar.

[[Voorhout]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of South Holland, Settlements in South Holland, Teylingen

Voorhout (ˈvoːrɦʌut) is a village and former municipality in the western Netherlands. It is in the province of South Holland. It had a population of 14,792 in 2004. Together with Sassenheim and Warmond, it has become part of the Teylingen municipality on January 1, 2006. 

Voorhout is located in an area called the "Dune and Bulb Region" (Duin- en Bollenstreek).

[[Lisse]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of South Holland, Cities in the Netherlands, Settlements in South Holland

Lisse (ˈlɪsə) is a town and municipality in the western Netherlands, in the province of South Holland. 

It covers an area of 16.05 km2 (6.20 sq mi). Its population was 22,800 in 2019.

[[Laskovyi Mai]]

CATEGORIES: Russian musical groups

Laskovyi Mai (may be spelled also as Laskovyy May, Laskovy May, Laskovy Mai, Laskoviy May; Ласковый май) was a Soviet boy band from Moscow. It was founded by Russian songwriter, composer and musician Sergei Kuznetsov. 

The group's best-known member was Yuri Shatunov. The groupd ended in 1992. Laskovyi Mai once had been called "the legends of the 80–90s".

[[Yuri Shatunov]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Russian singers

Yuriy Vasilevich Shatunov, commonly anglicized as Yuri (Russian:Юрий Васильевич Шатунов) (born 6 September 1973) is a Russian singer. He was best known for being the former frontman of the Russian 1980s band Laskoviy Mai (Ласковый май). He was born in Kumertau, Bashkir ASSR.

[[Albert Cheesebrough]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Lancashire, English footballers

Albert Cheesebrough (17 January 1935 – 2 September 2020) was an English footballer. He was a forward. He scored 88 goals in 345 leagues games over a sixteen-year professional career in the Football League.

Cheesebrough died in Southport on 2 September 2020, aged 85.

[[Bay City Rollers]]

CATEGORIES: Scottish musical groups

The Bay City Rollers are a Scottish pop rock in the 1970s. They were called the "teen sensations from Edinburgh".

The group's line-up had many changes over the years, but the classic line-up were guitarists Eric Faulkner and Stuart Wood, singer Les McKeown, bassist Alan Longmuir, and drummer Derek Longmuir.

[[Melanie Wade Goodwin]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from breast cancer, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from North Carolina, Politicians from Virginia, People from Richmond, Virginia, US Democratic Party politicians

Melanie Wade Goodwin (July 22, 1970 – September 1, 2020) was an American politician. Goodwin was in the North Carolina House of Representatives from the 66th district as a member of the Democratic Party. She was in office between 2005 and 2011.

She was the first member of the North Carolina General Assembly to give birth while in office.

Goodwin was born in Richmond, Virginia. She studied at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and at Campbell University.

In 2009, Goodwin was diagnosed with breast cancer. She died on September 1, 2020 from the disease, aged 50.

[[Hugh Cochrane (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish footballers, Sportspeople from Glasgow

Hugh Cochrane (9 February 1943 – 17 August 2020) was a Scottish professional footballer. He was born in Glasgow. His career lasted between 1961 to 1966.

He played as an inside forward. He played junior football for Dennistoun Waverley before signing for Dundee United in 1961. 

He signed for Barnsley in August 1963, making five Football League appearances. After leaving Barnsley, Cochrane played non-League football for Wimbledon, Ashford Town (Kent) and Margate.

Cochrane died on 17 August 2020 in Glasgow, aged 77.

[[Buffalo Wild Wings]]

CATEGORIES: American restaurants, 1982 establishments in the United States

Buffalo Wild Wings (nicknamed B-Dubs) is an American casual dining restaurant franchise. The restaurant does business in the United States, Canada, Mexico, India, Panama, the Philippines and several other countries.

The company was founded in 1982. It was originally called Buffalo Wild Wings & Weck.

As of June 2017, the company had 1,238 locations in all 50 states and the District of Columbia.

The company's headquarters is in Sandy Springs, Georgia. Sandy Springs is home to its parent company, Inspire Brands, which is just north of Atlanta. The brand runs its support center from Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The chain is best known for buffalo wings and for other items, such as chicken tenders and legs.

[[Peter Erskine]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, American drummers, American jazz musicians, Musicians from New Jersey

Peter Erskine (born June 5, 1954) is an American jazz drummer. He was a member of the jazz fusion groups Weather Report and Steps Ahead. Erskine was born in Somers Point, New Jersey. His career began in 1972.

[[Somers Point, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Jersey

Somers Point is the oldest settlement in Atlantic County, New Jersey, United States. It was first settled in 1693. At the 2010 United States Census, the city's population was 10,795.

[[David Kelly]]

David Kelly may refer to:

[[David Kelly (weapons expert)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2003 deaths, Suicides by blade weapons, English scientists, People from Glamorgan, Drug-related suicides

David Christopher Kelly GBR (14 May 1944 – 17 July 2003) was a Welsh scientist. He was a well known person in biological warfare (BW). He was born in Glamorgan.

In July 2003 he had an off-the-record conversation with BBC's Andrew Gilligan, during their discussion they talked about the 2002 dossier on Iraqi weapons of mass destruction, which stated that some of Iraq's chemical and biological weapons were deployable within 45 minutes.

After the BBC interview, Kelly's was called to appear on 15 July before the parliamentary Intelligence and Security and Foreign Affairs Select committees. Two days later Kelly was found dead near his home, aged 59.

Kelly killed himself by cutting his wrist while taking a large amount of dextropropoxyphene at a woodland area in Oxfordshire.

[[Doctor Fate]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes

Doctor Fate (also known as Fate) is the name of multiple fictional superheroes appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics.

Many people become Doctor Fate in the DC Universe when they become sorcerers. The original version of the character was created by writer Gardner Fox and artist Howard Sherman, and first appeared in More Fun Comics #55 (May 1940).

He will be played by Pierce Brosnan in the DC Extended Universe movie Black Adam (2022).

[[Gardner Fox]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1986 deaths, American comics writers, Deaths from pneumonia, Writers from New York City

Gardner Francis Cooper Fox (May 20, 1911 – December 24, 1986) was an American comics writer. He was known best for creating many comic book characters for DC Comics. He created Hawkman, The Flash, The Justice League, Batgirl and Doctor Fate.

Fox was born in New York City. He died on December 25, 1986 in Princeton, New Jersey from pneumonia at the age of 75.

[[Hawkman]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes

Hawkman is the name of several fictional superheroes appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. He was created by writer Gardner Fox and artist Dennis Neville. The original Hawkman first appeared in Flash Comics #1, published by All-American Publications in 1940.

There has been many versions of Hawkman in DC Comics, all of them use archaic weaponry and  have large wings, attached to a harness made from the special metal that allows them to fly. Most versions of Hawkman work closely with a partner/romantic interest named Hawkgirl or Hawkwoman.

[[Hawkgirl]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes

Hawkgirl is the name of several fictional superheroines appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. The original Hawkgirl, Shiera Sanders Hall, was created by writer Gardner Fox and artist Dennis Neville. She first appeared in Flash Comics #1 (January 1940). She is a member of The Justice League.

She often works with and sometimes has a romantic relationship with Hawkman. 

[[Booster Gold]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes

Booster Gold (Michael Jon Carter) is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. He was created by Dan Jurgens. The character first appeared in Booster Gold #1 (February 1986). He is a member of the Justice League.

He is known for his knowledge of historical events and future technology to use as his superpower. Over the course of his publication history and through personal tragedies, he becomes a true hero weighed down by the bad things he did in the past.

[[American comic book]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 establishments in the United States, Comics

An American comic book is a thin book in the United States that has comics usually of superheroes. While it was created in 1933, American comic books first became popular after the 1938 publication of Action Comics, which included the debut of the superhero Superman.  

This was followed by a superhero boom that lasted until the end of World War II. After the war, while superheroes were well known, the comic book industry later made comics of horror, crime, science fiction and romance.

[[Calistoga, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Napa County, California

Calistoga is a city in Napa County, in California's Wine Country. During the 2010 census, the population was 5,155.

[[Global citizenship]]

CATEGORIES: Politics, Citizenship

Global citizenship is the idea that everyone is a member of the world. This means that everyone has duties and rights no matter what country they come from.

[[Sidney Jellicoe]]

CATEGORIES: 1906 births, 1973 deaths

Sidney Jellicoe (25 August 1906 – 24 November 1973) was a British-Canadian dean emeritus, biblical scholar, Harrold professor of Divinity, theological educator, priest and gentleman.

[[I can't breathe]]

CATEGORIES: Police misconduct, American civil rights

I can't breathe is a slogan tied to the Black Lives Matter movement in the United States. The phrase comes from the last words of Eric Garner. He was an unarmed black man who was killed in 2014 after being put in a chokehold by New York City police officers.

A number of other black men and women said the phrase. That included George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man in Minneapolis, Minnesota who was killed by a Minneapolis police officer. The officer had his knee on Floyd's neck for almost nine minutes.

The words I can't breathe have become a protest chant.

Floyd told Minneapolis police officers more than 20 times that he couldn't breathe.

[[Hamidullah Karimi]]

CATEGORIES: Afghan sportspeople, Association football forwards, Living people

Hamidullah Karimi, sometimes called "Hamidullah Nesar Ahmad", is an Afghan football player.

[[Minstrel show]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century in the United States, American music

The minstrel show was an American form of entertainment. It was developed in the 19th century. Each show was of comic skits, dancing and music performances that showed people of African descent. The shows were played by mostly white people in makeup or blackface for the purpose of playing black people. There were also some African American performers and black-only minstrel groups that formed and toured.

Minstrel shows parodied blacks and African Americans as happy-go-lucky, lazy and dim-witted.

Minstrel shows came out as brief burlesques in the early 1830s in the Northeastern United States. They were developed into full-fledged form around the next decade.

By the turn of the 20th century, the minstrel show was a shadow of its former popularity. It was replaced for the most part by vaudeville.

[[Acting President]]

An acting president is a person who temporarily fills the role of a country's president when the incumbent president is unavailable (such as by illness or a vacation) or when the post is vacant (such as for death, injury, resignation, dismissal). [[Janata Party]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in India, 1977 establishments in Asia, 2010s disestablishments in India, 2013 disestablishments, Political parties in India

The Janata Party (JNP, translation: People's Party) was an amalgam of Indian political parties opposed to the Emergency that was imposed between 1975 to 1977 by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of the Indian National Congress. In the 1977 general election, the party defeated the Congress and Janata leader Morarji Desai became the first non-Congress prime minister in independent modern India's history.

[[Mooseknuckle (disambiguation)]]

A moose-knuckle is a male genital bulge. It may also refer to:

[[European mink]]

CATEGORIES: Mustelids, Mammals of Europe

The European mink (Mustela lutreola), is a semiaquatic type of mustelid. It is also called the Russian mink and Eurasian mink. It is native to Europe.

[[Patricia Carricaburu]]

Patricia Carricaburu (born 21 September 1988) is a French rugby union player. She was a member of the France women's national rugby union team. She played at the 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2016 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup, and 2018 Women's Six Nations Championship.

She played for Lons Rugby Féminin Béarn Pyrénées.

[[Mooseknuckle]]

CATEGORIES: Slang

A mooseknuckle or manbulge is slang for when the outline or bulge of a man's genitalia is visible through clothing. A slang word for when the mooseknuckle or manbulge seems erect or pointy includes trouser tent. Other slang words for the mooseknuckle or manbulge includes dick-print. The antonym of mooseknuckle or manbulge is cameltoe, which means the visible outline of a woman's genitalia. The mooseknuckle or manbulge tends to be more with clothing such as grey sweatpants. The reason why most men have a mooseknuckle or manbulge through clothes is because male genitalia is on the outside of the body.

[[Ranoidea fuscula]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Asia

Ranoidea fuscula is a tree frog from Indonesia.  Scientists saw it in the Derewo River Basin in Papua Province, 1890 meters above sea level.

This frog lives in mountain streams. The scientists who wrote the first paper about Ranoidea fuscula said it was closely related to Ranoidea dorsivena.

[[Reza Homam]]

CATEGORIES: Make-up artists, 1960 births, 2006 deaths

Reza Homam (born December 12, 1960 - January 28, 2006 in Hamburg) was a German-Iranian make-up artist.

Homam, who is considered the pioneer of permanent make-up, counted many prominent personalities among his customers, including Barbara Herzsprung, Esther Schweins, Dagmar Berghoff, Sonja Kirchberger, Jürgen Drews. He moderated several television programs and founded his own line of cosmetics. Homam was the brother of professional poker player Soraya Homam.

Reza Homam committed suicide in his Hamburg apartment in 2006.

[[Marge Gets a Job]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 4) episodes, 1992 television episodes

"Marge Gets a Job" is the 7th episode of the 4th season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on November 5, 1992. In the episode, Marge gets a job at the power plant where Homer works at. Mr. Burns (the boss of the power plant) starts to love Marge and tries to make a relationship with her. While this happens, Bart tries to get out of taking a test at school in an allusion of The Boy Who Cried Wolf.

[[Super Mario Bros. 35th Anniversary]]

The Super Mario Bros. 35th Anniversary was a special event also happening in Nintendo games. To remember the Super Mario Series created in 1985, Nintendo made a special Nintendo Direct and released many Super Mario related products. These products include:

-Super Mario Bros. 35 (a special edition of Super Mario Bros., which lets 35 people play a battle royale to be the last standing.)

-Super Mario 3D World + Bowser's Fury (The Nintendo Switch remaster of the Wii U game)

-Mario Kart LIVE: Home Circuit (an RC toy required installment in the long-lasting series)

-Super Mario 3D All Stars (Contains remastered ports of Mario 64, Sunshine, & Galaxy 1)

- A Nintendo Game & Watch with a special Super Mario Bros. Theme (Featuring Mario Bros. 1 & The Lost Levels)

-Toys/Clothing/Shoes at The Nintendo Store

-Special Super Mario themed events happening in Splatoon 2, Super Smash Bros. Ultimate, Animal Crossing: New Horizons, Mario Kart Tour'', etc.

[[Bart D. Ehrman]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, American agnostics, People from Lawrence, Kansas, Writers from Kansas

Bart Denton Ehrman (born October 5, 1955) is an American New Testament scholar focusing on textual criticism of the New Testament, the historical Jesus, the origins and development of early Christianity. He has written and edited 30 books, including three college textbooks. He has also authored six works included in The New York Times Best Seller list. He is currently the James A. Gray Distinguished Professor of Religious Studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

[[Marion Talayrach]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, French rugby union players

Marion Talayrach (born 11 August 1979) is a French rugby union player. She is part of the France women's national rugby union team, competing in the 2005 Women's Six Nations Championship and 2006 Women's Rugby World Cup.

She played wing for the USAT XV Toulouges club.

[[Alessia Pantarotto]]

On a club level, she played for Rugby San Donà, and Rugby Riviera 1975 ASD.

[[Chase (2010 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: NBC network shows, 2010 American television series debuts, English-language television programs

Chase was an American television show on the NBC network. On October 19, 2010, the network ordered a full season consisting of 22 episodes. On April 6, 2011, NBC announced the remaining five episodes would be broadcast on Saturday nights beginning on April 23 and ended the series on May 21, 2011. The show was replaced by Harry's Law.

[[S.C. Braga]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Portugal, 1921 establishments in Europe, Portuguese football clubs

Sporting Clube de Braga (ˈspɔɾtĩŋ ˈkluβ(ɨ) ðɨ ˈβɾaɣɐ) (SCB), commonly known as Sporting de Braga or just Braga, is a Portuguese sports club from the city of Braga. Its football team plays in the Primeira Liga at the Estádio Municipal de Braga.

[[Dito]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Portuguese footballers, Portuguese football managers, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Eduardo José Gomes Cameselle Mendez (18 January 1962 – 3 September 2020), known as Dito, was a Portuguese footballer. He played as a central defender, and a manager.

Dito won 17 caps for Portugal, his debut arriving on 28 October 1981, at the age of 19.

During his two-season spell with Benfica, Dito played 27 league games in his first year as the Lisbon club won the double. 

Dito died on 3 September 2020 from a heart attack in Monção, aged 58.

[[William Yorzyk]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, American Olympic gold medalists, American swimmers, American physicians, Sportspeople from Massachusetts

William Albert Yorzyk Jr. (May 29, 1933 – September 2, 2020) was an American competition swimmer. He was born in Northampton, Massachusetts.

Yorzyk represented the United States at the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne, Australia. He was the first swimmer to win the gold medal in the new 200-meter butterfly event.

Yorzyk was a physician in the United States Air Force Medical Corps and was commissioned a captain. He won the U.S. AAU indoor championship in the 220-yard butterfly in 1958. 

Yorzyk was honored into the International Swimming Hall of Fame as an "Honor Swimmer" in 1971.

Yorzyk died on 2 September 2020, aged 87.

[[František Vaněk]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Czech ice hockey players, Olympians

František Vaněk (3 December 1931 – 2 September 2020) was a Czech ice hockey player. He competed in the 1956 Winter Olympics and in the 1960 Winter Olympics. He was born in Uherský Ostroh, Czechoslovakia.

Vaněk died on 2 September 2020, aged 88.

[[Fred Davies]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from Liverpool

Frederick Davies (22 August 1939 – 2 September 2020) was an English footballer. He made nearly 400 appearances in the Football League playing as a goalkeeper for Wolverhampton Wanderers, Cardiff City and AFC Bournemouth. 

He later became a manager, taking charge of Shrewsbury Town and Weymouth. He was born in Liverpool.

Davies died on 2 September 2020 from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, aged 81.

[[David Graeber]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from hemorrhage, American anthropologists, American political activists, American political writers, American anarchists, American educators, Writers from New York City, Deaths from pancreatitis

David Rolfe Graeber (ˈ; February 12, 1961 – September 2, 2020) was an American anthropologist, anarchist activist and author. He was known for his books Debt: The First 5000 Years (2011), The Utopia of Rules (2015) and Bullshit Jobs: A Theory (2018). 

He was a professor of anthropology at the London School of Economics.

Graeber was born in New York City. He studied at the University of Chicago and at State University of New York at Purchase.

Graeber died on 2 September 2020 in a Venice hospital from a hemorrhage caused by pancreatitis at the age of 59.

[[Purchase, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York

Purchase is a hamlet in the town and village of Harrison, in Westchester County, New York. Purchase is home to State University of New York at Purchase and Manhattanville College.

[[Cecilia Zublena]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Italian rugby union players

Cecilia Zublena (born 16 May 1990) is an Italian rugby union player. She played in the 2009 Women's Six Nations Championship,  2013 Women's Six Nations Championship, and Rugby sevens at the 2013 Summer Universiade. She played for University of Rennes.

She played for Rennes in the French women's championship.

[[Yves Hervochon]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, French painters

Yves Hervochon (13 June 1935 – 27 August 2020) was a French painter. He won several prizes in Brittany, and two of his paintings were purchased by the City of Rennes. Hervochon painted nature primarily, mainly about the weather and time of year.

[[Pavel Branko]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Italian writers, Slovakian people, Movie critics, Translators

Pavel Branko (April 27, 1921 – August 17, 2020) was a Italian-born Slovak movie critic, movie theorist, translator of fiction and non-fiction literature. He was  called "the doyen of Slovak film criticism". He was born in Trieste, Italy. Many of his works focused on the impact of the history of Czechoslovakia.

Branko died in August 2020 at the age of 99.

[[Hervé Blanc]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, French movie actors, French television actors

Hervé Blanc (29 January 1955 – 16 August 2020) was a French actor. He was born in Lyon. He was known for his role in the 1980 drama movie A Week's Vacation. He also starred in L'Été ardent (1982), L'émir préfère les blondes (1983), Un fils (2003) and in Ceci est mon corps (2014).

Blanc died on 16 August 2020, aged 65.

[[Ping Pong (manga)]]

Ping Pong is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Taiyō Matsumoto about table tennis. It was serialized in Shogakukan's seinen manga magazine Big Comic Spirits from 1996 to 1997 and collected in five tankōbon volumes.

[[Laura Di Muzio]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, French rugby union players, Rugby sevens players, French television personalities

Laura Di Muzio (born 20 March 1990) is a French rugby union and rugby sevens player, and television commentator.

She played for Lille Métropole rugby club villeneuvois. She was captain of the team, and champion of France in 2016.

She was a television commentator for the 2018 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2019 Women's Rugby Super Series.

[[Lénaïg Corson]]

Lénaïg Corson (born on 15 March 1989) is a French rugby sevens and rugby union player.

She particpated at the 2014 Women's Rugby World Cup, 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup, and 2019 Women’s Rugby Super Series.

[[Aurélie Groizeleau]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, French rugby union players, Rugby sevens players, Referees

Aurélie Groizeleau (born 27 February 1989) is a French international rugby referee.

She grew up in Marans in Charente-Maritime. She was a member of the France women's national rugby union team and France women's national rugby sevens team. She was injured in 2007.

She was a referee at 2019 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2020 Women's Six Nations Championship.

[[Maria Grazia Cioffi]]

Maria Grazia Cioffi (born 3 February 1989) is an Italian rugby player and rugby coach.

She was a member of the Italian national team. She participated in the 2009 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup.

On the club level, she played for Colorno, where she won the Serie A 2017-2018 championship.

[[Croatia Records]]

CATEGORIES: Croatian record labels, Zagreb

Croatia Records is the largest record label in Croatia, based in Zagreb.

[[Thompson (band)]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Croatia, 1991 establishments in Europe, Rock bands, Croatia, Musical groups established in 1991

Thompson is a Croatian ethno band, founded by Marko Perković aka "Thompson", often thought of as the same as the band itself. "Thompson" is Perković's stage name. He is the songwriter and lead vocalist. The members of the band, aside from him, are Tomislav Mandarić, Ivan Ivanković, Duje Ivić, and Ivica Bilić Ike.

The band name originates from the Thompson submachine gun, a nickname given to Perković while he fought in the Croatian War of Independence. Although mostly formed in Čavoglave, Thompson is currently based in Zagreb. Thompson came to be popular during the Croatian war in 1991, with the release of the first single "Bojna Čavoglave", which is about the Croatian participation in the Yugoslav Wars and was included in the compilation album Rock za Hrvatsku. This song, with slightly different lyrics, named "Branitelji Sarajeva", was sung by the BiH Army during the Siege of Sarajevo (Sarajevo zaboravit neće nikada). During the 1990s Thompson became popular in Croatia with the release of the first album Moli mala in 1992. They later became popular again with the hit "Prijatelji" in 1998. April 2014

In 2002, Thompson started their first major tour to promote the album E, moj narode. This tour continued on and off until 2005, and included concerts at the Sydney Entertainment Centre and Melbourne's Vodafone Arena. In May 2005, the album was declared a Diamond Record with more than 60,000 copies sold. Touring continued in 2006 with Bilo jednom u Hrvatskoj, again performing internationally with concerts in Germany, Sweden, Australia, Canada, and the United States.

Thompson features annually at the Homeland Victory celebrations in their hometown of Čavoglave. These performances are attended by as many as 60,000 to 100,000 viewers, and feature Croatian singers like Mate Bulić, Dražen Zečić, Ivan Mikulić, and Baruni. The band has became controversial for its alleged praise of the World War Two Nazi-affiliated Ustaše regime in their songs and concerts.

[[Jugoton]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Croatia, 1947 establishments in Europe, 1990 disestablishments in Europe, Croatian record labels, Zagreb

Jugoton was the largest record label and chain record store in the former Yugoslavia based in Zagreb, SR Croatia.

[[Ramkrishna Baba Patil]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from diabetes, Indian politicians

Ramkrishna Jagannath Patil (2 September 1936 – 2 September 2020), popularly known as Ramkrishna Baba, was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Indian National Congress political party. He was born in Aurangabad, Maharashtra.

Patil was a member of the Maharashtra Legislative Assembly between 1985 to 1995. He later became a member of the Lok Sabha between 1998 to 2004.

Patil died of diabetes-related problems in Aurangabad on his 84th birthday on 2 September 2020.

[[Gianni Serra]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters, Italian theatre directors, Television directors, Television writers

Gianni Serra (14 December 1933 – 3 September 2020) was an Italian director and writer of movies, television and theatre. He was born in Montichiari, Italy. He was known for writing and directing the movies Uno dei tre (1973), Fortezze vuote (1975), La ragazza di via Millelire (1980) and Una lepre con la faccia di bambina (1988).

Serra died on 3 September 2020 in Rome, aged 86.

[[Dave Zeller]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Sacramento Kings players, Sportspeople from Ohio

David A. Zeller (June 8, 1939 – September 3, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He played college basketball for the Miami RedHawks. He played in the National Basketball Association for the Cincinnati Royals between 1961 to 1962. Zeller was born in New Carlisle, Ohio.

Zeller died on September 3, 2020 in Toledo, Ohio at the age of 81.

[[Richard M. Weiner]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, German physicists, Romanian scientists

Richard M. Weiner (6 February 1930 – 13 August 2020) was a Romanian-born German professor of theoretical physics. He worked at the University of Marburg in Marburg, Germany. He was an associate of the Laboratoire de Physique Théorique at Paris-Sud 11 University. Weiner was born in Czernowitz, Romania.

Weiner died on 13 August 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Manuela Furlan]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Italian rugby union players

Manuela Furlan (born 30 June 1988) is an Italian rugby union player. She is captain of the Italian Rugby Federation. She participated at the 2009 Six Nations Championship, 2013 Summer Universiade, 2015 Six Nations Championship, and 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup.

On the club level, she played for Benetton Rugby.

[[Flavia Severin]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Italian sportspeople, Italian rugby union players, Boxers

Flavia Severin (born 1 April 1987) is an Italian rugby player and boxer. She was four-time boxing champion of Italy in two weight categories, and finalist in the 2014 European amateur boxing championship. She won a gold medal at the 2018 Women's European Amateur Boxing Championships.

She was a member of the Italy women's national rugby union team. She participated at the 2006 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup.

She grew up in Paese.

She plays for the Red Panthers of Treviso.

[[Awa Coulibaly]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Italian rugby union players, Judoka, People from Bamako

Awa Gianna Coulibaly (born 6 March 1987) is an Italian rugby player, and judoka. She won the 2019 African Cadet Judo Championships. She played for Stade Rennes rugby.

She was born in Bamako. Her father was an architect, and her mother was an interior decorator. She was raised from the age of three in Chieri, where she finished her secondary studies. She practiced various sports at school before devoting herself to rugby. 

In 2005, she played for the Biella club, in Piedmont. In 2007, she joined the Orso Rugby Club ASD, in Biella. In 2011, she signed for AS Rugby Monza, Lombardy.

She played for the Italian team A at the 2012 European Championship in Rovereto, and on November 18 in Rome in a test match against the United States. She played at the 2012 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2013 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2014 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship. 

In 2013, she was one of the first group of Italian players to play in France to gain more experience, at Rennes. She attended a local university.

[[Birol Ünel]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, Turkish movie actors, Turkish stage actors, Turkish television actors, German movie actors, German television actors, German voice actors, German stage actors, Actors from Berlin

Birol Ünel (18 August 1961 – 3 September 2020) was a Turkish-born German actor. He was born in Mersin, Turkey. His first movie roles was in the 1988 German drama movie The Passenger – Welcome to Germany. He later became known for starring in In July (2000), Head-On (2004), Transylvania (2006), and in Soul Kitchen (2009).

Ünel, suffering from alcoholism, was hospitalized in August 2020. He died a few weeks later from liver cancer in Berlin, aged 59.

[[Wick Allison]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from bladder cancer, American political writers, American conservatives, Journalists from Texas, Writers from Dallas, Texas, Businesspeople from Dallas, Texas

Lodowick Brodie "Wick" Cobb Allison (March 17, 1948spndSeptember 1, 2020) was an American magazine publisher and author. He was the owner of D Magazine. He was also the principal owner of People Newspapers, which he purchased in 2003.  He was president of the non-profit American Ideas Institute, and publisher of The American Conservative. He also worked for the National Review. Allison was born in Dallas, Texas.

Allison died on September 1, 2020 at his cabin home in the Catskill Mountains from bladder cancer, aged 72.

[[Black Hole (2019 movie)]]

 Black Hole  is a 2019 Ukrainian short film directed by Nicholas Ovcharov.

The world premiere took place on July 11, 2019 at the Revelation Perth International Film Festival. The movie won the special jury prize of the 2019 Bardak Short Film Independent Film Festival.

[[Paola Zangirolami]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Italian rugby union players

Paola Zangirolami (born 22 October 1984) is an Italian rugby union player.

On March 22, 2003, she debuted for Italy against France, where her team won (7 to 3). She was a member of the Italian national team for 14 years. She participated in the  2009 Rugby World Cup Sevens, 2013 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2016 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup.

Zangirolami moved to London to study and play for Richmond F.C.

[[Indonesian mountain weasel]]

CATEGORIES: Mustelids, Mammals of Asia

The Indonesian mountain weasel (Mustela lutreolina) is a type of weasel. It lives on the islands of Java and Sumatra in Indonesia at altitudes of over 1,000 metres (3,280 ft). They live in mountainous, tropical, and rainforest areas. Indonesian mountain weasels can grow up to 11–12 inches. They are reddish-brown in color.

[[Anastasiya Mukharyamova]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Russian sportspeople, Rugby players

Anastasiya Khasyanovna Mukharyamova (born July 16, 1984) is a Russian rugby player. She was captain of the Russian women's national team, She was voted Russia's best rugby player in 2007, and 2013 European champion.

She was awarded the Master of Sports of Russia, and Honored Master of Sports of Russia.

In 2005, she graduated from the Russian State University of Tourism and Service. She won the European Championship in 2013 and 2014. She played at the 2013 Rugby World Cup Sevens. In 2015, she retired.

[[Maria Veronese]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Italian rugby union players

Maria Diletta Veronese (born 4 November 1982) is an Italian rugby player. She was a member of the Italian Women's Rugby team. She participated at the 2009 Rugby World Cup Sevens, 2009 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2010 Six Nations Championship, 2011 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2013 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2014 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2015 Six Nations Championship.

She graduated from Accademia di Belle Arti di Venezia.

[[Yoshihide Suga]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Japan, Current national leaders, Politicians from Kanagawa Prefecture

Yoshihide Suga is a Japanese politician. In September 2020, he was elected Prime Minister of Japan and became President of the Liberal Democratic Party replacing Shinzo Abe. He resigned in September 2021 after negative approval ratings because of his government's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic in Japan and the 2020 Summer Olympics. He was replaced by former Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida.

[[Black-footed ferret]]

CATEGORIES: Mustelids, Mammals of North America

The black-footed ferret (Mustela nigripes), is a type of weasel. It is also called the American polecat or prairie dog hunter. It is native to central North America. It is an endangered species.

[[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election]]

CATEGORIES: September 2020 events, 2020 elections in Asia, 2020s in Japan

The 2020 Liberal Democratic Party of Japan leadership election was held on 14 September 2020 to elect the next president of the Liberal Democratic Party of Japan. This happened three days before the National Diet held a session to elect the new Prime Minister.

Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga easily won the election. As the Liberal Democratic Party currently controls a majority in the National Diet as a member of the governing coalition, Suga is also expected to succeed Abe as Japan's prime minister.

[[Veronica Schiavon]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Italian rugby union players

Veronica Schiavon (born 24 July 1982) is an Italian rugby union player. She played for the Italian national team 82 times, between 2001 and 2017, with 383 points (an international record for Italy).

Her mother, Monica, Palla was a player in Treviso, and had 9 appearances for the Italian national team, and her sister Valentina plays scrum half, her club and national teammate. She played for the Benetton Treviso youth team. At 16, she moved to Mira.

She played at the 2002 Women's Rugby World Cup in Spain where the team finished twelfth; 2007 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2009 FIRA Women's European Trophy, 2010 FIRA Women's European Trophy, 2009 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2011 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2014 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2015 Women's Six Nations Championship, 2016 Women's Six Nations Championship, and 2017 Women's Rugby World Cup.

[[Diner]]

A diner is a small restaurant in the United States, which is run for 24 hours per day.

[[Kitty Genovese]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 1964 deaths, American LGBT people, American murder victims, Lesbians, People from Brooklyn

[[Murder of Kitty Genovese]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 in the United States, Crime in New York City, March events, Murder in New York, Murder in the 1960s, Murders by blade weapons, Queens (New York City), Robberies, Victims of anti-LGBT hate crimes

On March 13, 1964, 28-year-old Kitty Genovese was mugged and stabbed to death outside the apartment building on Austin Street, in the Kew Gardens neighborhood of Queens in New York City, United States. 

Two weeks after the murder, The New York Times published an article claiming that 38 witnesses saw or heard the attack, and that none of them called the police or came to her aid, that witness as Sophia Farrar.

The incident was the bystander effect or "Genovese syndrome," and the murder became a well known example of U.S. psychology textbooks. Genovese syndrome is when witnesses to a crime to not report a crime because they are scared and they believe that others will report it instead which in the end they do not and the crime goes unreported. 

However, this is not really what happened.  Police interviews showed that the other people nearby either attempted to call the police or were afraid to be involved.  This was before calling 911 was easy to do in the United States.  Because Genovese was killed late at night, many of the people nearby were asleep.  Some of the people who saw the attack also saw Genovese get up and walk away, so they did not think she had been badly hurt.

Winston Moseley, a 29-year-old man from Manhattan, was arrested during a house burglary six days after the murder. While in custody, he confessed to killing Genovese. At his trial, Moseley was found guilty. Moseley died in prison on March 28, 2016.

[[Clyde H. Hamilton]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from South Carolina, US Republican Party politicians

Clyde Henry Hamilton (February 8, 1934 – September 2, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit between 1991 until his death. He was also the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina between 1981 to 1991.

Hamilton was nominated to the South Caroline District Court by President Ronald Reagan. He was nominated to the Fourth Circuit Court by President George H. W. Bush. 

Hamilton was born in Edgefield, South Carolina. He studied at Wofford College and at George Washington University. Hamilton died on September 2, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Michael J. Cleary]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Irish people, Roman Catholic bishops, Gambian people

Michael J. Cleary (1 September 1925 – 3 September 2020) was an Irish-born Gambian Roman Catholic prelate. He was the Roman Catholic Bishop Emeritus of the Diocese of Banjul in Gambia. He was born in Brickens, County Mayo, Ireland. 

Cleary was made a priest on 29 June 1952.  On 24 January 1981, he was made Bishop of the Diocese of Banjul. Cleary retired on 25 February 2006.

Cleary died on 3 September 2020, aged 95.

[[Igor Maslennikov]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Soviet writers, Russian screenwriters, Russian movie directors

Igor Fyodorovich Maslennikov (Игорь Фёдорович Масленников; born 26 October 1931) is a Soviet and Russian movie  director and screenwriter. He was born in Nizhny Novgorod, Soviet Union. 

His career lasted between 1967 to 2002. He directed the movies Under en steinhimmel, Winter Cherry, The Queen of Spades and Tomorrow, on April 3rd....

In 2001 he was a member of the jury at the 23rd Moscow International Film Festival.

[[Cancer bush]]

CATEGORIES: Faboideae

Cancer bush  is an endemic plant of South Africa also known as Sutherlandia frutescens (balloon pea). It is a Fabaceous bush with bright red flowers and globose legumes. As an herbal plant is a panacea, especially among Nam, Khoi and San Peoples in stomach problems, diabetes and so on (adaptogen). As an array of biodynamic molecules represent a challenge for quality control; whereas flavonoids appear most replicable contents.

[[NGC 5114]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 5114 is a lenticular galaxy in the Centaurus constellation. It is located about 170 million light-years away. It was discovered by astronomer John Herschel.

[[Holy Roller]]

CATEGORIES: Christianity, Protestantism

Holy Roller is a term that was created in the 19th century. Some types of Protestant Christians who dance, shake, or roll on the floor during church services can be called Holy Rollers. People who do this say that the Holy Spirit makes them. Sometimes, the term 'Holy Roller' is used as an insult. However, Holy Rollers also use the term as a badge of honor, and it can also be used as a neutral term.

[[Giuliana Campanella]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Italian rugby union players

Giuliana Campanella (born 4 November 1976 Messina) is an Italian rugby union player, rugby coach, and sports manager. She played in 59 international matches and at two editions of the World Cup.

In April 1997, she made his international debut in Nice during the European championship in a victory against Ireland. She participated at  the 1998 women's rugby world cup, and 2002 Women's Rugby World Cup.

At the club level, she played for Messina, and Colleferro Red & Blu.

She was women's team manager for the Italian national team, beginning with the 2014 Six Nations championship.

[[Olatz Fernández]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, Spanish rugby union players

Olatz Fernández de Arroyabe (born 18 March 1970) is a Spanish rugby union player. She played the position of third wing line (n ° 6 or 7) for the club of Getxo RT, and for the Spain national rugby team.

In 2004, she was part of the team that toured South Africa. She played at the 1998 Women's Rugby World Cup, 2002 Women's Rugby World Cup, and  2006 Women's Rugby World Cup. She participated in the Six Nations Women's Tournament.

[[List of flags of French Indochina]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of flags
