[[Roadkill]]

CATEGORIES: Transport, Meat, Animals

Roadkill is any animal that has died on a road because it was hit by a vehicle, for example a deer hit by a car.  Vehicles pulled by animals, for example mule carts, did make roadkill, but there was much more roadkill after the invention of the automobile.

In the United States alone, one to two million large animals are killed as roadkill every year and many more small animals.

[[Wakko's Wish]]

CATEGORIES: Movies based on TV series, American animated movies, 1999 animated movies, 1999 comedy movies, American family movies, 1990s adventure movies, Warner Bros. movies

Wakko's Wish or Animaniacs: Wakko's Wish is a 1999 animated comedy-fantasy musical adventure family film based on the Animaniacs. This film was directed by Liz Holzman, Rusty Mills and Tom Ruegger. It was released on July 16, 1999.  It was not shown in theaters but instead sold on VHS. This movie about three human-like, dog-like characters, Yakko, Wakko and Dot, wishing on a star.  As of 2020, Wakko's Wish is streaming on Hulu.

[[Mtwapa]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Africa, Settlements in Kenya

Mtwapa is a small town lying on the Indian Ocean coast of Kenya.

The town is situated approximately 16 north-east of Mombasa on the Mombasa-Malindi road.

"Mtu wa hapa" – in Swahili; this translates to he who lives among us. 

Mtwapa is home to a large number of European retirees and holiday-makers from countries such as Germany, Holland and Great Britain. It is also a destination for sex tourism. Mtwapa Creek is a starting point for fishing tours.

[[Sarah McBride]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, American LGBT rights activists, LGBT politicians, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Wilmington, Delaware, US Democratic Party politicians, Transgender and transsexual people

Sarah McBride (born August 9, 1990) is an American LGBTQ rights activist and Democratic politician. She is currently the National Press Secretary of the Human Rights Campaign. 

After winning the September 15, 2020 Democratic primary in the safe Democratic 1st Delaware State Senate district, she is set to become the first transgender state senator in the country as well as the highest-ranking transgender official in the country.

[[Marion, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Mississippi

Marion is a town in Lauderdale County, Mississippi, United States.

[[Ralph Abernathy]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, American civil rights activists, Politicians from Alabama, Politicians from Atlanta, Georgia, US Democratic Party politicians

Ralph David Abernathy Sr. (March 11, 1926 – April 17, 1990) was an American civil rights activist and Baptist minister. He was ordained in the Baptist tradition in 1948. He was born in Linden, Alabama. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

As a leader of the civil rights movement, he was a close friend and mentor of Martin Luther King Jr. He worked with King to create the Montgomery Improvement Association which led to the Montgomery bus boycott. 

He also co-founded and was an executive board member of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC). He became president of the SCLC following the assassination of King in 1968. He led the Poor People's Campaign in Washington, D.C. 

He was an advisory committee member of the Congress on Racial Equality (CORE).

Abernathy died on April 17, 1990 of heart disease in Atlanta, Georgia at the age of 64.

[[Joseph Henabery]]

CATEGORIES: 1888 births, 1976 deaths, American movie actors, American silent movie actors, Actors from Omaha, Nebraska, Writers from Omaha, Nebraska, American movie directors

Joseph Henabery (January 15, 1888 – February 18, 1976) was an American actor, screenwriter, and director. He was born in Omaha, Nebraska. Henabery was best known for his role of Abraham Lincoln in D.W. Griffith's controversial 1915 silent movie The Birth of a Nation.

Henabery died on February 18, 1976, aged 88, in Los Angeles, California.

[[Reed Hastings]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, American educators, American political activists, Businesspeople from Boston, Massachusetts

Wilmot Reed Hastings Jr. (born October 8, 1960) is an American businessman. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts.

Hastings is the co-founder, chairman, and co-chief executive officer (CEO) of Netflix. He is on the boards and non-profit organizations.

[[George Lincoln Rockwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 1967 deaths, Assassinated people, American crime victims, Nazis, American political activists, Military people from Illinois, Politicians from Illinois, People from Bloomington, Illinois

George Lincoln Rockwell (March 9, 1918 – August 25, 1967) was an American politician and neo-Nazi. He founded the American Nazi Party. He was born in Bloomington, Illinois.

Rockwell denied The Holocaust and believed that Martin Luther King Jr. was a tool for Jewish Communists wanting to rule the white community. He blamed the civil rights movement on the Jews.

On August 25, 1967, Rockwell was shot and killed in Arlington by John Patler at the age of 49.

[[John Patler]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Nazis, American people convicted of manslaughter, American cartoonists, Writers from New York City, Criminals from New York City

John Patler (Γιάννης Πάτσαλος, born January 6, 1938) is an American former neo-Nazi who was convicted of killing American Nazi Party leader George Lincoln Rockwell on August 25, 1967. He was born in New York City.

Patler was in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1958 to 1960, when he was honorably discharged after being arrested at an American Nazi Party rally.

Patler later became a captain in the American Nazi Party and the editor and cartoonist for the party's magazine, Stormtrooper. However, he was expelled from the Party in March 1967 after disagreeing with party leader George Lincoln Rockwell about some of the party's policies.

[[Frazier Glenn Miller Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2021 deaths, American Christians, American people convicted of attempted murder, American people convicted of murder, American prisoners sentenced to death, American terrorists, Neo-Nazis, People who died in prison custody in the United States, Politicians from North Carolina

Frazier Glenn Miller Jr. (November 23, 1940 – May 3, 2021), commonly known as Glenn Miller or Frazier Glenn Cross, was an American domestic terrorist and former leader of the White Patriot Party. Miller was a perennial candidate for public office. 

He was a supporter of white nationalism, white separatism, Odinism, and antisemitism.

On April 13, 2014, Miller was arrested following the Overland Park Jewish Community Center shooting in Overland Park, Kansas. Johnson County prosecutors charged him with one count of capital murder and one count of first-degree murder. On October 17, 2014, the separate charge for first-degree murder was dismissed and all three deaths were included in a single capital murder count.

On August 31, 2015, Miller was found guilty in the Overland Park shooting of one count of capital murder, three counts of attempted murder and assault and weapons charges. Eight days later, the same jury recommended that Miller be put to death by lethal injection. On November 10, 2015, he was formally sentenced to death.

Miller died in prison at the El Dorado Correctional Facility in Butler County, Kansas on May 3, 2021. at the age of 80.

[[Overland Park Jewish Community Center shooting]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 in the United States, 2010s murders in the United States, April events, History of Kansas, Murder in 2014, Overland Park, Kansas

On April 13, 2014, two shootings occurred at the Jewish Community Center of Greater Kansas City and Village Shalom, a Jewish retirement community, both located in Overland Park, Kansas. A total of three people were killed in the shootings, two of whom were shot at the community center and one shot at the retirement community.

The gunman, 73-year-old Frazier Glenn Miller Jr. of Aurora, Missouri, originally from North Carolina, was arrested during the attack and was subsequently tried, convicted of murder and other crimes, and sentenced to death. Miller is a former Klansman, neo-Nazi and former political candidate.

[[Aurora, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Aurora is a city in Lawrence County, Missouri, United States. The population was 7,508 at the 2010 census.

[[Mount Vernon, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Mount Vernon is a city in and the county seat of Lawrence County, Missouri, United States. The population was 4,575 as of the 2010 census.

[[Lumbar vertebrae]]

CATEGORIES: Bones

No sources

The lumbar vertebrae in humans are the five vertebrae between the rib cage and the pelvis. 

They are important parts of the vertebral column. They are called L1 to L5, starting at the top. The lumbar vertebrae help support the weight of the body, and allow movement. In particular, they connect to the pelvis.

Most people have five lumbar vertebrae, but some have four or six. Not much movement takes place between the lumbar vertebrae.

[[Embassy of the United States, Tehran]]

CATEGORIES: United States, Iran, International relations

The Embassy of the United States of America in Tehran was the United States of America's diplomatic mission in the Imperial State of Iran. Diplomatic relations between the United States and Iran became intense following the Iranian Revolution in 1979, and the hostage crisis at the embassy in November 1979.

[[Economic sanctions]]

CATEGORIES: Economic policy

Economic sanctions are commercial and financial penalties applied by one or more countries against a state, group, or individual. 

Economic sanctions are acted because of economic reasons, but also for political and military reasons.

[[Head Start]]

CATEGORIES: United States Department of Health and Human Services

Head Start is a program of the United States Department of Health and Human Services that gives early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parent involvement services to low-income children and families. 

The program's services and resources are designed to help stable family relationships,children's physical and emotional health, and create an environment to for cognitive skills.

[[Timothy Kraft]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Jimmy Carter, American political commentators, Politicians from Indiana, US Democratic Party politicians

Timothy E. Kraft (born April 10, 1941) is a retired Democratic political consultant. He is best known as the campaign manager for the unsuccessful reelection bid of U.S. President Jimmy Carter. He was born in Noblesville, Indiana.

In September 1980, only weeks before the general election, he stepped down after it his cocaine was discovered.

[[Blue House]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in South Korea

Cheongwadae (청와대; Hanja: 靑瓦臺; literally "pavilion of blue tiles"), also known as the Blue House, is the executive office and official residence of the President of the Republic of Korea.

It is located in Jongno-gu of the capital Seoul. The Blue House is the most protected official residence in Asia.

[[RSD-10 Pioneer]]

CATEGORIES: Nuclear weapons

The RSD-10 ''Pioneer (ракета средней дальности (РСД) «Пионер»  tr.: raketa sredney dalnosti (RSD) "Pioner"; Medium-Range Missile "Pioneer") was an intermediate-range ballistic missile with a nuclear warhead, that stayed in the Soviet Union from 1976 to 1988. It carried GRAU designation '15Ж45 (''15Zh45''). Its NATO reporting name was SS-20 Saber'''.

[[Intermediate-range ballistic missile]]

CATEGORIES: Nuclear weapons

An intermediate-range ballistic missile (IRBM) is a ballistic missile with a range  of 3,000–5,500 km (1,864–3,418 miles), between a medium-range ballistic missile (MRBM) and an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM).

IRBMs are currently operated by the People's Republic of China, India, Israel, and North Korea.

[[Demilitarisation]]

CATEGORIES: Military tactics

Demilitarisation or demilitarization may mean the lowering of state armed forces. It is the opposite of militarisation. For instance, the demilitarisation of Northern Ireland caused a lowring British security and military weapons. Demilitarisation in this sense is usually the result of a peace treaty ending a war or a major conflict.

[[Operation Cyclone]]

CATEGORIES: 1979, 1989

Operation Cyclone was the code name for the United States Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) program to arm and finance the mujahideen (jihadists) in Afghanistan from 1979 to 1989. The mujahideen were also supported by Britain's MI6.

Operation Cyclone was one of the longest and most expensive covert CIA operations ever. Funding officially began with $695,000 in 1979.

[[Mujahideen]]

CATEGORIES: War in Afghanistan (since 1978)

Mujahideen (مجاهدين ar) is the plural of mujahid (no). Mujahid is the Arabic term for one engaged in jihad (literally, "struggle"). This term was first used to describe guerrilla-type militant groups led by the Islamist Afghan fighters in the Soviet–Afghan War. As of 2021, it is also used to described other jihadist groups in other countries. 

The English term jihadists is also related to the mujahideen.

[[Jihadism]]

CATEGORIES: Islamic organizations

"Jihadism" (also "jihadist movement", "jihadi movement" and variants) is a 21st-century neologism found in Western languages to describe Islamist  movements seen by the military to be "rooted in Islam" and a threat to the West. 

The term "jihadism" first appeared in South Asian media; Western journalists adopted it in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks of 2001.

[[One America Appeal]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in the United States, Jimmy Carter, George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Political organizations based in the United States

The One America Appeal is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization founded on 7 September 2017, by all five then living former U.S. Presidents: Jimmy Carter, George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama. This aimed to encourage support for recovery efforts for Hurricane Harvey, but was then extended to include areas most affected by Hurricanes Irma and Maria. 

The appeal was launched when the five former Presidents aired a joint PSA on the NFL’s regular season opening broadcast.

[[Aijalon Gomes]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, American crime victims, People who committed suicide, Writers from Boston, Massachusetts, American autobiographers

Aijalon Mahli Gomes ˈ (June 19, 1979 – November 17, 2017) was an American teacher. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts.

He was detained in North Korea for illegally entering the country through China on January 25, 2010. On August 27, 2010, it was announced that former U.S. president Jimmy Carter had secured Gomes's release. In May 2015, Gomes published an autobiography, Violence and Humanity. 

On November 17, 2017, he was found burned to death in what was ruled a suicide at a park in San Diego, California at the age of 38.

[[Tomás Borge]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2012 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Nicaraguan politicians, Political writers

Tomás Borge Martínez (13 August 1930 – 30 April 2012) was a Nicaraguan politician and writer. He was the cofounder of the Sandinista National Liberation Front in Nicaragua and was Interior Minister of Nicaragua during one of the administrations of Daniel Ortega. 

Borge also held the titles of "Vice-Secretary and President of the FSLN", member of the Nicaraguan Parliament and National Congress, and Ambassador to Peru. 

[[The Elders (organization)]]

CATEGORIES: Nelson Mandela

The Elders is an international non-governmental organisation of public figures known as elder statesmen, peace activists, and human rights advocates. They were brought together by Nelson Mandela in 2007. They describe themselves as "independent global leaders working together for peace and human rights". 

The goal Mandela set for the Elders was to use their "almost 1,000 years of collective experience" to work on solutions for controversial and long-lasting problems such as climate change, HIV/AIDS, and poverty, as well as to "use their political independence to help resolve some of the world's most intractable conflicts".

[[Nairobi Agreement, 1999]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Africa, Nairobi, Sudan, Uganda, 1990s in Africa, 1999, Jimmy Carter

The 1999 Nairobi Agreement was a deal signed by Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Omar al-Bashir of Sudan in Nairobi, Kenya, on 8 December 1999. 

The stated intent of the agreement was  to "provide the critical impetus for resolving the northern Uganda conflict." The deal was brokered by former US president Jimmy Carter.

[[Emory University Hospital]]

CATEGORIES: Hospitals in the United States, Buildings and structures in Atlanta, Georgia

Emory University Hospital is a 733-bed facility in Atlanta, Georgia, focusing in the care of acutely ill adults. Emory University Hospital is staffed by Emory University School of Medicine faculty who also are members of The Emory Clinic. 

The hospital is known as one of the nation's leaders in cardiology and cardiac surgery, oncology, transplantation, ophthalmology, and the neurosciences.

[[United Nations Prize in the Field of Human Rights]]

CATEGORIES: United Nations

The United Nations Prizes in the Field of Human Rights were created and given by United Nations General Assembly (UN General Assembly) in 1966. They are intended to "honour and commend people and organizations which have made an outstanding contribution to the promotion and protection of the human rights. The ceremony for the laureates is hold on Human Rights Day, 10 December in every fifth year.

[[Hoover Medal]]

CATEGORIES: Awards, Herbert Hoover

The Hoover Medal is an American engineering prize.

It has been given since 1930 for "outstanding extra-career services by engineers to humanity". 

The prize is given jointly by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical, and Petroleum Engineers, American Society of Civil Engineers, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME).

It is named for Herbert Hoover, the first recipient, who was an engineer by profession.

[[Disappearance of Brian Shaffer]]

CATEGORIES: Mysteries, March events, 2000s in Ohio, 2006 in the United States, Columbus, Ohio

Brian Shaffer (born February 25, 1979) was a medical student at Ohio State University. On the night of March 31, 2006, Shaffer went out with friends to celebrate the beginning of spring break. He was separated from them and they thought he had gone home. Shaffer has not been seen or heard from since. The case has received national media attention.

Columbus police have several theories about what happened; some interest and suspicion has been directed at a friend of Shaffer's who went with him that night but who has refused to take lie detector tests about the incident. 

While foul play has been suspected, including the possible involvement of the Smiley Face serial killer, it has also been speculated that he might be alive and living somewhere else under a new identity.

[[Smiley face murder theory]]

CATEGORIES: Mysteries, Conspiracy theories

The Smiley face murder theory (variations include Smiley face murders, Smiley face killings, Smiley face gang, and others) is a theory believed by retired New York City detectives Kevin Gannon and Anthony Duarte. They say that a number of young men found dead in bodies of water across several Midwestern American states from the late 1990s to the 2010s did not accidentally drown. They believe that they were victims of a serial killer or killers. 

The term "smiley face" became connected to the alleged murders when it was made public that the police had discovered graffiti showing a smiley face near locations where they think the killer dumped the bodies in at least a dozen of the cases. 

Gannon wrote a textbook case study on the subject titled "Case Studies in Drowning Forensics". The response of law enforcement investigators and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to not believe in this theory and had investigated it saying that it is a hoax.

[[Ahmed Al-Qadri]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Syrian politicians, Engineers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Ahmed Al-Qadri (1956 – 3 September 2020) was a Syrian agricultural engineer and politician. He was born in Al-Hasakah, Syria. He was a member of Bashar al-Assad's cabinet. He was Minister of Agriculture and Agrarian Reform between February 2013 to August 2020. 

Al-Qadri died of COVID-19 on 3 September 2020 at a hospital in Damascus at the age of 64.

[[Brumado]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Bahia

Brumado is a Brazilian municipality in the interior of Bahia, in the Northeast region of the country. In 2016, 69,473 people lived here.

[[André Lespagnol]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, French educators, French politicians

André Lespagnol (26 July 1943 – 13 September 2020) was a French politician and professor. He was a professor at the University of Rennes 2, focusing on the history of Saint-Malo. He was President of the University of Rennes 2 from 1991 to 1996. In 2004, he was elected Vice-President of the Regional Council of Brittany, serving until 2010. He was born in Crozon, France.

Lespagnol died on 13 September 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Russ Meekins Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Alaska, People from Anchorage, Alaska, US Democratic Party politicians

Edward Russell Meekins Jr. (1949 – September 13, 2020) was an American politician. He was a member of the Alaska House of Representatives between 1973 to 1975 and again from 1977 to 1983. His father Russ Meekins Sr. was also a politician. Meekins was a member of the Democratic Party. He was born in Anchorage, Alaska.

Meekins Jr. died on September 13, 2020 in Massachusetts at the age of 71.

[[Vital Alsar]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish scientists, Spanish educators, Sailors, Scientists from Mexico City

Vital Alsar Ramírez (August 7, 1933 – September 15, 2020) was a Spanish-born Mexican sailor and scientist. He made several extremely long sailing expeditions. He was born in Santander, Cantabria. He was known for having sailed 3,770.

Between 1966 and 1973, Alsar led three expeditions by raft across the Pacific Ocean, from Ecuador and Australia. The first expedition failed, but the second and third succeeded, both setting the record for the longest known raft voyages in history—8600 and 9000.

Vital later replaced the rafts with galleons to carry out the project "Mar, hombre y paz", which was begun in 1980. This expedition took the trapo blanco (white rag), around the world on board the La Marigalante.

Alsar died on September 15, 2020 in Mexico City at the age of 87.

[[Parliament of Uganda]]

CATEGORIES: Uganda

The Parliament of Uganda is the country's unicameral legislative body.

The most significant of the Ugandan parliament's job is to pass laws. The fiscal issues of the government, such as taxation and loans need the sanction of the parliament, after appropriate debate.

[[Faith Alupo]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, 2020 deaths, Ugandan politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Uganda

Faith Alupo (9 October 1983 – 15 September 2020) was a Ugandan politician. She was a Member of Parliament, representing the Pallisa District. She was elected to that position in June 2018. She was a member of the National Resistance Movement.

Alupo died on 15 September 2020 in Kampala, Uganda from COVID-19 at the age of 36.

[[John Ferris (swimmer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in California, American swimmers, American Olympic bronze medalists, Sportspeople from Sacramento, California

John Edward Ferris (July 24, 1949 – September 13, 2020) was an American competition swimmer and former world record-holder. He was born in Sacramento, California.

Ferris won two bronze medals at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City. He received a gold medal in the 200-meter butterfly at the 1967 World University Games, where he set a new world-record time of 2:06.0.  

Ferris died in Walnut Creek, California on September 13, 2020 from lung cancer, aged 71.

[[Ahmed Ben Salah]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Tunisian politicians, Trade unionists

Ahmed Ben Salah (أحمد بن صالح) (13 January 1926 – 16 September 2020) was a Tunisian politician and trades union leader. His ideas for a planned economy were important for Tunisia's economic development between 1957 to 1969. He was born in Moknine, Tunisia. Ben Salah was the Minister of Finance between 1961 to 1969.

Ben Salah died on 16 September 2020 in Tunis at the age of 94.

[[Hurricane Alice (December 1954)]]

CATEGORIES: 1954, Hurricanes

Hurricane Alice is the only known Atlantic hurricane to span two calendar years. It is one of two named Atlantic tropical cyclones. The other is Tropical Storm Zeta of 2005.

[[Hanson, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Hanson is a town in Plymouth County in the state of Massachusetts. One of the inland towns of the South Shore, the population was 10,209 at the 2010 census.

[[Stanley Crouch]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, American poets, American critics, American columnists, Journalists from California, Journalists from New York City, Writers from Los Angeles, California

Stanley Lawrence Crouch (December 14, 1945 – September 16, 2020) was an American poet, music, and cultural critic. He was best known for his jazz criticism and his 2000 novel Don't the Moon Look Lonesome? Crouch was born in Los Angeles. He was also a known critic of jazz in New York City and worked with The New York Times.

Crouch died on September 16, 2020 at a hospital in New York City at the age of 74.

[[Núria Gispert i Feliu]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Political activists, Politicians from Barcelona

Núria Gispert y Feliu (6 June 1936 – 16 September 2020) was a Spanish politician, Catholic activist and social worker. She was born in Barcelona. She was a member of the Socialists' Party of Catalonia. Between 1979 to 1995, she was a member of the City Council of Barcelona.

Feliu died on 16 September 2020 in Barcelona of colon cancer at the age of 84.

[[Enrique Irazoqui]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1944 births, Spanish movie actors, Political activists, People from Barcelona

Enrique Irazoqui (5 July 1944 – 16 September 2020) was a Spanish actor and political activist. He was born in Barcelona. Irazoqui was best known for his role as Jesus Christ in the 1964 movie The Gospel According to St. Matthew.

Irazoqui died on 16 September 2020 in Barcelona at the age of 76.

[[Ed Bearss]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American historians, American military personnel of World War II, Writers from Montana, People from Billings, Montana

Edwin Cole Bearss (ˈ; June 26, 1923 – September 15, 2020) was an American military historian and writer. He was a United States Marine Corps veteran of World War II. 

He was known for his work on the American Civil War and World War II eras. He was a tour guide of historic battlefields for The Smithsonian Associates and was Chief Historian of the National Park Service from 1981 to 1994. He was born in Billings, Montana.

Bearss died at his home in Arlington, Virginia on September 15, 2020 at the age of 97.

[[Jack Kelley (ice hockey)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Massachusetts

John Henry "Jack" Kelley (July 10, 1927 – September 15, 2020) was an American ice hockey coach. He was a member of the United States Hockey Hall of Fame. Kelley was the first general manager and head coach of the New England Whalers of the World Hockey Association (WHA). 

He was head coach at Boston University. He was born in Medford, Massachusetts.

Kelley died on September 15, 2020 at the age of 93.

[[William Henry Danforth]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American physicians, American educators, Scientists from St. Louis, Missouri

William Henry Danforth II (April 10, 1926 – September 16, 2020) was an American physician, professor of medicine, and academic administrator. He was chancellor of Washington University in St. Louis from 1971 until 1995. He was the brother of former U.S. Senator John Danforth. Danforth was born in St. Louis, Missouri.

Danford died on September 16, 2020 in St. Louis from problems caused by a fall at the age of 94.

[[Maxim Martsinkevich]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, 2020 deaths, Political activists, Nazis, People who committed suicide in prison custody, Criminals, People from Moscow

Maxim Sergeyevich Martsinkevich (Макси́м Серге́евич Марцинке́вич, 8 May 1984 – 16 September 2020), better known as Tesak (Cleaver, Hatchet, Hand Axe, Machete), was a Russian neo-Nazi activist, media personality, vlogger, and the leader and co-founder of the Restruct movement.

[[Balli Durga Prasad Rao]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

Balli Durga Prasad Rao (15 June 1956 – 16 September 2020) was an Indian politician. He was elected to the Lok Sabha, lower house of the Parliament of India in the 2019 Indian general election. He was a member of the YSR Congress Party. Rao was also a member of the Andhra Pradesh MLA from 1985 to 1989, 1994 to 1999, and 2009 to 2014.

Rao died at a medical center in New Delhi on 16 September 2020 from COVID-19, aged 64.

[[Main's frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

Main's water-holding frog, Main's frog, the sheep frog or western collared frog (Ranoidea maini) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia.

This frog can live on flood plains, claypans, grassland and wetlands that dry up.  It lays eggs whenever there is enough water, and the tadpoles grow into frogs quickly.

This frog is 5.0 cm long with a round body.  The skin on its back is gray or brown with darker marks.  Some frogs can change the color of their skin, making it much lighter in color in a few hours.  Their front feet are not webbed, and their hind feet are webbed about halfway.

This frog is named after frog scientist Albert Main.

[[Whirlpool (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s crime movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Otto Preminger

Whirlpool is a 1949 American crime drama movie directed by Otto Preminger and based on the novel Methinks the Lady by Guy Endore. It stars Gene Tierney, Richard Conte, José Ferrer, Charles Bickford, Barbara O'Neil, Eduard Franz, Constance Collier and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Saefullah]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia

Saefullah (11 February 1964 – 16 September 2020) was an Indonesian politician and educator. He was born in Jakarta, Indonesia. He was the Mayor of Central Jakarta from 2010 to 2014. He was also Regional Secretary of Jakarta from 2014 until his death. 

Saefullah died on 16 September 2020 at a hospital in Jakarta from COVID-19, aged 56.

[[Tony Tanner]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, British theatre directors, Choreographers, Actors from Middlesex

Tony Tanner (27 July 1932 – 8 September 2020) was a British actor, theatre director and choreographer. He was born in Hillingdon, Middlesex. His career began in 1953. He directed Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat in the West End production in 1970. He also starred as Terry in Strictly for the Birds (1964) and as Littlechap in Stop the World – I Want to Get Off (1966).

Tanner died at his home in Los Angeles on 8 September 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Edwin M. Cronk]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2020 deaths, American centenarians, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from Minneapolis, Minnesota, US Republican Party politicians

Edwin Monroe Cronk (May 20, 1918 – September 1, 2020) was an American politician. He was the third United States Ambassador to Singapore from 1972 to 1975 during the Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford presidencies. He was born in Minneapolis. He was Dean and Director of Deep Springs College from 1976 to 1980.

Cronk died on September 1, 2020 at the age of 102.

[[Emil Kraepelin]]

CATEGORIES: 1856 births, 1926 deaths, German psychiatrists, German educators

Emil Wilhelm Georg Magnus Kraepelin (ˈ; ˈeːmiːl 'kʁɛːpəliːn; 15 February 1856 – 7 October 1926) was a German psychiatrist. He is the founder of modern scientific psychiatry, psychopharmacology and psychiatric genetics.

[[John Kricfalusi]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Canadian voice actors, Canadian television actors, Animators, Actors from Quebec, People with bipolar disorder

Michael John Kricfalusi (,; born September 9, 1955), known professionally as John K., is a Canadian blogger, former animator and voice actor. He is best known for creating the Nickelodeon animated television series The Ren & Stimpy Show, voicing Ren and being the original singer for the song Happy Happy Joy Joy on the show and for voicing Dr. Theopolis in Buck Rogers in the 25th Century and in the 1979 film of the same name. He was born in Chicoutimi, Quebec.

In 2018, Kricfalusi was accused of sexually abusing underage girls in the late 1990s. Kricfalusi released an apology for his behavior, blaming his bipolar disorder.

[[Liladhar Vaghela]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Indian politicians

Liladhar Vaghela (17 February 1935 – 16 September 2020) was an Indian politician. He was born in Gujarat, Indian. He was a member of Lok Sabha between 2014 to 2019 as a member of the Indian National Congress. He was also a member of the Gujarat Legislative Assembly betweem 1975 to 1980, 1985 to 1995, 1998 to 2002 and lastly from 2007 to 2014.

Vaghela died on 16 September 2020 in Gandhinagar, Gujarat from acute respiratory failure, aged 85.

[[September 2020 Western United States wildfires]]

CATEGORIES: August 2020 events, September 2020 events, Fires in the United States, 2020 in California, 2020 in the United States

In 2020, the Western United States experienced a series of major wildfires. 

Intense August thunderstorms lit many wildfires across California, Oregon, and Washington, followed in early September by additional ignitions across the West Coast. 

Fanned by strong, gusty winds and fueled by hot, dry terrains, many of the fires exploded and coalesced into record-breaking, fire cloud producing, megafires, burning more than 4.6 of land. It has killed at least 35 people, with many more still missing. 

Climate change and poor forest management practices led to the severity of the wildfires.

[[B. C. Kamble]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, Living people, Indian politicians, Indian writers, Indian activists, Indian journalists, Jurists, Political writers, Centenarians

Bapu Chandrasen Kamble (born 15 July 1919), commonly known as B. C. Kamble, is an Indian politician, writer, editor, jurist, and social activist. He was born in Maharashtra, India. He is a member of the Republican Party. Between 1957 to 1962 and again from 1977 to 1979, he was a member of the Lok Sabha.

He was also a member of the Bombay Legislative Assembly from 1952 to 1957. In 1984, he unsuccessfully ran for Vice-President of India losing to R. Venkataraman.

During 1956 to 1957, he was a Professor of Constitutional Law in Siddharth College of Law, Mumbai.

[[Sushilkumar Shinde]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Governors of Andhra Pradesh

Sushilkumar Sambhaji Shinde (born 4 September 1941) is an Indian politician. He was the Minister of Home Affairs and  Power in the Manmohan Singh government. 

He was also the Leader of the House in Lok Sabha until 26 May 2014. 

He was the Chief Minister of the state of Maharashtra during 18 January 2003 to October 2004.

Shinde unsuccessfully ran for Vice-President of India in 2002, but lost the election to Bhairon Singh Shekhawat.

[[Pinner]]

CATEGORIES: Areas of London, London Borough of Harrow

Pinner is an area in Greater London, in the London Borough of Harrow. It is 12 miles (19 km) northwest from Charing Cross. Previously it was in Middlesex, as that county used to be.

Pinner is close to the northern border of the London Borough of Hillingdon.

[[Tell Me a Riddle]]

Tell Me a Riddle is a 1980 American drama movie directed by Lee Grant and starring Melvyn Douglas, Lila Kedrova, Brooke Adams, Peter Coyote, Zalman King.

[[Small frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The small frog, bleating water-holding frog, creek frog or little collared-frog (Ranoidea manya) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland on the Cape York Peninsula.

[[René Marqués]]

CATEGORIES: Plays, Puerto Rico, American playwrights, American essayists

René Marqués was an important Puerto Rican playwright. He was born on October 4, 1919 in Arecibo, Puerto Rico.  He died on March 22, 1979 in San Juan.  Critics say he is the most important Puerto Rican playwright of the 20th Century.

[[Puerto Rican literature]]

CATEGORIES: Puerto Rico, American literature

Puerto Rico has a vibrant literature. Puerto Rican poetry, novels, essays, and theater plays are mostly written in Spanish. However, Puerto Rican authors sometimes write in a mixture of Spanish and English and in English. The most important authors are René Marqués, Julia de Burgos, Rosario Ferrer, Luis Rafael Sanchez, Giannina Braschi, Lin-Manuel Miranda, and Esmeralda Santiago.

[[Giannina Braschi]]

CATEGORIES: Puerto Rican people, American novelists, American poets, American playwrights, Puerto Rican entertainers, Essayists, Novelists

Giannina Braschi (San Juan, Puerto Rico, 5 February 1953) is a Puerto Rican poet, novelist, and scholar. Her best-known books are Empire of Dreams, Yo-Yo Boing!, and United States of Banana.

[[Murdoc Niccals]]

CATEGORIES: Animated characters, Fictional British people, Rock musicians, Bassists

Murdoc Faust Niccals (born Murdoc Alphonce Niccals; 6 June 1966) is the fictional bassist for the British animated rock band Gorillaz. He is voiced by Phil Cornwell and was created by Damon Albarn and Jamie Hewlett.

[[Nicolette Poulos]]

Nicolette Poulos (born 4 January 1977) is a South African female water polo player.

She played at the 2009 World Aquatics Championships, and 2011 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Catharanthus roseus]]

CATEGORIES: Plants of Pakistan

Sadabahar is a small plant with dark green oval leaves and flat petalled pink flowers. It is the source of vinca alkaloids, used in chemotherapy (as vinblastine, vincristine, etc) for leukaemia and other cancers. Has been used as a herbal remedy for diabetes. Its investigation as a treatment for arthritis led to the discovery of its cytotoxic properties. It the Provincial flower of the Punjab in Pakistan.

[[Republican Party (Liberia)]]

CATEGORIES: Political parties in Africa, 1848 establishments, 1840s establishments in Africa, 1899 disestablishments, Disestablishments in Africa, Liberia

The Republican Party (or Liberian Party) was a political party in Liberia. The people in the party are mostly Americo-Liberians who had mixed African and European ancestry. The True Whig Party is the opposing party.

[[Winston Groom]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American novelists, American historians, American journalists, Writers from Washington, D.C., Writers from Alabama, People from Mobile, Alabama

Winston Francis Groom Jr. (March 23, 1943 – September 17, 2020) was an American novelist and non-fiction writer. He was born in Washington, D.C. but raised near Mobile, Alabama.

He was best known for writing Forrest Gump, which was made into the popular 1994 movie Forrest Gump. He published a sequel, Gump and Co., in 1995. 

He also wrote many non-fiction works such as about the American Civil War and World War I.

Groom died on September 17, 2020 in Fairhope, Alabama from a heart attack at the age of 77.

[[Czech Academy of Sciences]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 establishments in Europe, Buildings and structures in the Czech Republic, Prague

The Czech Academy of Sciences (abbr. CAS, Akademie věd České republiky, abbr. AV ČR) was created in 1992 by the Czech National Council. It replaced the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences. The Academy is the leading non-university public research institution in the Czech Republic. It is located in the Czech capital of Prague.

[[Luboš Perek]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, Czech astronomers, People from Prague, Centenarians

Luboš Perek (26 July 1919 – 17 September 2020) was a Czech astronomer. He was born in Prague. Perek was best known for his Catalogue of Galactic Planetary Nebulae co-written in 1967 with Luboš Kohoutek. 

From 1967 to 1970, he was General-Secretariat of the International Astronomical Union.

He worked on the mass in the galaxy, high-velocity stars, planetary nebulae, definition of outer space, geostationary orbit, space debris, and management of outer space.

Perek turned 100 in July 2019. He died on 17 September 2020 in Prague, aged 101.

[[Ashok Gasti]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians, Indian lawyers

Ashok Gasti (1965 – 17 September 2020) was an Indian politician and a lawyer. He was born in Raichur, Karnataka. He represented Karnataka in the Rajya Sabha for less than 3 months until his death in 2020. He was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

Gasti died of COVID-19 on 17 September 2020 at a hospital near Udupi, Karnataka at the age of 55.

[[Ricardo Ciciliano]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, 2020 deaths, Colombian footballers, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Colombia

Ricardo Manuel Ciciliano Bustillo (September 23, 1976 – September 17, 2020) was a Colombian football midfielder. Ciciliano was born in Barranquilla, Colombia. He mainly played for Millonarios F.C. with 65 appearances and with Juan Aurich with 58 appearances. 

Ciciliano died on September 17, 2020 at a hospital in Barranquilla from pneumonia caused by COVID-19, aged 43.

[[Roy C]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, American singer-songwriters, American soul singers, Record producers, Singers from Georgia (U.S. state), Writers from Georgia (U.S. state), Businesspeople from Georgia (U.S. state)

Roy Charles Hammond (August 3, 1939 – September 16, 2020), better known as Roy C or Roy "C", was an American southern soul singer-songwriter and record executive. He was best known for his songs "Shotgun Wedding" and "Impeach the President". He was born in Newington, Georgia.

Hammond died on September 16, 2020 in Allendale, South Carolina from liver cancer at the age of 81.

[[Newington, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Georgia (U.S. state)

Newington is a town in Screven County, Georgia, United States. The population was 322 at the 2000 census.

[[Wang Zhiliang]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese table tennis players, Deaths from stroke

Wang Zhiliang (王志良; 1941 – 15 September 2020) was a Chinese table tennis player and coach. At the 1963 World Table Tennis Championships, he and partner Zhang Xielin became the first Chinese duo to win the men's doubles gold medal in world championships. He was born in Xushui District, China.

Wang died on 15 September 2020 from a stroke in Beijing at the age of 79.

[[Steve Carter (playwright)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, American playwrights, Writers from New York City, Writers from Chicago

Horace Edward "Steve" Carter Jr. (November 7, 1929 – September 15, 2020) was an American playwright. Carter was best known for his plays involving Caribbean immigrants living in the United States. He was born in New York City. He was known for writing the 1978 play Nevis Mountain Dew. He was a playwright-in-residence at Victory Gardens Theater in Chicago.

Carter died on September 15, 2020 in Tomball, Texas at the age of 90.

[[Russell A. Anderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Minnesota, US Republican Party politicians

Russell A. Anderson (May 28, 1942 – September 15, 2020) was an American politician and attorney. He was Chief Justice of the Minnesota Supreme Court from 2006 to 2008. He was an Associate Justice of the court from September 1, 1998 until he was 2006. He was born in Bemidji, Minnesota

Anderson died on September 15, 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Anne Stevenson]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, British poets, American poets, People from Cambridge

Anne Stevenson (January 3, 1933 – September 14, 2020) was an American-British poet and writer. She received the Lannan Literary Award in 2007. Stevenson was born in Cambridge, England, but went to America at six months old. There she spent her childhood and youth. She hoped to be a musician, but she gradually lost her hearing, so switched to being a writer. Once she got her university degree, she decided to return to England where she settled for the rest of her life. In the 1960s she lived and wrote in Cambridge, Glasgow, Dundee and Oxford. She was writer in residence at the University of Dundee and co-founded Other Poetry (magazine). She wrote the controversial biography of the American poet Sylvia Plath.

Stevenson died on September 14, 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Gordon Getty]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, American philanthropists, American composers, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Businesspeople from Los Angeles, California

Gordon Peter Getty (born December 20, 1933) is an American businessman, investor, philanthropist and classical music composer.

He is the fourth child of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty. His mother, Ann Rork, was his father's fourth wife.

Getty got control of Getty's US$2 billion trust after his father's death. His net worth was $2.1 billion in May 2019, making him number 383 on the Forbes 400 list of the wealthiest Americans.

[[Reggie Johnson (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, Musicians from Kentucky, People from Owensboro, Kentucky

Reginald Volney Johnson (December 13, 1940 – September 11, 2020) was an American jazz double-bassist. He was born in Owensboro, Kentucky. He joined Art Blakey's band for a month-long residency at the Five Spot Café in December 1965.

He played and/or recorded with Bill Dixon, Sun Ra, and Burton Greene, Lonnie Liston Smith, Stanley Cowell, Bobby Hutcherson, Harold Land, Blue Mitchell, Walter Bishop Jr., Sonny Rollins, Sonny Stitt, Sarah Vaughan, Carmen McRae, Art Pepper, Kenny Burrell,  Clark Terry, The Crusaders, Johnny Coles, and Frank Wess.

Johnson died on September 11, 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Tony Villars]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Welsh footballers

Anthony Keith Villars (24 January 1952 – 9 September 2020) was a Welsh footballer. He was born in Pontypool, Wales. He made three appearances for the national team in 1974. From 1971 to 1976, he played for the Cardiff City F.C.. Between 1976 and 1977, he also played for the Newport County A.F.C..

Villars died on 9 September 2020 at the age of 68.

[[Luba Perchyshyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Businesspeople from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Writers from Minneapolis, Minnesota

Luba Perchyshyn (born Luba Mary Procai; October 10, 1923 – September 7, 2020) was an American businesswoman and crafter. She promoted the art of pysanky (Ukrainian decorated eggs). She was born in Minneapolis.

Perchyshyn co-authored several books, including Ukrainian Easter Eggs and How We Make Them (1979) and The Ukrainian Design Book (1999).

Perchyshyn's eggs were admired and sold internationally, and were included in White House holiday decorations and events.

Perchyshyn died on September 7, 2020 in Minneapolis at the age of 96.

[[Ethan Peters]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 births, 2020 deaths, Drug-related deaths in the United States, American artists, American YouTubers, Bloggers, LGBT artists, LGBT businesspeople, Gay men, LGBT people from Texas, Businesspeople from Houston, Texas, Make-up artists

Ethan Peters (March 8, 2003 – September 5, 2020) was an American beauty blogger, makeup artist, and social media personality. He had a large amount of followers on many social media platforms including Instagram and YouTube. He was known for his avant-garde, emo, and gay-inspired made-up style. Peters was the founder of the clothing line Hellboy.

Peters died of a drug overdose at his home in Huntsville, Texas on September 5, 2020 at the age of 17.

[[John Najarian]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, American physicians, Surgeons, Scientists from Oakland, California, Scientists from Minneapolis, Minnesota

John Sarkis Najarian (December 22, 1927 – September 1, 2020) was an American transplant surgeon. He was a clinical professor of transplant surgery at the University of Minnesota. Najarian was an important person in the discovery and usage of thoracic transplant surgery. He was born in Oakland, California.

Najarian died on September 1, 2020 in Stillwater, Minnesota at the age of 92.

[[James A. Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian mayors, Canadian lawyers, Politicians from Ontario

James Allan Taylor (May 2, 1928 – September 1, 2020) was a Canadian lawyer and politician. He was in the Legislative Assembly of Ontario from 1971 to 1987 and was a cabinet minister in the government of Bill Davis. Taylor was a member of the Progressive Conservative Party. He was born in Timmins, Ontario.

Taylor served as the first mayor of Prince Edward County from 1997 to 2003. 

Taylor died on September 1, 2020 in Belleville, Ontario at the age of 92.

[[Luboš Kohoutek]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Czech astronomers

Luboš Kohoutek (ˈkoɦou̯tɛk, born 29 January 1935) is a Czech astronomer. He was known as a discoverer of minor planets and comets, including Comet Kohoutek which was visible to the naked eye in 1973. He also discovered comets 75D/Kohoutek and 76P/West–Kohoutek–Ikemura.

The main-belt asteroid 1850 Kohoutek was named after him.

[[British Academy]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 establishments, Buildings and structures in London

The British Academy is the United Kingdom's national academy for the humanities and the social sciences.

It was created in 1902 and received its royal charter in the same year.

The academy is a self-governing and independent registered charity, based at 10–11 Carlton House Terrace in London.

The British Academy is funded with an annual grant from the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS).

[[Udupi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in India, Settlements in Karnataka

Udupi, otherwise spelt Udipi and also known as Odipu, is a city in the Indian state of Karnataka. Udupi is located about 55 north of the educational, commercial & industrial hub Mangalore and about 422 west of state capital Bangalore by road. 

[[Jeff Bergman]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Actors from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, American voice actors, American television actors, Comedians from Pennsylvania

Jeffrey Allen Bergman (born July 10, 1960) is an American voice actor, comedian and impressionist. He is known for his voice work with Looney Tunes and Hanna-Barbera characters. 

Bergman was the first to replace Mel Blanc as the voice of Bugs Bunny and several other Warner Bros. cartoon characters following Blanc's death in 1989. 

[[Eric Bauza]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, Actors from Toronto, American animators, American television actors, American video game actors, American voice actors, Canadian animators, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Eric Adrian Bauza (born December 7, 1979) is a Canadian-American voice actor, animation artist and stand-up comedian. His roles include Stimpy on Ren and Stimpy "Adult Party Cartoon", Rudolfo Rivera/White Pantera on El Tigre: The Adventures of Manny Rivera, Foop on The Fairly OddParents and Lord Stingray on Superjail!, The Powerpuff Girls.

He is also one of the current voices of characters such as Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Marvin the Martian, Pepé Le Pew, Tweety, Woody Woodpecker, Boo-Boo Bear, Ranger Smith, Scrappy Doo, and Dino.

[[Selectorate theory]]

CATEGORIES: Political systems, Non-fiction books

Selectorate Theory is a political theory that attributes the actions of leaders to rational, calculated decisions based on acquiring and maintaining power, originally proposed by Bruce Bueno de Mesquita.

[[Conversation Piece]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, Italian drama movies, French drama movies, Movies directed by Luchino Visconti, Movies set in Rome

Conversation Piece (Gruppo di famiglia in un interno) is a 1974 Italian French erotic drama movie directed by Luchino Visconti and starring Burt Lancaster, Helmut Berger, Silvana Mangano, Claudia Marsani, Romolo Valli, Philippe Hersent, Umberto Raho.

[[The Damned (1969 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 drama movies, LGBT movies, Italian drama movies, German drama movies, Liechtenstein movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Luchino Visconti

The Damned (Italian title: La caduta degli dei, lit. "The Fall of the Gods") is a 1969 Italian German Liechtenstein drama movie directed by Luchino Visconti and starring Dirk Bogarde, Ingrid Thulin, Helmut Griem, Helmut Berger, Renaud Verley, Umberto Orsini, Charlotte Rampling. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1970 and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Hattie Morahan]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English voice actors, Actors from London

Harriet Jane Morahan (born 7 October 1978) is an English actress. Her roles include Alice in The Bletchley Circle, Gale Benson in The Bank Job  (2008), Ann in Mr. Holmes (2015), Rose Coyne in My Mother and Other Strangers (2016), and Agathe/The Enchantress in Beauty and the Beast (2017).

[[Joe Ruklick]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, Golden State Warriors players, Sportspeople from Illinois

Joseph Ruklick (ˈ RUCK (August 3, 1938 – September 17, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He played in the National Basketball Association (NBA). He played for the Philadelphia Warriors between 1959 to 1962. Ruklick was born in Princeton, Illinois.

Ruklick died of natural causes on September 17, 2020 in Evanston, Illinois at the age of 82.

[[Berni Alder]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, German physicists, American physicists, Scientists from Berkeley, California, People from North Rhine-Westphalia

Berni Julian Alder (September 9, 1925 – September 7, 2020) was a German-born American physicist. His works focused in statistical mechanics, and an important person of numerical simulation in physics. He was born in Duisburg, Germany. In 2008, he became a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. In 2009, he was honored with the National Medal of Science.

Alder died on September 7, 2020 at the age of 94.

[[Scheduled monument]]

CATEGORIES: Archaeological sites, United Kingdom law

In the United Kingdom, a scheduled monument is a nationally important archaeological site or historic building. The schedule legally protects the monument from unauthorised change.

The protection of scheduled monuments is given under the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979. There are about 20,000 scheduled monuments in England.

According to the 1979 Act, a monument cannot be a structure which is occupied as a dwelling, used as a place of worship or protected under the Protection of Wrecks Act 1973.

[[Anikó Gyöngyössy]]

Anikó Gyöngyössy (born 21 May 1990) is a Hungarian water polo player. She's the goalkeeper for Budapesti VSC (BVSC) until 2022.

It is the fourthKing Kong movie and second Japanese King Kong movie. this film was special effects by Eiji Tsuburaya. about an giant ape named Kong an Mondo Islander tries to hunt the terrorist leader Dr. Who creating a giant robot called Mechani-Kong or Robot Kong in English-dub, an 20-meter ape robot.

Cristina Lopez Aliaga (born 20 October 1982) is a Spanish water polo player.

On the club level, she played with Club Natació Sabadell, champion of Spain, in 2004, 2005, 2007 and 2009.

On the club level, she played for Alcorcón Swimming Club.  

[[List of reptiles of Alabama]]

CATEGORIES: Reptiles of North America, United States-related lists, Alabama

Alabama is home to 93 indigenous reptile species. Indigenous species include one type of crocodilian, 12 types of lizard, 49 types of snake, and 31 types of turtle. Three native species may be extinct in the state. These include the eastern indigo snake, southern hognose snake and the mimic glass lizard.

[[Kuranda tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The Kuranda tree frog (Ranoidea myola) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland.  Scientists have only seen it near the Barron River.

The adult male frog is 3.5 to 4.5 cm long and the adult female frog is 5.7 to 6.9 cm long.  They can be brown, tan, gray or a mix of these with darker brown or green marks.  The female frog spends most of her time in trees and the male frog spends most of his time near streams.

This frog is endangered because of habitat loss, because of the fungal disease chytridiomycosis, because of predators brought from other places and because of competition from a similar frog, the green-eyed tree frog.

[[Northern copperhead snake]]

CATEGORIES: Vipers, Reptiles of North America

The northern copperhead snake (Agkistrodon contortrix mokasen) is a subspecies of the copperhead snake. It is found in the eastern United States.

[[Kim Cheong-gi]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, South Korean movie directors

Kim Cheong-gi (born April 4, 1941) is a South Korean director of animated, fantasy, and science fiction themed films.

His most well known work, Robot Taekwon V (1976), is considered one of the milestones of Korean animation. With actor Shim Hyung-rae, he created the Ureme series, one of the more popular Korean children's series of the late 1980s. 

[[Hieracium]]

CATEGORIES: Asteraceae

Hieracium is the hawkweed. This genus of sunflowers has a huge number of species  over ten thousand species and subspecies. 

Some experts split it up into two genera: what is here treated as the single genus Hieracium is treated by some European experts as two genera, Hieracium and Pilosella.

Like all members of the family, hawkweeds have tightly packed flowerheads made of many small flowers. They reproduce asexually by seeds which are genetically identical to those of the mother plant.

[[Shah Ahmad Shafi]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from diabetes, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Bangladeshi writers, Bangladeshi educators

Shah Ahmad Shafi (শাহ আহমদ শফী) (1916 – 18 September 2020) was a Bangladeshi educator. He was the chief of Hefajat-e-Islam Bangladesh. He was rector of Al-Jamiatul Ahlia Darul Ulum Moinul Islam Hathazari from 1986 until his death and also the chairman of Bangladesh Qawmi Madrasah Education Board. He was born in Rangunia, Chittagong.

Shafi died on 18 September 2020 from a heart attack caused by diabetes in Dhaka, aged 104.

[[Space Gundam V]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 movies, South Korean movies

Space Gundam V  (스페이스 간담 V)  or Space Gandam V is a 1983 South Korean animated science fiction action mecha film directed by Kim-Cheong-Gi. produced by Seoul Donghwa Productions.

[[Mohamed Atwi]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, 2020 deaths, Lebanese footballers, Deaths by firearm

Mohamed Ahmed Atwi (محمد أحمد عطوي; 10 January 1987 – 18 September 2020) was a Lebanese professional footballer who last played as a midfielder. He played for the national team from 2011 to 2014. From 2008 to 2018, he played for Al Ansar. Atwi was born in Harouf, Lebanon.

On 21 August 2020, Atwi was hit in the head by a stray bullet in Beirut. He died a month later on 18 September, aged 33.

[[Pir Hameeduddin Sialvi]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Pakistani politicians

Hazrat Pir Khwaja Hameeduddin Sialvi (1936 – 17 September 2020) was a Pakistani spiritual leader and politician. He was the  sajjadah nasheen of  Sial Sharif shrine in Sargodha, Pakistan. He was a member of the Senate of Pakistan between 1988 to 1994. He was a member of the Pakistan Muslim League (Q). Sialvi was born in Sial Sharif.

Sialvi died on 17 September 2020 in Sial Sharif at the age of 84.

[[Reg Harrison]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from West Midlands (county), People from Derby

Reginald Frederick Harrison (22 May 1923 – 17 September 2020) was an English professional footballer. He played as a right winger. Harrison was born in Normanton, Derby. His career began in 1939 and he retired in 1962. 

He played for Derby County, Boston United and Long Eaton United. He managed Long Eaton United between 1958 to 1962.

Harrison died at home in Alvaston, Derby on 17 September 2020 at the age of 97. At the time of his death he was the oldest living FA Cup finalist.

[[Stéphane Caillat]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, French composers, French conductors, People from Lyon

Stéphane Caillat (1928 – 11 September 2020) was a French composer and conductor of orchestras and choirs. He was born in Lyon, France. 

In 1954, he founded the choir named after him, Stéphane Caillat. In 1979, he founded the Centre d'études polyphoniques et chorales de Paris Île-de-France, which he directed for ten years. He also produced music programs for France Musique during the 1980s.

Caillat died in Paris on 11 September 2020, aged 92.

[[Sheila Ingram]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, American track and field athletes, American Olympic silver medalists, Sportspeople from Washington, D.C.

Sheila Rena Ingram (March 23, 1957 – September 1, 2020) was an American athlete. She competed mainly in the 400 metres. She was born in Washington, D.C.. She competed for United States in the 1976 Summer Olympics, winning a silver medal.

Ingram died on September 1, 2020 at the age of 63.

[[Walnut Creek, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Cities in the San Francisco Bay Area, Settlements in Contra Costa County, California

Walnut Creek is a city in Contra Costa County, California, United States. It is located in the East Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area, about 16 east of the city of Oakland. About 70,166 people live here.

[[Aigre]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Charente

Aigre (Fr-aigre.ogg) is a commune in the Charente department in the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region of southwestern France.

The commune has been awarded one flower by the National Council of Towns and Villages in Bloom in the Competition of cities and villages in Bloom.

On 1 January 2019, the former commune of Villejésus was merged into Aigre.

[[Watamu]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Africa, Settlements in Kenya

Watamu is a small town located approximately 105 km north of Mombasa and about 15 km south of Malindi on the Indian Ocean coast of Kenya.   Its main economic activities are tourism and fishing. The town has a population of around 30,000 in 2020.

[[Siwanoy]]

CATEGORIES: Native American, Ethnic groups in the United States

The Siwanoy were a tribe of Native Americans who lived mostly in The Bronx and Westchester County, New York. They were part of a group of tribes called the Wappinger-Mattabesec Confederacy. 

Today, the descendants of the Siwanoy people live all across the United States.

CATEGORIES: United States Supreme Court cases, 1993 in the United States

Austin v. United States, 509 U.S. 602 (1993), was an Supreme Court case in 1993 where the Supreme Court decided that the Eighth Amendment includes the government seizing property as punishment.

[[LiHe]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

LiHe is a chemical compound. It contains helium and lithium. The substance is a cold low density gas. It is made of a helium atom and lithium atom held together by van der Waals force. It was detected in 2013.

Northumberland County is a county in the U.S. state of Virginia. As of the 2010 census, 12,330 people lived there. Its county seat is Heathsville.

[[Lithium 12-hydroxystearate]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium 12-hydroxystearate is a chemical compound. Its chemical formula is C18H35LiO3. It is classified as a lithium soap. In chemistry, "soap" refers to salts of fatty acids. Lithium 12-hydroxystearate is a white solid.

[[Larry Wilson (American football)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Arizona Cardinals players, Sportspeople from Idaho, Businesspeople from Idaho

Larry Frank Wilson (March 24, 1938spaced ndashSeptember 17, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a free safety with the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League (NFL) between 1960 to 1972. He was born in Rigby, Idaho.

He played his entire 13-year career with the Cardinals and remained on the team's payroll until 2003. After his playing career, he stayed with the Cardinals as a coach and executive between 1973 to 2002. 

Wilson died on September 18, 2020 from cancer in Scottsdale, Arizona at the age of 82.

[[Audrey Azoulay]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, French politicians

Audrey Azoulay (o.dʁɛ a.zu.lɛ; born 4 August 1972) is a French politician. She was France's Minister of Culture from 2016 to 2017.  

She was nominated on 13 October 2017 and, on 10 November 2017, appointed as the Director-General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), becoming the second female leader of the organization.

[[De Fryske Marren]]

CATEGORIES: De Fryske Marren, 2010s establishments in the Netherlands, 2014 establishments in Europe

De Fryske Marren (De Friese Meren) is a municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. In 2019, 51,430 people lived there.

It was created on 1 January 2014 and consists of the former municipalities of Gaasterlân-Sleat, Lemsterland, Skarsterlân and parts of Boarnsterhim, all four of which were dissolved on the same day.

Boarnsterhim (Boornsterhem) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. On 1 January 2014, the municipality was dissolved and its territory was split between four other municipalities: De Fryske Marren, which was created that day, Leeuwarden, Heerenveen and Súdwest-Fryslân.

[[Lithium aluminium hydride]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium aluminium hydride is an inorganic compound. Its chemical formula is LiAlH4. It is commonly abbreviated as LAH. It is a grey solid. It was discovered by Finholt, Bond and Schlesinger in 1947.

[[Melinda Plowman]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Actors from Texas, Movie directors from Texas, American child actors

Melinda Plowman (born May 13, 1941), also called Melinda Ann Casey and Melinda Casey, is an American actress and associate director. She started acting aged 6 and was in many movies and television series in the 1960s. Her first lead role was in the 1966 horror movie Billy the Kid Versus Dracula. She joined the Directors Guild of America in the 1970s and was an associate director in the 1990s.

[[Henry Selick]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, American animators, Screenwriters from New Jersey, Movie directors from New Jersey, Movie producers from New Jersey, People from Glen Ridge, New Jersey, Disney animators, Living people

Charles Henry Selick (born November 30, 1952) is an American stop motion director, producer, and screenwriter. He is best known for directing the stop-motion animation movies The Nightmare Before Christmas (1993), James and the Giant Peach (1996), Coraline (2009), and his upcoming stop-motion movie Wendell and Wild (2021) with Jordan Peele and Keegan-Michael Key.

[[U Škripcu]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 establishments in Europe, 1990s disestablishments in Europe, 1991 disestablishments, Rock bands, Belgrade, Musical groups established in 1980, Musical groups disestablished in 1991

U Škripcu (У Шкрипцу; trans. In Dire Straits) was a Serbian and Yugoslav rock band from Belgrade.

The band was created in 1980 by Zoran Vulović "Vule" (keyboards), Milan Delčić "Delča" (vocals) and Aleksandar Vasiljević "Vasa" (guitar), who later added Miloš Obrenović (drums) and Aleksandar Lukić (bass guitar) to the band, and to change the name of the band to U Škripcu. After the band became successful and popular around Yugoslavia with the release of the album O je! and EP Nove godine!, they failed to repeat this success, and so they disbanded in 1985.

In 1986, Vulović and Delčić re-created the band, but the latter soon left the band, so the new lineup, which included the vocalist Aleksandar Tabaš and various musicians, recorded the fourth studio album, U Škripcu. The album was not successful, so the band disbanded again in 1988. The next year, Vulović reunited with Delčić and Vasiljević, Lukić on guitar, bassist Dejan Škopelja, and drummer Ratko Ljubičić. They recorded the fifth studio album Izgleda da mi smo sami. After this, the band disbanded again. After this, Vulović became a producer and manager, Delčić pursued a solo career with his band Sklekovi, and Vasiljević and Lukić became a part of the supergroup Familija. In 2007, the original lineup came back together at the Delča i Sklekovi concert at the Belgrade Dom Omladine, which was released in 2008 as Ljubilarnih 20 i nešto godina - Live, under the moniker Delča a i U Škripcu. Delčić died of cancer on 24 July 2011.

[[The Beautiful Blonde from Bashful Bend]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s comedy movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s western movies, American romantic comedy movies, American western movies, 20th Century Fox movies

The Beautiful Blonde from Bashful Bend is a 1949 American romantic western comedy movie directed by Preston Sturges and was based on the story by Earl Felton. It stars Betty Grable, Cesar Romero, Rudy Vallee, Sterling Holloway, Hugh Herbert, El Brendel and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Papa Legba]]

CATEGORIES: Mythology, Religion, Afro-American religion

Papa Legba is a loa in Voodoo, who serves as the intermediary between the loa and humanity. He stands at a spiritual crossroads and gives permission to speak with the spirits of Guinee.

[[Plasticity (physics)]]

CATEGORIES: Physics stubs, Physics, Engineering

Plasticity, or plastic deformation, is the ability of a solid material to have a permanent change in shape. In physics and materials science, this is called deformation.  

For example, a solid piece of metal being bent or pounded into a new shape shows plasticity. Permanent changes occur in the material itself. In engineering, the transition from elastic behaviour to plastic behaviour is known as yielding.

[[Iaido]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese culture, Martial art techniques

Iaido is a Japanese martial art that focuses on drawing a sword (typically a katana). It is about being aware and being capable of quickly drawing the sword and responding to a sudden attack.

Iaido movements are elegant movements. New learners often start using a wooden sword and then move on to an iaitō (A metal but fairly blunt sword). People that do Iaido may be called ''iaidoka.

[[Barton Highway]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in Australia, Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales

The Barton Highway is a highway in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, Australia. It is also known as A25.

Later this year 2020, the Barton Highway duplication project will happen and will retain the M25 route marker in 2023.

[[Stephen F. Cohen]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, American historians, American educators, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in New York City, Writers from Indianapolis, Indiana, American political writers, American editors

Stephen Frand Cohen (November 25, 1938 – September 18, 2020) was an American historian of Russian studies. His works focused on modern Russian history since the Bolshevik Revolution and Russia's relationship with the United States. Cohen was an editor to The Nation magazine. Cohen was a founding director of the reestablished American Committee for East–West Accord which was revived in 2015. He was born in Indianapolis, Indiana.

Cohen died on September 18, 2020 from lung cancer in New York City, aged 81.

[[Robert W. Gore]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, Engineers from Utah, American inventors, Businesspeople from Salt Lake City, Utah, Scientists from Utah

Robert W. "Bob" Gore (April 15, 1937 – September 17, 2020) was an American engineer, scientist, inventor and businessman. He was born Salt Lake City, Utah. Gore led his family's company, W. L. Gore & Associates. He was known for his invention of Gore-Tex.

Gore died on September 17, 2020 in Newark, Delaware from cancer at the age of 83.

[[Arnold Thackray]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, English historians, English scientists

Arnold Thackray (born 30 July 1939) is an English science historian. He is the founding president of the Chemical Heritage Foundation (now the Science History Institute), the Life Sciences Foundation, and Science History Consultants. He is an emeritus professor at the University of Pennsylvania.

[[Donald Trump photo op at St. John's Church]]

CATEGORIES: June 2020 events, Donald Trump, 2020 in the United States, 21st century in Washington, D.C.

On June 1, 2020, amid the George Floyd protests in Washington, D.C., law enforcement officers used tear gas and other riot control tactics to forcefully clear peaceful protesters from Lafayette Square.

This was done to create a path for President Donald Trump and senior administration officials to walk from the White House to St. John's Episcopal Church. Trump held up a Bible and posed for a photo shoot in front of Ashburton House (the church's parish house), which had been damaged by a fire during protests the night before.

Former military leaders, current religious leaders, and elected officials from both parties criticized Trump for the event. The event was described by The New York Times as "a burst of violence unlike any seen in the shadow of the White House in generations" and possibly one of the defining moments of the Trump presidency. Joe Biden and some newspapers said that Donald Trump held the Bible upside down, which is not true.

[[Bud]]

CATEGORIES: Plant physiology, Plant tissues

A bud usually occurs  in the axil of a leaf or at the tip of a stem. They are one way plants can reproduce asexually. They connect with phloem and xylem to get nourishment. 

Some plants normally develop adventitious buds on their roots. The buds can grow quite a distance from the plant. Shoots that develop from adventitious buds on roots are termed suckers. They occur in many grasses, quaking aspen and Canada thistle. A famous quaking aspen known as the Pando grew from one trunk to 47,000 trunks by adventitious bud formation on a single root system.

[[Gnesau]]

Gnesau (Knežova) is a municipality of the district Feldkirchen in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

[[Lithium aspartate]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium aspartate is a salt of aspartic acid and lithium. Its chemical formula is C4H6LiNO4. It is sometimes sold as a dietary supplement which is used in small doses to treat some diseases. However, there are no studies that support the efficiency, or safety, of lithium aspartate. It is not approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to treat any disease.

[[Quaking aspen]]

CATEGORIES: Forests

The quaking aspen is a term for two different aspen species.

All aspens spread by suckers (root sprouts). They may come to air up to 40 m from the parent tree, and form extensive clonal colonies.
