[[Lithium azide]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium azide is the lithium salt of hydrazoic acid. It is an unstable and toxic compound. It decomposes into lithium and nitrogen when heated.

[[Jitsi]]

CATEGORIES: Free software, Instant messaging software, Video chat

Jitsi is a group of free and open-source voice (VoIP), videoconferencing and instant messaging for many platforms, like the web platform, Windows, Linux, macOS, iOS and Android. The Jitsi project started with Jitsi Desktop (previously known as SIP Communicator). With the growth of WebRTC, the Jitsi team decided to focus on Jitsi Videobridge for doing web-based video calling for multiple people. Later the team added Jitsi Meet, a full video conferencing application that includes web, Android, and iOS clients. Jitsi also operates meet.jit.si, a version of Jitsi Meet hosted by Jitsi for free to be used by the community. Other projects are: Jigasi, lib-jitsi-meet, Jidesha, and Jitsi.

Jitsi is supportefd by various institutions such as the NLnet Foundation, the University of Strasbourg and the Region of Alsace and it has participated multiple times on Google Summer of Code program.

[[Lithium beryllide]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium beryllide is a hypothetical intermetallic compound of lithium and beryllium. It may have many possible compositions. They include LiBe, LiBe2, Li2Be, LiBe3, Li3Be, Li2Be3, Li3Be2, LiBe4 and Li4Be.

[[Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) s a hydrophilic salt. Its chemical formula is LiC2F6NO4S2. It is commonly used as a source of lithium ions in electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries. It is an alternative to the commonly used lithium hexafluorophosphate. It is made up of one lithium cation and a bistriflimide anion. LiTFSI is toxic if swallowed. It is toxic in contact with skin and can cause severe skin burns. Therefore, sealed batteries must not be opened. 

[[Waterfall frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The waterfall frog or torrent tree frog (Ranoidea nannotis) is a frog from Australia. Scientists have seen it between 180 and 1300 metres above sea level.

The adult male frog is 3.2 to 5.2 cm long and the adult female frog is 4.8 to 5.9 cm long.  This frog lives in fast-flowing streams in rainforests and other forests.  It does not only lay its eggs in fast streams.  It spends most of its time in or near the water.  The adult frog is gray or olive on the back with mottling colors and a white belly.  This frog can lay eggs at any time of year.  The female frog lays her eggs underneath rocks.  The tadpoles have strong tails for swimming and mouths on the underside of their bodies so they can hold onto rocks.  Adult frogs hide in the stream or near waterfalls during the day and look for food at night. They usually do not go more than 35 metres away from the water.

This frog eats almost any animal without bones inside that it can fit into its mouth.  It will eat flies, dragonflies, beetles, true bugs, mites, bees, wasps, ants, insect larvae and millipedes.

This frog is endangered.  Scientists think this might be because feral pigs brought to Australia by humans rip up their streams, but they are not sure.  Some scientists looked at whether habitat loss or or chemicals that humans use to kill insects might be killing the frogs, and they found this is probably not what is killing them.  Some scientists think the fungal disease chytridiomycosis could be killing the frogs

[[Lithium bis(trimethylsilyl)amide]]

CATEGORIES: Lithium compounds

Lithium bis(trimethylsilyl)amide is a lithiated organosilicon compound. Its chemical formula is LiN(SiMe3)2. It is commonly abbreviated as LiHMDS which means lithium hexamethyldisilazide. It is mainly used as a strong non-nucleophilic base and as a ligand.

[[Gympie gympie]]

CATEGORIES: Urticaceae, Toxicology, Plants of Australia

Dendrocnide moroides,  the gympie gympie, or gympie stinger, is a plant of rainforest areas in the north east of Australia. It is also found in Indonesia. It has stinging hairs over the whole plant. It delivers a strong neurotoxin when touched. The small bulb  on the tip of the stinging hairs break off and penetrating the skin, injecting the toxin. It is the most toxic of the Australian  stinging trees. The fruit can be eaten if the stinging hairs that cover it are removed.

Ernie Rider, who was slapped in the face and torso with the foliage in 1963, said:

For two or three days the pain was almost unbearable; I couldn’t work or sleep, then it was pretty bad pain for another fortnight or so. The stinging persisted for two years and recurred every time I had a cold shower. ... There's nothing to rival it; it's ten times worse than anything else.

The sting does not stop several small marsupial species (such as the red-legged pademelon, some insects, such as Prasyptera mastersi, and some birds, from eating the leaves.

[[High tech]]

CATEGORIES: Technology

High technology (or high tech for short) is the best technology available at the moment. High technology can be defined as the most complex or the newest technology on the market. The opposite of high technology is low technology (or low tech for short). This is simple and cheap technology.

[[About the Mystery of the Letters]]

CATEGORIES: Christian texts

About the Mystery of the Letters (Περὶ τοῦ μυστηρίου τῶν γραμμάτων, Peri tou mystēriou tōn grammatōn) is a work about the names and forms of letters of the Greek and Hebrew letters. The author of the work is unknown, but he probably had a Christian background. It was probably written in the 6th century Byzantine Palaestina Prima.

[[St. Lawrence Island]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of North America, Islands of Alaska

St. Lawrence Island is an island found in the Bering Sea, west of the U.S. State Alaska. The island has an area of 4,640 square kilometers, and is 140 km long, and 35 km wide. The island is part of Alaska, although it is closer to Russia. The island is a one of the last above water parts of the ancient landmass known as Beringia. It is the sixth largest island in the United States, and is the 113th largest island in the world. In 2010, 1,292 people lived on the island, most of which live in the two main villages of Savoonga and Gambell. 

[[Economic growth]]

CATEGORIES: Economics

Economic growth occurs when the labor force increases it productive output. This is through the population working harder or a technological advancement

[[Forests of Azerbaijan]]

CATEGORIES: Forests, Geography of Azerbaijan, Azerbaijan-related lists

The forests of Azerbaijan have 150 endemic species of trees and bushes out of a total of 435 species of trees and bushes.

The total forest area of Azerbaijan is 1,021,880 ha or 11.8% of the country's area. The forest biomes are made up of temperate deciduous forests, temperate mixed deciduous and coniferous forests, temperate coniferous forests and riparian forests. Specialists estimate that in the 8th-9th centuries the forest cover was around 30-35%, most of it is in mountainous areas.

While as a whole, Azerbaijan is a country with modest forest cover, the forest cover is unevenly spread across the country. In the low-lying areas, the forest cover is very sparse, also due to the fact that the precipitation is too low for trees and forests to grow in most of these areas; whereas in many mountainous areas, the forest cover is much greater especially in wetter areas.

49% of the country's forests are located in the Greater Caucasus Mountains, 34% in the Lesser Caucasus Mountains, 15% in the Talysh Mountains-Lankaran Lowland region, 2% in the Kur-Araz Lowland, and 0.5% in the Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic.

The forests are classified into two major ecoregions in Azerbaijan: the Caucasus mixed forests of the Greater Caucasus Mountains and the Lesser Caucasus Mountains, and the Caspian Hyrcanian mixed forests of the Talysh Mountains-Lankaran Lowland region.

Azerbaijan has many endemic tree and shrub species, relicts of the Tertiary period which were not affected by Pliocene and Pleistocene glaciations.

[[Popular.reviews]]

CATEGORIES: Websites

Popular.Reviews is a consumer review website founded in Romania. Originally launched in 2016, it provides price comparisons, articles, and reviews on home use products and appliances, tech devices, beauty products, and other topics of interest. The website relies on a team of expert reviewers who focus on consumer-oriented research, editorial pieces following strict content guidelines to comply with market and reader demands.

[[Anacleto Oliveira]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Lisbon, Road accident deaths

Anacleto Cordeiro Gonçalves de Oliveira (17 July 1946 – 18 September 2020) was a Portuguese Roman Catholic prelate. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1970. He was auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lisbon from 2005 to 2010. He then was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Viana do Castelo, Portugal, from 2010 until his death.

Oliveira died on 18 September 2020 in Lisbon from a car crash at the age of 74.

[[Mike Tilleman]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Minnesota Vikings players, New Orleans Saints players, Tennessee Titans players, Atlanta Falcons players, Sportspeople from Montana

Michael John Tilleman (March 30, 1944 – September 18, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a defensive tackle in the National Football League (NFL) for 11 seasons (1966–76). He played college football for the Montana Grizzlies. He was born in Chinook, Montana.

He played for the Minnesota Vikings, New Orleans Saints, Houston Oilers and the Atlanta Falcons.

Tilleman died on September 18, 2020 in Havre, Montana from heart disease-related problems, aged 76.

[[Roza Vidyadhar Deshpande]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians

Roza Vidyadhar Deshpande (1929 – 19 September 2020) was an Indian politician. She was a member of the United Communist Party of India. Deshpande was born in Bombay Presidency, British India. Deshpande was a member of Lok Sabha from 1973 to 1977. 

Deshpande died on 19 September 2020 in Mumbai at the age of 91.

[[Lee Kerslake]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, English rock singers, English rock drummers, Singer-songwriters from London, Musicians from London, Trumpeters

Lee Kerslake (16 April 1947nbsp– 19 September 2020) was an English singer-songwriter and drummer. He was best known as the longtime drummer and backing vocalist for the rock band Uriah Heep and for his work with Ozzy Osbourne in the early 1980s.

On 19 September 2020, Kerslake died from prostate cancer at age 73.

[[Virgin and Child with Canon van der Paele]]

CATEGORIES: 15th century paintings, Depictions of Mary (mother of Jesus)

The Virgin and Child with Canon van der Paele is a large painting finished around 1434–1436 by Jan van Eyck. It shows Joris van der Paele, who was the donor portrait of the painting, with a number of saints. The Virgin Mary is at the centre of the painting on a throne with Jesus Christ as a baby in her arms. The painting is set in a rounded church with the throne being where the altar would be. Many people believe the painting to be one of van Eyck's best, with some calling it a "masterpiece of masterpieces".

[[Bluey (dog)]]

CATEGORIES: 1910 births, 1939 deaths, Individual dogs

Bluey (7 June 1910 – 14 November 1939) was an Australian Cattle Dog. Bluey's owners are Les and Esma Hall from Rochester, Victoria, Australia. Guinness World Records says that Bluey is the oldest known dog. Bluey lived for 29 years and 5 months.

Another dog named Chilla was said to have lived for 32 years. A study was done to see if Australian Cattle Dogs lived longer than other dog breeds. 100 dogs were surveyed. The study showed that Australian Cattle Dogs lived on average for 13.41 years, almost a year longer than other dog breeds. In the end, the study says that Bluey and Chilla should be seen as distinct from other dogs instead of showing longer lives for Australian Cattle Dogs.

Three other dogs named Max, Bella, and Maggie were said by their owners to have lived longer than Bluey. Guinness World Records did not put any of the dogs in their book because the dog owners could not verify that fact.

[[Ghost pepper]]

CATEGORIES: Capsicum

The ghost pepper, also known as bhut jolokia, is a chili pepper grown in Northeast India.

Guinness World Records said it was the hottest pepper in the world in 2007. It has a rating of over one million Scoville Heat Units (SHUs). It was passed by three hotter chillis during 2011. These was passed by the Carolina Reaper in 2013, which is still currently the hottest pepper.

[[Shawn Fonteno]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Actors from Los Angeles, California, African-American movie actors, African-American voice actors, American rap musicians from California

Shawn Darnell Fonteno, also known as Solo, is an American actor and rapper. He is best known as the voice and the motion capture performer of Franklin Clinton in the video game Grand Theft Auto V (2013). He is also the cousin of rapper Young Maylay who voiced Carl "CJ" Johnson, the protagonist of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas.

Fonteno was born in Los Angeles, California, and grew up in neighborhood of Watts.

[[Four pests campaign]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century in China, Chinese communist politicians, Pests, 1950s in China, 1960s in China

The Four Pests Campaign (除) was one of the campaigns of China, agains four pests: namely rats, flies, mosquitoes and sparrows. It was part of a campaign called the Great Leap Forward, which wanted to boost Chinese economy, in the mid-20th century. The campaign started in 1958.   

The extermination of sparrows is also known as Smash Sparrows Campaign (打) or Eliminate Sparrows Campaign (消灭麻雀运动). It caused severe ecological imbalance; it was one of the causes of the Great Chinese Famine. In 1960. Mao Zedong ended the campaign against sparrows and redirected the fourth focus to bed bugs. Only after Mao Zedong had died, in 1976, did the official Chinese press agency announce that sparrows were more useful than harmful. The government took measures to increase the sparrow population in the province of Shandong.

[[Christmas elf]]

CATEGORIES: Christmas

A Christmas elf is a diminutive elf that lives with Santa Claus at the North Pole and serves as his helper. Christmas elves are often said to wear green or red clad with large, pointy ears and pointy hats. Santa's elves are known to make the toys in Santa's workshop and take care of his reindeer, among other tasks.

The Christmas elf appeared in literature as early as 1850 when Louisa May Alcott completed, but never published a book entitled Christmas Elves. The image of the elves in the workshop was popularized by Godey's Lady's Book, with a front cover illustration for its 1873 Christmas Issue showing Santa surrounded by toys and elves with the caption, "Here we have an idea of the preparations that are made to supply the young folks with toys at Christmas time." During this time, Godey's was immensely influential to the birth of Christmas traditions, having shown the first widely circulated picture of a modern Christmas tree on the front cover of its 1850 Christmas issue. Additional recognition was given in Austin Thompson's 1876 work "The House of Santa Claus, a Christmas Fairy Show for Sunday Schools".

The elves are generally said to live for hundreds, or even thousands, of years, despite the fact that in some cases they appear eternally youthful as children.

[[Carbonatite]]

CATEGORIES: Minerals, Carbonates, Igneous rocks

Carbonatite (pron) is a type of igneous rock. It has greater than 50% carbonate minerals.  Carbonatites may be confused with marble, so may need geochemical analysis to make sure.

Carbonatites usually occur as small plugs, or as dikes, sills, breccias, and veins. They are almost all near or in continental rift-related tectonic settings. 

It seems that there has been a steady increase in the carbonatitic igneous activity through the Earth's history, from the Archean eon to the present. Carbonates in general are typical products of life-forms.

[[Oglethorpe, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

[[Caves of Azerbaijan]]

CATEGORIES: Caves, Geography of Azerbaijan

There are many natural caves in Azerbaijan. Most of these caves are karstic caves and the rest are volcanic caves (lava tubes). These caves were also the first shelters and dwellings of Stone Age hominids and humans.

Azykh Cave, one of the most famous caves of Azerbaijan, is known as the settlement of Stone Age hominids. It was determined that the cave was the settlement of the Acheulean and the Mousterian cultures. During the period of the Mousterian culture, Neanderthals lived in Azykh Cave.

[[Vessigebro]]

Vessigebro is a locality in Falkenberg Municipality in Halland County in Sweden. In 2010, 740 people lived there.

Füssen is a town in the district of Ostallgäu in the German state of Bavaria.

It has about 15,500 inhabitants.

[[The Black Rose]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 movies, 1950s adventure movies, American adventure movies, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

The Black Rose is a 1950 American historical adventure movie directed by Henry Hathaway and starring Tyrone Power, Orson Welles, Cécile Aubry, Jack Hawkins. The screenplay by Talbot Jennings was based on the 1945 novel of the same name by Thomas B. Costain and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1951.

[[Cryogenics]]

CATEGORIES: Physics, Temperature, Machines

In physics, cryogenics is the production and behaviour of materials at very low temperatures.

It is not well defined at what point on the temperature scale refrigeration ends and cryogenics begins. A gas may be cryogenic if it can be liquefied at or below -150. 

The U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology considers cryogenics as involving temperatures below -180. The normal boiling points of helium, hydrogen, neon, nitrogen, oxygen, and normal air are below −180 °C. 

The Freon refrigerants, hydrocarbons, and other common refrigerants have boiling points above −180 °C.

Discovery of superconducting materials has raised interest in reliable, low cost methods of producing high temperature cryogenic refrigeration. The term "high temperature cryogenic" means temperatures from above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen, -195.79, up to -50.

Cryogenicists use the Kelvin or Rankine temperature scale, both of which measure from absolute zero, rather than more usual scales such as Celsius which measures from the freezing point of water at sea level or Fahrenheit with its zero at an arbitrary temperature.

[[General Grievous]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 2004, Fictional war veterans, Star Wars characters

General Grievous is a fictional character and a villain in the Star Wars series. He is a Kaleesh turned cyborg who served for the CIS during the Clone Wars.

[[Snow Mountains tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Snow Mountains tree frog (Ranoidea napaea) is a frog from New Guinea and Indonesia.  It lives in the Snow Mountains and Wapoga River.

[[New Holland frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The New Holland frog, eastern snipping frog or wide-mouthed frog (Ranoidea novaehollandiae)  is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland on Cape York and in New South Wales.

This frog does not live in forests or high in mountains.  It lays eggs in pools where the water does not move quickly, about 1000 at a time.

[[Capture the Flag (movie)]]

Capture the Flag (Spanish: Atrapa la bandera) is a 2015 Spanish computer animated movie produced by 4 Cats Pictures and Lightbox Entertainment, It was directed by Enrique Gato. It was released on 25 August 2015 in the Spain.

[[Barbara Lagoa]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Miami, Florida, US Republican Party politicians

Barbara Lagoa (born November 2, 1967) is an American attorney and jurist. She is a United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit since 2019. 

She was the first Hispanic woman to be appointed as a Justice of the Supreme Court of Florida. 

Lagoa is reported to be one of President Donald Trump's possible Associate Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court candidate to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

[[Nicky Jam]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, American hip hop musicians, American pop singers, American rap musicians from Massachusetts, American singer-songwriters, Writers from Massachusetts, Singers from Massachusetts, Musicians from Massachusetts, People from Lawrence, Massachusetts

Nick Rivera Caminero (born March 17, 1981), known professionally as Nicky Jam, is an American singer-songwriter. His songs are usually Latin trap and reggaeton. He is best known for hits such as "X", "Travesuras", "En la Cama", "Te Busco", "El Perdón", "Hasta el Amanecer", and "El Amante".

[[Paolo Knill]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss scientists, Swiss artists, Swiss educators, People from Zürich

Paolo Knill (June 11, 1932 – September 13, 2020) was a Swiss scientist, artist, and therapist. Knill was a professor at Lesley University in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He was a founder of their Expressive Arts Therapy. In 1994, Knill founded the European Graduate School in Saas-Fee, Switzerland. He was born in Zurich.

Knill died on September 13, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Robert Chabbal]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, French physicians, Researchers

Robert Chabbal (6 February 1927 – 14 September 2020) was a French physician and scientific researcher. He was Director General of the French National Centre for Scientific Research (CNRS) from 1976 to 1979. From 1980 to 1983, Chabbal worked at NATO as Deputy Secretary General for Scientific Affairs.

Chabbal died on 14 September 2020, aged 93.

[[Darvin Moon]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Poker players, Businesspeople from Maryland

Darvin Moon (October 1, 1963 – September 19, 2020) was an American logger and amateur poker player. He was the runner-up of the 2009 World Series of Poker (WSOP) US$10,000 no-limit Texas hold'em Main Event. It was his first time playing in the World Series of Poker.

Moon, who taught himself how to play poker, ran a small logging company in the Maryland Panhandle before earning a 2009 World Series seat by winning a $130 satellite tournament. He was born in Oakland, Maryland.

Moon died on September 19, 2020 from problems caused by surgery, aged 56.

[[Shehu Idris]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerian people, Royalty

Shehu Idris (20 February 1936 – 20 September 2020) was a Nigerian royal. He was the 18th Fulani Emir of Zazzau and the Chairman of Zazzau Emirate Council and Kaduna State Emirate Council from 1975 until his death. He became emir 8 February 1975 following the death of Alhaji Muhammadu Aminu, the 17th Emir of Zazzau. He was born in Zaria, Nigeria.

On 10 January 2015 he celebrated his 40 years coronation anniversary, and 8 February 2020, he celebrated his 45 years coronation anniversary.

Idris died 20 September 2020 at the age of 84 at a military hospital in Zaria.

[[Fabien Roy]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Politicians from Quebec

Fabien Roy (born April 17, 1928) is a Canadian politician. Roy was elected to the National Assembly of Quebec and the House of Commons of Canada in 1979 and left office in 1980. He was a supporter of social credit theories of monetary reform. Roy was a member and Leader of the Social Credit Party of Canada. He was born in Saint-Prosper, Quebec.

[[Ed Broadbent]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Canadian political scientists, Political activists, Canadian activists, Politicians from Ontario, People from Ottawa

John Edward "Ed" Broadbent CAN (born March 21, 1936) is a Canadian social-democratic politician, political scientist, and political activist. He is the chair of the Broadbent Institute. Broadbent was born in Oshawa, Ontario.

He was leader of the New Democratic Party from 1975 to 1989. 

In the 2004 federal election, he returned to Parliament for one additional term as the Member of Parliament for Ottawa Centre. Before, he represented Oshawa in the parliament between 1968 to 1990.

Between 2014 until her death in 2016, he was married to historian Ellen Meiksins Wood.

[[Ephrem M'Bom]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Cameroonian footballers

Ephrem M'Bom (18 July 1954 – 20 September 2020) was a Cameroonian professional footballer. He competed for the Cameroon national football team at the 1982 FIFA World Cup. He played for the national team between 1981 to 1984 making seven appearances. From 1980 to 1990, he played for Canon Yaoundé. M'Bom was born in Yaoundé, Cameroon.

M'Bom died on 20 September 2020 in Douala, Cameroon at the age of 66.

[[Charles Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Presidents of Liberia, Criminals

Charles McArthur Ghankay Taylor (born 28 January 1948) is a Liberian politician and convicted war criminal. He was the 22nd President of Liberia from 2 August 1997 until his resignation on 11 August 2003.

[[Jewel Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Nigerian politicians, First Ladies, Vice presidents

Jewel Cianeh Taylor (née Howard; born January 17, 1963) is a Liberian politician. In 2018, she became the Vice President of Liberia. 

She was married to convicted war criminal and former president Charles Taylor (whom she married in 1997, but later divorced in 2006) and was First Lady of Liberia during his presidency. 

In 2005, Jewel Taylor was elected to the Senate of Liberia in Bong County as a member of the National Patriotic Party. She was the Chairperson of the Senate Health and Social Welfare Committee on Gender, Women and Children.

In August 2020, she was infected with COVID-19 and flown to Ghana for treatment.

[[Harvey Hodder]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Canada, People from Newfoundland and Labrador, Canadian politicians

Harvey Hodder (1943 – 17 September 2020) was a Canadian politician. Hodder was the Progressive Conservative Member of the House of Assembly (MHA) for the riding of Waterford Valley from 1993 to 2007. From 2003 to 2007, he was the Speaker of the Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly.

Hodder died of cancer on 17 September 2020 in Marystown, Newfoundland and Labrador at the age of 77.

[[Miao Chunting]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, Centenarians, Chinese politicians

Miao Chunting (May 1919 – 17 September 2020) was a Chinese politician. He was born in Shandong Province. He was twice Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference Committee of Guizhou from 1959 to 1967 and again from 1980 to 1993. He was a member of the Communist Party of China.

Miao died on 17 September 2020 in Guizhou at the age of 101.

[[Rossana Rossanda]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians, Italian journalists, Feminist writers, Italian communists

Rossana Rossanda (23 April 1924 – 20 September 2020) was an Italian left-wing politician, journalist, and feminist. She was born in Pula, then-Kingdom of Italy. She was a member of the Italian Communist Party and Proletarian Unity Party Between 1963 to 1968, she was a member of the Chamber of Deputies. In 1969, she founded the newspaper Il manifesto.

Rossanda died on 20 September 2020 in Rome at the age of 96.

[[Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Princes and princesses, Royalty from London

Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, GBR (born Lady Alice Christabel Montagu Douglas Scott; 25 December 1901 – 29 October 2004) was the wife of Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, the third son of King George V and Queen Mary. She was the mother of Prince William of Gloucester and Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester.

She was the daughter of the 7th Duke of Buccleuch, Scotland's largest landowner.

She became by marriage a princess of the United Kingdom, and a sister-in-law to Edward VIII and George VI. She was an aunt by marriage to Elizabeth II. 

At the time of her death at 102, she was the oldest living member of the British Royal Family.

Princess Alice died on 29 October 2004 in her sleep at Kensington Palace at age 102, 57 days before her 103rd birthday and several years after suffering a stroke. 

[[Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1974 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Princes and princesses, Australian Governors-General, Politicians from London, Royalty from London

Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, GBR (Henry William Frederick Albert; 31 March 1900 – 10 June 1974) was an English royal and politician. He was the third son and fourth child of King George V and Queen Mary. He was Governor-General of Australia from 1945 to 1947, the only member of the British royal family to hold the post.

Prince Henry died on 10 June 1974 from problems caused by multiple strokes at Barnwell Manor in Northamptonshire at the age of 74. 

[[David Cook (Northern Ireland politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, Northern Ireland politicians, Political activists

David Somerville Cook (January 1944 – 19 September 2020) was a Northern Irish politician. He was a member of the Alliance Party of Northern Ireland (APNI), which he helped found. He was elected to Belfast City Council in 1973 and left office in 1985. From 1982 to 1986, he was a member of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

In 1978, he became the first non-Unionist Lord Mayor of Belfast. He ran multiple times to become a member of parliament, but never won an election.

On 20 September 2020 it was announced that Cook had died after being diagnosed with COVID-19. He died on 19 September 2020 at a Craigavon hospital, aged 76.

[[Bianca Andreescu]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 births, Living people, Canadian tennis players, Sportspeople from Ontario, Grand Slam (tennis) tournament champions, US Open (tennis) champions

Bianca Vanessa Andreescu (andreˈesku; born June 16, 2000) is a Canadian professional tennis player. She was born in Mississauga, Ontario.

She has a career-high ranking of No. 4 in the world, and is the highest-ranked Canadian in the history of the Women's Tennis Association (WTA). 

Andreescu was the champion at the US Open and the Canadian Open in 2019, beating Serena Williams to win both titles. 

She is the first Canadian tennis player to win a Grand Slam singles title and the first to win the Canadian Open in 50 years. She is also the first player to win a Grand Slam singles title as a teenager since Maria Sharapova in 2006.

[[John W. de Gruchy]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, South African writers, Theologians, Educators

John W. de Gruchy (born 18 March 1939) is a South African Christian theologian. He is known for his work resisting apartheid.

He is a Emeritus Professor at the University of Cape Town and Extraordinary Professor at the University of Stellenbosch. He was born in Pretoria, South Africa.

[[Zaria]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Nigeria

Zaria is a major city in Kaduna State in northern Nigeria, as well as being a Local Government Area. 

It was one of the original seven Hausa city-states. Today, it is known for housing Nigeria's largest university,  Ahmadu Bello University.

In December 2015, Nigeria's military was reported to have killed 300 Shia Muslims and buried their bodies in a mass grave. Although the government denies the event, it has been described as a Massacre.

[[Erzulie]]

CATEGORIES: Mythology, Religion, Afro-American religion

Erzulie (sometimes spelled Erzili or Ezili) is a family of loa in Voodoo.

[[World's Biggest Coffee Morning]]

CATEGORIES: Altruism, Coffee

World's Biggest Coffee Morning is the biggest fundraising event by Macmillan Cancer Support. Every year, people in the UK and other places host an event called a Coffee Morning. The money received is to be used for services provided by Macmillan Cancer Support. In 2016, World's Biggest Coffee Morning raised £29.5 million. 

[[Meron Benvenisti]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Columnists, Deaths from renal failure, Deputy mayors, Harvard University alumni, Hebrew University of Jerusalem alumni, Israeli activists, Israeli historians, Israeli journalists, Israeli trade unionists, Jewish academics, Jewish activists, Jewish Israeli politicians, Jewish Israeli writers, Jewish scientists, People from Jerusalem, Israeli political scientists

Meron Benvenisti (מירון בנבנשתי, April 21, 1934 – September 20, 2020) was an Israeli political scientist and politician. He was the Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem under Teddy Kollek from 1971 to 1978. He was in charge of East Jerusalem and was Jerusalem's Chief Planning Officer. He was a critic of Israel's policies towards Palestine.

Benvenisti was born in Jerusalem and also died in Jerusalem from renal failure at the age of 86.

[[Teddy Kollek]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 2007 deaths, Austrian Jews, HaAvoda politicians, Hungarian Jews, Israeli civil servants, Israeli mayors, Jewish Israeli politicians, Naturalized citizens of Israel, People from Jerusalem, Refugees from Nazism

Theodor "Teddy" Kollek (טדי קולק; 27 May 1911 – 2 January 2007) was a Hungarian-born Israeli Labor politician. He was the mayor of Jerusalem from 1965 to 1993. He was the founder of the Jerusalem Foundation. Kollek was re-elected five times, in 1969, 1973, 1978, 1983 and 1989. He lost his re-election in 1993 to Likud candidate and future Prime Minister of Israel Ehud Olmert.

During his time as mayor, Jerusalem became a modern city, especially after its reunification in 1967. He was once called "the greatest builder of Jerusalem since Herod." Teddy Stadium is named after him.

Kollek was born in Nagyvázsony, Hungary. In 1935, shortly before Nazis took power of Austria, his family moved to Jerusalem. Kollek died on 2 January 2007 in Jerusalem at the age of 95.

[[Body cavity]]

CATEGORIES: Anatomy

Many animals have spaces or compartments in their body. These spaces or compartments are called body cavity. They  are there for organs, or other structures. Sometimes, there is a space between two organs. This space is known as potential body cavity. Potential body cavities usually contain fluid. In the human body, there is a large body cavity on the side of the belly, and another on the side of the back. The one on the side of the belly is called ventral body cavity, the one on the back dorsal body cavity.

The membranes that surround the central nervous system organs (the brain and the spinal cord, in the cranial and spinal cavities are the three meninges. The differently lined spaces contain different types of fluid. In the meninges for example the fluid is cerebrospinal fluid; in the abdominal cavity the fluid contained in the peritoneum is a serous fluid.

In amniotes and some invertebrates the peritoneum lines their largest body cavity called  the coelom.

[[Augmented reality]]

CATEGORIES: Technology, Marketing, Reality

Augmented reality (often known as AR) is a computer technology that shows digital images on top of the current real world. For example it can show a digital table on top of a floor. It is different from virtual reality which makes a person feel they are somewhere else.

[[Password manager]]

CATEGORIES: Computer security, Technology

A password manager is a computer program that stores passwords, and shows the passwords that are put or made in the password manager. They are used to make passwords and store passwords. This is usually used to store multiple passwords as a person may forget some passwords. People store many passwords for different services as it is not safe to only use one password as if someone else knows the passwords of one of their items, they know the passwords of their other things too since they all have the same password. Recently they have been used to stored other things such as credit card numbers, security questions, One-Time Passwords,  and account recovery questions. To access the items in the password manager the person usually has to remember one password, if they lose this password, then they will usually not be able to access the data in their password manager.

[[Pothohar]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Pakistan

The Pothohar Plateau is a flat-topped high place in northeastern Pakistan, forming the northern part of Punjab. It borders the western parts of Azad Kashmir and the southern part of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

[[Haifa District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Israel

The Haifa District (מחוז חיפה, Mehoz Ḥeifa; منطقة حيفا) is one of the six districts of Israel. Its capital is Haifa.

[[Tel Aviv District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Israel

The Tel Aviv District (מָחוֹז תֵּל אָבִיב; منطقة تل أبيب) is one of the six districts of Israel. Its capital is Tel Aviv.

[[Central District (Israel)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Israel

The Central District (מְחוֹז הַמֶּרְכָּז, Meḥoz haMerkaz; المنطقة الوسطى) is one of the six districts of Israel. Its capital is Ramla.

[[Northern District (Israel)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Israel

The Northern District (منطقة الشمال, Minṭaqat ash-Shamāl; מחוז הצפון, Meḥoz HaTzafon) is one of the six districts of Israel. The capital is Nof HaGalil and the largest city is Nazareth. It has an area of 4,478. In 2016, 1,401,300 people lived there.

[[Southern District (Israel)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Israel

The Southern District (מחוז הדרום, Meḥoz HaDarom; لواء الجنوب) is one of the six districts of Israel. It covers most of the Negev desert, as well as the Arava valley. Its capital is Beersheba and its largest city is Ashdod.

It is the largest district of Israel by area.

[[Dillinger (1945 movie)]]

Dillinger is a 1945 American crime drama movie directed by Max Nosseck and starring Lawrence Tierney in the title role, Edmund Lowe, Anne Jeffreys, Eduardo Cianelli, Marc Lawrence, Elisha Cook Jr.. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1946 and was distributed by Monogram Pictures.

[[Narrow fringed frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The leaf green tree frog, leaf green river tree frog or narrow fringed tree frog (Ranoidea nudidigita) is a frog from Victoria and New South Wales.  It lives on the flat lands not far from the ocean.

This frog is 2.5 to 4.0 cm long.  It is bright green, dark green or brown.  Adult frogs can change color.  It has a black and gold stripe down its side.  It lives in streams and lays eggs in small pools next to the stream.  Tadpoles swim in the stream and eat algae from rocks.  Scientists used to think it was the same species as Litoria phyllochroa, which is also called leaf green tree frog, but they now think it is its own species.  They think so because the Ranoidea nudidigita has a different voice call and lives in different places than Litoria phyllochroa.

[[Emperor Go-Daigo]]

CATEGORIES: 1288 births, 1339 deaths, Emperors of Japan

Emperor Go-Daigo or Go-daigo Tennō (1288-1339) was the emperor of Japan from 1318 to 1339.  He was the 96th emperor of Japan.  When he lived, the shoguns had a lot of power in Japan.  Emperor Go-Diago tried to take power from them so he could rule Japan.

When Go-Daigo lived, Japan had two governments.  There was one government set up by the emperors of Japan, who lived in Kyoto.  There was another government run by the shoguns, the bakufu.  The law said the emperors were rulers, but the bakufu had more power than they did. Neither the emperor's government nor the shogun's government was powerful enough to rule very well.

[[Alpharetta, Georgia]]

[[Lydia Bailey]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 movies, 1950s adventure movies, American adventure movies, Movies directed by Jean Negulesco

[[King Kong Lives]]

CATEGORIES: American monster movies, Monster movies, 1986 movies, Giant gorilla movies, Movies set in the 1980s, Movies set in islands, Movies set in Asia, King Kong, Movies directed by John Guillermin, American independent movies, 1980s monster movies, 20th Century Fox movies

King Kong Lives also known as King Kong 2 in other countries, is a 1986 American action-adventure fantasy monster movie directed by John Guillermin, and starring Brian Kerwin and Linda Hamilton. It was released in December 19, 1986. It is the sixth King Kong movie, as well as the sequel of the 1976 movie.

[[Leaf green tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The leaf green tree frog, leaf green river tree frog or narrow fringed tree frog (Ranoidea phyllochroa) is a frog from Victoria and New South Wales.

This frog lives in forests and grasslands, but it can also live in suburbs and cities. This frog lives near streams.  The female lays eggs on plants underneath the water.  The tadpoles grow into frogs in 12 weeks.

Even though it is called the "leaf green" tree frog, it is usually olive green in color.  It has a yellow stripe down each side of its body.  This frog can change color, becoming very dark, to blend in with the area around it to hide.

Scientists used to think the narrow fringed frog was the same species as the leaf green tree frog but they now think they are two species.  They think so because the narrow fringed frog and leaf green tree frog have different voice calls and live in different places.  The narrow fringed frog is also called the leaf green tree frog or leaf green river tree frog.

[[Streptokinase]]

Streptokinase (STK) is a medication used to dissolve blood clots (thrombolysis) in human body. Streptokinase is used mainly treat heart attacks (Myocardia Infarction). There are 2 main types of heart attacks; STEMI and non-STEMI and Streptokinase is only used in STEMI type heart attacks after confirming with an ECG. It is given as an injection into a vein.

[[The Remains of the Day (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 drama movies, American drama movies, British drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by James Ivory

The Remains of the Day is a 1993 British-American drama movie. It is based from the Booker Prize-winning 1989 novel of the same name by Kazuo Ishiguro. The movie was directed by James Ivory, produced by Ismail Merchant, Mike Nichols, and John Calley.

It stars Anthony Hopkins as James Stevens and Emma Thompson as Miss Kenton, with James Fox, Christopher Reeve, Hugh Grant, Michael Lonsdale, Paul Copley and Ben Chaplin in supporting roles.

The movie was nominated for eight Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Actor (Hopkins), Best Actress (Thompson) and Best Adapted Screenplay (Jhabvala). 

In 1999, the British Film Institute ranked The Remains of the Day the 64th greatest British film of the 20th century.

[[Ben Chaplin]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English voice actors, Actors from Berkshire

Ben Chaplin (born Benedict John Greenwood; 31 July 1969) is an English actor. He was born in Windsor, Berkshire. He is known for his role as a servant in The Remains of the Day. He also starred as Con Wainwright in Feast of July (1995) and as Tom Wingfield in Sam Mendes' stage production of The Glass Menagerie.

[[Dee Dee Myers]]

Margaret Jane "Dee Dee" Myers (born September 1, 1961) is an American political analyst. She was the 19th White House Press Secretary from January 20, 1993 until December 22, 1994 and was the first female press secretary.

[[Tuğçe San]]

[[Russian desman]]

CATEGORIES: Eulipotyphla, Mammals of Asia, Mammals of Europe

The Russian desman (Desmana moschata) is a type of mammal in the family Talpidae. It is the largest type of mole. It is found in the Volga, Don and Ural River basins in Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan. It digs burrows into the banks of ponds and slow-moving streams. It prefers small, overgrown ponds with lots of insects, crayfish and amphibians. The Russian desman often lives in small groups of two to five of them that are usually not related.

[[Santa Claus, Arizona]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Arizona, 1937 establishments in the United States, Ghost towns in the United States, Settlements in Arizona

Santa Claus (also known as Santa Claus Acres) is a ghost town in Mohave County, Arizona, United States.

Santa Claus was started in 1937, it lies about 14 northwest of Kingman, Arizona, along U.S. Route 93 between mile markers 57 and 58, immediately north of Hermit Drive and just south of both Grasshopper Junction, Arizona, and the Junk Art of Chloride, a group of metal statues in Chloride, Arizona, that include a flamingo made out of a motorcycle gas tank. Characterized in 1988 as "a little roadside place on the west shoulder of U.S. Route 93," Santa Claus receives traffic from motorists driving between Phoenix, Arizona, and Las Vegas, Nevada, or Hoover Dam.

[[American shrew mole]]

CATEGORIES: Eulipotyphla, Mammals of North America

The American shrew mole (Neurotrichus gibbsii) is the smallest species of mole. It is the only living member of the genus Neurotrichus and the tribe Neurotrichini. It is also known as Gibb's shrew mole and least shrew mole.

[[Asian house shrew]]

CATEGORIES: Soricomorphs, Mammals of Asia

The Asian house shrew (Suncus murinus) is a type of shrew. It is native to South and Southeast Asia. It is the largest type of shrew. It is a least concern species. It has been introduced in several West Asian and East African countries. It is an invasive species.

[[Ildefons Cerdà]]

CATEGORIES: 1815 births, 1876 deaths, Spanish engineers, Urban planners, Politicians from Catalonia, Catalan engineers

Ildefons Cerdà i Sunyer (23 December 1815 – 21 August 1876) was a Catalan-Spanish urban planner, civil engineer, politician. He developed a new urban theories, including the extension plan of Barcelona 19th-century.

[[Desman]]

CATEGORIES: Soricomorphs

The desman is an insectivore in the mole family, the Talpidae. 

It is a diving insectivore. It is in the tribe Desmanini (and subfamily Desmaninae). The tribe has only two  species in Eurasia. There is one in Russia and the other in the northwest of the Iberian peninsula and Pyrenees. Both species are vulnerable.

[[Metformin]]

CATEGORIES: Drugs, Diabetes mellitus

Metformin is a drug used to treat patients having diabetes. There are 2 types of diabetes, type 1 and type 2 and metformin is only used to treat people having type 2 diabetes. Metformin come as a tablet and taken by mouth. It is the drug of choice to lower the blood sugar level when a person is first found to have diabetes.

[[Mountain mist frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The mountain mist frog, Henrietta Creek tree frog or Nyakala frog (Ranoidea nyakalensis) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland between 380 and 1020 metres above sea level.

This frog lives in and near streams where the water flowed so fast that it turned white.  Scientists saw the adult frogs sitting on rocks or leaves near the streams.

The tadpoles live in the fast water.  Scientists wrote that they had strong tails for swimming and bodies meant for the water to flow over them. Sometimes they would dig into the sand to hold on during floods.  The tadpoles would spend the winter in mountain streams and grow into frogs in the spring.

This frog is in danger of dying out. Scientists last saw the adult frog and tadpoles in 1990.  They saw them in the Carbine Tableland.

Scientists think pigs that escaped from humans might be one reason why the frog is endangered.  The pigs rip up the streams where the frog would live.  They also think the fungal disease chytridiomycosis might be killing these frogs.  Scientists also thought habitat loss, human beings building roads and farms where the frog would live, was killing the frogs, but the Australian government protected the frogs' home in 1988.

[[Home Office]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of the United Kingdom Government

The Home Office (HO) is a ministerial department of the Government of the United Kingdom. It is responsible for immigration, security and law and order in the U.K. 

It is responsible for policing in England and Wales, fire and rescue services in England, visas and immigration and the Security Service (MI5). 

It is also in charge of government policy on security-related issues such as drugs, counter-terrorism and ID cards. The Cabinet minister responsible for the department is the Home Secretary, currently Priti Patel.

The Home Office, which is considered to be one of the Great Offices of State, is known, in official papers and in Parliament, as the Home Department.

[[Adèle Exarchopoulos]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, French movie actors, French television actors, Award winning actors, Actors from Paris, Living people

Adèle Exarchopoulos (born November 22, 1993) is a French actress. She is most well-known for playing Adèle in the drama movie Blue is the Warmest Colour (2013). She won the Palme d'Or award for this performance. She was the youngest person to win this award. For her acting in Blue is the Warmest Colour, she also won the César Award for the Most Promising Actress, the Los Angeles Film Critic Award for Best Actress and Trophée Chopard Award for Female Revelation of the Year.

Exarchopoulos acted in the movies Turk's Head (2010), The Round Up (also 2010) and I Used to be Darker (2013).

Exarchopoulos was born in Paris, France.

[[Foreign Office]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of the United Kingdom Government

The Foreign Office is a department of the British Government. Its official name has changed from time to time, and at present it is the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO). Its head is known as the Foreign Secretary, and this is one of the four top posts in the British Cabinet.

The Foreign Office is responsible for protecting and promoting British interests worldwide. It was formed in 1782. In its present form it was created in 1968 by merging the Foreign Office and the Commonwealth Office (to FCO). Later on it merged with the Department for International Development.

The Foreign Office provides staff for embassies and other diplomatic stations throughout the world. It trains staff in foreign languages. At one time (a century ago) its staff ruled over a third of the world. The overseas British Empire recovered after the loss of the Thirteen Colonies in 1776, and reached its peak about 1920. Foreign policy made sure it was never seriously threatened.  

[[Campione d'Italia]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Lombardy, Exclaves

Campione d'Italia is a comune in the Province of Como in Lombardy, Italy. As of 31 March 2019, 1,961 people lived there. Its area is 0.91 km². It is 273 meters above sea level.

It is an exclave surrounded by the Swiss canton of Ticino and is on the eastern shore of Lake Lugano.

[[Hispaniolan solenodon]]

CATEGORIES: Soricomorphs, Mammals of North America

The Hispaniolan solenodon (Solenodon paradoxus) is a type of solenodon. It is only found on Hispaniola. It is also called the Haitian solenodon, or agouta.

[[Rita MacNeil]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2013 deaths, Canadian singers, Country singers, Deaths from surgical complications, Entertainers from Nova Scotia, Folk singers, Infectious disease deaths in Canada, Order of Canada

Rita MacNeil CM ONS (May 28, 1944 – April 16, 2013) was a Canadian country and folk singer. MacNeil was from the community of Big Pond on Nova Scotia's Cape Breton Island. Her biggest hit, "Flying On Your Own", was a crossover Top 40 hit in 1987 and was covered by Anne Murray the next year.

In 1990, MacNeil was the bestselling country artist in Canada, selling more records than even Garth Brooks and Clint Black. She was also the only female singer ever to have three separate albums chart in the same year in Australia.

On April 16, 2013, MacNeil died in Sydney, Nova Scotia, from problems caused by surgery after a repeated infection. She was 68.

[[Atmosphere of Mercury]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere

Mercury has a very weak atmosphere. Its atmosphere contains hydrogen, helium, oxygen, sodium, calcium, potassium and water vapor. It has a combined pressure level of about 10−14 bar (1 nPa). The elements may come from either the solar wind or from the planetary crust.

[[NGC 706]]

[[Atmosphere of Venus]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere

The atmosphere of Venus is the layer of gases that surrounds Venus. It is mainly composed of carbon dioxide. Its atmosphere is denser and hotter than the atmosphere of Earth. The temperature at the surface is 740 K (467 °C, 872 °F). The pressure is 93 bar (9.3 MPa). It is composed of carbon dioxide (96.5 %), nitrogen (3.5 %), sulfur dioxide (150 ppm), argon (70 ppm), water vapor (20 ppm), carbon monoxide (17 ppm), helium (12 ppm), hydrogen chloride (0.1–0.6 ppm) and hydrogen fluoride (0.001–0.005 ppm).

[[NGC 708]]

CATEGORIES: Elliptical galaxies, Local galaxies

NGC 708 is an elliptical galaxy in the Andromeda constellation. It is about 223 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

NGC 709 is a lenticular galaxy in the Andromeda constellation. It is about 166 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 535]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 535 is a lenticular galaxy in the Cetus constellation. It is about 222 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Atmosphere of Uranus]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere

The atmosphere of Uranus is mainly made up of hydrogen and helium. The lower atmosphere is made up of volatiles such as water, ammonia and methane. The upper atmosphere contains very few gases that are heavier than hydrogen and helium because the temperature of its atmosphere is low. Uranus's atmosphere is the coldest atmosphere of all the planets in the Solar system. Its temperature is as low as 49 K.

[[Any Wednesday]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 comedy movies, 1960s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Warner Bros. movies

Any Wednesday is a 1966 American romantic comedy movie directed by first time director Robert Ellis Miller and starring Jane Fonda, Jason Robards, Dean Jones, Rosemary Murphy, Ann Prentiss. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was based on the play of the same name.

[[Atmosphere of Jupiter]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere

The atmosphere of Jupiter is the largest planetary atmosphere in the Solar System. It is mostly made up of molecular hydrogen and helium. It is also made up of methane, ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, water, nitrogen, sulfur, and noble gases.

[[HD 189733 b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets

HD 189733 b is an exoplanet. It is approximately 64.5 light years away from the Solar System. It a hot Jupiter. It is found in the constellation of Vulpecula. It was discovered orbiting the star HD 189733 on October 5, 2005. It has a mass 13% higher than that of Jupiter. HD 189733 b orbits HD 189733 once every 2.2 days. It has an orbital speed of 152.5 kilometres per second (341,000 mph).

[[NGC 534]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 534 is a lenticular galaxy in the Sculptor constellation. It is about 258 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[HD 209458 b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets, HD 209458 System

HD 209458 b is an exoplanet. It orbits HD 209458 in the constellation Pegasus. It is approximately 159 light years from the Solar System. A year on HD 209458 b is 3.5 Earth days. It has an estimated surface temperature of about 1,000 °C (about 1,800 °F). Its mass is 220 times that of Earth.

[[Tau Boötis b]]

[[Tiara Tahiti]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 comedy movies, 1962 drama movies, 1960s comedy-drama movies, British comedy movies, British drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Ted Kotcheff

Tiara Tahiti is a 1962 British comedy-drama movie directed by first time director Ted Kotcheff and based on the novel by Geoffrey Cotterell. It stars John Mills, James Mason, Herbert Lom, Rosenda Monteros, Claude Dauphin, Roy Kinnear.

[[Nephrotic syndrome]]

CATEGORIES: Syndromes

Nephrotic syndrome is the medical term used to describe a collection of signs and symptoms. They occur because of kidney damage. This is different from nephritic syndrome where there are red blood cells in urine, giving it a red colour appearance. 

Nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed by doctors based on the classical symptoms of oedema,  proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidaemia (which is explained below).

[[HAT-P-11b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets

HAT-P-11b is an extrasolar planet. It  is also called Kepler-3b. It orbits the star HAT-P-11. It was discovered by the HATNet Project team in 2009 using the transit method.

[[XO-1b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets

XO-1b is an extrasolar planet. It is approximately 536 light years away. It was discovered in 2006 by the XO Project which is an international team of professional and amateur astronomers. They used the transit method to find XO-1b. It a little bit larger than Jupiter. It is a hot Jupiter. The Hubble Space Telescope found water in the atmosphere of the XO-1b.

[[WASP-17b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets

WASP-17b is an exoplanet. It is found in the constellation Scorpius. It orbits the star WASP-17. Its discovery was announced on 11 August 2009. It is the first planet that was discovered to have a retrograde orbit. On 3 December 2013, scientists working with the Hubble Space Telescope found water in the atmosphere of WASP-17b.

[[NGC 502]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 502 is a lenticular galaxy in the Pisces constellation. It is about 117 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 505]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 505 is a lenticular galaxy in the Pisces constellation. It is about 252 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Western water-holding frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The western water-holding frog is a frog from Australia.  Scientists are not sure whether it should be called Ranoidea occidentalis or Cyclorana occidentalis.  It lives in Western Australia.

The adult male frog is 6.0 cm long and the adult female frog is 7.0 cm long.  It has a flat body.  The frog lives in places where the ground is dry.  It has webbed feet and spends much of its time in the water.  Because it has such a wide head, scientist think this frog eats other frogs.  They think it eats them when they come to lay eggs in the same temporary bodies of water where the western water-holding frog lays its eggs.

This frog has young when it rains.  The female lays eggs in bodies of water that dry up quickly, 500 at a time.

The tadpoles are 8.0 cm long.  Once they become young frogs, they are 3.5 cm long.

[[WASP-19b]]

CATEGORIES: Exoplanets

WASP-19b is an extrasolar planet. It has one of the shortest orbital periods of any known planet. Its orbital period is approximately 18.932 hours. It is much 1.31 times larger than Jupiter. It orbits the star WASP-19 in the Vela constellation. In December 2013, scientists working with the Hubble Space Telescope found water in the atmosphere of the WASP-19b.

[[NGC 508]]

CATEGORIES: Elliptical galaxies

NGC 508 is an elliptical galaxy in the Pisces constellation. It is about 253 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 507]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 507 is a lenticular galaxy in the Pisces constellation. It is about 227 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 509]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 509 is a lenticular galaxy in the Pisces constellation. It is about 105 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 720]]

CATEGORIES: Elliptical galaxies

NGC 720 is an elliptical galaxy in the Cetus constellation. It is about 78 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Stellar atmosphere]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere, Stars

The stellar atmosphere is the outer region of a star. It is found above the convection zone.

[[Torquemada]]

CATEGORIES: Spain, History, Catholicism, Islamophobia

Tomás de Torquemada (October 14, 1420 – September 16, 1498), also written in English as Thomas of Torquemada, was a Castilian Dominican friar.  He was the first Grand Inquisitor in the Spanish Inquisition.  The Inquisition made thousands Jews and Muslims leave Spain.

[[The Wayward Bus (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies

The Wayward Bus is a 1957 American drama movie directed by Victor Vicas and was based on the 1947 novel of the same name by John Steinbeck. It stars Joan Collins, Jayne Mansfield, Dan Dailey, Rick Jason and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Moon Over Miami (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical comedy movies, Movies directed by Walter Lang

Moon Over Miami is a 1941 American musical comedy movie directed by Walter Lang and starring Betty Grable, Don Ameche, Robert Cummings, Carole Landis, Jack Haley, Charlotte Greenwood. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[NGC 721]]

CATEGORIES: Barred spiral galaxies

NGC 721 is a barred spiral galaxy in the Andromeda constellation. It is about 256 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 722]]

CATEGORIES: Spiral galaxies

NGC 722 is a spiral galaxy in the Aries constellation. It is about 223 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Spearmint]]

CATEGORIES: Herbs, Oils, Plants of Asia, Asterids

(of M. spicata subsp. spicata)

Spearmint is a type of mint. It is also called garden mint, common mint, lamb mint and mackerel mint. It is native to Europe and southern Asia. It is naturalized in northern and southern Africa, North America and South America. It is used as a flavouring in food and herbal teas.

The species and subspecies have many synonyms.

[[Burgos, Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Capital cities in Spain, Cities in Castile and León, Municipalities in Castile and León

Burgos is a Spanish city in the autonomous community of Castile and León. It is the capital of the province of Burgos.

[[Menthol]]

CATEGORIES: Analgesics, Organic compounds

Menthol is an organic compound. It is gotten from the oils of corn mint, peppermint, or other mints. It can also be made artificially. It is a waxy, crystalline substance. It is white in color. It is a solid at room temperature. It melts at a temperature that is a little bit higher than room temperature.

Menthol has local anaesthetic qualities, and reduces irritation of the throat.

Mentha arvensis is the main type of mint used to make natural menthol crystals. It is mainly grown in the Uttar Pradesh region in India.

Natural menthol is made by freezing peppermint oil and separating methanol from the frozen the peppermint oil by filtration.

[[2020 Brazil wildfires]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 disasters, 2020s fires, 2020s in Brazil, Disasters in South America, Environment, Rainforests

The 2020 Brazil wildfires were a group of wildfires that began burning Brazil's rainforests in June and continued into September. More than 12% of all the plants in the Pantanal rainforest had burned by August.

In June, Brazil's National Institute for Space Research (INPE) said its satellites had taken pictures of 2,248 fires. In June 2019, there had been 1,880 fires.

[[Ferlach]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Carinthia (state)

Ferlach (Borovlje) is a town of the district of Klagenfurt-Land in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

[[Grafenstein]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Carinthia (state)

Grafenstein (Grabštajn) is a market town of the district Klagenfurt-Land in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

[[Keutschach am See]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Carinthia (state)

Keutschach am See (Hodiše ob jezeru) is a municipality of the district Klagenfurt-Land in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

[[Camphor]]

CATEGORIES: Chemical compounds

Camphor is a waxy, flammable, transparent solid. It has a strong smell. It is a terpenoid. Its chemical formula is C10H16O. It is found in the wood of the camphor laurel (Cinnamomum camphora). Camphor can also be artificially made from the oil of turpentine.

[[Asian Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Asian championships, Asian Rowing Championships, Rowing competitions

The Asian Rowing Championship is a rowing championship organised by the Asian Rowing Federation for competitors from the Asian countries.

[[European Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: European championships, 1893 establishments in Europe

The European Rowing Championships is an international Rowing regatta organised by FISA (the International Rowing Federation) for European rowing nations.

[[Sensillum]]

CATEGORIES: Sensory system, Arthropods

A sensillum is an arthropod sensory organ. It sticks out from the cuticle of the exoskeleton. It is sometimes found within or under the cuticle. Inside each sensillum there are two to three sensory neurons.

[[Antennal lobe]]

CATEGORIES: Sensory system, Insects

The antennal lobe is the main part of the brain of an insect that controls the olfactory sense. The antennal lobe is a sphere-shaped deutocerebral neuropil in the brain. It receives information from the olfactory sensory neurons in the antennae and mouthparts.

[[2015 Asian Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Rowing Championships

The 2015 Asian Rowing Championships were the 16th Asian Rowing Championships and took place from September 24–28, 2015, in Shunyi Olympic Rowing-Canoeing Park, Beijing, China.

[[2016 Asian Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Rowing Championships

The 2016 Asian Rowing Championships were the 17th Asian Rowing Championships and took place from September 9–13, 2016, in Fenhu Water Sports Center, Jiashan, China.

[[2017 Asian Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Rowing Championships

The 2017 Asian Rowing Championships were the 18th Asian Rowing Championships and took place from September 4–8, 2017, in Klong Phai Water Sport Training Centre, Pattaya, Thailand.

[[2019 Asian Rowing Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Rowing Championships

The 2019 Asian Rowing Championships were the 19th Asian Rowing Championships and took place from October 23–27, 2019, in Tangeum Lake International Rowing Regatta, Chungju, South Korea.

[[Perfumer]]

A perfumer is an expert on making perfumes. A perfumer must know lots of different fragrance ingredients and their smells. A perfumer must be able to know the kind of ingredients whether they are alone or mixed together with other fragrances.

[[Humphreys County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Humphreys County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 18,538 people lived there. The county seat is Waverly.

[[Flavorist]]

CATEGORIES: Food and drink, Occupations

A flavorist is someone who uses chemistry to make artificial and natural flavors.  They are also called a flavor chemist. Flavorists try to mimic or change the smell and taste of food.

[[Pottery Cottage murders]]

CATEGORIES: Mass murder in the 1970s, 1970s in the United Kingdom, 1977, January events

The Pottery Cottage murders happened in Eastmoor, Chesterfield in January 1977. William Thomas Hughes escaped from police whilst being moved from prison to court where he was facing charges of rape and assault. He stabbed two prison officers during his escape and then took five members of a local family hostage. Only one person from this family survived. 

Police shot Hughes dead after he had killed four members of the family. He was the first person to be shot dead by the Derbyshire Constabulary.

[[Olfactory receptor]]

CATEGORIES: Sensory system, Cell biology

Olfactory receptors are receptors found in the cell membranes of olfactory receptor neurons. They are responsible for detecting odorants. Olfactory receptors activates nerve impulses which send information about odor to the brain. These receptors are members of the class A rhodopsin-like which is family of G protein-coupled receptors.

[[Law of multiple proportions]]

CATEGORIES: Physical chemistry

The law of multiple proportions states that when two chemical elements combine with each other to form more than one compound, the weights of one element that combine with a fixed weight of the other are in a ratio of small whole numbers.

== References == 

[[Simon Boyle]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, British businesspeople, British politicians

Sir Simon Hugh Patrick Boyle, KCVO,  JP, DL (22 March 1941 – 4 September 2020) was a British business executive and politician. He was Lord Lieutenant of Gwent from 2001 to 2016.

He died on 4 September 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Anita Lindblom]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish movie actors, Swedish television actors, Swedish stage actors, Swedish singers

Anita Lindblom (14 December 1937 – 6 September 2020) was a Swedish actress and singer. She appeared in thirteen movies between 1957 and 1974. Lindblom also recorded music. Her single Sånt är livet (a cover of Roy Hamilton's You Can Have Her) was a Norwegian #1 in 1962.

Her best known movies were in Mannequin in Red (1958), Sailors (1964) and A Swedish Love Story (1970). He was born in Gävle, Sweden.

Lindblom died on 6 September 2020 in Paris, aged 82.

[[Chhetan Gurung]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2020 deaths, Nepalese writers, Screenwriters, Nepalese movie directors

Chhetan Gurung (Nepali: छेतन गुरुङ; 5 February 1979spnd9 September 2020) was a Nepalese movie director and writer. He was known for his work in Nepali cinema. He has written scripts for Nepali movies including November Rain (2014), Classic (2016), A Mero Hajur 3 (2019), and Prem Geet 3. 

Gurung died of liver disease on 9 September 2020 in Kathmandu, Nepal at the age of 41.

[[Terry Buckle]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Bishops, Cancer deaths in Canada, People from Ontario

Terrence Owen Buckle (24 August 1940 – 10 September 2020) was a Canadian Anglican bishop. He was Archbishop of Yukon from 1995 to 2010  and Metropolitan of British Columbia and Yukon from 2005 until 2010, in the Anglican Church of Canada. He was born in Ontario.

Buckle died on 10 September 2020 in Whitehorse, Yukon from cancer at the age of 80.

[[Marine mammal]]

CATEGORIES: Marine mammals

Marine mammals are mammals that depend on the ocean and other marine ecosystems to live. They include animals such as seals, whales, manatees, sea otters and polar bears.

Cetaceans are fully aquatic. Seals and sea-lions are semiaquatic. They spend the most of their time in the water but need to return to land to mate, breed and molt. Some marine mammals eat zooplankton, others eat fish, squid, shellfish, or sea grass, and a few eat other mammals.

[[Grant Larson]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Utah, Politicians from Wyoming, People from Provo, Utah, US Republican Party politicians

Grant Larson (June 2, 1933 – September 11, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Wyoming Senate of the 17th district from 1995 to 2011. He was born in Provo, Utah. 

Larson died on September 11, 2020 in Jackson, Wyoming at age 87.

[[Council Julian Dunbar Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Businesspeople from South Carolina, Politicians from South Carolina, US Republican Party politicians

Council Julian Dunbar Jr. (August 4, 1922 – September 14, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was in the South Carolina House of Representatives from 1971 to 1972, representing Allendale County, South Carolina. He was an insurance agent. Dunbar Jr. was born in Martin, South Carolina.

Dunbar Jr. died on September 14, 2020 at the age of 98.

[[Martin, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in the United States, Settlements in South Carolina

Martin is an unincorporated community in northwestern Allendale County, South Carolina, United States.  It lies along SC 125 northwest of the town of Allendale, the county seat of Allendale County. 

[[Jeff Dunne]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

Jeffrey "Jeff" Dunne (14 May 1956 – 14 September 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played 102 games for St Kilda and Richmond in the top tier Victorian Football League during the 1970s and 1980s. He played for St Kilda from 1977 to 1983.

He went on to coach East Launceston and North Launceston in the Tasmanian Football league in the mid 1980s.

Dunne died of a heart attack on 14 September 2020, aged 64.

Cave-In-Rock is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Nijisanji]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 establishments in Asia, 2010s establishments in Asia, Japan, Social networking, Companies of Japan, Websites

Nijisanji is an online Japanese video sharing social networking service for iPhone X. It is a group of mostly Live2D-only Virtual YouTubers who are also known as "Virtual Livers" (バーチャルライバー Bācharu Raibā) when posting on sites outside of YouTube, such as NicoNico Douga, Twitch and Bilibili. The term Liver, coined by mixing Japanese and English, is a heteronym for calling Nijisanji's streamers.

Managed by ANYCOLOR Inc. (formerly known as Ichikara Inc. until May 16, 2021), the group started in Japan in February 2018 and has since 2019 expanded to other countries such as China, Indonesia, South Korea and English speaking markets as an international project.

As of August 2021, there are 107 Japanese NIJISANJI members, 19 NIJISANJI ID members, 20 NIJISANJI KR members, 6 NIJISANJI EN members and 42 VirtuaReal members (a joint venture between Bilibili and Anycolor in China). There are also 5 VirtuaReal Star members and 22 VirtuaReal Link members who are independent VTubers, not considered part of Nijisanji's VirtuaReal per se and are only in a network partner system.

Vrtiska died on September 15, 2020 in Lincoln, Nebraska at age of 93.
