[[Body of water]]

CATEGORIES: Bodies of water

A body of water or waterbody is any collection of water on a planet's surface. A body of water can be still (like a lake) or moving (like a river).

[[Hassan Achour]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Algerian footballers, Algerian football managers

Hassan Louahid nicknamed Achour (14 March 1938 – 17 September 2020) was an Algerian international footballer and manager. He was born in Sétif, Algeria. He had 16 caps for the Algeria national team between 1965 to 1969.

Achour died on 17 September 2020 in Algiers at the age of 82.

[[Joachim Kunert]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, German movie directors, German screenwriters, Writers from Berlin

Joachim Kunert (24 September 1929 – 18 September 2020) was a German movie director and screenwriter. He directed more than 20 movies between 1954 and 1989. His 1965 movie The Adventures of Werner Holt was entered into the 4th Moscow International Film Festival. He was born in Berlin.

Kunert died on 18 September 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Sam McBratney]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Children's writers, People from Belfast

Samuel (Sam) McBratney (1 March 1943 – 18 September 2020) was a Northern Irish writer.  He wrote more than fifty books for children and young adults. He was best known as the author of the best-selling children's book Guess How Much I Love You. He was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

McBratney died on 18 September 2020 in County Antrim, Northern Ireland at the age of 77.

[[Carbonic acid]]

CATEGORIES: Carbonates, Acids

Carbonic acid is a chemical compound. Its chemical formula is H2CO3. Carbonic acid is a weak acid. It forms two kinds of salts: the carbonates and the bicarbonates. In geology, carbonic acid causes limestone to dissolve, making calcium bicarbonate.

[[J. Delano Ellis]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, People from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, People from Cleveland, Ohio

Jesse Delano Ellis II, known as J. Delano Ellis, (December 11, 1944 – September 19, 2020) was a leader in African American Pentecostalism in the United States. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

He was the founding president/chairman and Archbishop Metropolitan of the Joint College of Bishops. Ellis also created and was presiding prelate of the Apostolic/Oneness United Pentecostal Churches of Christ (today the United Covenant Churches of Christ) and Pentecostal Churches of Christ. 

He was the senior pastor of the Pentecostal Church of Christ in Cleveland, Ohio, a ministry to which he was called on May 14, 1989.

Ellis died on September 19, 2020 in Cleveland at the age of 75.

[[Donald M. Kendall]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Businesspeople from Washington

Donald Mcintosh "Don" Kendall (March 16, 1921 – September 19, 2020) was an American businessman and political adviser. He was CEO of Pepsi Cola and as CEO of PepsiCo from 1971 to 1986. Kendall was born in Sequim, Washington.

Kendall died on September 19, 2020 in Greenwich, Connecticut at the age of 99.

[[Roaring Forties]]

CATEGORIES: Winds

The Roaring Forties are strong westerly winds. It is found in the Southern hemisphere. It is found between the latitudes of 40 and 50 degrees.

[[Sequim, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state)

Sequim En-us-Sequim.ogg is a city in Clallam County, Washington, United States. The 2010 census counted a population of 6,606. Sequim is located along the Dungeness River near the base of the Olympic Mountains. 

[[Al Langlois]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Bruins players, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Detroit Red Wings players, Montreal Canadiens players, New York Rangers players, Ice hockey people from Quebec

Joseph Albert Oliver "Junior" Langlois (November 6, 1934 – September 19, 2020) was a Canadian ice hockey defenceman. Langlois started his National Hockey League career with the Montreal Canadiens in 1958 and ended in 1966 with the Boston Bruins. He also played with the New York Rangers and Detroit Red Wings. 

Langlois won three Stanley Cups with Montreal, in 1958, 1959 and 1960. He was born in Magog, Quebec.

Langlois died on September 19, 2020 in California, aged 85.

[[Magog, Quebec]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Quebec

Magog (local; maˈɡɔɡ) is a city in southeastern Quebec, Canada, about 120 east of Montreal.

[[Michael Chapman (cinematographer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, American cinematographers, Movie directors from New York City

Michael Crawford Chapman, A.S.C. (November 21, 1935 – September 20, 2020) was an American cinematographer and movie director. He was known for his works with Martin Scorsese and Ivan Reitman. Chapman was born in New York City. His best known works was in Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Space Jam and in The Fugitive.

Chapman died from congestive heart failure on September 20, 2020, at his home in Los Angeles, aged 84.

[[Joe Pytka]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Movie directors from Pennsylvania, Writers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Joe Pytka (born November 4, 1938) is an American movie and music video director. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He holds the record for the most nominations for the Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directing – Commercials. He directed many music videos of Michael Jackson and directed Space Jam.

[[The Fugitive (1993 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 action movies, 1993 thriller movies, 1990s action thriller movies, American action thriller movies, Movies directed by Andrew Davis

The Fugitive is a 1993 American action thriller movie based on the 1960s television series of the same name created by Roy Huggins. The movie was directed by Andrew Davis and stars Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones, with supporting roles by Sela Ward, Joe Pantoliano, Andreas Katsulas, and Jeroen Krabbé.

The Fugitive premiered in the United States on August 6, 1993.

It was nominated for seven Academy Awards including Best Picture; Jones won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.

[[Robert Graetz]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, American civil rights activists, American Lutherans, Writers from West Virginia, Writers from Alabama, People from Montgomery, Alabama

Robert Sylvester Graetz Jr. (May 16, 1928 – September 20, 2020) was an American Lutheran clergyman. He was the white pastor of a black congregation in Montgomery, Alabama. He openly supported the Montgomery bus boycott and became a well known activist during the civil rights movement.

Graetz died from Parkinson's disease at his home in Montgomery, Alabama on September 20, 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Clarksburg, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Clarksburg is a city in and the county seat of Harrison County, West Virginia, United States. The population of the city was 16,578 at the 2010 census. 

[[Richard A. Clarke]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, American political writers, American political commentators, Politicians from Boston, Massachusetts, Writers from Boston, Massachusetts, People from Dorchester, Massachusetts

Richard Alan Clarke (born October 27, 1950) is an American former government official. He was National Coordinator for Security, Infrastructure Protection, and Counter-terrorism for the United States between 1998 and 2003.

Clarke worked for the State Department during the presidency of Ronald Reagan. 

In 1992, President George H.W. Bush appointed him to chair the Counter-terrorism Security Group and to a seat on the United States National Security Council. 

President Bill Clinton kept Clarke and in 1998 promoted him to be the National Coordinator for Security, Infrastructure Protection, and Counter-terrorism, the chief counter-terrorism adviser on the National Security Council. 

Under President George W. Bush, Clarke initially continued in the same position but no longer had Cabinet-level access. He later was appointed as the Special Advisor to the President on cybersecurity. 

Clarke left the Bush administration in 2003 after criticizing him over invading Iraq after the September 11 attacks.

[[The Two Noble Kinsmen]]

CATEGORIES: Plays by William Shakespeare

The Two Noble Kinsmen is a Jacobean tragic comedy. It was first published in 1634 by  William Shakespeare. Its plot comes from "The Knight's Tale" in Geoffrey Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales.

This play is believed to have been William Shakespeare's final play before he retired to Stratford-Upon-Avon and died three years later.

[[Cle Elum, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state), Kittitas County, Washington

Cle Elum is a city in Kittitas County, Washington, United States. The population was 1,872 at the 2010 census. About 96 by car from Seattle.

[[Lake City, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina

Lake City is a city in Florence County, South Carolina, United States. The population was 6,675 at the 2010 census.

[[ZeniMax Media]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Maryland, 1999 establishments in the United States, Companies of the United States, Video game companies, Microsoft

ZeniMax Media Inc. is an American video game holding company based in Rockville, Maryland, and founded in 1999. 

The company owns id Software (developer of the Doom, Quake and Rage series), Arkane Studios (developer of Dishonored and Prey), MachineGames (developer of the Wolfenstein series), Tango Gameworks (developer of The Evil Within), publisher Bethesda Softworks with its Bethesda Game Studios (developer of The Elder Scrolls and Fallout series) and ZeniMax Online Studios (developer of The Elder Scrolls Online). 

On September 21, 2020, Microsoft announced they entered into an agreement to buy ZeniMax Media and all its subsidaries for $7.5 billion.

[[Rosa María Ortiz Ríos]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Peruvian lawyers, Peruvian politicians, People from Lima

Rosa María Ortiz Ríos (9 September 1955 – 20 September 2020) was a Peruvian lawyer and politician. She was Minister of Energy and Mines between 17 February 2015 until 28 July 2018 during the Ollanta Humala presidency. Ortiz Ríos was born in Lima, Peru.

Ortiz Ríos died on 20 September 2020 in Lima at the age of 65.

[[Garland F. Pinholster]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American basketball players, State legislators of the United States, Sportspeople from Georgia (U.S. state), Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Republican Party politicians

Garland Folsom Pinholster (February 19, 1928 – September 20, 2020) was an American athletic director as well as college basketball, baseball, and tennis coach. He was elected to the Oglethorpe Athletic Hall of Fame in its inaugural year of 1962. He coached Oglethorpe University's basketball team between 1956 to 1966. From 1948 to 1950, he played for North Georgia Nighthawks. Pinholster was born in Clyattville, Georgia.

Pinholster was in the Georgia House of Representatives from 1990 to 2002 and was a Republican.

Pinholster died on September 20, 2020 in Ball Ground, Georgia at the age of 92.

[[Mary Pruitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, Deaths from blood clot, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Nashville, Tennessee, US Democratic Party politicians

Mary Pruitt (February 3, 1934 – September 20, 2020) was an American politician. She was born in Brentwood, Tennessee. Pruitt was a member of the Democratic Party. Between 1985 to 2013, she was a member of the Tennessee House of Representatives.

Pruitt died on September 20, 2020 at a Nashville, Tennessee hospital from a blood clot caused by a fall, aged 86.

[[Moshe Sharoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Former Members of Knesset, Haifa University alumni, Israeli former political leaders, Jewish Israeli politicians, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Romanian Jews

Moshe Sharoni (משה שרוני, 1929 – 20 September 2020) was a Romanian-born Israeli politician. He was a member of the Knesset for Gil between 2006 and 2009. He was head of the breakaway faction, Justice for the Elderly. Sharoni was born in Buhuși, Romania.

Sharoni died on 20 September 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Gerardo Vera]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish movie actors, Spanish stage actors, Spanish television actors, Spanish movie directors, Spanish theatre directors, Costume designers, Actors from Madrid, Writers from Madrid, Goya Award winners

Gerardo Vera Perales (10 March 1947snd20 September 2020) was a Spanish costume and set designer, opera director, actor, and movie and theatre director. He was born in Madrid. Vera was known for his works in La Celestina (1994) and in Second Skin (2000). He won a Goya Award in 1986.

Vera died on 20 September 2020 in Madrid from COVID-19, aged 73.

[[Clyattville, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Clyattville is an unincorporated community in Lowndes County, Georgia, United States. It was created in the 1840s.

[[Ball Ground, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Ball Ground is a city in Cherokee County, Georgia, United States. The 2010 census shows the city had a population of 1,433.

[[Hytale]]

CATEGORIES: Adventure games, Indie video games, MacOS games, Online games, Role-playing video games, Upcoming video games, Windows games

Hytale is an upcoming sandbox video game by Hypixel Studios. Creation of the game began in 2015 by Minecraft server Hypixel developers with help from Riot Games. Hypixel plans to be release Hytale for PC, consoles, and mobile devices as early as 2023.

[[Vitória S.C.]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Portugal, 1922 establishments in Europe, Portuguese football clubs

Vitória Sport Clube, commonly known as Vitória de Guimarães, is a Portuguese professional football club based in Guimarães that competes in the Primeira Liga, the top-flight of football in Portugal.

Vitória de Guimarães have finished third in the Primeira Liga on four occasions.

[[Jaime Alves]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2020 deaths, Portuguese footballers

Jaime Alves Magalhães (28 March 1965 – 21 September 2020), known as Alves, was a Portuguese footballer who played as a midfielder. He was born in Espinho, Portugal. He made 135 appearances for Boavista F.C. between 1985 to 1991 and another 85 between 1992 to 1998. He also played for the Portugal national football team between 1988 to 1989.

Alves died on 21 September 2020, aged 55.

[[Triple Cross (1966 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 movies, 1960s action movies, 1960s war movies, British action movies, British war movies, French action movies, German movies, Warner Bros. movies, World War II movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Terence Young

Triple Cross is a 1966 British French German World War II action movie directed by Terence Young and was based on the 1953 novel by Eddie Chapman. It stars Christopher Plummer, Romy Schneider, Trevor Howard, Yul Brynner, Claudine Auger, Harry Meyen, Gert Fröbe and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Project X (1968 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 movies, 1960s science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by William Castle

Project X is a 1968 American science fiction movie directed by William Castle and was based on the novels by L. P. Davies. It stars Christopher George, Greta Baldwin, Henry Jones, Harold Gould, Monte Markham, Phillip Pine, Lee Delano and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Theotonius Amal Ganguly]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 1977 deaths, Roman Catholic archbishops, People from Dhaka

Theotonious Amal Ganguly, CSC, (18 February 1920–2 September 1977) was a catholic priest and educator. He was the second Archbishop of Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Dhaka.

[[Hamdi Benani]]

Hamdi Benani (حمدي بناني; 1 January 1943 – 21 September 2020) was an Algerian singer and musician.

[[Virginio Bettini]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, MEPs for Italy, Former MEPs

Virginio Bettini (29 June 1942 – 21 September 2020) was an Italian politician. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 1989 to 1994. He was a member of the Green Italy.

Bettini died on 21 September 2020, aged 72.

[[Giuseppe Caldarola]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Italian journalists, Italian politicians, People from Bari

Giuseppe Caldarola (9 April 1946 – 21 September 2020) was an Italian journalist and politician. He was a Deputy from 2001 to 2008. He was born in Bari, Italy. He was a member of the Democrats of the Left.

Caldarola died in Rome on 21 September 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Water extraction]]

CATEGORIES: Water

Water extraction is the process of taking water from any body of water. It either taken temporarily or permanently. It can be used to control floods or to get water for other uses. The water could also be used as drinking water after it is treated.

[[KRL Commuterline]]

CATEGORIES: Trains

KRL Commuter Line is an Public transport operated on Jakarta.

[[Ron Cobb]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia with Lewy bodies, Naturalised citizens of Australia, American cartoonists, American comics artists, American animators, American television writers, Australian artists, Writers from Sydney, Australian movie directors, Australian screenwriters, Movie directors from Los Angeles, California, Screenwriters from Los Angeles, California

Ronald Ray Cobb (September 21, 1937 – September 21, 2020) was an American-Australian cartoonist, artist, and movie designer. Cobb was born in Los Angeles, California. 

He worked on many movies such as Dark Star (1974), Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979), Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981), Conan the Barbarian (1982), Back to the Future (1985), The Abyss (1989),  and Total Recall (1990). 

Cobb died on September 21, 2020 in Sydney from Lewy body dementia on his 83rd birthday.

[[Roy Head]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American singer-songwriters, American rock singers, American soul singers, American R&B singers, American blues singers, Writers from Texas, Singers from Texas

Roy Kent Head (January 9, 1941 – September 21, 2020) was an rockabilly American singer-songwriter. He was best known for his hit record "Treat Her Right". He was born in Three Rivers, Texas. 

Head died on September 21, 2020 from a heart attack in Montgomery County, Texas at the age of 79.

[[Three Rivers, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Three Rivers is a city in Live Oak County, Texas, United States. The population was 1,848 at the 2010 census.

[[Lars-Åke Lagrell]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish politicians, Sports commentators

Lars-Åke Lagrell (20 January 1940 – 21 September 2020) was a Swedish sports personality. He was born near Växjö, Sweden. He was the president of the Swedish Football Association between 1991 and 2012. 

In 2002 Prime Minister of Sweden Göran Persson appointed him Governor of Kronoberg County. He left the office in 2006. 

Lagrell died on 21 September 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Amos Lin]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Basketball players, Israeli sportspeople, Olympians

Amos Lin (2 July 1933 – 21 September 2020) was an Israeli basketball player. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1952 Summer Olympics.

Lin died on 21 September 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Ecohydrology]]

CATEGORIES: Ecology, Water

Ecohydrology is the scientific study of how water interacts with ecological systems. It is a subdiscipline of hydrology, that focuses on the ecology. These interactions may happen in a water bodies, such as rivers and lakes, or on land, in forests, deserts, and other terrestrial ecosystems. Areas of research in ecohydrology include transpiration, how plants use water, adaptation of organisms to their environment in the water, effects of vegetation and benthic plants on smoving water, and interactions between ecological processes and the hydrological cycle.

[[Chungju]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Korea

Chungju (tɕʰuŋ.dʑu) is a city in North Chungcheong province, South Korea. Uamsan is a mountain located within the outskirts of the city.

The city is famous for the annual martial arts festival held in October. Also of note, former UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-moon grew up here.

[[Gilbert Meyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from glioblastoma, French mayors

Gilbert Meyer (26 December 1941 – 21 September 2020) was a French politician. He was a deputy in the National Assembly from 1993 to 2007. He was the Mayor of Colmar from 1995 to 4 July 2020.

He was a member of the Rally for the Republic (RPR) and Union for a Popular Movement (UMP). Meyer was born in Dessenheim, France.

Meyer died on 21 September 2020 from a stroke caused by glioblastoma in Colmar at the age of 78.

[[Bioprecipitation]]

CATEGORIES: Bacteria, Meteorology

Bioprecipitation is a theory about rain-making bacteria. It was proposed by David Sands from Montana State University in 1982. They believe that biological ice nuclei have the ability to catalyze freezing at warmer temperatures. New research shows that bacteria may be found in clouds as a way spread their spores.

[[Harold Moss]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, American mayors, Politicians from Texas, Politicians from Washington, People from Tacoma, Washington

Harold Moss (October 1, 1929 – September 21, 2020) was an American politician and businessman. He was the 34th mayor of Tacoma, Washington. He was the first African American member of the city's council. 

Moss died on September, 21, 2020 at the age of 90 in Tacoma, Washington.

[[Bob Nevin]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian ice hockey right wingers, Los Angeles Kings players, Memorial Cup winners, Minnesota North Stars players, New York Rangers players, Stanley Cup champions, Ice hockey people from Ontario

Robert Frank Nevin (March 18, 1938 – September 21, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey right wing. He played 18 seasons in the National Hockey League (NHL) between 1957–58 and 1975–76. He was born in Timmins, Ontario.

He was known for playing with Toronto Maple Leafs, New York Rangers, Minnesota North Stars, Los Angeles Kings and Edmonton Oilers.

Nevin died on September 21, 2020 at the age of 82.

[[Supersolid]]

CATEGORIES: States of matter

In condensed matter physics, a supersolid is a solid material with superfluid properties. A supersolid is a special state of matter where particles form a solid, but also flow with zero viscosity.

[[String-net liquid]]

CATEGORIES: States of matter

In condensed matter physics, a string-net is a special state of matter. Its behavior was proposed by Michael A. Levin and Xiao-Gang Wen.

[[Ang Rita Sherpa]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Nepalese people, Mountain climbers, Sherpa

Ang Rita Sherpa (आङरिता शेर्पा; 1948Spaced en dash21 September 2020) was a Nepali mountaineer. He climbed Mount Everest ten times without the use of supplemental oxygen between 1983 and 1996. 

His sixth climb set the world record for the most successful ascents of Mount Everest, which he re-set on his tenth climb. He was also the first, and to date only, person to climb Mount Everest without supplementary oxygen in winter. He was nicknamed the "Snow Leopard" by his peers.

Sherpa died on 21 September 2020 from a stroke at the age of 72.

[[Bob Atkins (American football)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Tennessee Titans players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Sportspeople from Atlanta, Georgia, Sportspeople from California

Robert Lee Atkins, Jr. (April 2, 1946 – September 22, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a defensive back in the National Football League (NFL). He played for the St. Louis Cardinals from 1968 to 1969 and for the Houston Oilers from 1970 to 1976. Atkins was born in Modesto, California.

Atkins died on September 22, 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Aquincum]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Rome, Cities in Hungary

Aquincum (aˈkᶣɪŋkũː) was an ancient city, situated on the North East of Pannonia in Roman Empire. The ruins of the city can be found today in Budapest, the capital of Hungary. It is believed that Marcus Aurelius lived there some time. Aquincum was settled by a Celtic tribe and was a military base at that time (1 century AD). After AD 106, Aquincum became the capital city of the Pannon province.

[[Michael Gwisdek]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, German movie actors, German television actors, German movie directors, German screenwriters, German stage actors, Actors from Berlin, Writers from Berlin

Michael Gwisdek (14 January 1942 – 22 September 2020) was a German actor and movie director. He was born in Berlin. His first movie was Treffen in Travers (1988). He was also known for his works The Big Mambo (1998) and Nightshapes (1999).

Gwisdek died on 22 September 2020, aged 78.

[[Sergey Khoruzhiy]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Russian physicists, Russian mathematicians, Russian philosophers, Theologians

Sergey Khoruzhiy (5 October 1941 – 22 September 2020) was a Russian physicist, mathematician, philosopher, and theologian.

Khoruzhiy became a member of the Russian Academy of Natural Sciences in 1993. He was a professor at the Institute of Philosophy, Russian Academy of Sciences. He also was a professor in the Department of Comparative Study of Religious Traditions at UNESCO, and directed the Institute of Synergistic Anthropology, beginning in 2005. 

Khoruzhiy died on 22 September 2020, aged 78.

[[Frie Leysen]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian artists, People from Brussels

Frie Leysen (19 February 1950 – 22 September 2020) was a Belgian festival director. She was director of the art centre deSingel from 1980 until 1991. In 1994, she co-founded the Kunstenfestivaldesarts in Brussels.

Leysen died on 22 September 2020 aged 70.

[[Dan Olweus]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish scientists, Norwegian scientists, Swedish psychologist, Norwegian psychologists

Dan Olweus (April 18, 1931 – September 2020) was a Swedish-Norwegian psychologist. He was a research professor of psychology at the University of Bergen, Norway. Olweus was known as a pioneer of research on bullying. He was born in Nässjö, Sweden.

Olweus died in September 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Road Warrior Animal]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, WWE wrestlers, Sportspeople from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Sportspeople from Chicago

Joseph Michael Laurinaitis (September 12, 1960 – September 22, 2020) better known by his ring name, Road Warrior Animal (or simply Animal), was an American professional wrestler. Along with Road Warrior Hawk, he was one half of the tag team The Road Warriors/The Legion of Doom.

He performed with many pay-per-view events for the WWF and WCW, competing for the WCW World Heavyweight Championship at 2001's Sin.

Animal was inducted with Hawk and their manager Paul Ellering into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2011.

Laurinaitis died of natural causes on September 22, 2020, ten days after his 60th birthday in Osage Beach, Missouri.

[[Osage Beach, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Osage Beach is a city in Camden and Miller counties in the U.S. state of Missouri. Most of the city is in Camden County, while a small eastern sliver is in Miller County.  The population was 4,351 at the 2010 census.

[[Tuscumbia, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Tuscumbia is a village in and the county seat of Miller County, Missouri, United States. The population was 203 at the 2010 census, at which time it was a town.

[[Gergely Vari]]

Gergely "Gergo" Vari (April 6, 1977) is a businessman of Hungarian origin, CEO of Lensa, Inc.

[[Camdenton, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Camdenton is a city in of Camden County, Missouri, United States. Its population was 3,718 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Camden County.

[[Parliament of Ghana]]

CATEGORIES: Ghana

The Parliament of Ghana is the legislative body of the Government of Ghana.

[[Parliament of Jamaica]]

CATEGORIES: Jamaica

The Parliament of Jamaica is the legislative branch of the government of Jamaica. It consists of three elements: the Crown (represented by the Governor-General), the appointed Senate and the directly elected House of Representatives.

[[Hwacheon]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of South Korea

Hwacheon County (Hwacheon-gun) is a county in Gangwon Province, South Korea. The northern border is, in some places, within nine kilometres of the Korean Demilitarized Zone. Neighboring counties are Cheorwon to the northwest and north, Yanggu to the east, Chuncheon to the south, and the Gyeonggi-do province to the southwest. The county consists largely of mountains and rivers, between which are small farming communities, military bases and military training grounds. The area is renowned for its rivers, lake trout, indigenous otters, and natural scenery.

[[Adamu Daramani Sakande]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Ghanaian politicians

Adamu Daramani Sakande (6 May 1962 – 22 September 2020) was a Ghanaian politician. He was a member of the Fifth Parliament of the Fourth Republic for the Bawku Central Constituency between 2009 to 2013. He was a member of the New Patriotic Party.

Sakande died of a long-illness at a London hospital on 22 September 2020, aged 58.

[[Yilan County, Taiwan]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Taiwan

Yilan County, alternately spelled I-lan, is a county in northeastern Taiwan, Republic of China.

[[Agne Simonsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Swedish footballers, Swedish football managers, People from Gothenburg

Tore Klas Agne Simonsson (19 October 1935 – 22 September 2020) was a Swedish footballer. He played as a striker. Beginning his career with Örgryte IS, he went on to represent Real Madrid and Real Sociedad in La Liga in the early 1960s before returning to Örgryte in 1963.

Simonsson won 51 caps for the Sweden national team. He was a part of the Sweden team that finished second at the 1958 FIFA World Cup. He was the recipient of the 1959 Svenska Dagbladet Gold Medal.

Simonsson died on 22 September 2020 from pneumonia in Gothenburg at the age of 84.

[[Andre Vltchek]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Russian journalists, American journalists, American political commentators, Russian screenwriters, Russian movie directors, American screenwriters

André Vltchek (Андре Влчек, 1962 – 22 September 2020) was a Soviet-born American political analyst, journalist, and a filmmaker. Vltchek was born in Leningrad. 

[[Sha Tin]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Asia, Geography of Hong Kong

Sha Tin, also spelt Shatin, is a satellite town along  Shing Mun River in Sha Tin District of East New Territories, Hong Kong. Administratively, it is part of the Sha Tin District. It is one of Hong Kong's most prominent examples of new town developments in the 1970s. Together with its satellite town Ma On Shan, Shatin is the most populous city in the New Territories, with a 2011 population census of 630,273 within an area of 35.87. It is in the southern half of New Territories East below Tolo Harbour, it is the principal city of Sha Tin District, which is the second most populous district of the territory.

The city was founded in 1973 under the New Towns Development Programme of the Hong Kong government. Its current name was named after the nearby village of Sha Tin Wai. Housing the industrial area of Fo Tan, Shatin's economy once heavily relied on manufacturing, logistics and transportation. Since the late 1990s, it has undergone an extensive transition into areas such as business, service, tourism, entertainment, culture, education, sports, technology and scientific research. This has been marked by the building of Sha Tin Racecourse, Hong Kong Sports Institute and the Hong Kong Science Park in its outskirts.

[[Lu'an]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in China

Lu'an (六安), is a prefecture-level city in western Anhui province, People's Republic of China, bordering Henan to the northwest and Hubei to the southwest. At the 2010 census, it had a total population of 5,612,590, whom 1,644,344 lived in the built-up area made of 2 urban districts. Neighbouring prefecture-level cities are the provincial capital of Hefei to the east, Anqing to the south, Huanggang (Hubei) and Xinyang (Henan) to the west, and Huainan and Fuyang to the north. Although the character "六" (literally: "six") is normally pronounced "Liù", in this case it changes to "Lù" on account of the historical literary reading.

[[Jiashan County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties, Zhejiang

Jiashan County (嘉善县) is a county in the north of Zhejiang Province, bordering Shanghai to the northeast and Jiangsu province to the north. It is administered by the prefecture-level city of Jiaxing. Jiashan is nicknamed "The Land of Fish and Rice", and is 80 southwest of central Shanghai, 95 east of Hangzhou, and 90 south of Suzhou. The county seat is located on 126 People Avenue, Weitang Town. The second campus of Sanda University, known as Guangbiao Institute, is in Jiashan County.

[[Vakha Agaev]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Russian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia

Vakha Agaev (15 March 1953 – 23 September 2020) was a Russian politician. He was a member of the State Duma representing the Krasnoyarsk region from 2011 until his death. He was a member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. 

Agaev died on 23 September 2020 in Moscow from COVID-19, aged 67.

Naganuma is a town that is in Sorachi Subprefecture, Hokkaidō, Japan.

[[2013 Asian Rowing Championships]]

The 2013 Asian Rowing Championships were the 15th Asian Rowing Championships and took place from September 22–25, 2013, in  Lu'an , China.

[[Suresh Angadi]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

Suresh Angadi (1 June 1955 – 23 September 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of parliament from 2004 until his death. He was Minister of State for Railways from 2019 until his death in 2020. He was a leader of Bharatiya Janata Party from Karnataka. He was born in Karnataka, India.

Angadi died on 23 September 2020 at a hospital in New Delhi from COVID-19 at the age of 65. 

[[Zlatko Portner]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Olympic bronze medalists, Yugoslavian sportspeople

Zlatko Portner (16 January 1962 – 23 September 2020) was a Yugoslav handball player. He competed at the 1988 Summer Olympics. Portner was born in Ruma. During his successful career he played for RK Metaloplastika and FC Barcelona Handbol.

In 1988 he was part of the Yugoslav team which won the bronze medal. He played in all six matches and scored 31 goals.

Portner died on 23 September 2020, aged 58.

[[Yrsa Sigurðardóttir]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Icelandic writers, Novelists, People from Reykjavík

Vilborg Yrsa Sigurðardóttir (born 1963) is an Icelandic novelist. She writes both crime novels and children's fiction in Icelandic. She has been writing since 1998. Her works have been translated into English by Bernard Scudder, Philip Roughton and Victoria Cobb. She is known for her Thóra Gudmundsdóttir (Þóra Guðmundsdóttir) crime novel series. As a children's writer, she won the 2003 Icelandic Children's Book Prize for Biobörn.

Yrsa was born in Reykjavík. She is married and has two children. Outside of writing, she has had a career as a civil engineer.

[[Rowing at the Asian Games]]

CATEGORIES: Rowing competitions, Asian Games

Rowing has been contested at every Asian Games since its introduction to the program at the 1982 Asian Games.

[[Law 4000]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 drama movies, Greek movies, Movies directed by Giannis Dalianidis

Nomos 4000 (Νόμος 4000, "Law 4000") is a 1962 Greek drama movie directed by Giannis Dalianidis and starring Zoi Laskari, Kostas Voutsas, Eleni Zafeiriou, Vangelos Voulgaridis, Vasilis Diamantopoulos.

[[Pierre Troisgros]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, French businesspeople

Pierre Troisgros (3 September 1928 – 23 September 2020) was a French restaurateur.

He was best known for his restaurant Frères Troisgros. Within ten years, it became the most popular restaurant in the region and soon it was one of the best known restaurants in France. In 1965, the restaurant, got its second star, and, in 1968, its third.

On 23 September 2020, Troisgros died at home in Le Coteau near Roanne from a heart attack, aged 92.

[[Iván Verebély]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian movie actors, Hungarian television actors, Voice actors, Actors from Budapest

Iván Verebély (born Iván Weinberg 7 December 1937 – 23 September 2020) was a Hungarian actor and comedian. He was born in Budapest. He  played in Miskolci Nemzeti Színház, Nemzeti Színház, and in Vidámszínpad.

He appeared in the 2008 movie The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas. He gave the voice to Mayor Manx for the Hungarian dub of SWAT Kats: The Radical Squadron.

Verebély died on 23 September 2020 in Budapest at the age of 82.

[[Blanche M. Manning]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, Politicians from Chicago, American judges, US Democratic Party politicians

Blanche M. Manning (December 12, 1934 – September 20, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the Senior United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois between 2010 until his death. Manning was nominated to the court by President Bill Clinton in 1994. Manning was born in Chicago.

Manning died on September 20, 2020 in Chicago at the age of 85.

[[Georgina Mace]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, British educators, Ecologists, Scientists from London

Dame Georgina Mary Mace, GBR (12 July 1953 – 19 September 2020) was a British ecologist and conservation scientist. She was Professor of Biodiversity and Ecosystems at University College London. 

She was Professor of Conservation Science and Director of the Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) Centre for Population Biology, Imperial College London (2006–2012) and Director of Science at the Zoological Society of London (2000–2006).

[[Donald Keith Duncan]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Jamaican politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Donald Keith "D.K." Duncan, CD, (1940 – September 17, 2020) was a Jamaican dental surgeon and politician. He was a member of the People's National Party (PNP). He was Minister of National Mobilization & Human Resource Development between 1977 to 1980. Duncan was born in St. Ann, Jamaica. He was a member of the Parliament of Jamaica between 1976 to 1983 and again from 2007 to 2016.

Duncan died on September 17, 2020 from COVID-19, aged 80.

[[President of Cantabria]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Cantabria

The President of Cantabria is the person in charge of the Government of Cantabria. The job holds the supreme representation of the autonomous community and ordinary representation of the State in Cantabria. He or she is elected by the Parliament of Cantabria.

[[José Antonio Rodríguez Martínez]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Presidents of Cantabria, Living people

José Antonio Rodríguez Martínez (born 26 May 1931) is a Spanish politician. He was the first President of Cantabria between 1982 and 1984. He was born in Santander, Cantabria.

[[Juan Hormaechea]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Presidents of Cantabria, Mayors

Juan Hormaechea Cazón (5 June 1939 – 1 December 2020) was a Spanish politician. He was the President of Cantabria between 1987 and 1990, and again from 1991 to 1995. He was also Mayor of Santander between 1977 and 1987. He was born in Santander.

Hormaechea died on 1 December 2020 in Santander at the age of 81.

[[Jaime Blanco García]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Presidents of Cantabria

Jaime Blanco García (1 May 1944spnd24 September 2020) was a Spanish politician. He was President of Cantabria between 1990 and 1991. He was born in Santander, Cantabria. He was a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party.

Blanco García died on 24 September 2020, aged 76.

[[Miguel Ángel Revilla]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Presidents of Cantabria, Living people

Miguel Ángel Revilla Roiz (born 23 January 1943) is a Spanish politician, economist and bank employee. He was the 9th President of the Autonomous Community of Cantabria. Before this, Revilla has was the 7th President between 2003 and 2011.

[[Sekhar Basu]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian scientists

Sekhar Basu (20 September 1952 – 24 September 2020) was an Indian nuclear scientist. He was born in Muzaffarpur, Bihar. From 2012 to 2016, he was Director of the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre. Between 2015 to 2018, he was Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission of India.

Basu died of COVID-19 in Kolkata, West Bengal on 24 September 2020, four days after his 68th birthday.

[[Claude Moisy]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, French journalists, French novelists

Claude Moisy (26 June 1927 – 21 September 2020) was a French journalist and writer. He was President of the Agence France-Presse from 1990 to 1993. He was born in Caen, France. Moisy began his journalistic career with Ouest-France. Moisy joined Reporters Without Borders. He also worked for Le Monde.

Moisy died on 21 September 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Harold Evans]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Naturalized citizens of the United States, British journalists, Journalists from New York City

Sir Harold Matthew Evans (28 June 1928 – 23 September 2020) was a British-American journalist and writer. He was editor of The Sunday Times from 1967 to 1981.

He also worked for U.S. News & World Report, The Atlantic Monthly, and the New York Daily News. In 1986, he founded Condé Nast Traveler.

Evans was honored as a Knight Bachelor in 2004.

On 13 June 2011, Evans was appointed editor-at-large of the Reuters news agency. From 2013 until 2019, he was chairman of the European Press Prize jury panel.

Evans died in New York City on 23 September 2020 from heart failure, aged 92.

[[Richard O. Covey]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, American astronauts, People from Fayetteville, Arkansas, Scientists from Arkansas, Scientists from Colorado

Richard Oswalt Covey (born August 1, 1946) is a retired United States Air Force officer and former NASA astronaut. He was part of the Space Shuttle Discovery crew.

[[Arnaldo Tamayo Méndez]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Cuban people, Astronauts

Arnaldo Tamayo Méndez (born January 29, 1942) is a Cuban military officer, legislator, and former cosmonaut. He was the first person of African heritage in space. 

As a member of the crew of Soyuz 38, he became the first Cuban citizen, the first Latin American, and the first person from a country in the Western Hemisphere other than the United States to travel into Earth orbit.

[[Vaporization]]

CATEGORIES: States of matter

Vaporization is a phase change from liquid to vapor. There are two types of vaporization: evaporation and boiling.

Evaporation is a phase change from liquid to vapour. Evaporation happens below the boiling point of a substance at a given pressure. Evaporation happens on a surface.

Boiling is also a phase change from liquid to gas. Boiling takes place when the vapor pressure of the substance is greater than or equal to the pressure of its environment. The temperature at which  a substance boils is called the boiling point.

[[Richard H. Truly]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American astronauts, Administrators of NASA, Politicians from Mississippi, Scientists from Mississippi

Richard Harrison Truly (born November 12, 1937) is a retired Vice Admiral in the United States Navy. He was the eighth Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) from 1989 to 1992. He was the first former astronaut to head the space agency.

[[Daniel Goldin]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Administrators of NASA, American astronauts, Politicians from New York City, Scientists from New York City

Daniel Saul Goldin (born July 23, 1940) is an American astronaut. He was the 9th and longest-tenured Administrator of NASA from April 1, 1992, to November 17, 2001. He was appointed by President George H. W. Bush and also served under Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.

[[Barbara Morgan]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, American educators, American astronauts, Scientists from California, People from Fresno, California

Barbara Radding Morgan (born November 28, 1951) is an American teacher and a former NASA astronaut. She participated in the Teacher in Space program as backup to Christa McAuliffe for the 1986 ill-fated STS-51-L mission of the Space Shuttle Challenger.

She then trained as a Mission Specialist, and flew on STS-118 in August 2007.

[[Peter Billingsley]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American child actors, Actors from New York City, Movie directors from New York City, Movie producers from New York City

Peter Billingsley (born April 16, 1971), also known as Peter Michaelsen and Peter Billingsley-Michaelsen, is an American actor, director, and producer.

He is best known for his role as Ralphie Parker in the 1983 movie A Christmas Story, Jack Simmons in The Dirt Bike Kid, Billy in Death Valley, and as Messy Marvin in the Hershey's chocolate syrup commercials during the 1980s. 

[[Fritz Strassmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1980 deaths, German chemists

Friedrich Wilhelm "Fritz" Strassmann (22 February 1902 – 22 April 1980) was a German chemist. In 1939, he worked with Otto Hahn, to find out that barium was a product of the bombardment of uranium with neutrons.

[[William P. Rogers]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 2001 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, United States Secretaries of State, United States Attorneys General, American military personnel of World War II, Politicians from New York, US Republican Party politicians, United States Deputy Attorneys General

William Pierce Rogers (June 23, 1913 – January 2, 2001) was an American politician, diplomat, and lawyer. He was United States Attorney General under President Dwight D. Eisenhower from 1957 to 1961 and United States Secretary of State under President Richard Nixon from 1969 to 1973.

Rogers died of congestive heart failure, at the Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Maryland, on January 2, 2001, at the age of 87.

[[Norfolk, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Norfolk is a town in St. Lawrence County in the U.S. state of New York. The population was 4,668 at the 2010 census.

[[Rogers Commission Report]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 in the United States

The Rogers Commission Report was created by a Presidential Commission charged with investigating the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster during its 10th mission, STS-51-L. 

[[Joe Sutter]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2016 deaths, Engineers from Washington (state), Deaths from pneumonia, Scientists from Seattle, Washington

Joseph Frederick Sutter (March 21, 1921 – August 30, 2016) was an American engineer for the Boeing Airplane Company and manager of the design team for the Boeing 747 under Malcolm T. Stamper. Smithsonian Air and Space Magazine has described Sutter as the "father of the 747".

[[Alton G. Keel Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Engineers from Virginia, Permanent Representatives of the United States to NATO, Businesspeople from Virginia, Politicians from Virginia, US Republican Party politicians

Alton Gold Keel Jr. (born September 15, 1943) is an American engineer, diplomat, and businessman. He was born in Hampton, Virginia.

In July 1986, President Ronald Reagan appointed Keel as the acting principal deputy to the National Security Advisor.  From 1987-89, Keel was the United States Permanent Representative to NATO.

[[Donald J. Kutyna]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, American generals, American aviators, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, Military people from Chicago

General Donald Joseph Kutyna (born December 6, 1933) is a retired United States Air Force officer. He was born in Chicago. 

He was commander in chief of the North American Aerospace Defense Command and the United States Space Command from 1990 to 1992, and commander of Air Force Space Command at Peterson Air Force Base, Colorado from 1987 to 1990.

[[Gene Porter Bridwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Engineers from Indiana, Scientists from Indiana

Gene Porter Bridwell (born October 4, 1935) is an American NASA official. He was the seventh director of the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center located in Huntsville, Alabama. He was director from January 6, 1994 to February 3, 1996. Bridwell was born in Linton, Indiana.

[[William R. Lucas]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, Living people, American chemists, Scientists from Tennessee

William Ronald Lucas (born March 1, 1922) is an American NASA official and chemist. He was the fourth Director of the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center.  He was director from June 15, 1974 to July 3, 1986. Lucas was born in Newbern, Tennessee.

[[Newbern, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Tennessee

Newbern is a town in Dyer County, Tennessee. As of the 2010 census, the town population was 3,313.

[[Dyersburg, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Dyersburg is a city and the county seat of Dyer County, Tennessee, in the United States. It is located in northwest Tennessee, 79 northeast of Memphis on the Forked Deer River. The population was 17,145 at the 2010 census.

[[Rick Husband]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2003 deaths, Aviation deaths, American astronauts, American aviators, Scientists from Texas, People from Amarillo, Texas

Rick Douglas Husband (July 12, 1957 – February 1, 2003) (Colonel, USAF) was an American astronaut and fighter pilot. He traveled into space twice: as Pilot of STS-96 and Commander of STS-107. He and the rest of the crew of STS-107 were killed when Columbia disintegrated during reentry into the Earth's atmosphere.

[[William C. McCool]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2003 deaths, Aviation deaths, American astronauts, Engineers from California, Scientists from San Diego, California

William Cameron "Willie" McCool (September 23, 1961 – February 1, 2003) (Cmdr, USN) was an American naval officer and aviator, test pilot, aeronautical engineer, and NASA astronaut.

He was the pilot of Space Shuttle Columbia mission STS-107. He and the rest of the crew of STS-107 were killed when Columbia disintegrated during re-entry into the atmosphere. He was the youngest male member of the crew. McCool was posthumously awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor.

[[Michael P. Anderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2003 deaths, American astronauts, Scientists from New York, Aviation deaths in the United States

Michael Phillip Anderson (December 25, 1959 – February 1, 2003) was a United States Air Force officer and NASA astronaut. Anderson and his six fellow crew members were killed in the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster when the craft disintegrated during its re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere.

[[David M. Brown]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2003 deaths, American astronauts, Aviation deaths in the United States, Scientists from Virginia, People from Arlington, Virginia

David McDowell Brown (April 16, 1956 – February 1, 2003) was a United States Navy captain and a NASA astronaut. He died on his first spaceflight, when the Space Shuttle Columbia (STS-107) disintegrated during orbital reentry into the Earth's atmosphere. 

Brown became an astronaut in 1996, but had not served on a space mission prior to the Columbia disaster. Brown was posthumously awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor.

[[Laurel Clark]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2003 deaths, Aviation deaths in the United States, American physicians, American astronauts, Scientists from Iowa

Laurel Blair Clark (née Salton; March 10, 1961 – February 1, 2003) was an American medical doctor, United States Navy Captain, NASA astronaut and Space Shuttle mission specialist. 

Clark died along with her six fellow crew members in the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.

[[Wakarusa, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Indiana

Wakarusa is a town in Harrison and Olive townships in Elkhart County, Indiana, United States. The population was 1,758 at the 2010 census.

[[Károly Fatér]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian footballers, Olympic gold medalists, Sportspeople from Budapest

Károly Fatér (9 April 1940 – 19 September 2020) was a Hungarian footballer. He was born in Veszprém County. He competed at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City, where he won a gold medal with the Hungarian team.

Fatér died on 19 September 2020 in Budapest, aged 80.

[[Steve Smith (pole vaulter)]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, American track and field athletes, American Olympians, People from Long Beach, California, Sportspeople from California

Stephen Norwood Smith (November 24, 1951 – September 23, 2020) was an American Olympic pole vaulter. He was the first person to clear the 18 foot barrier indoors.  He was the number one ranked pole vaulter in the world in 1973. Smith was born in Long Beach, California. He took part in the 1972 and 1980 Summer Olympics.

Smith died on September 23, 2020, in San Clemente, California. He was 68.

[[Vyacheslav Voynarovskii]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Russian singers, Russian movie actors, Russian stage actors, Russian television actors, Russian voice actors

Vyacheslav Igorevich Voinarovskiy (8 February 1946 – 24 September 2020) was a Russian opera singer and actor. He was born in Khabarovsk, Soviet Union. He was known for his roles in The Garage (1980), To Kill a Dragon (1989) and in Mother (1990). In 1999, he was honored as a People's Artist of Russia.

Voynarovskii died on 24 September 2020 from a long-illness in Moscow, aged 74.

[[Primordial nuclide]]

CATEGORIES: Primordial nuclides

Primordial nuclides are nuclides found on Earth which have existed since before the Earth was formed. They are also called primordial isotopes. 

Primordial nuclides are found in the interstellar medium. They were formed in or after the Big Bang, by nucleosynthesis in stars and supernovae. or by being hit by cosmic rays. Only 286 primordial nuclides are known.

There are 252 stable nuclides, plus another 34 nuclides that have half-lives long enough to have survived from the formation of the Earth. These are the primordial nuclides. The 34 primordial radionuclides are isotopes of 28 separate elements. 

[[Ramatuelle]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Var

Ramatuelle (Provençal: Ramatuela) is a commune in the Var department of the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in Southeastern France. In 2016, it had a population of 2,077.

[[Dudley Riggs]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Comedians from New York City, People from Little Rock, Arkansas, People from Minneapolis, Minnesota

Dudley Riggs (January 18, 1932 – September 22, 2020) was an American improvisational comedian. He created the Instant Theater Company in New York City. He later moved to Minneapolis to become a member of the Brave New Workshop comedy group. He was born in Little Rock, Arkansas.

Riggs died on September 22, 2020 in Minneapolis, aged 88.

[[Victory Gardens Theater]]

CATEGORIES: Theatres in Chicago

Victory Gardens Theater is a theater company in Chicago, Illinois dedicated to the creation and production of new plays and playwrights. It is located in the Lincoln Park area of the city near DePaul University.

The theater company was founded in 1974. Eight local actors gave $1,000 to start a company outside the Chicago Loop. The theater's first production, The Velvet Rose, by Stacy Myatt premiered on October 9, 1974. Since 2011, Chay Yew has continued their mission as the Artistic Director.

[[Victory Gardens, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Victory Gardens is a borough in Morris County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the borough's population was 1,520. 

[[Glory (1989 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 drama movies, 1980s war movies, American war movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Edward Zwick

Glory is a 1989 American war drama movie directed by Edward Zwick.

It is about the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment, the Union Army's first African-American regiment in the American Civil War.

It stars Matthew Broderick as Colonel Robert Gould Shaw and Denzel Washington, Cary Elwes, and Morgan Freeman as fictional members of the 54th.

Glory was nominated for five Academy Awards and won three, including Best Supporting Actor for Washington.

It premiered in limited release in the United States on December 14, 1989, and in wide release on February 16, 1990, making $27 million on an $18 million budget.

[[Cary Elwes]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Actors from London, British movie actors, British stage actors, British television actors, British voice actors, Writers from London

Ivan Simon Cary Elwes (ˈ; born 26 October 1962) is a British actor and writer. He is best known for his leading movie roles as Westley in The Princess Bride (1987), Robin Hood in Robin Hood: Men in Tights (1993), and Dr. Lawrence Gordon in the Saw movie series.

[[Edward Zwick]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winners, 1952 births, Living people, American television writers, American television directors, American television producers, Movie directors from Chicago, Movie producers from Chicago, Screenwriters from Chicago

Edward M. Zwick (born October 8, 1952) is an Emmy Award-winning American movie and television director, writer and producer. He was born in Chicago. His best known movies are About Last Night, Glory, Legends of the Fall, and The Last Samurai. He is also the co-creator of the television series thirtysomething and Once and Again.

[[Dean Jones (cricketer)]]

CATEGORIES: Sportspeople from Melbourne, 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Australian cricketers, Australian sports commentators

Dean Mervyn Jones AUS (24 March 1961 – 24 September 2020) was an Australian cricket commentator, coach and former cricketer. He played Tests and One Day Internationals for Australia. In 2019 Jones was added into the Australian Cricket Hall of Fame. He was born near Melbourne, Victoria. He played for Victoria, Derbyshire and the national team. He worked for The Sydney Morning Herald.

Jones died of cardiac arrest caused by a stroke at a Mumbai hospital on 24 September 2020 at the age of 59.

[[Vapor pressure]]

CATEGORIES: Thermodynamics

Vapor pressure is the pressure applied by a vapor in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases at a given temperature in a closed system. The vapor pressure shows how fast a liquid evaporates. A substance with a high vapor pressure at normal temperatures is often called a volatile.  As the temperature of a liquid increases, the kinetic energy of its molecules also increases. As the kinetic energy of the molecules increases, the number of molecules changing into a vapor also increases, so it increases the vapor pressure.

[[Cubic crystal system]]

CATEGORIES: Crystal systems, Cubes

In crystallography, the cubic crystal system is a crystal system where the unit cell is in the shape of a cube. This is one of the most common and simplest shapes found in crystals and minerals.

There are three main types of these crystals:

[[Paramagnetism]]

CATEGORIES: Magnetism

Paramagnetism is a form of magnetism whereby some materials are weakly attracted by an applied magnetic field and form induced magnetic fields in the direction of the magnetic field. Paramagnetic materials include most chemical elements and some compounds. They have a relative magnetic permeability that is a little bit higher than 1. The magnetic moment caused by the applied magnetic field is linear in the field strength and weak.

[[NGC 727]]

NGC 727 is a barred spiral galaxy in the Fornax constellation. It is about 446 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 731]]

CATEGORIES: Elliptical galaxies

NGC 731 is an elliptical galaxy in the Cetus constellation. It is about 172 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[NGC 732]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 732 is a lenticular galaxy in the Andromeda constellation. It is about 269 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Lisa Gartner]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners, George Polk Award winners, Year of birth missing (living people)

Lisa Gartner is an American journalist. She won a 2016 Pulitzer Prize for Local Reporting, and Livingston Award . In 2019, she won a George Polk Award. She graduated from Northwestern University. She worked for the the Washington Examiner, Tampa Bay Times, Philadelphia Inquirer, and San Francisco Chronicle. 

[[Baldringen]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Rhineland-Palatinate, Trier-Saarburg

[[Corine Rottschäfer]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch models, Miss World winners, People from North Holland

Corine Spier-Rottschäfer (8 May 1938 – 24 September 2020) was a Dutch model and beauty queen. She won the 1959 Miss World contest, representing the Netherlands.  She was the first woman from her country to win the title. The pageant was held in London, United Kingdom. Rottschäfer was born in Hoorn, Netherlands.

Rottschäfer died on 24 September 2020 at the age of 82.

[[Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac]]

CATEGORIES: 1778 births, 1850 deaths, French chemists, French physicists, People from Nouvelle-Aquitaine

Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac (6 December 1778 – 9 May 1850) was a French chemist and physicist. He is mostly known because he discovered that water is made up of two atoms of hydrogen and one atom oxygen with Alexander von Humboldt. He is also known for two laws related to gases with temperature and for his work on alcohol and water mixtures.

[[Bobby Wilson (tennis)]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Tennis players, English sportspeople, People from Middlesex

Robert Keith Wilson (22 November 1935 – 22 September 2020) was a top-ranking English tennis player. Wilson reached the quarterfinals of Wimbledon four times, Forest Hills twice, and Roland Garros once during the late 1950s and early 1960s. He was also a well known Great Britain Davis Cup team member. Wilson was born in Hendon, Middlesex.

Wilson died on 22 September 2020 in Finchley, Middlesex at the age of 84.

[[Cara Fitzpatrick]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners, George Polk Award winners, Year of birth missing (living people)

Cara Fitzpatrick is an American journalist. She won a 2016 Pulitzer Prize in Local Reporting. and 2015 George Polk Award. In 2018, she was a Spencer Fellow. In 2019, she was a New Arizona Fellow. She graduated from University of Washington, and the Columbia University School of Journalism. She worked for the Tampa Bay Times.  She is an editor at Chalkbeat.

[[Pearson's green tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

Pearson's green tree frog, Pearson's tree frog, the mountain stream tree frog, cascade tree frog or Cedar Creek tree frog (Ranoidea pearsoniana) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland and New South Wales, from 200 to 1000 metres above sea level.

This frog lives in forests where the trees are close together.  It lives in fast-flowing streams in the forest.  It hides under rocks during the day and looks for food at night.  The females lay eggs in pools where the water does not flow fast, 360-730 at a time.  The eggs stick to the undersides of rocks or to plants or to the bottom of the pool.  The tadpoles become frogs after 2 to 2.5 months.

[[European Canoe Slalom Championships]]

CATEGORIES: European Canoe Slalom Championships, Boat racing, European championships

The European Canoe Slalom Championships is an annual international canoeing and kayaking event organized by the European Canoe Association (ECA) since 1996. Until 2004 it was held every two years.

[[European Canoe Sprint Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Boat racing, Sport in Europe

The Canoe Sprint European Championships is an international canoeing and kayaking event organized by the European Canoe Association (ECA). It was first held in 1933 in Prague under the auspices of the International Canoe Federation. In 1997, the European Championships were resumed, and now take place annually.

[[World Canoe Slalom Championships]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 establishments, Boat racing, Sports competitions

The ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships are an international event in canoeing organized by the International Canoe Federation. The World Championships have taken place every year in non-Summer Olympic years since 2002. From 1949 to 1999, they had taken place in odd-numbered years. The 2001 championships were scheduled to take place in Ducktown, Tennessee (East of Chattanooga) from 20 to 23 September, but were canceled in the wake of the September 11 attacks.

[[European Canoe Association]]

CATEGORIES: Water sports, Sports governing bodies in Europe

The European Canoe Association (ECA) is the umbrella organization for canoeing sport in Europe. It was founded in Rome, Italy, on December 11, 1993. The organization has 45 member countries. The association was recognized by the International Canoe Federation at the ICF congress in Acapulco in 1994.

[[European Canoe Marathon Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Boat racing, Sport in Europe

The Canoe Marathon European Championships is an international canoe marathon event organised by the European Canoe Association. The first edition took place in 1995 and subsequent stagings were held every two years until 2013, after which it became an annual competition.

[[European Shooting Championships]]

CATEGORIES: European Shooting Championships, European championships, Sport shooting

The European Shooting Championships are the global sport shooting European championships as regards the disciplines of the sport shooting.

[[European Gymnastics Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Gymnastics

The European Union of Gymnastics organises European Gymnastics Championships for each of the following gymnastics disciplines:

[[European Union of Gymnastics]]

CATEGORIES: Gymnastics, Sports governing bodies in Europe, 1982 establishments in Europe

European Gymnastics is one of five continental unions that represents the interests of Europe in the Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique. It was formed on 27 March 1982.

[[European Inline Speed Skating Championships]]

CATEGORIES: European championships, 1989 establishments in Europe, Inline speed skating competitions

The European Inline Speed Skating Championships is the main inline speed skating championships in Europe, organized by European Confederation of Roller Skating.

[[European Badminton Championships]]

CATEGORIES: European Badminton Championships, International badminton competitions, European championships, Badminton, Badminton tournaments in Europe

The European Badminton Championships is a tournament organized by the Badminton Europe (BE).

[[Badminton Europe]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 establishments in Europe, Sports governing bodies in Europe, Badminton

Badminton Europe (BE) is the governing body of badminton in Europe. It is one of the five continental bodies under the flag of the Badminton World Federation (BWF). It now has 53 member associations and 1 associate member. It was founded on 27 September 1967 in Frankfurt, Germany.

On its annual meeting held on 8 April 2006 the members decided to change the name from European Badminton Union (EBU), to Badminton Europe (BE).

[[University of Kashmir]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s establishments in India, 1948 establishments in Asia, Colleges and universities in India, Jammu and Kashmir

The University of Kashmir (also known as Kashmir University and abbreviated as KU) is a university located in Srinagar, in the Indian Union territory of Jammu and Kashmir.

Talat Ahmad was appointed as the Vice Chancelor of the KU in August 2018.

[[Johnson County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Johnson County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 18,244 people lived there. The county seat is Mountain City.

[[Heartbreaker (song)]]

CATEGORIES: Pop songs, 1999 songs, Mariah Carey songs

"Heartbreaker" is a pop song under singer-songwriter Mariah Carey. The song was released on September 21, 1999 in North America. The song samples the 1982 pop song "Attack of the Name Game" under Stacy Lattisaw. "Heartbreaker" is about a relationship from a female perspective; the protagonist returns to her lover. But her lover constantly cheats on her.

"Heartbreaker" received mixed music reviews from critics. A number of critics felt the song wasn't original in terms of a creative step forward. However, it hit #1 on the United States Billboard Hot 100 and the Canadian Singles Chart.

In the video, Carey played two women: herself and a woman named Bianca. There was a physical fight between these two women in a movie theater.

[[Lauderdale County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Lauderdale County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 27,815 people lived there. The county seat is Ripley.

[[Gerhard Weber (designer)]]

CATEGORIES: Fashion designers, German businesspeople, 1941 births, 2020 deaths, People from North Rhine-Westphalia

Gerhard Weber (3 June 1941 – 24 September 2020) was a German fashion designer and entrepreneur. He founded Gerry Weber, a fashion manufacturer and retailer in Halle, North Rhine-Westphalia. He sponsored sports, especially tennis, and built a stadium named after the company. Weber was born in Halle.

Weber died on 24 September 2020 in Münster, Germany at the age of 79.

[[John J. Myers]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, American Roman Catholics, People from Peoria, Illinois

John Joseph Myers (July 26, 1941 – September 24, 2020) was an American prelate of the Catholic Church. He was Bishop of Peoria between 1990 and 2001, Ecclesiastical Superior of Turks and Caicos from 2001 to 2016 and Archbishop of Newark during the same time. Myers was born in Earlville, Illinois.

Myers died on September 24, 2020 in Ottawa, Illinois at the age of 79. 

[[John Walter Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Welsh politicians, Business people

John Walter Jones (28 March 1946 – 24 September 2020) was a Welsh civil servant and executive. He was the first Chief Executive of the Welsh Language Board, a post which he held between 1993 and 2004. Jones was born in Moelfre, Anglesey.

Jones died in September 2020 at the age of 74. 

[[Ray Batten]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, English rugby union players, Sportspeople from Yorkshire, People from York

Raymond "Ray" Batten (23 September 1945 – 23 September 2020) was an English professional rugby league footballer. He was born in York, Yorkshire. He played in the 1960s and 1970s, and coached in the 1980s. 

He played at representative level for Great Britain and England, and at club level for Heworth ARLFC and Leeds. He coached at club level for Wakefield Trinity.

Batten died on his 75th birthday on 23 September 2020.

[[Brenda Robertson]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, People from New Brunswick, Canadian politicians

Brenda Mary Robertson, CM, ONB (May 23, 1929 – September 23, 2020) was a Canadian Conservative politician. She was a Senator from New Brunswick between 1984 to 2004. She was the first woman elected to the Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick and the first woman to become a cabinet minister in the province. She was born in Sussex, New Brunswick.

Robertson died on September 23, 2020 in Riverview, New Brunswick at the age of 91.

[[Moelfre, Anglesey]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Wales, Anglesey

Moelfre (ˈmɔɨ̯lvrɛ) is a village, a community and until 2012 an electoral ward on the north-east coast of the Isle of Anglesey in Wales. 

The 2011 census measured the village population as 710.

Collin Priest is a Dutch songwriter and record producer based in North Brabant. Collin is better known for his dance music.

[[Dualism (philosophy of mind)]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophy

Dualism is the belief that minds and bodies are separate things. One of the main dualist views comes from René Descartes and is named Cartesian dualism after him. It is also called substance dualism because he thought that minds and bodies were two completely different substances (like matter) in the world.

[[Muammar Z.A.]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Indonesian people, Islamic religious leaders, Living people, Muslims, Quran reciters, Religious workers

Muammar Zainal Abedin (معمر زين العابدین, born June 14, 1954) sometimes shortened Muammar ZA or Muammar Z.A. is a popular senior Qari or Qur'an reciter and Hafiz from Indonesia well known nationally and internationally.

[[2020 Hungarian Grand Prix]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in sports, July 2020 events

The 2020 Hungarian Grand Prix (officially known as the Formula 1 Aramco Magyar Nagydíj 2020) was a Formula One motor race. It started on 19 July 2020 at the Hungaroring in Mogyoród, Hungary. The race was the third round of the 2020 Formula One World Championship. It was the 36th running of the Hungarian Grand Prix. It was also the 35th time the race had been run as a World Championship event. Lewis Hamilton was the winner of this Grand Prix. It was his second win in a row of the 2020 season and his eighth at the Hungaroring.

[[Isotopes of oxygen]]

CATEGORIES: Isotopes

There are three known stable isotopes of oxygen: 16O, 17O, and 18O. Oxygen also has radioisotopes ranging from 11O to 26O. They all have short half-lives. The longest-lived radioisotope is 15O. It has a half-life of 122.24 seconds. The shortest-lived radioisotope is 12O. It has a half-life of 580(30)×10−24 seconds.

[[Raoul Pictet]]

CATEGORIES: 1846 births, 1929 deaths, Swiss scientists, Physicists, People from Geneva

Raoul-Pierre Pictet (4 April 1846 – 27 July 1929) was a Swiss physicist. He was the first person to liquefy nitrogen.

[[That Wonderful Urge]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies

That Wonderful Urge is a 1948 American romantic comedy movie directed by Robert B. Sinclair and was based on the 1937 remake Love Is News. It stars Gene Tierney, Tyrone Power, Reginald Gardiner, Arleen Whelan, Lucile Watson, Gene Lockhart, Lloyd Gough and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Dyne]]

CATEGORIES: Units of measurement

The dyne is a unit of force stated in the centimetre-gram-second system of units. It is a predecessor of the modern SI. The name dyne was first proposed as a CGS unit of force in 1873 by a Committee of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. The dyne per centimetre is a unit used to measure surface tension.

[[Manorial Lordship of Caldecote]]

Manorial Lordship of Caldecote or Lord of Manor of Caldecote is the ownership title of Caldecote Manor and its land, located in Newport, Pagnell, Buckinghamshire. It was introduced after the Norman Invasion. Urian Brereton was the first person to acquire this title. Paul G. Guppy holds the legal rights of the title as per the contract drawn up between him and the Manorial Counsel Limited on October 13, 2016, in compliance with the Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act 1925 (Hatton Solicitors).

[[Meniscus (liquid)]]

CATEGORIES: Fluid mechanics

[[Iodomethane]]

CATEGORIES: Iodine compounds

Iodomethane is a chemical compound. Its chemical formula is CH3I. It is also called methyl iodide. It is commonly abbreviated as "MeI". It is a dense, colorless, volatile liquid. It is naturally released by rice plantations in small amounts. It is also made in large quantities by algae and kelp in the world's temperate oceans. It is made in small amounts on land by fungi and bacteria. It is used in organic synthesis as a source of methyl groups.

[[Evangelista Torricelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1608 births, 1647 deaths, Italian physicists, Italian mathematicians, Deaths from typhoid fever

Evangelista Torricelli (15 October 1608 – 25 October 1647) was an Italian physicist and mathematician. He was a student of Galileo. He is known for his invention of the barometer. He is also known for improving the field of optics and his work on the method of indivisibles.

Torricelli died from typhoid fever in Florence on 25 October 1647 at the age of 39.

[[Death and state funeral of Richard Nixon]]

CATEGORIES: Richard Nixon, State funerals, 1994 in California, April events

On April 22, 1994, Richard Milhous Nixon, the 37th President of the United States, died after having a stroke

four days earlier, at the age of 81. His state funeral followed five days later at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum in his hometown of Yorba Linda, California. His death was the first Presidential death in 21 years, since President Lyndon B. Johnson's death in 1973. 

[[Death and state funeral of Gerald Ford]]

CATEGORIES: Gerald Ford, 2006 in the United States, 2007 in the United States, State funerals, December events

On December 26, 2006, Gerald Ford, the 38th President of the United States, died at his home in Rancho Mirage, California at 6:45 p.m. local time (02:45, December 27, UTC).
