Jannine Weigel (Thai: ญานนีน ภารวี ไวเกล; born 30 July 2000) is a Thai singer and actor with Thai and German ancestry. Her works (Music) on YouTube made her known. She was an artist under GMM Grammy and now an independent artist in Germany.

[[Saint Anthony Falls]]

CATEGORIES: Waterfalls, Landforms of the United States, Geography of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota

Saint Anthony Falls was a large waterfall. It is found northeast of downtown Minneapolis, Minnesota. It was the only large natural waterfall on the Upper Mississippi River. It was also called the Falls of Saint Anthony. The natural falls were replaced by a spillway after it collapsed in 1869.

[[Fishkeeping]]

CATEGORIES: Hobbies, Fish

Fishkeeping is a popular hobby, done by aquarists. It is concerned with keeping fish in a home aquarium or garden pond. Fish have been raised as food in pools and ponds for thousands of years.

[[NGC 734]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 734 is a lenticular galaxy in the Cetus constellation. It is about 538 million light-years away from the Milky Way.

[[Peppered tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The peppered tree frog or Black Creek tree frog, speckled leaf tree frog or speckled tree frog (Ranoidea piperata) is a frog from Australia.  Scientists saw it on the New England Tableland in New South Wales.  Scientists have seen it between 800 and 1120 metres above sea level.

This frog is in danger of dying out.  It might already be extinct.  Scientists have not seen this frog for sure since 1973.  Some scientists saw and heard a frog that looked like the peppered tree frog in the 1990s, but their voices sounded different.  In the 1990s, scientists decided that they needed to study the genes and DNA of this frog and its relatives before they could truly say which were separate species and which were not.  Its relatives are Ranoidea barringtonensis, Ranoidea pearsoniana, and Ranoidea phyllochroa.

Scientists are not sure why this frog is dying out.  Many of the streams where it used to live have been changed by human beings who wanted to graze animals there.  These streams also have invasive species, for example the mosquitofish, which eats tadpoles.

[[Pan American Cycling Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Pan American Road and Track Championships, Road bicycle races, Track cycling races, Cycle races

The Pan American Road and Track Championships are the continental cycling championships for road bicycle racing and track cycling held annually for member nations of the Pan American Cycling Confederation.  Riders competing in the Pan American Cycling Championships are selected by the national governing body.

The European Confederation of Roller Skating (Confédération Européenne de Roller Skating, or CERS) was the main European roller skating organization. The CERS was part of the International Roller Sports Federation or FIRS. Varieties of skating governed by the CERS included:

[[World Skate Europe]]

CATEGORIES: Roller skating organizations, Sports governing bodies in Europe

World Skate Europe - Rink Hockey, formerly known as Comité Européen de Rink-Hockey, is a technical committee responsible for the governing of rink hockey (or roller hockey) in Europe. World Skate Europe is one of the 5 regions governed by World Skate.

[[World Skate]]

CATEGORIES: Roller skating organizations

World Skate is the current IOC recognised organisational body for roller sports, including skateboarding, rink hockey, inline hockey, inline speed skating, inline alpine, downhill, roller derby, roller freestyle, inline freestyle, Freestyle scootering, aggressive inline skating, inline figure skating and artistic roller skating. The organisation is the result of the merger of the Fédération Internationale de Roller Sports (FIRS) and the International Skateboarding Federation (ISF) in September 2017 after the ISF's involvement with the scheduled skateboarding events at the Japan 2020 Olympics were rejected.

[[Confederation of Asian Roller Sports]]

CATEGORIES: Roller skating organizations

The Confederation of Asia Roller Sports (CARS) is the main roller skating organization of Asia.  The CARS is part of the International Roller Sports Federation. 

[[International Roller Sports Federation]]

CATEGORIES: Roller skating organizations

The Fédération Internationale de Roller Sports (FIRS; International Federation of Roller Sports) was the world governing body for roller sports.

[[Sunbird]]

CATEGORIES: Passeriformes

Sunbirds and spiderhunters make up the family Nectariniidae. They are small, slender passerines from the Old World, usually with downward-curved bills. Many are brightly coloured, with iridescent feathers, especially the males. Many species have long tail feathers. They live mainly in equatorial regions. There are 145 species in 16 genera.  

Most sunbirds feed largely on nectar, but will also eat insects and spiders, especially when feeding their young. Long narrow flowers are punctured at the base near the nectaries, where the birds get the nectar. Fruit is also often part of their diet. 

The sunbirds have similarities with two distantly related groups: the hummingbirds of the Americas and the honeyeaters of Australia. The resemblances are due to convergent evolution. They all have a similar nectar-feeding lifestyle. Some sunbird species can take nectar by hovering like a hummingbird, but they usually perch to feed.

[[Sarmatians]]

CATEGORIES: Iranian people, Ethnic groups in Asia, History of Ukraine, History of Russia

The Sarmatians (s; Sarmatae, Sauromatae) were groups of Iranic peoples that lived in a region called Sarmatia that is the present day Ukraine near the Black Sea shore. They were flourishing from 5th century BC to the 4-5th century AD.

[[Desmond Child]]

[[Bruce Fairbairn]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 1999 deaths, Record producers, Musicians from Vancouver

Bruce Earl Fairbairn (December 30, 1949 – May 17, 1999) was a Canadian musician and record producer. He was born in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Fairbairn was active as a producer from 1976 to 1999. His most successful productions are Slippery When Wet and New Jersey by Bon Jovi, Permanent Vacation, Pump, and Get a Grip by Aerosmith, The Razors Edge by AC/DC, and Balance by Van Halen, each of which sold at least five million copies. He was a trumpet player, then started a career as a record producer for the Canadian rock band Prism. He won the Canadian music industry Producer of the Year Juno Award three times. He produced albums for many well-known international artists such as Loverboy, Blue Öyster Cult, Bon Jovi, Poison, Aerosmith, AC/DC, Scorpions, Van Halen, Chicago, The Cranberries, INXS, Kiss and Yes.

Fairbairn died suddenly on May 17, 1999 due to unknown causes.

[[Bob Rock]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Record producers, Musicians from Vancouver, Living people

Robert Jens Rock (born April 19, 1954) is a Canadian musician, sound engineer, and record producer. He is best known for producing rock bands and music artists such as Metallica, Mötley Crüe, Bon Jovi, Aerosmith, the Tragically Hip,  the Cult, 311, Our Lady Peace, Bryan Adams, the Offspring, Michael Bublé, Black Veil Brides, David Lee Roth, and Ron Sexsmith.

[[Shady Records]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in New York (state), 1999 establishments in the United States, American record labels, Eminem, Music in New York City

Shady Records is an American record label founded in 1999 by rapper Eminem and his manager Paul Rosenberg, after the highly successful release of Eminem's The Slim Shady LP. Both serve as the label's presidents.

[[2020 Formula One World Championship]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in sports, Formula One seasons

The 2020 Formula One World Championship was the 71st season of the Formula One World Championship. The motor racing championship is the highest class of competition for open-wheel racing cars.

The 2020 season was delayed by the COVID-19 pandemic, and started in Austria on 5 July and finished in Abu Dhabi on 13 December.

[[Marise Payne]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Australian ministers for Foreign Affairs, Liberal Party of Australia politicians, Members of the Australian Senate, Politicians from Sydney

Marise Ann Payne (born 29 July 1964) is an Australian politician. She has been Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Morrison Government since 2018. She was also named Minister for Women in 2019. She is a member of the Liberal Party. She has been a Senator for New South Wales since 1997.

Payne was born in Sydney. She is in a relationship with New South Wales politician Stuart Ayres.

[[Stieg Larsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Socialists, Swedish journalists, Swedish novelists

Karl Stig-Erland "Stieg" Larsson (15 August 1954 – 9 November 2004) was a Swedish journalist and writer. He became best known after his death for his Millennium trilogy of crime novels. His books were published from 2005 to 2007. The series was made into three movies in Sweden and one in the United States. After his death in 2004, David Lagercrantz continued the series. As a journalist, Larsson's work covered socialist politics. He was an independent researcher of right-wing extremism.

Larsson was born in Skelleftehamn. In the 1970s, he changed the spelling of his first name to "Stieg" as his friend, Stig Larsson, was already a well-known writer. His partner of thirty years was Eva Gabrielsson.

Larsson died of a heart attack in Stockholm on 9 November 2004. He was 50.

[[Cradleboard]]

CATEGORIES: Babies, Human-powered vehicles

When children are infants, they need to be carried around a lot.  Indigenous cultures in North America and throughout northern Scandinavia have come up with a structure they called Cradleboard. Cradleboards are baby-carriers that protect the baby.  In Cheyenne, a cradleboard is called pâhoešestôtse or ☃☃, in Skolt Sami it is called ǩiõtkâmpâhoešestôtse or ǩiõtkâm. There are different styles of cradleboard; each culture has its own style or styles. Some communities still use cradleboards. 

[[The Barkleys of Broadway]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by Charles Walters

The Barkleys of Broadway is a 1949 American musical movie directed by Charles Walters and starring Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Oscar Levant, Billie Burke, Gale Robbins, Jacques François, Clinton Sundberg, George Zucco. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1950.

[[Localism (politics)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics

Localism is the ideology of prioritizing localization over imports and exports in order to supply consumers with their needs. 

Localism in agriculture is when local consumers rely on their local products rather than imports to supply themselves.

[[Nolan Gould]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, American child actors, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from New York City, Living people

Nolan Gould (born October 28, 1998) is an American actor. He is known for his role as Luke Dunphy on the ABC sitcom Modern Family.

[[Intraplate earthquake]]

CATEGORIES: Earthquakes

An intraplate earthquake is an earthquake that does not occur at the border of one tectonic plate, but inside the plate. Most earthquakes occur at the boundary of different plates. An example of an intraplate earthquake is the 1811-12 New Madrid Earthquake.

[[When My Baby Smiles at Me]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies based on plays, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Walter Lang

When My Baby Smiles at Me is a 1948 American musical movie directed by Walter Lang and is the third adaption of the 1927 play Burlesque. It stars Betty Grable, Dan Dailey, Jack Oakie, June Havoc, Richard Arlen, James Gleason and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1949.

[[Gentleman's Agreement]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Elia Kazan, 20th Century Fox movies

Gentleman's Agreement is a 1947 American drama movie directed by Elia Kazan and was based on the 1947 novel of the same name by Laura Z. Hobson. It stars Gregory Peck, Dorothy McGuire, John Garfield, Celeste Holm, June Havoc, Anne Revere, Dean Stockwell and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for eight and won three Oscars in 1948.

[[State Fair (1945 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 movies, 1940s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by Walter Lang

State Fair is a 1945 American musical movie directed by Walter Lang and starring Jeanne Crain, Dana Andrews, Dick Haymes, Vivian Blaine, Fay Bainter, Charles Winninger. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and won 1 Oscar in 1946.

[[The Fortune Cookie]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 comedy movies, American black comedy movies, Movies directed by Billy Wilder

[[Eastern water-holding frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The eastern water-holding frog, flat-headed frog, common water-holding frog or water-holding frog (Ranoidea platycephala) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in the dry middle of the country in Queensland, Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales.

The adult frog is from 6.0 to 9.0 cm long.  It is dark in color or mottled green. This frog lives in many kinds of land, for example grasslands, temporary wetlands, and Australian wetlands called billabongs.  When the weather is dry, this frog digs a burrow in the ground and saves water.  It lays eggs, 500 at a time, when the ground floods and makes temporary pools.

[[Black Feather Messengers (Album)]]

Black Feather Messengers is the debut album from Bedlam Brethren, a rap group made up of American rappers Hollow Christ (also known as Udi the Erratic Assassin), Cheating Death (also known as Merc Versus), and New Zealand record producer and rapper Spearman. It was released independently through Invisible Inc and 116 Productions. The album features appearances from Chief Kamachi, Kevlaar 7, Thirstin Howl the 3rd, C-Rayz Walz, and Verbal Godz.

Blogger Copper Tony of The Hip Hop Speakeasy said in his review of this album: "This New York/New Zealand based hip hop trio, consisting of emcees Udi the Erratic Assassin, Cheating Death and producer Spearman, come swinging out the gate with 14 tracks of the Brethren’s own unique The Roots-meets-Cypress Hill sound. Dope rhyme schemes and clever wordplay flow freely over the dark & mysterious, yet soulfully optimistic beats of Spearman."

[[Joanna Janetakis]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, American movie actors, Actors from New York City, Living people

Joanna Janetakis (born May 27, 1992) is a Greek and Egyptian actress and writer. She is known for Either Side Of Midnight (2021) What Children Do (2017), Wallows: 1980s Horror Film (2018) and The Wisdom Tooth (2019). Born in New York City.

Joanna studied at Yale University in a drama intensive. Only five actors were chosen for the "Acting In Film" Intensive. In 2011 Joanna had a supporting role in the short film "VR" which made the official Selection at the Cannes Film Festival.

[[Lady in the Lake]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s crime movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books

Lady in the Lake is a 1947 American crime drama movie directed by Robert Montgomery (who also stars) and was based on the 1943 novel of the same name by Raymond Chandler. It also stars Audrey Totter, Lloyd Nolan, Leon Ames, Audrey Meadows, Kathleen Lockhart. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Westlink M7]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in Australia, Transport in Sydney

The Westlink M7 Motorway or Westlink M7 – formerly Western Sydney Orbital – is one of Sydney's urban motorways and a part of the Sydney Orbital Network. It is a tolled motorway that is owned and operated by NorthWestern Roads Group (NWR) and connects three motorways: M5 South Western Motorway at Prestons, M4 Western Motorway at Eastern Creek and M2 Hills Motorway at Baulkham Hills. It opened on 16 December 2005, eight months ahead of schedule.

[[Kiss of Death (1947 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s thriller movies, American crime thriller movies, Movies based on short stories, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

Kiss of Death is a 1947 American crime thriller movie directed by Henry Hathaway and was based on the short story by Eleazar Lipsky. It stars Victor Mature, Brian Donlevy, Coleen Gray, Mildred Dunnock, Richard Widmark, Karl Malden and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1948 and was remade in 1995.

[[Whatever Works]]

Whatever Works is a 2009 American French romantic comedy movie directed by Woody Allen and starring Larry David, Ed Begley Jr., Henry Cavill, Evan Rachel Wood, Patricia Clarkson, Carolyn McCormick, Jessica Hecht, Michael McKean. It was distributed by Sony Pictures Classics.

[[The Ghost and Mrs. Muir]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s romance movies, American fantasy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz

The Ghost and Mrs. Muir is a 1947 American romantic fantasy movie directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and was based on the 1945 novel by Josephine Leslie. It stars Gene Tierney, Rex Harrison, George Sanders, Edna Best, Vanessa Brown, Natalie Wood, Victoria Horne, Isobel Elsom. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1948. It was spun off in a television series in 1968.

[[Vallées-d'Antraigues-Asperjoc]]

Vallées-d'Antraigues-Asperjoc is a commune of the Ardèche department, in the southern part of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Antraigues-sur-Volane (the seat) and Asperjoc.

[[The Shocking Miss Pilgrim]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical movies, American comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by George Seaton

The Shocking Miss Pilgrim is a 1947 American musical comedy movie directed by George Seaton and starring Betty Grable, Dick Haymes, Anne Revere, Gene Lockhart, Elizabeth Patterson, Allyn Joslyn, Arthur Shields, Charles Kemper, Elisabeth Risdon, Marilyn Monroe. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was a box office disappointment.

[[Goran Paskaljević]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, People from Belgrade, Movie directors from Paris

Goran Paskaljević (Горан Паскаљевић; ɡɔ̌ran paskǎːʎɛvit͡ɕ; 22 April 1947 – 25 September 2020) was a Serbian-French movie director. He was born in Belgrade. 

Paskaljević lived between Belgrade and Paris and he held both Serbian and French citizenship. As of 2008 he was named Officer of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.

He died on 25 September 2020 in Paris, aged 73.

[[Lord Alfred Hayes]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2005 deaths, Wrestling in Europe, Wrestlers, Officers of the Order of the British Empire

Alfred George James Hayes, GBR (8 August 1928 – 21 July 2005) he is English professional wrestler, manager, announcer in wrestling. Best known for his appearances in the United States with the World Wrestling Federation between 1982 and 1995 where he was known as Lord Alfred Hayes.

[[Yūko Takeuchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese movie actors, Japanese television actors, Japanese voice actors, Japanese stage actors, People who committed suicide

Yūko Takeuchi was a Japanese actress. She was born in Urawa, Saitama. Her career began in 1996. She was best known for her roles as Tomoko in Ring (1998), Miss Sherlock (2018) and in FlashForward (2009–2010).

Takeuchi committed suicide at her Tokyo apartment on September 27, 2020 at the age of 40.

[[Jacques Beurlet]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian footballers

Jacques Beurlet (21 December 1944 – 26 September 2020) was a Belgian footballer. He was born in Marche-en-Famenne, Belgium. During his career he played for R. Standard de Liège. He appeared for the Belgium national football team.

Beurlet died on 26 September 2020 at the age of 75.

[[Hélène Langevin-Joliot]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, French physicists, French educators, Scientists from Paris

Hélène Langevin-Joliot (born 19 September 1927) is a French nuclear physicist. Her parents were Irène Joliot-Curie and Frédéric Joliot-Curie. She is a member of the French government's advisory committee. 

She is a professor of nuclear physics at the Institute of Nuclear Physics at the University of Paris and a director of research at the CNRS.

[[Frédéric Joliot-Curie]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1958 deaths, French physicists, Scientists from Paris

ChemistryJean Frédéric Joliot-Curie (fʁedeʁik ʒɔljo kyʁi; né Joliot; 19 March 1900 – 14 August 1958) was a French physicist.

He was the husband of Irène Joliot-Curie. Both were given the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1935 for their discovery of artificial radioactivity. 

He founded with his wife Irène Joliot-Curie the Orsay Faculty of Sciences, part of the Paris-Saclay University.

[[Pierre Joliot]]

CATEGORIES: French biologists, French chemists, Scientists from Paris, French educators, Living people, 1932 births

Pierre Adrien Joliot-Curie (born 12 March 1932) is a French biologist and researcher for the CNRS. He became a Director of Research in 1974 and a member of their scientific council in 1992. 

He was a scientific advisor to the French Prime Minister from 1985 to 1986 and is a member of Academia Europæa. He was made a commander of the Ordre National du Mérite (English: the National Order of Merit) in 1982 and of the Légion d'honneur (English: Legion of Honor) in 1984. He was born in Paris.

His grandparents, Marie and Pierre Curie together with Henri Becquerel won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903 for their study of radioactivity. Marie also won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911.  Joliot's parents, Irène Joliot-Curie and Frédéric Joliot-Curie, won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1935.

[[Academia Europaea]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 establishments in Europe, Education, Europe

The Academia Europaea is the pan-European Academy of Humanities, Letters, Law, and Sciences.

The Academia was founded in 1988. It focuses on all fields of scholarly inquiry. It acts as co-ordinator of European interests in national research agencies.

[[Jimmy Winston]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Keyboardists, English rock musicians, English stage actors, English television actors, English movie actors, Actors from London, Musicians from London, Singers from London

James Edward Winston Langwith (20 April 1945 – 26 September 2020), known professionally as Jimmy Winston, was an English musician and actor. He was the original keyboard player with Small Faces. He was born in London. As an actor, his best known roles were in Hair and the 1972 Doctor Who serial Day of the Daleks.

Winston died on 26 September 2020 at the age of 75.

[[Mill Creek (conservation area)]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Virginia

Protected natural area in Virginia, United States

The area, a valley between two mountain ridges with many cliffs, rocky outcrops and an almost impenetrable vegetation, has the sense of being isolated from the civilized world although it is not far from nearby towns.  Several trails give access to the area.

The area is part of the Angels Rest Cluster.

[[Liliane Weissberg]]

CATEGORIES: living people, Harvard University alumni

Liliane Weissberg is Christopher H. Browne Distinguished Professor in Arts and Sciences and Professor of German and Comparative Literature at the University of Pennsylvania. 

Weissberg's work has been supported, among others, by the Alexander von Humboldt Research Prize, the Anna-Maria Kellen Fellowship at the American Academy in Berlin, and a Guggenheim Fellowship. She has published widely on German, American, and French Literature of late eighteenth, nineteenth, and early twentieth centuries, and on German-Jewish culture.

[[François Tronchin]]

CATEGORIES: 1704 births, 1798 deaths, Swiss lawyers, Bankers, People from Geneva

François Tronchin (23 October 1704 – 7 February 1798) was a Swiss lawyer, banker, and collector. 

He knew many artists, Jean-Pierre Saint-Ours, Joseph Vernet, Jean-Baptiste Lemoyne, Étienne-Maurice Falconet, Nicolas Henri Joseph de Fassin, and philosophers, Voltaire, Denis Diderot, and Melchior Grimm.

He sold many paintings in his collection to Catherine II of Russia.

[[Rio Vista Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Airports in California

The Rio Vista Airport is a 273 acre, $13 million general use airport in Rio Vista, California.

[[Red Lady of Paviland]]

CATEGORIES: Archaeology

Red Lady of Paviland is the name of an almost complete  skeleton, which was found in a cave about 20 from Swansea, in 1823. It was the first time, there was a scientific publication on the find of an anatomically modern man. The skeleton turned out to be 33.000 years old, and was probably among the first people on the British Isles.

The skeleton was painted with red ochre.  As pearls and ivory was found nearby, the skeleton was first thought to be that of a woman. William Buckland who found it, thought that it must have been that of a witch or a prosititute during the Roman Era Britain. In 1968, radiocarbo dating was done, and the skeleton was found to be about 22.000 years old. The man had been bout 21, at the time of his death. The age of 22.000 years was problematic though: it meant that the British Isles would have been settled during a time when it was very cold. Another dating was done in 1989; it found an age of 33.000 years. Another dating, done in 2008, gave an age of 33.000 years. 33.000 years ago, there was one of the warmer periods of the ice age. 

Today , the skeleton is kept at the Oxford Museum of Natural History.

[[Helga Weisz]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births

Helga Weisz (born 1961 Villach) is an Austrian climate scientist. She is a researcher at Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research. She is editor–in-chief of the journal GAIA.

She graduated from University of Vienna, and from Humboldt University Berlin. She was visiting scholar, at University of Queensland.

She is a professor at Humboldt University Berlin.

[[Wake in Fright]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 drama movies, 1971 thriller movies, 1970s LGBT movies, Australian drama movies, British drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Ted Kotcheff, Movies set in deserts

Wake in Fright is a 1971 Australian British American drama thriller movie directed by Ted Kotcheff and was based on the 1961 novel of the same name by Kenneth Cook. It stars Gary Bond, Donald Pleasence, Chips Rafferty, Jack Thompson, John Meillon and was distributed by United Artists.

[[John D. Barrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, English physicists, English mathematicians, Scientists from London, Writers from London

John David Barrow GBR (29 November 1952 – 26 September 2020) was an English cosmologist, theoretical physicist, and mathematician. He was Gresham Professor of Geometry at Gresham College from 2008 to 2011. 

Barrow was also a writer of popular science and an amateur playwright.

Barrow died on 27 September 2020 from colon cancer, aged 62.

[[Bah Ndaw]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Presidents of Mali

Bah Ndaw (also spelled N'Daw, N'Dah, and N'Daou; born 23 August 1950) is a Malian military officer and politician. He became the President of Mali on 25 September 2020. Between May 2014 and January 2015, he was Minister of Defense.

On 24 May 2021, Ndaw and Prime Minister Moctar Ouane were arrested by the military and taken to Kati military base nearby Malian capital Bamako. The next day, the UN Chief António Guterres called for their immediate release.

On August 27, 2021, Bah N'daw was released from house arrest.

[[Medium Cool]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 drama movies, American drama movies

Medium Cool is a 1969 American drama movie directed by Haskell Wexler and starring Robert Forster, Verna Bloom, Peter Boyle, Peter Bonerz, Marianna Hill, China Lee. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Mass Appeal]]

Mass Appeal is a 1984 American comedy-drama movie directed by Glenn Jordan and was based on the 1980 play of the same name by Bill C. Davis. It stars Jack Lemmon, Željko Ivanek, Charles Durning, Louise Latham, Talia Balsman and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Rachel and the Stranger]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s western movies, American western movies, Movies based on short stories, Movies directed by Norman Foster

Rachel and the Stranger is a 1948 American romantic western movie directed by Norman Foster and was based on the short story by Howard Fast. It stars William Holden, Loretta Young, Robert Mitchum, Gary Gray, Tom Tully, Sara Haden, Frank Ferguson and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures.

[[Zyklon-B]]

CATEGORIES: Chemicals, The Holocaust, World War II

Zyklon-B was the trade name of a chemical.  It was invented to kill insects and other pests, but the Nazis used it to kill human beings during the Holocaust and captured people from Allied countries..It consisted of hydrogen cyanide (prussic acid), as well as a cautionary eye irritant and one of several adsorbents such as diatomaceous earth.

[[Mahbubey Alam]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bangladesh, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims, Bangladeshi lawyers

Mahbubey Alam (17 February 1949 – 27 September 2020) was a Bangladeshi politician and lawyer. He was the Attorney General of Bangladesh from 2009 until his death in 2020. He was a senior advocate at the Supreme Court of Bangladesh. He was born in Munshiganj District, present-day Bangladesh.

Alam was hospitalized at a Dhaka hospital on 4 September 2020 with COVID-19. He died four weeks later on 27 September from the infection, aged 71.

Hilarion "Larry" Cuenca Silva (October 21, 1937 – April 27, 2004) was a Filipino actor, comedian and politician. He was the acting Vice Mayor of Manila from May 20, 1998 to June 30, 1998.

[[Yuri Orlov]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Russian physicists, Human rights activists, Writers from Moscow

Yuri Fyodorovich Orlov (Ю́рий Фёдорович Орло́в, 13 August 1924 – 27 September 2020) was a Soviet-born Russian nuclear physicist and human rights activist. He was born in Moscow. He was a Soviet dissident.

Orlov was the founder of the Moscow Helsinki Group and a founding member of the Soviet Amnesty International group. 

Orlov was the Professor of Physics at Cornell University. He was declared a prisoner of conscience while serving nine years in prison and internal exile for monitoring the Helsinki human rights accords as a founder of the human rights movement in the Soviet Union.

Orlov died on 27 September 2020 in Ithaca, New York at the age of 96.

[[Mayor of Manila]]

The Mayor of Manila (Punong Lungsod ng Maynila) is the head of government of Manila. The current mayor is Isko Moreno since June 30, 2019.

[[Arsenio Cruz Herrera]]

CATEGORIES: 1863 births, 1917 deaths, Mayors of Manila

No sourcesright|250px

Arsenio Cruz Herrera (December 14, 1863 – April 8, 1917) was a Filipino politician. He was the first Mayor of Manila from August 7, 1901 to September 18, 1905. He was also the leader of the Progresista Party from 1907 to 1914.

[[Click through rate]]

Click through rate (CTR) is a measurement used in online Advertising. Email campaigns and Search Results. Click through rate is given as a percentage. If an advertisement has a click through rate of 5%, this means out of 100 people who saw the advertisement, 5 people clicked the link and reached the target website.

[[Quarkonium]]

CATEGORIES: Subatomic particles

In particle physics, quarkonium (pl. quarkonia) is a flavorless meson whose constituents are a heavy quark and its own antiquark, making it a neutral particle and the antiparticle of itself.

[[Francis M. Drake]]

CATEGORIES: 1830 births, 1903 deaths, 19th-century American politicians, American businesspeople, American lawyers, Governors of Iowa, Republicans (United States)

Francis Marion Drake was Iowa's 16th governor.  Term: Jan 16, 1896 to Jan 13, 1898.  Republican.  Military: Army.  Born 30 Dec 1830 Rushville, Schuyler, IL and died 20 Nov 1903 Centerville, Appanoose, IA with burial in Oakland Cemetery there.  Married Mary Jane Lord (1833-1883).  They had seven children.  HIs parents were John Adams Drake 1802 Nashville Co., NC - 1880 Drakesville, Davis, IA and Harriet Jane O'Neal.  Siblings of Francis M. Drake were: John Hamilton Drake 1828-1883, Nancy M. Drake 1836-1917 (married Lockman), Melissa Drake 1839-1848, Henrietta Drake 1842-1915 (married Carpenter), Marietta Drake 1850-1853, Kate Ella Drake 1853-1890 (married Lane). (Source: Find A Grave website, memorial #5024935.) On 28 March 1896 Francis Drake's daughter, Mary, christened the battleship USS Iowa.

[[Hurricane Rosa (1994)]]

Hurricane Rosa was the only Pacific hurricane to make landfall during the 1994 Pacific hurricane season. It killed at least 4 people in Mexico. Rosa  was the 18th named storm and the 10th hurricane of the 1994 Pacific hurricane season.

[[Rhabdomyolysis]]

Rhabdomyolysis is where damaged skeletal muscles quickly break down. The symptoms can be muscle pains, weakness, vomiting, and confusion. There can also be confusion and tea-colored urine. Rhabdomyolysis can also injure the kidneys with myoglobin.

The most common causes of Rhabdomyolysis are crush injury, strenuous exercise, medications, or drug abuse. 

During rhabdomyolysis, a protein that stores oxygen in the muscles called myoglobin is released into the blood. The kidneys filter the blood and remove the myoglobin. However, the myoglobin breaks down into other chemicals which damages the kidneys which can cause severe injury or even death.

[[Duck, duck, goose]]

CATEGORIES: Games

Duck, duck, goose is a traditional game, three teams play outdoors. The idea of the game is simple: Everyone sits in a circle and chooses a person who, with a handkerchief in his hand, walks behind the back of the other participants. Before the end of the song, the person walking around should throw a handkerchief on someone's back and quickly surround the other participants to take their place. During this time, the person for whom the handkerchief was thrown should get up quickly and catch the person running. If she fails, she takes the handkerchief and goes around the circle.

[[The Notebook]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 romance movies, 2004 drama movies, 2000s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books

The Notebook is a 2004 American romantic drama movie directed by Nick Cassavetes. It was written by Jeremy Leven and Jan Sardi. It is based on the 1996 novel of the same name by Nicholas Sparks. 

The movie stars Ryan Gosling and Rachel McAdams as a young couple who fall in love in the 1940s. The movie also stars James Garner, Gena Rowlands, James Marsden, Sam Shepard, Joan Allen and David Thornton.

The Notebook received generally mixed reviews. It has become popular after years it was released.

[[Nick Cassavetes]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Movie directors from New York City, Screenwriters from New York City, Actors from New York City

Nicholas David Rowland Cassavetes (born May 21, 1959) is an American actor, director, and writer. He was born in New York City. He was known for directing the 2004 romantic drama The Notebook. His parents were Gena Rowlands and John Cassavetes.

[[David Thornton (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from South Carolina

David Farrington Thornton (born June 12, 1953) is an American actor. He has appeared in John Q, Home Alone 3, Law & Order, The Notebook, and The Other Woman.

He is the husband of Grammy Award-winning singer-songwriter Cyndi Lauper.

[[Meng Jin]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Writers

Meng Jin is an American writer. She was born in Shanghai and graduated from Hunter College. She is a Kundiman fellow. Her work has  appeared in The Masters Review, The Baltimore Review, Vogue, and Ploughshares.

[[Nicholas Sparks]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, American novelists, American philanthropists, American screenwriters, Writers from Omaha, Nebraska

Nicholas Charles Sparks (born December 31, 1965) is an American novelist, screenwriter, and philanthropist. He has published twenty one novels and two non-fiction books, all of which have been The New York Times bestsellers list. He was born in Omaha, Nebraska. He is known for writing The Notebook which eventually became a movie in 2004.

[[Happy Death Day]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 comedy movies, 2017 horror movies, American comedy movies, American horror movies

Happy Death Day is a 2017 American black comedy slasher movie directed by Christopher Landon, and written by Scott Lobdell. It stars Jessica Rothe and Israel Broussard. The movie was produced by Jason Blum.

It is about a college girl who is murdered on her birthday and begins to relive the day repeatedly, at which point she sets out to find the killer and stop her death.

The movie was released on October 13, 2017, by Universal Pictures.

A sequel, Happy Death Day 2U, was released on February 13, 2019.

[[Happy Death Day 2U]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 science fiction movies, 2019 horror movies, 2019 comedy movies, American science fiction movies, American horror movies, American comedy movies

Happy Death Day 2U is a 2019 American science fiction black comedy slasher movie written and directed by Christopher Landon. It stars Jessica Rothe, Israel Broussard, Suraj Sharma, and Steve Zissis.

The movie is a sequel to 2017's Happy Death Day, with Jason Blum.

The movie was released in the United States on February 13, 2019, by Universal Pictures. It received generally positive reviews from critics.

[[Jason Blum]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, American television producers, Movie producers from Los Angeles, California

Jason Ferus Blum (b; born February 20, 1969) is an American movie and television producer. He is the founder and CEO of Blumhouse Productions.

[[Jim Owens (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Cincinnati Reds players, Houston Astros players, Philadelphia Phillies players

James Philip Owens (January 16, 1934 – September 8, 2020), nicknamed "Bear", was an American professional baseball right-handed pitcher and pitching coach. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) between 1955 and 1967 for the Philadelphia Phillies, Cincinnati Reds and Houston Astros.  He was born in McKean County, Pennsylvania.

Owens died on September 8, 2020 in Houston, Texas at the age of 86.

[[Talat Basari]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Iranian writers, Iranian poets, Iranian educators

Tal'at Bassari (طلعت بصاري, 1923 – 18 September 2020), was an Iranian Bahai poet, feminist, academic, and writer. She was born in Babol, Iran. 

In 1967, she had also published a biography on Zandokht Shirazi, a pioneer in the feminist movement in Iran.

She also worked on the editorial board of the New Jersey-based magazine, Persian Heritage. She identified as Bahai. Bassari also assisted in books on the life of the influential Persian Bahai poet Táhirih.

Basari died on 18 September 2020 in Los Angeles, aged 97.

[[Yutakayama Hiromitsu]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese sumo wrestlers, Deaths from pancreatic cancer

Yutakayama Hiromitsu was a sumo wrestler. He was born in Shibata, Niigata. He turned professional in 1970. His highest rank was komusubi. He wrestled for Tokitsukaze stable.

After his retirement in 1981 he became an elder of the Japan Sumo Association, and founded the Minato stable which he led from 1982 until 2010. 

Hiromitsu died of pancreatic cancer on 19 September 2020, aged 72.

[[Macaroni (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy-drama movies, Italian comedy movies, Italian drama movies, Movies directed by Ettore Scola

Macaroni is a 1985 Italian comedy-drama movie directed by Ettore Scola and starring Jack Lemmon, Marcello Mastroianni, Daria Nicolodi, Isa Danieli, Marc Berman, Patrizia Sacchi, Bruno Esposito.

[[The Couch Trip]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Michael Ritchie

The Couch Trip is a 1988 American comedy movie directed by Michael Ritchie and starring Dan Aykroyd, Walter Matthau, Charles Grodin, Donna Dixon, Richard Romanus, Mary Gross, David Clennon, Chevy Chase. It was distributed by Orion Pictures and was a box office failure.

[[Plymouth Belvedere]]

CATEGORIES: 1950s automobiles, 1960s automobiles, 1970s automobiles, Coupes, Sedans

The Plymouth Belvedere is an American car made by Chrysler from 1954 to 1970. 

It is a full-size from 1954 to 1964 and a mid-size 1965 to 1970.

A red and white 1958 Belvedere was famous for the movie Christine.

[[Cadillac Brougham]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s automobiles, 1990s automobiles, Cadillac automobiles, Sedans

The Cadillac Brougham is a full-size luxury car made by Cadillac of General Motors from 1987 to 1992.

It preceded the 1977-1986 Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham and was succeeded by the 1993-1996 Cadillac Fleetwood.

[[Kiwi Farms]]

CATEGORIES: American websites, Internet culture

Kiwi Farms, formerly known as CWCki Forums, is an American Internet forum dedicated to the trolling and harassment of online people and communities it calls "lolcows", as well as the mentally ill. It was first called the CWCki Forums.

The site has been involved in many controversies including the Christchurch mosque shootings, as well as the suicides of game developer Chloe Segal and Byuu / Near.cn

[[House Calls (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Howard Zieff

House Calls is a 1978 American comedy movie directed by Howard Zieff and starring Walter Matthau, Glenda Jackson, Richard Benjamin, Art Carney, Candice Azzara, Dick O'Neill. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was spun off into a television series in 1979.

[[Night on Earth (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 comedy movies, American comedy movies, French comedy movies, British comedy movies, German comedy movies, Finnish movies, Japanese movies, Movies directed by Jim Jarmusch, Movies set in Rome

Night on Earth is a 1991 American French British German Finnish Japanese comedy movie directed by Jim Jarmusch and starring Winona Ryder, Gena Rowlands, Armin Mueller-Stahl, Rosie Perez, Roberto Benigni, Paolo Bonacelli, Matti Pellonpää, Béatrice Dalle. It was distributed by Fine Line Features.

[[The Platform (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 horror movies, 2019 science fiction movies, Spanish movies, Spanish-language movies, Movies set in Spain, Dystopian movies

The Platform (El hoyo, The Hole) is a 2019 Spanish science fiction-horror movie. It is directed by Galder Gaztelu-Urrutia. The movie is set in a vertical prison, in which the food for the prisoners is taken down on a lowering platform, leaving the prisoners on the lower levels to get the leftovers.

The movie's cast includes Iván Massagué, Antonia San Juan, Zorion Eguileor, Emilio Buale and Alexandra Masangkay.

The Platform was first shown on 6 September 2019 at the Toronto International Film Festival. It was released on Netflix on 20 March 2020.

[[Galder Gaztelu-Urrutia]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, People from Bilbao, Spanish movie directors, Spanish movie producers

Galder Gaztelu-Urrutia (born 1974) is a Spanish director and producer. He is best known for his first feature movie, 2019's The Platform (El hoyo, The Hole). He has also directed many television advertisements. 

Gaztelu-Urrutia was born in Bilbao, Basque Country.

[[Iván Massagué]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, People from Barcelona, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors

Iván Massagué Horta (born 4 September 1976) is a Spanish actor. He is best known worldwide for his role as Goreng in the movie The Platform (2019). He has appeared in many television shows such as 7 vidas, La familia Mata, El barco and Gym Tony. His other movie credits include Pan's Labyrinth (2006) and Pancho, el perro millonario (2014).

Massagué was born in Barcelona, Catalonia.

[[Antonia San Juan]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Atheists, People from the Canary Islands, Spanish movie actors, Spanish movie directors, Spanish screenwriters, Spanish stage actors, Spanish television actors

Antonia San Juan Fernández (born 22 May 1961) is a Spanish actress, director and screenwriter. She is best known for her roles as Agrado in comedy-drama movie All About My Mother (1999) and Imoguiri in the science ficiton-horror movie The Platform (2019). She has also appeared in television shows such as La que se avecina and Gym Tony.

San Juan was born in Las Palmas, Canary Islands. She was married to actor Luis Miguel Seguí from 2009 to 2015. She is an atheist.

[[Dick Nemelka]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American basketball players, Sportspeople from Salt Lake City, Utah

Richard Samuel Nemelka (October 1, 1943 – September 19, 2020) was an American professional basketball player for the American Basketball Association (ABA). He was born in Salt Lake City, Utah.

As a college player, he earned All-American honor at Brigham Young University (BYU). He played for the Utah Stars between 1970 to 1971. 

Nemelka died on September 19, 2020 in Salt Lake City from cancer, aged 76.

[[Li Dongying]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese businesspeople, Chinese scientists, People from Beijing

Li Dongying (李东英; December 14, 1920 - September 22, 2020) was a Chinese metallurgist. He was one of the founders of China's rare metal industry. He was born in Beijing. In December 1980, he co-founded the Chinese Society of Rare Earths (CSRE) in Beijing. In 1995, he was a member of the Chinese Academy of Engineering.

On September 22, 2020, Li died in Beijing at the age of 99.

[[Zorion Eguileor]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, Spanish movie actors, Radio personalities, Spanish singers, Spanish television actors

Zorion Eguileor (born 15 March 1946) is a Spanish actor, singer and broadcaster. He is best known worldwide for his role as Trimagasi in the movie The Platform (2019). His television credits include Qué grande es el teatro, Cuéntame cómo pasó, Mi querido Klikowsky, La que se avecina, El tiempo entre costuras and Estoy vivo.

Eguileor was born in Mundaka, Basque Country.

[[Yvette Alloo]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Paralympic gold medalists, Sportspeople from Brussels

[[Emilio Buale]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Equatoguinean people, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors

Ludwig Emilio Buale Coka (born 26 November 1972) is an Equatoguinean-born Spanish actor. He is best known worldwide for his role as Baharat in the movie The Platform (2019). He is also known for roles in Bwana and La que se avecina.

Buale was born in Equatorial Guinea and is a Bubi. He moved to Spain at the age of six.

[[Eric Bransby]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2020 deaths, American centenarians, American educators, Artists from New York

Eric James Bransby (October 25, 1916 – September 23, 2020) was an American artist and muralist. He studied and made murals in Colorado Springs, Colorado. He taught at Yale University, Brigham Young University, and University of Missouri-Kansas City. Bransby was born in Auburn, New York. 

He turned 100 in October 2016 and died in September 2020 at the age of 103.

[[Renzo Eusebi]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Italian painters, Italian sculptors, Marche, Living people

Renzo Eusebi (born 18 April 1946 in Montalto delle Marche) is an Italian painter, sculptor of contemporary art. He is co-founder of the artistic movements of Transvisionismo (1995) and GAD (Dialectical Aniconism Group-1997). 

[[Colette Giudicelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians

Colette Giudicelli (24 November 1943 – 24 September 2020) was a French politician. She was a member of the Senate of France from 2008 until her death. She represented the Alpes-Maritimes department. Giudicelli was a member of the Union for a Popular Movement party and later of The Republicans.

She began her political career as city councillor of Menton in 1989. Giudicelli was married to Jean-Claude Guibal, mayor of Menton. 

Giudicelli died on 24 September 2020, at the age of 76.

[[Jean-Claude Guibal]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, French mayors

Jean-Claude Guibal (born 13 January 1941) is a French politician. He was a member of the National Assembly of France.  He represented the 4th constituency of the Alpes-Maritimes department. He is a member of The Republicans. In 1989, he became Mayor of Menton.

Guibal was married to Colette Giudicelli until her death.

[[Antonio Servillo]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Italian painters, People from Veneto, Padua, Living people

Antonio Servillo (born 12 November 1964 in Padua) is an Italian surrealist painter of contemporary art.

[[Bhutanese animation]]

CATEGORIES: Animation, Bhutan

Bhutanese animation is animation from Bhutan. It is mostly used to make people aware of relevant social issues, economical issues and political issues or to promote Bhutanese culture. Bhutanese animators and clients believe using animation for public awareness is more effective than brochures and pamphlets. For example, Ap Naka was made to tell people about earthquakes.

The Bhutanese animation industry is quite new. Pema Tshering D made the first Bhutanese 3D-animated film, which came out in 2001. His first animation was of a beetle dancing, and his first public awareness animation is Oye Penjor, which is about AIDS. It took about three months to make, was the first Bhutanese 3D animation, and was made with Druk Vision Studio, which he owns. In 2005, KLK anImagine and Druk Vision Studio, which are major animation studios in Bhutan, were started. KLK anImagine is owned by Kinga Sithup. The first Bhutanese 2D animation is an awareness campaign about rubella that was made by KLK anImagine. It is common for Bhutanese animators to split 10 frames into 25 frames or to animate in 24 frames per second. By 2008, Druk Vision Studio had made about 7 animated films, and KLK anImagine had made about 20 animated films.

The first Bhutanese full-length 3D-animated film is Ap Bokto, which first came out in September 2014. Ap Bokto was made by Athang Animation Studio, which was started in 2010.

[[Guitar Crusher]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American blues singers, American blues musicians, American guitarists, Singers from North Carolina, Musicians from North Carolina

Sidney Selby (July 28, 1931 – September 23, 2020), known as "Guitar Crusher" and formerly as "Bone Crusher", was an American blues singer and guitarist. He was known as "The Big Voice from New York". He also played guitar and blues harmonica. Selby was born in Hyde County, North Carolina. He also toured with artists such as Ben E. King, The Drifters and The Isley Brothers.

The rapper Desiigner is his grandson.

Selby died on September 23, 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Laurie Smith Camp]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, US Republican Party politicians, Politicians from Omaha, Nebraska

Laurie Smith Camp (November 28, 1953 – September 23, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. In 2001, she was nominated as a Judge of the United States District Court for the District of Nebraska by President George W. Bush. Camp was born in Omaha, Nebraska. From 2011 to 2018, she became Chief Justice. 

Camp died suddenly on September 23, 2020 in Omaha at the age of 66.

[[Goodpasture syndrome]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Goodpasture syndrome (GPS), also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane disease,  is a rare autoimmune disease in which antibodies attack the basement membrane in lungs and kidneys. This causes bleeding from the lungs and kidney failure. 

Goodpasture syndrome may quickly result in permanent lung and kidney damage, often leading to death. 

[[Robert Bechtle]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia with Lewy bodies, American painters, American educators, Artists from San Francisco

Robert Bechtle (May 14, 1932 – September 24, 2020) was an American painter. He lived nearly all his life in the San Francisco Bay Area. His art focused on scenes from everyday local life in San Francisco. Bechtle was born in San Francisco. 

Bechtle was represented by the Barbara Gladstone Gallery in New York City, and Gallery Paule Anglim in San Francisco.

From 1956 to 1966 he taught at the University of California, Berkeley and from 1967 to 1968 at the University of California, Davis. From 1968 he taught at San Francisco State University and lived in San Francisco's Potrero Hill neighborhood. 

Bechtle died of Lewy body dementia in Berkeley, California on September 24, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Antonello Spadafora]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Italian painters, People from Calabria, Living people

Antonello Spadafora (born 13 June 1979 in Paola, Calabria) is an Italian painter of contemporary art.

[[Max Merritt]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from autoimmune disease, Guitarists, New Zealand singers, People from Christchurch

Maxwell James Merritt (30 April 1941 – 24 September 2020) was a New Zealand-born singer-songwriter and guitarist. He was known as an interpreter of soul music and R&B. 

As leader of Max Merritt & The Meteors his best known hits are "Slippin' Away", which reached No. 2 on the 1976 Australian singles charts, and "Hey, Western Union Man" which reached No. 13. Merritt rose to prominence in New Zealand from 1958 and relocated to Sydney, Australia, in December 1964.

In 2008, he was hospitalized with kidney failure and was diagnosed with godpasture syndrome. Merritt died from the disease on 24 September 2020 in Los Angeles, aged 79.

[[Paul Pettit]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Pittsburgh Pirates players, Sportspeople from Los Angeles, California

George William Paul Pettit (November 29, 1931 – September 24, 2020) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1951 and 1953. Pettit was born in Los Angeles, California.

Pettit died on September 24, 2020 in Canyon Lake, California at the age of 88.

Canyon Lake is a city and gated community on Canyon Lake reservoir, located in the Inland Empire, Riverside County, California, United States.

[[Anwara Taimur]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians, Deaths from cardiac arrest

Syeda Anwara Taimur (24 November 1936 – 28 September 2020) was an Indian politician. She was Chief Minister of Assam from 6 December 1980 to 30 June 1981. She was a leader of the Indian National Congress.

Taimur died in Australia from cardiac arrest on 28 September 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Juan Carlos Guerra Zunzunegui]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish lawyers, Spanish politicians, People from Madrid

Juan Carlos Guerra Zunzunegui (1 February 1935 – 28 September 2020) was a Spanish politician and lawyer. Guerra Zunzunegui was born in Madrid. He was a member of the People's Party. From 1977 to 1986, he was a member of the Senate. Between 1986 to 2008, he was in the Congress of Deputies.

Guerra Zunzunegui died on 28 September 2020 in Madrid, aged 85.

[[2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war]]

CATEGORIES: September 2020 events, 21st century in Azerbaijan, 21st century in Armenia, Battles, October 2020 events, November 2020 events

The  2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war was a war between the Azerbaijani and Armenian armed forces in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh. This is the most recent event during the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. 

The clashes began on the morning of 27 September 2020 along the Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact. Both sides reported military and civilian casualties. In response to the clashes, Armenia and the Republic of Artsakh placed curfews, martial law and total mobilization, while Azerbaijan introduced martial law and a curfew. 

On 28 September partial mobilization was declared in Azerbaijan.

On 10 October, both Armenia and Azerbaijan agreed to a ceasefire, the stopping of any military action, for a short time.

On 9 November, with the help of Russian President Vladimir Putin, both Armenia and Azerbaijan signed a peace treaty in Moscow, ending the war the next day.

[[John Waddy (British Army officer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, British military personnel of World War II, English centenarians, People from Somerset

Colonel John Llewellyn Waddy OBE (17 June 1920 – 27 September 2020) was a British Army officer. He was born in Taunton, Somerset, England. He was in World War II, Palestine and the Malayan Emergency before becoming Colonel of the SAS. 

Waddy died on 27 September 2020, aged 100.

[[Kevin Burns]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, American television producers, American television directors, American television writers, Movie directors from New York, Movie producers from New York, Screenwriters from New York, People from Schenectady, New York

Kevin Burns (June 18, 1955spndSeptember 27, 2020) was an American television and movie producer, director, and screenwriter. He was born in Schenectady, New York. He produced the 2006 disaster movie Poseidon and History Channel's Ancient Aliens.

His work can be seen on A&E, National Geographic Channel, E!, Animal Planet, AMC, Bravo, WE tv, Travel Channel, Lifetime, and The History Channel. 

Burns created and executive-produced more than 800 hours of television programming.

Burns died on September 27, 2020 from cardiac arrest at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, aged 65.

Frans Derks OON (1 November 1930 – 25 September 2020) was a Dutch football referee and sports executive. He was born in Vaals, Netherlands. He was Chairman of FC Dordrecht. From 1956 to 1978, he was a referee for Eredivisie.

Derks died of a short-illness on 25 September 2020 in Breda, Netherlands at the age of 89.

[[Peter Hampton]]

Peter John Hampton (12 September 1954spnd25 September 2020) was an English footballer. He played as a left back in the Football League for Leeds United, Stoke City, Burnley, Rochdale and Carlisle United. His career began in 1972 and he retired in 1988. Hampton was born in Oldham, Greater Manchester.

Hampton died on 25 September 2020 in Cyprus at the age of 66.

[[Viktor Panin]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Russian physicists, Russian educators

Viktor Yevgenievich Panin (Виктор Евгеньевич Панин; 10 November 1930 – 25 September 2020) was a Soviet and Russian physicist and professor. He was an advisor of the Russian Academy of Sciences. He was an expert in the fields of solid mechanics, plastic deformation and physical materials. Panin was born in Semey, then-Soviet Union.

Panin died on 25 September 2020 in Tomsk, Russia at the age of 89.

[[Erik Bartnes]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian politicians, Mayors

Erik Bartnes (27 November 1939 – 26 September 2020) was a Norwegian farmer and politician. He was a member of the Centre Party. He was from Beitstad in Steinkjer.

He has worked in the Norwegian Agrarian Association. He was mayor of Steinkjer. In 2003, he became county mayor of Nord-Trøndelag. 

He was a board member of the Regional Development Fund.

Bartnes died on 26 September 2020, aged 80.

[[Isher Judge Ahluwalia]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from glioblastoma, Indian economists, Indian businesspeople, Indian educators, Researchers

Isher Judge Ahluwalia (1 October 1945spnd26 September 2020) was an Indian economist, public policy researcher, and professor. She was Chairperson Emeritus, Board of Governors, at the Indian Council for Research on International Economic Relations (ICRIER).

She also was the chairperson of the board of the International Food Policy Research Institute, and the chairperson of the Government of India's High-Powered Committee on Urban Infrastructure Services. She was awarded India's third highest civilian award, Padma Bhushan in 2009.

She was married to Montek Singh Ahluwalia.

Ahluwalia died of glioblastoma on 26 September 2020 at a hospital in Mumbai, aged 74.

[[Dai Yuanben]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese scientists, Chinese educators, Physicists

Dai Yuanben (戴元本; July 31, 1928 – September 26, 2020) was a Chinese physicist. He was a member of the 7th, 8th and 9th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. He was born in Nanjing, China. In 1980, he became a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. 

Dai died on September 26, 2020 in Beijing at the age of 92. 

[[Moshe Efrati]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Choreographers, People from Tel Aviv

Moshe Efrati (1934 – 26 September 2020) was an Israeli choreographer. He was the founder and artistic director of the Kol Demama Dance Company, based in Tel Aviv. In 1996, he was honored with the Israel Prize. Efrati was born in Tel Aviv.

Efrati died on 26 September 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Israel Prize]]

CATEGORIES: Israel, Awards

The Israel Prize (פרס ישראל; pras israél) is an award handed out by the State of Israel and regarded as the state's highest cultural honor.

Abdul Mahdi Hadi (عبد المهدي هادي, 26 February 1946 – 26 September 2020) was an Iraqi coach and international football player. He also played for Al-Minaa from 1966 to 1978. He played for the national team in 1970. He was born in Basra, Iraq.

Hadi died on 26 September 2020 in Basra from COVID-19 at the age of 74.

[[Jay Johnstone]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American sports commentators, Chicago Cubs players, Chicago White Sox players, Los Angeles Dodgers players, Oakland Athletics players, Philadelphia Phillies players, San Diego Padres players, Sportspeople from Connecticut

John William Johnstone Jr. (November 20, 1945 – September 26, 2020) was an American professional baseball player and television sports announcer. He was born in Manchester, Connecticut.

He played in Major League Baseball as an outfielder from 1966 to 1985 for the California Angels, Chicago White Sox, Oakland Athletics, Philadelphia Phillies, New York Yankees, San Diego Padres, Los Angeles Dodgers, and Chicago Cubs. 

Johnstone died on September 26, 2020 from dementia and COVID-19 in Los Angeles, aged 74.

[[Leo Sugar]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Detroit Lions players, Philadelphia Eagles players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Sportspeople from Michigan, People from Flint, Michigan

Leo Tateusz Sugar (April 6, 1929 – September 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a defensive end in the National Football League (NFL) for the Chicago Cardinals/St. Louis Cardinals, Philadelphia Eagles, and the Detroit Lions.  He went to two Pro Bowls during his nine-year career.  

Sugar played college football at Purdue University. He was born in Flint, Michigan.

Sugar died in Fort Myers, Florida in September 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Denis Tillinac]]

CATEGORIES: Writers from Paris, 1947 births, 2020 deaths, French journalists, Political commentators, Political writers

Denis Tillinac (26 May 1947 – 26 September 2020) was a French writer and journalist. He was born in Paris. He wrote a weekly column in Valeurs actuelles. He was a close friend to President Jacques Chirac.

He was a Catholic and wrote books about the Catholic origins of France.

Tillinac died on 26 September 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Suzanne Tremblay]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Canada, Politicians from Montreal

Suzanne Tremblay (syzan tʁɑ̃blɛ; January 24, 1937 – September 26, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He was born in Montreal. He was a Bloc Québécois member of the House of Commons of Canada from 1993 to 2004. In 1997, she was Opposition House Leader for a short time.

Tremblay died on September 26, 2020 in Rimouski, Quebec from cancer, aged 83.

[[Sune Wehlin]]

Sune Wehlin (12 January 1923 – 21 September 2020) was a Swedish modern pentathlete. He was born in Stockholm. He competed at the 1948 Summer Olympics.

Wehlin died on 21 September 2020 in Stockholm, aged 97.

[[Conrad Roland]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, German architects

Conrad Roland (born Konrad Roland Lehmann; 1934 – 26 September 2020) was a German architect. He was an important person in the construction of spacenets (tensile structures), which primarily are to be found as rope climbing frames on playgrounds. 

In 1978 he designed and constructed the biggest spacenet of the world until today, the Super Four Mast Spacenet, for the Federal Horticultural Show (BUGA).

He studied architecture in Chicago. Roland died on 26 September 2020, aged 86.

[[Jeannette Charles]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors

Jeannette Charles (born 15 October 1927) is an English actress. She is known for playing Queen Elizabeth II in many television shows and movies. She played the Queen in Secrets of a Superstud (1976), Queen Kong (1976), All You Need Is Cash (1978), National Lampoon's European Vacation (1985), The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! (1988) and Austin Powers in Goldmember (2002).

[[Arthur Leonard Schawlow]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 1999 deaths, American physicists, Scientists from New York, People from Mount Vernon, New York

PhysicsArthur Leonard Schawlow (May 5, 1921 – April 28, 1999) was an American physicist. He was the co-inventor of the laser with Charles Townes. He shared the 1981 Nobel Prize in Physics with Nicolaas Bloembergen and Kai Siegbahn for his work using lasers to determine atomic energy levels with great precision.

[[Kai Siegbahn]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2007 deaths, Swedish scientists, Physicists

PhysicsKai Manne Börje Siegbahn (20 April 1918 – 20 July 2007) was a Swedish physicist. He won the 1981 Nobel Prize in Physics with Arthur Leonard Schawlow and Nicolaas Bloembergen. He was known for his works in high-resolution electron spectroscopy.

[[Nick Mourouzis]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American football quarterbacks, Sportspeople from Ohio, Sportspeople from Indiana

Nick Mourouzis (April 16, 1937 – September 16, 2020) was an American football player and coach. He was the head football coach at DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana from 1981 to 2003. He had a winning record of 133–82–4. As a college football player, Mourouzis was a starting quarterback at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. Mourouzis was born in New Philadelphia, Ohio.

Mourouzis died on September 16, 2020 from COVID-19 in Greencastle, Indiana at the age of 83.

[[DePauw University]]

CATEGORIES: 1837 establishments in Indiana, Colleges and universities in Indiana

DePauw University is a private university in Greencastle, Indiana. It has an enrollment of 1,972 students. The school has a Methodist heritage. It was originally known as Indiana Asbury University. The Society of Professional Journalists was founded at DePauw.

[[Ripley, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Ripley is a city in Lauderdale County, Tennessee, United States. The population was 8,445 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Lauderdale County.

The plot is that a boy named Charlie Rockit needs $50,000 to fix his aunt and uncle's tractor engine, so Chuck E. Cheese and his friends go to the Galaxy 5000 to win it in a race.

[[Growling grass frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The growling grass frog, green and gold frog, blue-thighed tree frog, southern bell frog, warty bell frog or green and golden frog (Ranoidea raniformis) is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria.  It also lives in Tasmania.  It lives in New Zealand as an invasive specie.

When people see this frog, it is usually sitting on plants near ponds, dams or other bodies of water that do not dry up.  It sometimes hides under logs.  Sometimes the tadpoles become frogs in the fall and sometimes they stay tadpoles through the winter and become frogs in the spring.

Scientists are not sure why this frog is endangered.  It could be because there is more ultraviolet radiation than there used to be.  It could be because invasive species, for example the eastern mosquitofish, eat its eggs and tadpoles.  This frog can also catch the fungal disease chytridiomycosis.

[[List of prime ministers of Kuwait]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Kuwait

The Prime Minister of Kuwait is the head of government of Kuwait. As the third most powerful official in the country, following the Emir of Kuwait and Speaker of the National Assembly, the prime minister leads the executive branch of the Government of Kuwait.

[[Sabah Al-Khalid Al-Sabah]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Kuwait, Current national leaders

Sabah Al Khalid Al Sabah (born 3 March 1953) is a Kuwaiti diplomat and politician. In November 2019, he became the Prime Minister of Kuwait.

[[Nasser Al-Sabah]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Kuwait

Nasser Mohammed Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah (الشيخ  ناصر المحمد الأحمد الصباح, born 22 December 1940) is a Kuwaiti politician. He was Prime Minister of Kuwait from 7 February 2006 until resigning on 28 November 2011. He is the first prime minister to date that never became ruler or even crown prince.

[[Emir of Kuwait]]

CATEGORIES: Emirs of Kuwait

The Emir of the State of Kuwait is the monarch and head of state of Kuwait. It is the most powerful position in the country. The emirs of Kuwait are members of the Al-Sabah dynasty.

The most recent emir, Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah, died on 29 September 2020. Crown Prince Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah is expected to take over.

[[2006 Mumbai train bombings]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 crimes, Crime in India, Explosions in Asia, Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2000s, Islamic terrorist incidents in Asia, Mass murder in the 2000s, Mass murder in Asia, Terrorist incidents in Asia, July 2006 events, Mumbai

The 2006 Mumbai train bombings were a series of seven bomb blasts on 11 July. They took place over a period of 11 minutes on the Suburban Railway in Mumbai, the capital of the Indian state of Maharashtra. The bombs were set off in pressure cookers on trains plying on the Western Line Suburban Section of the Mumbai Division of Western Railway. The blasts killed 209 people and injured over 700 more.

[[National Technical University of Athens]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Greece, 1830s establishments in Europe, 1837 establishments, Colleges and universities in Europe, Athens

The National (Metsovian) Technical University of Athens (NTUA; Εθνικό Μετσόβιο Πολυτεχνείο, National Metsovian Polytechnic), sometimes known as Athens Polytechnic, is among the oldest higher education institutions of Greece. It is also one of the best engineering schools in the country and the world.

It was founded in 1837.

[[Whitney Able]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Actors from Texas

Whitney Able is an American actor and model.  She is best known for her roles in All the Boys Love Mandy Lane and Monsters.

[[The Providence Journal]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Rhode Island, 1829 establishments in the United States, Providence, Rhode Island, Newspapers in the United States

The Providence Journal, also known as the ProJo, is a daily newspaper for Providence, Rhode Island, and is the largest newspaper in Rhode Island. The newspaper was first published in 1829. The newspaper has won four Pulitzer Prizes.

The Journal calls itself as "America's oldest daily newspaper in continuous publication".

[[Anastrophe]]

CATEGORIES: Figures of speech, Rhetoric

Anastrophe (from the Greek: ἀναστροφή, anastrophē, "a turning back or about") is a figure of speech in which the normal word order of the subject, the verb, and the object is changed. For example, subject–verb–object ("I like potatoes") might be changed to object–subject–verb ("potatoes I like").

[[Rise of the Guardians]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 movies, 2012 animated movies, English-language movies, American animated movies, American comedy movies

Rise of the Guardians is a 2012 American computer animated movie produced by DreamWorks Animation for Paramount Pictures. It stars Chris Pine, Alec Baldwin, Jude Law, Isla Fisher, and Hugh Jackman. It was released on October 10, 2012.

[[Leeuwarderadeel]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Friesland, Leeuwarden

Leeuwarderadeel (Ljouwerteradiel) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. Since 2018, it has been part of the municipality of Leeuwarden.

Ferwerderadiel (Ferwerderadeel) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. Since 2019, it has been part of the new municipality of Noardeast-Fryslân.

[[Ghede Nibo]]

CATEGORIES: Mythology, Afro-American religion

Ghede Nibo is a loa who is leader of the spirits of the dead in Voodoo. Formerly human, Ghede Nibo was a handsome young man who was killed violently. After death, he was adopted as a loa by Baron Samedi and Maman Brigitte.

[[Liza Soberano]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Filipino actors, American child actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American Roman Catholics, Filipino Roman Catholics, Actors from Santa Clara County, California, Living people

Hope Elizabeth "Liza" Soberano (born January 4, 1998) is a Filipina-American actress and model. She started acting in a range of television series and movies, including Wansapanataym (2011), Kung Ako'y Iiwan Mo (2012), She's the One (2013), Must Be... Love(2013). She rose to fame after playing the main role in the romantic comedy television series Forevermore (2014–2015) with Enrique Gil. She has since paired with Gil in the movies Just The Way You Are (2015), Everyday I Love You (2015), My Ex and Whys (2017), Alone/Together (2019) and the television series Dolce Amore (2016), Bagani (2018) and Make It with You (2020).

Soberano is a Roman Catholic.
