[[Enrique Gil]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Filipino actors, Filipino singers, Filipino movie actors, Filipino television actors, Models, Dancers, Living people

Enrique Mari Bacay Gil V (born 30 March 1992) is a Filipino actor, dancer, model, and singer. Gil has appeared in a number of movies and television shows such as Mula Sa Puso, Budoy, Muling Buksan Ang Puso and She's the One. He is best known for playing Alexander "Xander" Grande III in the television series Forevermore in 2014–15, with Liza Soberano. Since then, he has starred in the movies Just The Way You Are (2015), Everyday I Love You (2015), Dukot (2016), My Ex and Whys (2017), Seven Sundays (2017), and Alone/Together; (2019) and the television series Dolce Amore (2016) Bagani (2018), and Make It with You (2020).

[[Heparin]]

CATEGORIES: Blood

Heparin is an anticoagulant (substance that stops blood clots) discovered by Jay McLean and William Henry Howell. It is generally injected under the skin or into veins. As of now it seems safe to use on pregnant people. It is identified as a glycosaminoglycan (long polysaccharide (the stuff that cells are made of) chains consisting of long repeating disaccharide chains.

The discoverers first extracted heparin from the guts of animals such as turkey, atlantic salmon, mice, and even humans. The specimen of choice is a fresh, nonhemolyzed (intact red blood cells is broken) plasma anticoagulated by fluorides. Overdose can cause heparin-caused thrombocytopenia, a condition where white blood cells attack platelets (the stuff in your blood that heal wounds), causing a slowed heal time, bad breakdown of tissue n the leg, heart infections, and strokes, none of which will be benign.

Heparin is rated one of the World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines, showing its value and popularity and rate of success.

[[Haley Tju]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 births, Living people, Actors from California

Haley Alexandra Tju (born February 15, 2001) is an American actor. She is known for her role as Pepper in the Nickelodeon television show Bella and the Bulldogs.

[[Morris dance]]

The Morris Dance is an English folk dance.

The earliest known English written mention of Morris dance is dated to 1448 and records the payment of seven shillings to Morris dancers by the Goldsmiths' Company in London.

It is danced by a group of dancers wearing bells on their shins or shoes.

People danced this dance in their homes until it became a well known folk dance. uk-stub

[[Tadeusz Szelachowski]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Polish politicians

Tadeusz Szelachowski (7 April 1932 – 9 September 2020) was a Polish physician and politician. He was born in Sielachowskie, Poland. From 1981 to 1985, he was Minister of Health. Between 1985 to 1989, he was a member of Sejm. 

Szelachowski died on 9 September 2020 in Warsaw, aged 88.

[[Sheldon Gomes]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Trinidad and Tobago sportspeople, West Indies cricketers

Sheldon Anthony Gomes (18 October 1950 – 15 September 2020) was a cricketer. He played first-class and List A cricket for Trinidad and Tobago and other Trinidad teams from 1969 to 1983. That was also his most prolific first-class season, with 633 runs at an average of 70.33 and three centuries.

Gomes died in Las Vegas, Nevada, on 15 September 2020 at the age of 69.

[[James "T" Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American football quarterbacks, Sportspeople from Texas

James Carroll "T" Jones  (January 10, 1931 – September 15, 2020) was an American football player, coach and athletic director.  He was the starting quarterback of the Texas Longhorns in 1951–52. He was the athletic director at Texas Tech University from 1985 to 1993. Jones was born in Childress, Texas.

Jones died on September 15, 2020 in Horseshoe Bay, Texas at the age of 89.

[[Horseshoe Bay, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Horseshoe Bay is a city in Llano and Burnet counties in the U.S. state of Texas. The CDP population was 3,337 at the 2000 census. The 2010 census put the population at 3,418.

[[Caroline Kaart]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish singers, Dutch singers, Scottish television personalities, Dutch television personalities

Caroline Kaart (born Caroline Paterson Raitt; 21 December 1931 – 15 September 2020) was a Scottish-Dutch opera singer and television presenter. Kaart was born in Edinburgh. She was a mezzo-soprano. In 1982, she was honored with Order of Orange-Nassau. For many years, she was the host of Classic with Caroline.

Kaart died on 15 September 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Irdinansyah Tarmizi]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Indonesian politicians

Irdinansyah Tarmizi (13 March 1957 – 19 September 2020) was an Indonesian politician. He was born in Bukittinggi, Indonesia. He was a member of the Golkar Party. Between 2014 to 2015, he was Deputy Regent of the Tanah Datar Regency. In 2016, he became the official Regent of Tanah Datar. 

Tarmizi died of colon cancer on 19 September 2020 at a hospital in Padang, Indonesia at the age of 63.

[[Wan Mokhtar]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Malaysian politicians, Deaths from cardiovascular disease

Wan Mokhtar bin Wan Ahmad (21 March 1932 – 21 September 2020) was a Malaysian politician. He was the 11th Menteri Besar of Terengganu and Member of the Terengganu State Legislative Assembly (MLA) for Cukai from September 1974 to December 1999. He was a member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO). Mokhtar was born in Kuala Terengganu, Indonesia.

Mokhtar died on 21 September 2020 in Kuala Lumpur from problems caused by heart disease, aged 88.

[[Gerson King Combo]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from diabetes, Brazilian singers, Brazilian writers, Songwriters, People from Rio de Janeiro

Gérson Rodrigues Côrtes (30 November 1943 – 22 September 2020) was a Brazilian soul funk singer-songwriter. He was born in Rio de Janeiro. He began his career in performing on the variety program Hoje é Dia de Rock. He founded and performed in the 1960s musical group Formula 7. He was also a key person in the 1970s counterculture movent Black Rio.

Côrtes died on 22 September 2020 in Rio de Janeiro from diabetes-related problems, aged 76.

[[Mary Gergen]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, American feminist writers, American psychologists, Writers from Minnesota, Scientists from Minnesota

Mary McCanney Gergen (December 12, 1938 – September 22, 2020) was an American social psychologist. Her works focused on feminist studies women's studies and social constructionism. She was known for her works to the field of feminist studies, organization development, and social process.

Gergen died on September 22, 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Tim Lopes]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2002 deaths, Brazilian journalists, Murder victims

Tim Lopes (born Arcanjo Antonino Lopes do Nascimento; November 18, 1950 – June 2, 2002) was a Brazilian investigative journalist and producer for the Brazilian television network Rede Globo. 

In 2002, he was reported him missing while working undercover on a story in one of Rio's favelas. It was later learned that Lopes was kidnapped by drug leaders. He was tortured by having his hands, arms, and legs severed with a sword while still alive. He was later burned alive on June 2, 2002.

[[Capistrano Francisco Heim]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, American Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, Brazilian people, People from New York City

Capistrano Francisco Heim (21 January 1934 – 24 September 2020) was an American-born Brazilian Roman Catholic bishop. Heim was born in Catskill, New York. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1965. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Territorial Prelature of Itaituba, Brazil from 1988 until 2010.

Heim died in New York City on 24 September 2020, aged 86.

[[Zhang Xinshi]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Ecologists, Chinese scientists

Zhang Xinshi (张新时; June 30, 1934 – September 24, 2020) was a Chinese plant ecologist. He was the founder of China's vegetation ecology and international information ecology. He created China's first laboratory of quantitative vegetation ecology. 

He was a member of the 8th, 9th and 10th Standing Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. In 1991, he became a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Zhang was born in Kaifeng, Henan.

Zhang died on September 24, 2020 in Seattle, Washington at the age of 86.

[[Rubén Anguiano]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, Mexican footballers

Rubén Anguiano (17 November 1955 – 28 September 2020) was a Mexican footballer. He played as a midfielder. Anguiano played for Zacatepec, Leones Negros and Atlante. He was born in Mexico City.

He earned 8 caps for the Mexican national team between 1974 and 1977.

Anguiano died on 28 September 2020 aged 64, from COVID-19 in Mexico City, aged 64.

[[Tennison Cooray]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Sri Lankan people, Sri Lankan movie actors, Comedians, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Merengnnakuge Tennison Cooray (සිංහල:ටෙනිසන් කුරේ) (30 April 1952 – 28 September 2020) was a Sri Lankan comedian and actor. He was born in Moratuwa, Sri Lanka. Cooray was known for his roles as Miguel in the Re Daniel Dawal Migel movie series, his small roles in the Cheriyo movie series and as Bean in Somy Boys.

Cooray died on 28 September 2020 in Colombo, Sri Lanka from a heart attack, aged 68.

[[Frédéric Devreese]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch composers, Dutch conductors, Belgian composers

Frédéric Devreese (2 June 1929 – 28 September 2020) was a Duthc-born Belgian composer. His works were mostly orchestral, chamber and piano. He was known for his movie scores for Benvenuta by André Delvaux and The Cruel Embrace by Marion Hänsel. He was born in Amsterdam.

Devreese died on 28 September 2020 in Brussels, Belgium at the age of 91.

[[Abd al-Rahman Abd al-Khaliq]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Egyptian writers, Kuwaiti people

Abd al-Rahman Abd al-Khaliq (عبد الرحمن عبد الخالق) (5 November 1939 – 29 September 2020) was an Egyptian-Kuwaiti Islamic scholar and preacher. He published more than 60 books related to Islam, especially Salafism. He was born in Monufia, Egypt. In 2011, he became a Kuwaiti citizen.

Abd al-Khaliq died on 29 September 2020 in Kuwait City from a heart attack, aged 80.

[[Luigi Arisio]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians, People from Turin

Luigi Arisio (25 March 1926 – 29 September 2020) was an Italian politician. He was a Deputy from 1983 to 1987. Arisio was born in Turin. He was a member of the Italian Republican Party. 

Arisio died on 29 September 2020 in Turin at the age of 94.

[[Isidora Žebeljan]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Composers, Conductors, People from Belgrade

Isidora Žebeljan (27 September 1967 – 29 September 2020) was a Serbian composer and conductor. She was a professor of composition at the Belgrade Music Academy. She was a member of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts. She won many national awards for her music, among them the Stevan Mokranjac National Music Award in 2004. Žebeljan was born in Belgrade.

Žebeljan died on 29 September 2020 in Belgrade at the age of 53.

[[François Diederich]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Luxembourgian people, Chemists, Educators, Deaths from cancer

Professor François Diederich (9 July 1952 – 23 September 2020) was a Luxembourgian chemist. His works focused in organic chemistry. Diederich was born in Ettelbruck, Luxembourg. In 1992 he was appointed Professor of Organic Chemistry at ETH Zurich. He retired on July 31, 2017. He was a foreign member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and National Academy of Sciences.

Diederich died on 23 September 2020 from cancer, aged 68.

[[2021 Formula One World Championship]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 in sports, Formula One seasons

The 2021 Formula One World Championship is the 72nd season of the Formula One World Championship. The motor racing championship is the highest class of competition for open-wheel racing cars.

[[Mario Luis Bautista Maulión]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Buenos Aires

Mario Luis Bautista Maulión (4 December 1934 – 27 September 2020) was an Argentina Roman Catholic archbishop. He was born in Buenos Aires. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1960. 

He was titular bishop of Febiana and was auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rosario, Argentina, from 1988 to 1995 and as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Nicolás de los Arroyos, Argentina, from 1995 to 2003. 

He was archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Paraná, Argentina, from 1995 to 2010.

Bautista Maulión died on 27 September 2020 in Rosario, Argentina at the age of 85.

[[Oleg Osetinsky]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Russian screenwriters, Russian movie directors

Oleg Evgenievich Osetinsky (9 July 1937 – 27 September 2020) was a Soviet-Russian screenwriter and documentary movie director. He was born in Yekaterinburg, Russia. His career began in 1961. He was best known for writing the screenplay for The Captivating Star of Happiness and Takeoff.

Osetinsky died on 27 September 2020 in Moscow, aged 83.

[[Brad Parscale]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American political commentators, People from Topeka, Kansas, Businesspeople from Kansas

Brad Parscale (born January 3, 1976) is an American digital consultant and political advisor. He was the senior adviser for data and digital operations for Donald Trump's 2020 presidential campaign.

He was the digital media director for Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and as campaign manager for Donald Trump's 2020 presidential campaign from February 2018 to July 2020, being replaced by Bill Stepien.

On September 27, 2020, Parscale was hospitalized after his wife told Fort Lauderdale police that he had guns and he was threatening to kill himself. He was arrested and hospitalized in Fort Lauderdale, Florida because of his mental health and for beating his wife.

[[Stranger Than Paradise]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 comedy movies, American comedy movies, German comedy movies, Movies directed by Jim Jarmusch

Stranger Than Paradise is a 1984 American German comedy movie directed by Jim Jarmusch and starring John Lurie, Eszter Balint, Richard Edson, Cecillia Stark, Tom DiCillo, Sara Driver.

[[The Notorious Landlady]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 comedy movies, 1960s mystery movies, American comedy movies, American mystery movies, Movies directed by Richard Quine

The Notorious Landlady is a 1962 American mystery comedy movie directed by Richard Quine and starring Kim Novak, Jack Lemmon, Fred Astaire, Lionel Jeffries, Estelle Winwood, Maxwell Reed, Doris Lloyd, Ronald Long. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Mac Davis]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Deaths from surgical complications, American country singers, American singer-songwriters, American country guitarists, American television actors, American movie actors, American voice actors, Musicians from Texas, Singers from Texas, Writers from Texas, Actors from Texas, People from Lubbock, Texas

Morris Mac Davis (January 21, 1942 – September 29, 2020) was an American country music singer-songwriter, guitarist and actor. His early work writing for Elvis Presley produced the hits "Memories", "In the Ghetto", "Don't Cry Daddy", and "A Little Less Conversation". He was also known for his solo hit "Baby, Don't Get Hooked on Me". 

Davis died on Nashville, Tennessee on September 29, 2020 from a heart attack caused by heart surgery, aged 78.

[[Hidden Figures]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 drama movies, 2010s biographical movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies composed by Hans Zimmer

Hidden Figures is a 2016 American biographical drama movie directed by Theodore Melfi and written by Melfi and Allison Schroeder. It is loosely based on the 2016 non-fiction book of the same name by Margot Lee Shetterly.

[[Christine Darden]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American mathematicians, Engineers from North Carolina, Scientists from North Carolina

Christine Darden (born Christine Mann; September 10, 1942) is an American mathematician, data analyst, and aeronautical engineer. She worked for NASA to researching supersonic flight and sonic booms for forty years. 

She was the first African-American woman at NASA's Langley Research Center to be promoted into the Senior Executive Service, the top rank in the federal civil service. She was born in Monroe, North Carolina.

In 2019, Darden was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal.

[[Margot Lee Shetterly]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, American historians, Writers from Virginia, People from Hampton, Virginia

Margot Lee Shetterly (born June 30, 1969) is an American non-fiction writer. 

Her first book, Hidden Figures: The Story of the African-American Women Who Helped Win the Space Race (2016). Her book was later made into an Academy Award-nominated movie Hidden Figures (2016). 

[[North Dallas Forty]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 comedy movies, 1979 drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Ted Kotcheff

North Dallas Forty is a 1979 American comedy-drama movie directed by Ted Kotcheff and was based on the 1973 novel of the same name by Peter Gent. It stars Nick Nolte, Mac Davis, Dayle Haddon, Bo Svenson, G. D. Spradlin, Dabney Coleman, Charles Durning and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[VX Sagittarii]]

CATEGORIES: Red giants

VX Sagittarii, also known as HIP 88838, is red hypergiant star with a diameter pulsating between 1.120 and 1.940 times greater than Sun, a luminosity between 3.200 and 3.400 degrees Kelvin. The star has a pulsation period of 732 days and is located 1.5 kiloparsecs away from the Earth. Older studies frequently higher luminositoes.

[[That's Life! (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Blake Edwards, American independent movies

That's Life! is a 1986 American comedy-drama movie directed by Blake Edwards and starring Jack Lemmon, Julie Andrews, Sally Kellerman, Robert Loggia, Jennifer Edwards, Rob Knepper, Chris Lemmon, Felicia Farr, Cynthia Sikes. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1987.

[[Missing (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, 1980s biographical movies, American drama movies, Mexican movies, Movies set in South America, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Costa-Gavras

Missing is a 1982 American Mexican biographical drama movie directed by Costa-Gavras and based on the 1978 novel by Thomas Hauser. It stars Jack Lemmon, Sissy Spacek, Melanie Mayron, John Shea, David Clennon, Jerry Hardin, Richard Venture and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 4 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1983.

[[The Axe (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 drama movies, Belgian movies, French drama movies, Spanish movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Costa-Gavras

The Axe is a 2005 Belgian French Spanish drama movie directed by Costa-Gavras and was based on the 1997 novel of the same name by Donald E. Westlake. It stars José Garcia, Karin Viard, Geordy Monfils, Christa Theret, Ulrich Tukur, Olivier Gourmet, Thierry Hancisse.

[[Quark-star]]

CATEGORIES: Stars

Quark-star is hypothetically celestial object that is intermediate in density between a neutron star and black hole, as the remnant of a massive neutron star that has collapsed with gravitational pressure sufficient to reduce all constituent particles to strange quarks. Quark-star can be smallest than 11 kilometers diameter. Like neutron stars, quark star are composed of neutrons that have undergone enough pressure by the collapse of the star to have lost their differentiation and disolved into a mass of quarks and gluons. The up and down quarks of which neutrons are composed than change into strange quarks, with the resulting strange mattery compacting into an even denser mass than a neutron star.

[[Quasi-star]]

CATEGORIES: Black holes

Quasi-star, also known as black hole star, is hypothetically star are believed to have only existed of beginning of the universe when most a the material in the galaxy was hydrogen and helium. A Quasi-star could be as large as 10 billion kilometers or roughly large than 7.000 times the radius of the sun. Quasi-star is supermassive star with a central black hole and are both considered as potential progenitor for the formation of supermassive black hole. They are expeted to form from rapidly accreting protostars in massive primordial halos.

[[Roberto Venturoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2011 deaths, Italian painters, Italian sculptors, Engravers, People from Rome

Roberto Venturoni (22 October 1945 – 18 September 2011) was an Italian painter, engraver and sculptor.

Luigi Salvatori (born 25 October 1951 in Palestrina) is an Italian painter of contemporary art.

[[Alone/Together]]

Alone/Together is a 2019 Filipino romantic drama movie directed by Antoinette Jadaone and starring Enrique Gil, Liza Soberano, Jasmine Curtis-Smith, Sylvia Sanchez, Adrian Alandy. It was distributed by ABS-CBN Films.

[[Timothy Ray Brown]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, American LGBT people, Cancer deaths in California, Deaths from leukemia, Gay men, People from Seattle, Washington

Timothy Ray Brown (March 11, 1966 – September 29, 2020) was an American man believed to be the first person cured of HIV/AIDS. Brown was called "The Berlin Patient" at the 2008 Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections (CROI). His identity was kept anonymous until he chose to come forward in 2010.

Brown grew up in Seattle, Washington. As an adult, he traveled across Europe. He was diagnosed with HIV in 1995 while studying in Berlin. In 2006, he was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia.

In 2019, Brown was again diagnosed with leukemia. He died in Palm Springs, California, on September 29, 2020. He was 54.

[[Naxalism]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s establishments, Communism, Politics of India

Naxalism is a type of Communism in India.  It started in the 1960s.  Naxalites believe in anti national terrorism and guerrilla warfare.  According to the Indian government, Naxalites are terrorists. Famous naxalites include Arundhati Roy, Ramchandra Guha, Kunal Kamra, Etc. 

Naxalism is named after the town of Naxalbari in West Bengal.

[[Castilleja del Campo]]

San Juan de Aznalfarache is a municipality found in the province of Seville in the autonomous community of Andalusia in Spain.

[[Inferior nasal conchae]]

CATEGORIES: Head (body part)

The inferior nasal conchae (inferior turbinated bone or inferior turbinal/turbinate) is one of the three paired nasal conchae in the nose. It extends horizontally along the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and consists of a lamina of spongy bone, curled upon itself like a scroll, (turbinate meaning inverted cone).

[[Barakaldo]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Basque Country, Municipalities in the Basque Country

Barakaldo (Baracaldo) is a municipality of 100,881 people (2019). It is in the province of Biscay in the autonomous community of the Basque Country in Spain.

[[Ranoidea rara]]

Ranoidea rara is a frog from Indonesia.  Scientists saw it in Papua Province, about 750 meters above sea level.

[[Rijnsburg]]

Valkenburg is a former municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. Since 2006, it has been part of the municipality of Katwijk.

[[Sassenheim]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in South Holland, Former municipalities of South Holland, Teylingen

Sassenheim is a former municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. Since 2006, it has been part of the new municipality of Teylingen.

The former municipality covers an area of 6.62 km² (of which 0.23 km² water). In 2005, it had a population of 14,906.

[[Warmond]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in South Holland, Former municipalities of South Holland, Teylingen

Warmond is a former municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. Since 2006, it has been part of the municipality of Teylingen.

[[Teylingen]]

CATEGORIES: Teylingen, 2006 establishments in the Netherlands

Teylingen is a municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. In 2019, 37,061 people lived there.

It was created on 1 January 2006 from the former municipalities of Sassenheim, Voorhout, and Warmond.

[[Bergschenhoek]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in South Holland, Former municipalities of South Holland, Lansingerland

Bergschenhoek is a former municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. Since 2007, it has been part of the new municipality of Lansingerland.

[[Seo Yea-ji]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, South Korean television actors, South Korean movie actors, People from Seoul, Living people

Seo Yea-ji (서예지, born April 6, 1990) is a South Korean actress. She is known for her roles in the television series Diary of a Night Watchman (2014), Save Me (2017),  Lawless Lawyer (2018), and It's Okay to Not Be Okay (2020). She also known for her roles in movies The Throne (2015), Another Way (2017), and By Quantum Physics: A Nightlife Venture (2019).

[[Manfred Cross]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, Australian Labor Party politicians, Members of the Australian House of Representatives, Order of Australia, Politicians from Brisbane

Manfred Douglas Cross AUS (born 12 August 1929) is a former Australian politician. He was a member of the Labor Party. He served two terms in the House of Representatives for the Division of Brisbane from 1961 to 1975, and again from 1980 to 1990. 

Cross was born in Brisbane, Queensland.

[[William Henry Howell]]

CATEGORIES: 1860 births, 1945 deaths, American psychologists, Scientists from Baltimore, Maryland

William Henry Howell, Ph.D., M.D., LL.D., Sc.D. (February 20, 1860 – February 6, 1945) was an American-born physiologist best known for pioneering the use of heparin as an anticoagulant. He was born in Baltimore, Maryland.

[[Anticoagulant]]

CATEGORIES: Medical tests, Blood, Drugs

An anticoagulant is a chemical injected under the skin or directly into a vein that stops blood clots.

[[Bernard Madrelle]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, French mayors

Bernard Madrelle (27 April 1944 – 25 September 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the Socialist Party. He was born in Saint-Seurin-de-Cursac, France. 

From 1978 to 2007, he was a member of the National Assembly. He was also Mayor of Saint-Seurin-de-Cursac between 1983 to 1989 and for Blaye between 1989 to 2008.

Madrelle died of liver cancer in Blaye, France on 25 September 2020 at the age of 76.

[[Angelita Castany]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Dancers, Actors from Mexico City, Singers from Mexico City

Angelita Castany (13 March 1934 – 29 September 2020) was a Cuban-born Mexican actress, dancer and singer. Castany appeared in many movies and telenovelas. She was known for her roles in Por mis pistolas (1968), Infamia (1981), Extraños caminos del amor (1981) and Valentina (1993).

Castany was born in Havana, Cuba. Her career began in 1960 when she moved to Mexico City. She was married to comedian Chabelo. Castany died at a hospital in Mexico City from respiratory failure on 29 September 2020, aged 86.

[[Rocco Prestia]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver disease, Organ transplant recipients, American jazz musicians, American funk musicians, American guitarists, Musicians from California

Francis Rocco Prestia Jr. (March 7, 1951 – September 29, 2020) was an American jazz bassist. He was born in Sonora, California. He was best known for his work with the funk band Tower of Power. He was with the band from the 1970s until the early 2000s when he left because of his health.

In December 2014, Prestia had a liver transplant. He died on September 29, 2020 from liver disease, aged 69.

[[Doyle Royal]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, American centenarians, American footballers, American tennis players, Sportspeople from Washington, D.C., Sportspeople from Maryland

Doyle P. Royal (January 29, 1919 – September 29, 2020) was an American college soccer and tennis coach. He coached the University of Maryland soccer team from 1946 to 1973, and the tennis team from 1954 to 1980. He played for the Maryland Terrapins between 1939 to 1943. Royal was born in Washington, D.C..

In January 2019, Doyle celebrated his 100th birthday in Bethesda, Maryland.

Royal died on September 29, 2020 at the age of 101.

[[My Ex and Whys]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 comedy movies, 2010s romantic comedy movies, Filipino movies, South Korean movies, Movies directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina

My Ex and Whys is a 2017 Filipino South Korean romantic comedy movie directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Enrique Gil, Liza Soberano, Joey Marquez, Cai Cortez, Ara Mina, Ryan Bang, Dominic Roque. It was distributed by Star Cinema.

[[The Americanization of Emily]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 drama movies, 1960s romantic drama movies, 1960s war movies, American romantic drama movies, World War II movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Arthur Hiller

The Americanization of Emily is a 1964 American World War II romantic drama movie directed by Arthur Hiller and was based on the novel of the same name by William Bradford Huie. It stars James Garner, Julie Andrews, James Coburn, Paul Newlan, Joyce Grenfell, Keenwan Wynn, Liz Frazer, Edward Binns and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1965.

[[John Whittaker (rugby league)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, New Zealand rugby league players

John Albert Whittaker (28 March 1950 – 29 September 2020) was a New Zealand rugby league footballer. He played in the 1970s and 1980s at international level for the New Zealand national rugby league team and the Cook Islands.

Whittaker died on 29 September 2020 from cancer at the age of 70.

[[Generoso Pompa]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Italian painters, People from Alexandria, Living people

Generoso Pompa (born 11 March 1952 in Alexandria), also known as Gene (pseudonym), is an Italian painter of contemporary art.

[[National Monument (Indonesia)]]

CATEGORIES: Monuments and memorials, Buildings and structures in Indonesia, Jakarta

The National Monument or Monas (Indonesia: Monumen Nasional) is an icon of Jakarta which is located in center of Jakarta, it is an attractive tourist and educational center for resident of Jakarta and its surroundings. Monas was founded on August 1959 and inaugurated two years later on August 17 1961. It was designed by Soedarsono, Frederick Silaban and Ir. Rooseno and inaugurated by Ir. Soekarno, began to be opened to the public since July 12 1975. Monas is always crowded with tourists to see the beauty of the city of Jakarta from the top of Monas, and insight into history of indonesia into the diaroma room or enjoy the fresh urban forest of approximately 80 hectares in the middle of Indonesia and has height of about 132 meters.

[[Emyr Humphreys]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, British centenarians, Welsh novelists, Welsh poets

Emyr Humphreys (15 April 1919 – 30 September 2020) was a Welsh novelist and poet. During his long bilingual writing career, he published over twenty novels. They include A Toy Epic (1958), Outside the House of Baal (1965), and The Land of the Living

Humphreys died on 30 September 2020 at the age of 101.

[[Quino]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Argentine artists, Cartoonists

Joaquín Salvador Lavado Tejón, better known by his pen name Quino (ˈkino; 17 July 1932 – 30 September 2020), was an Argentine cartoonist. His comic strip Mafalda (which ran from 1964 to 1973) is popular in many parts of the Americas and Europe. He was born in Mendoza, Argentina.

Quino died on 30 September 2020 from a stroke in Mendoza, at the age of 88.

[[Leona Farris]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, Living people, American educators, Writers from Ohio, American centenarians

Leona Wright Farris (born August 11, 1917) is an American educator. She was born in Stow, Ohio.

Farris worked as an assistant professor at the University of Akron from 1969 to 1998. She was the first African American woman to hold that position at the university. Her family was one of the first black families to live in Stow, Ohio. 

Farris turned 100 in August 2017.

[[Ulysses S. Grant Memorial]]

CATEGORIES: Ulysses S. Grant, Monuments and memorials in the United States, Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The Ulysses S. Grant Memorial is a presidential memorial in Washington, D.C.. It honors American Civil War general and 18th United States President Ulysses S. Grant. 

It is located at the base of Capitol Hill, below the west front of the United States Capitol. 

Its central sculpture of Grant on horseback faces west, overlooking the Capitol Reflecting Pool and facing toward the Lincoln Memorial.

[[Capitol Reflecting Pool]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The Capitol Reflecting Pool is a reflecting pool in Washington, D.C., United States. It lies to the west of the United States Capitol and is the westernmost section of the Capitol grounds. The Capitol Dome and the Ulysses S. Grant Memorial are reflected in its waters.

[[United States Capitol dome]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The United States Capitol dome is the dome located above the rotunda of the

United States Capitol. 

The dome is 288 in height and 96 in diameter. 

It was designed by Thomas U. Walter, the fourth Architect of the Capitol, and constructed between 1855 and 1866 at a cost of $1,047,291.

[[United States Capitol rotunda]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The United States Capitol rotunda is the central rotunda of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C.. It was built 1818–1824. It is located below the Capitol dome, built 1857–1866. It is the tallest part of the Capitol and has been described as its "symbolic and physical heart".

The rotunda is 96 in diameter, rises 48 to the top of its original walls and 180.

[[Rotunda (architecture)]]

CATEGORIES: Architecture

A rotunda (from Latin rotundus) is any building with a circular plan, and sometimes covered by a dome. It may also refer to a round room within a building. A famous example is the one below the dome of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C..

[[Seven Sundays (2017 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 comedy-drama movies, Filipino movies, Movies directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina

Seven Sundays is a 2017 Filipino comedy-drama movie directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Aga Muhlach, Dingdong Dantes, Cristine Reyes, Enrique Gil, Ronaldo Valdez. It was distributed by Star Cinema.

[[Mount Tangkuban Parahu]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes, Geography of Indonesia

Tangkuban Parahu is an active volcano in Indonesia.  It is in Northern Bandung, Cikole, Lembang. It is about 20 km from the center of Bandung city, Western Java. Tangkuban Parahu is 2084 meters above sea level or about 6873 feet high. The temperature in this area is 17 degrees Celsius at noon and can reach 2 degrees Celsius at night.

Unlike other volcanoes, the peak of Tangkuban Parahu looks similar to an overturned boat when looked at from the side.

There is a legend, the legend of Sangkuriang which tells the origin of Tangkuban Parahu.

The volcano has several craters. Some are Ratu crater, Upas crater, and Domas crater.

[[The Warrior (song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 songs

"The Warrior" is a song by Scandal featuring Patty Smyth, from the album Warrior.

[[Who's Got the Action?]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Daniel Mann

Who's Got the Action? is a 1962 American comedy movie directed by Daniel Mann and was based on the novel by Alexander Rose. It stars Dean Martin, Lana Turner, Walter Matthau, Eddie Albert, Jack Albertson and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[János Dalmati]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian sportspeople, Sportspeople from Budapest

János Dalmati (26 February 1942 – 29 September 2020) was a Hungarian racewalker. He competed in the men's 50 kilometres walk at the 1972 Summer Olympics. He was born in Budapest.

Dalmati died on 29 September 2020 in Budapest, aged 78.

[[European Green Deal]]

CATEGORIES: European Union, December 2019 events, January 2020 events

The European Green Deal is a set of policy plans by the European Commission with the aim of making Europe climate neutral in 2050. It will increase the EU's greenhouse gas emission reductions target for 2030 to at least 50% and towards 55% compared with 1990 levels. 

The president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said that the European Green Deal would be Europe's "man on the Moon moment", as the plan would make Europe the first climate-neutral continent. Von der Leyen appointed Frans Timmermans as Executive Vice President of the European Commission for the European Green Deal. 

On 13 December 2019, the European Council decided to approve the plan, with a rejection from Poland. On 15 January 2020 the European Parliament voted to support the deal as well. 

[[Frans Timmermans]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Deputy government ministers of the Netherlands, European Commissioners, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Government ministers of the Netherlands, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, People from Maastricht, Politicians from Limburg (Netherlands)

Franciscus Cornelis Gerardus Maria Timmermans (frɑnˈsɪskʏs kɔrˈneːlɪs xeːˈrɑrdʏs frɑns ˈtɪmərˌmɑns; born 6 May 1961) is a Dutch politician. He is the First Vice President of the European Commission since 2014. He is also the Executive Vice President of the European Commission for the European Green Deal and European Commissioner for Climate Action since 2019.

[[Keith Jobling]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, Sportspeople from Lincolnshire, English football managers

Keith Jobling (26 March 1934 – 20 September 2020) was an English professional footballer. He was born in New Waltham, Lincolnshire.

He made 450 appearances in the Football League as a centre half for Grimsby Town. After leaving Grimsby he joined Boston United, first as a player and then as a manager.

Jobling died on 20 September 2020, at the age of 86.

[[Malcolm Innes of Edingight]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Politicians from Edinburgh

Sir Malcolm Rognvald Innes of Edingight GBR (25 May 1938 – 20 September 2020) was a Scottish civil servant. He was the Lord Lyon King of Arms of Scotland from 1981 until 2001. He was born in Edinburgh. 

He was appointed a Writer to the Signet in 1964. Following his retirement in 2001, he was appointed Orkney Herald of Arms Extraordinary. He was a co-founder of the Heraldry Society of Scotland.

He died on 20 September 2020 at the age of 82 from cancer.

[[Serhiy Atelkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Ukrainian footballers

Serhiy Atelkin (Сергій Ателькін, January 8, 1972 – October 1, 2020) was a Ukrainian footballer. Atelkin became the first player from the independent Ukraine who played in the Italian Seria A. He was born in Khrestivka, Ukraine. He made two caps for the national team in 1997. From 1990 to 1997, he played for FC Shakhtar Donetsk.

Atelkin died of a heart attack in Kiev, Ukraine on October 1, 2020, at the age of 48.

[[National Assembly (Kuwait)]]

CATEGORIES: Kuwait

The National Assembly (مجلس الأمة), is the unicameral legislature of Kuwait. The National Assembly meets in Kuwait City.

Members are chosen through direct election; the country is divided into five electoral districts with ten members representing each district. There are no official political parties in Kuwait.

[[Yemi Osinbajo]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Nigerian politicians, Presidents of Nigeria

Oluyemi Oluleke "Yemi" Osinbajo  (born 8 March 1957), is a Nigerian lawyer and politician. He is the current Vice President of Nigeria, in office since 29 May 2015.

[[Bill Nation]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, American mayors, Politicians from Wyoming, US Democratic Party politicians

Bill Nation (born 1925) is an American politician for the Democratic Party. He served as the 45th and 50th mayor of Cheyenne, Wyoming, from 1962 to 1966 and 1973 to 1977. He was a member of the Wyoming House of Representatives from Laramie County between 1965 and 1967.

Nation was born in Lingle, Wyoming. He is married to Jo Ann Petersen and has four children.

[[Plaza Suite]]

Plaza Suite is a 1971 American comedy movie directed by Arthur Hiller and was based on the 1968 play of the same name by Neil Simon. It stars Walter Matthau, Maureen Stapleton, Barbara Harris, Lee Grant, Jenny Sullivan and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Pia Juul]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Danish poets, Novelists, Danish educators, Translators, People from Copenhagen

Pia Juul (May 30, 1962 – September 30, 2020) was a Danish poet, writer and translator. She received several prizes. She was a member of the Danish Academy. She also taught at the Danish writing school Forfatterskolen in Copenhagen. Juul was born in Korsør, Denmark.

Juul died on September 30, 2020 in Copenhagen at the age of 58.

[[Allan Savory]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Ecologists, Zimbabwean people

Clifford Allan Redin Savory (born 15 September 1935) is a Zimbabwean ecologist and livestock farmer. He is the president and co-founder of the Savory Institute. His works focuses on holistic management for resources. His controversial ideas include that livestock are the only ones that can limit desertification.

Prince Charles called him "a remarkable ecologist".

[[Zamani Saul]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1972 births, South African politicians

Zamani Saul (born 7 March 1972) is a South African politician. He has been the Premier of the Northern Cape and a Member of the Northern Cape Provincial Legislature since May 2019. He is a member of the ruling African National Congress and the party's current provincial chairperson. Saul was formerly the party's provincial secretary and deputy provincial secretary.

[[Albrandswaard]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of South Holland

Albrandswaard is a municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. In 2019, 25,271 people lived there.

Albrandswaard has two settlements: Rhoon and Poortugaal.

[[Alphen aan den Rijn]]

CATEGORIES: Alphen aan den Rijn, Settlements in South Holland

Alphen aan den Rijn is a municipality in the Dutch province of South Holland. In 2019, 110,986 people lived there.

On 1 January 2014, the former municipalities of Boskoop and Rijnwoude joined together to become the municipality of Alphen aan den Rijn.

[[Common mist frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The common mist frog, Atherton Tableland tree frog, creek frog (Ranoidea rhecola) is a tree frog from Australia.  Scientists saw it in northern Queensland.  It lives as low as sea level and as high as 1120 metres up in the hills.

This frog is in danger of dying out.  It lives in rainforests and sclerophyll forests, in streams where the water flows quickly.  The adult male frog spends time in rocky streams and the female frog and young frog sit on plants near streams.  The tadpole lives where the water flows fast.  They hold onto rocks with their mouths, which are on the undersides of their bodies.

The female frog lays 46-63 eggs at a time.  They are 2.4-2.6 mm in diameter. She lays them in groups under rocks in the water.

Scientists are not sure why this frog is endangered, but they do not think it is droughts or that humans have changed too much of the wild places where they live.  This is because Australia made laws protecting the frogs' home in 1988, but there are still fewer and fewer of them.  Scientists say one reason this frog is endangered is because pigs that have run away from people run through their streams and kill adult frogs.  This frog can catch the fungal disease chytridiomycosis.

Scientists say this frog is related to Ranoidea nannotis.

[[Himnusz]]

CATEGORIES: National anthems, Hungary

Himnusz (pron. ˈhimnus "HIM-noose"; en. "Hymn") is the national anthem of Hungary. It was adopted in 1844 as the de facto (unofficial) anthem of Hungary, then later in 1989 as de jure (in accordance with the law). The lyrics (music words) were written by Ferenc Kölcsey in 1823, and the melody was composed by Ferenc Erkel in 1844.

It has been translated into many languages. It was translated into English in 1881 by American-Hungarian translator and author William Noah Loew (1847–1922).

[[Fred Ngajiro]]

Fred Fabian Ngajiro also known as Fred Vunjabei (Born 16th June 1987 in Iringa) is a Tanzania businessman and entrepreneur. He is among the youngest entrepreneurs and business people in Tanzania. Fred is the the founder and CEO of one of the Tanzania`s Clothing Store Vunjabei (T) Group Limited and President of Too Much Money Limited which manage few Tanzania artist such as Whozu. He was nominated at Tanzania Digital Awards as Best Male Entrepreneur on the Digital in 2019 and in 2020 he was nominated as Most Preferred Upcoming Male Business Icon Of The Year 2020 at Tanzania Consumer Choice Awards.

[[Plevna March]]

CATEGORIES: Ottoman Empire, Turkey

"Plevne Marşı" (en. The Plevne March), also "Osman Paşa Marşı", is an Ottoman Turkish song written by Mehmet Ali Bey to commemorate Osman Nuri Pasha (or Bey), an Ottoman field marshal who led Ottoman troops in the Siege of Plevna. Dikran Çuhacıyan wrote it.

[[Potting soil]]

CATEGORIES: Gardening

Potting soil is also known as potting mix.  The main use for potting mix is to give the plant a place for its roots to grow.  Many potting mixes contain vermiculute or perlite, which keep the potting mix fluffy so air can reach the plant's roots.  Potting mix allows for drainage, meaning it holds on to water long enough for the plant to take some of it, but then the rest of the water flows away so that the roots do not become too wet.

[[Shooting of Philando Castile]]

CATEGORIES: People shot dead by law enforcement officers in the United States, Black Lives Matter

Philando Castile was a 32-year-old African American man who was shot dead by two Minnesota police officers during a routine traffic stop on July 6, 2016.

Castile was driving with his girlfriend, Diamond Reynolds and her 4-year-old daughter when they were pulled over by Officer Yanez and his partner. Yanez asked Castile for his license and registration and Castile told him that he was legally carrying a firearm. The officers told him not to reach for it, to which Castile told them he was not reaching for his weapon. Yanez fired 7 rounds at close range, hitting Castile 5 times. Castile died 20 minutes later.

[[The Proud Boys]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in the United States, Political parties in the United States, Fascism, Nationalism

The Proud Boys are a twenty-first century alt-right organization.  They do most of their things in the United States.  A Canadian-British man called Gavin McInnes started the group because he hoped Donald Trump would win the 2016 United States presidential election.  The Proud Boys only allow men to join, so there are no women. They call themselves "western chauvinists," meaning they think Western Civilization is the best, and they say they are not racist, are not alt-right and do not support white supremacy or fascism or violence.  Experts disagree and say they are racist, are alt-right and do support white supremacy and violence.

According to the Anti-Defamation League, the Proud Boys hate women, Muslims, transmen and transwomen, and immigrants.  The United States FBI says they are an extremist group.  The Southern Poverty Law Center says they are a hate group.

As of 2020, Twitter, Facebook and other social media sites do not allow Proud Boys to post. Square, J.P. Morgan Chase and Paypal all stopped processing payments from the Proud Boys' online store.

[[Lingle, Wyoming]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Wyoming

Lingle is a town in Goshen County, Wyoming, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 468.

[[Superior, Wyoming]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Wyoming

Superior is a town in Sweetwater County, Wyoming, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 336.

[[Lindy Chamberlain-Creighton]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Australian writers, Naturalised citizens of Australia, People from North Island

Alice Lynne "Lindy" Chamberlain-Creighton (née Murchison; born 4 March 1948) is a New Zealand-born Australian woman who was wrongfully convicted of the death of her nine-week-old daughter daughter Azaria in 1980. The event happened at a campsite near Uluru, Northern Territory. It was one of Australia's most notable murder trials. Chamberlain said that she saw a dingo leave the tent where Azaria was sleeping.

Chamberlain was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of her daughter in 1982. Her appeals to the Federal Court of Australia and High Court of Australia were dismissed. On 7 February 1986, after the discovery of new evidence, Chamberlain was released from prison. She and her husband Michael Chamberlain were officially pardoned in 1987.

Chamberlain was born in Whakatāne, New Zealand. She married Michael Chamberlain in 1969. Aside from Azaria, the couple had three other children. They divorced in 1991. She married Rick Creighton in 1992.

In the movie Evil Angels (1988), Meryl Streep played the role of Chamberlain. Streep's performance earnt her an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress in 1989.

Lyman is a town in Wyoming in the United States.

[[Peixinhos da horta]]

CATEGORIES: Portuguese food

Peixinhos da horta (pɐjˈʃĩɲuʒ or pejˈʃĩɲuʒ ðɐ ˈɔɾtɐ) is a Portuguse dish. Its name in Portuguese means "little fishes from the garden", as it looks like small pieces of colourful fish. It was brought to Japan by Portuguese sailors in the 16th century, where it became tempura.

[[Mary Barbera]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1965 births, Autism, American psychologists, American writers

Mary Barbera is an American behavior analyst and author who works on autism. She is known for her work on using Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) for children with autism. Her books include The Verbal Behavior Approach (2007), a book about Applied Behavior Analysis and B. F. Skinner's analysis of verbal behavior.

[[Environmental racism]]

CATEGORIES: Environment, Racism

Many countries make rules to protect the environment. These rules can be laws, guidelines, or regulations. Ideally, these rules affect all groups in society in the same way. When this is not the case, and one group or community is affected more than the others, this is known as environmental racism.  As is common with racism, the groups are defined based on race, or skin color; sometimes on income.  Very often, all the people decide on these rules. When some groups are excluded from the decision-making process, this is also known as environmental racism.  

Benjamin Chavis first used the term, in the 1980s. At the time, he was a leading member of the Civil rights movement in the United States. The movement found that  when a new landfill was constructed, minorities such as hispanics and black people were affected more often than the white people. The explanation given was the difference in income - hispanics and black people often earn less than white people. A study of 2007 showed that this explanation is too simple and that there are more complex patterns at play. The study also showed that environmental racism occurs in almost all bigger cities in the United States. 

The term was later used to describe the situation in the Niger delta, and in Western New Guinea. 

Environmental justice is a term that started about the same time; it focuses more on distruibuting the benefits and burdens of environmental policies equally in society.

[[Environmental revitalization]]

CATEGORIES: Environment, Ecology

Environmental revitalization is a process where plant life and other life is brought back to an area that was polluted, barren, contaminated, or turned into desert. Areas of environmental revitalization can be wetlands, meadows and forests.

[[White House Rose Garden]]

CATEGORIES: Gardens, Parks in the United States, Washington, D.C.

The White House Rose Garden is a garden by the White House in Washington, D.C., United States. The president holds speeches talks in the Rose Garden.

[[Bye Bye Bye]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 songs, NSYNC, Pop songs

"Bye Bye Bye" is a pop song under the American boy band NSYNC. The song was released on January 17, 2000 off the album No Strings Attached. The song lyrics talk about the end of a relationship.

"Bye Bye Bye" was a strong success. It peaked at #4 on the United States "Billboard" Hot 100. It also peaked in the top 10 in every country in which it charted. The song got a Grammy nomination for Best Record of the Year. But it lost to U2's "Beautiful Day".

[[Yuko Natsuyoshi]]

Yuko Natsuyoshi is a voice actress of anime characters. She is the voices for Sasha Necron in The Misfit of Demon King Academy and Yuyu Shirai in Assault Lilly BOUQUET.

[[Jamie Babbit]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, American television directors, Lesbians, LGBT directors, LGBT screenwriters, LGBT people from Ohio, Movie producers from Ohio, Movie directors from Ohio, Screenwriters from Ohio, People from Shaker Heights, Ohio, Living people

Jamie Babbit (born November 16, 1970) is an American movie director, producer and screenwriter. She directed the movies But I'm a Cheerleader and The Quiet. She also directed certain episodes of Gilmore Girls, Malcolm in the Middle and The L Word.

In 1999, Babbit's movie But I'm a Cheerleader was given an NC-17 by the Motion Picture Association of America because of lesbian scenes. Seven years later, Babbit went on This Film Is Not Yet Rated about her experience with the MPAA.

Babbit was born in the Cleveland area of northern Ohio.

[[Dafydd Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Canadian astronauts, Canadian physicians, Canadian writers, Order of Canada, People from Saskatoon

Dafydd Rhys Williams OC OOnt CCFP FCFP FRCPC FRCP (born May 16, 1954) is a Canadian physician, public speaker, writer and retired astronaut. He was chosen by the Canadian Space Agency (CSA) in 1992. Williams took part in two spaceflights. He flew aboard Space Shuttle Columbia for mission STS-90 and Space Shuttle Endeavour for mission STS-118.

In 1998, Williams became the first non-American to hold a senior management position within NASA. He held the role of Director of the Space and Life Sciences Directorate at the Johnson Space Center and Deputy Associate Administrator of the Office of Spaceflight at NASA's headquarters.

Williams was born in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. His father, Bill Williams, was Welsh. He is married and has three children. In 2004, he had his prostate removed after he was diagnosed with cancer.

[[Agile marketing]]

CATEGORIES: Marketing

Agile marketing is a term used in marketing. Agile marketing means using the results of a marketing campaign to analyze whether the campaign is going to succeed or fail at the end and adjusting the marketing strategy. If initial results from the marketing campaign suggests the campaign is going to be a successful one, the marketers will use the data to make it a more successful one. If the initial results suggests the campaign is failing, the marketers can adjust their strategy to minimize their costs and make the failing campaign a successful one.

[[Henry Morgan]]

CATEGORIES: 1630 births, 1630s births, 1635 births, 1688 deaths, 17th century births, Admirals, British explorers, British military people, British politicians, Deaths from cirrhosis, English people, History of Jamaica, History of Panama, History of Wales, Knights Bachelor, Pirates, Slavers, Welsh people

Sir Henry Poopan was a Welsh privateer, plantation owner, and, later, Lieutenant Governor of Jamaica. From his base in Port Royal, Jamaica, he raided settlements and shipping on the Spanish Main, becoming wealthy as he did so.

[[Job board]]

Job board or an employment website is a website created for looking for employment. Job board is an online platform that displays a wide range of job advertisements. Employers usually pays fees for jobs posting. Online job exchanges are usually free of charge for job seekers. You can often find tips and information on the topics of jobs, careers and applications on job exchanges. Some job boards also specialize in certain industries, occupational groups or geographical areas.

[[Berimbau]]

CATEGORIES: Musical instruments, Brazilian culture

The berimbau (beɾĩˈbaw) is a single-string percussion instrument, a musical bow, from Brazil. Originally from Africa where it receives different names, the berimbau was eventually brought into the practice of the Afro-Brazilian martial art capoeira, the berimbau leads the capoeiristas movement in the roda—the faster the berimbau is playing the faster the capoeirista moves in the game.
