[[Wilcox's frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

Wilcox's frog, Kinghorn's tree frog, or Ithica Creek treefrog (Ranoidea wilcoxii)  is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland and New South Wales.

The adult male frog is 3.5 to 4.8 cm long and the adult female frog is 3.9 to 6.5 cm long.  This frog is light brown.  Some frogs have markings and some do not.  This frog has a black and yellow stripe down each side of its body.  The eggs are dark in color.  The female frog lays eggs at the edges of streams where the water does not flow quickly or under rocks in the water.  This frog can catch the fungal disease chytridiomycosis.

[[207 series (JR East)]]

CATEGORIES: Electric multiple units

The 207 series or 207-900 series was a commuter electric multiple unit (EMU) train type introduced in 1986 by the Japanese National Railways (JNR) and operated by the  East Japan Railway Company (JR East) on through services between the Joban Line and Tokyo Metro Chiyoda Line. Only one 10-car set was built, which was withdrawn in December 2009.

[[East Japan Railway Company]]

CATEGORIES: East Japan Railway Company, 1987 establishments in Japan, Train operating companies, Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange

The East Japan Railway Company (JR東日本) or the JR East is a major passenger railway company in Japan and is the biggest of the seven Japan Railways Group companies. The company's headquarters are in Yoyogi, Shibuya, Tokyo. It is listed in the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

[[Tokyo Metro 7000 series]]

CATEGORIES: Electric multiple units

The Tokyo Metro 7000 series is an electric multiple unit (EMU) train type operated by the Tokyo subway operator Tokyo Metro in Tokyo, Japan, since 1974. The design is based on the earlier Tokyo Metro 6000 series trains used on the Tokyo Metro Chiyoda Line.

[[Tokyo Metro 08 series]]

CATEGORIES: Electric multiple units

The Tokyo Metro 08 series is an electric multiple unit (EMU) train type operated on the Tokyo Metro Hanzōmon Line in Tokyo, Japan since 2003. Introduced into service on 1 July 2003, a total of six ten-car trainsets were manufactured by Nippon Sharyo between 2002 and 2003 to augment the Tokyo Metro 8000 series trains following the extension to Oshiage.

[[E233 series]]

CATEGORIES: Electric multiple units

The E233 series is a commuter and suburban electric multiple unit (EMU) train type developed by East Japan Railway Company (JR East) from the earlier E231 series and the E531 series design. The first train was introduced in December 2006 for use on the Chūō Line (Rapid), followed by the E233-1000 series variant in 2007 for use on the Keihin–Tōhoku and Negishi lines, the E233-3000 series outer-suburban variant in December 2007 for use on the Tōkaidō Main Line, and narrow-bodied E233-2000 series variant for Jōban Line and Tokyo Metro Chiyoda Line inter-running services. Further variants were built for use on the Keiyō Line, Yokohama Line, Saikyō Line, and Nambu Line.

[[N700 Series Shinkansen]]

CATEGORIES: Shinkansen

The N700 series (N700系, Enu nanahyaku-kei) is a Japanese Shinkansen high-speed train with tilting capability developed jointly by JR Central and JR West for use on the Tokaido and San'yō Shinkansen lines since 2007, and also operated by JR Kyushu on the Kyushu Shinkansen line.

[[R142 (New York City Subway car)]]

CATEGORIES: New York City Subway

The R142 was the first successful type of new technology (NTT) A-division subway car for the New York City Subway. It was built by Bombardier Transportation in La Pocatiere, Quebec and Barre, Vermont. Final assembly was performed in Plattsburgh, New York. These cars were built from 1999 to 2003. There are 800 cars numbered 6301-7150 and another 400 cars numbered 1101-1250, for a total of 1,200 cars, all arranged as five-car sets. The R142 and R142A replaced the Redbird trains, including the R26, R28, R29, R33, R33S, and R36.

[[R160 (New York City Subway car)]]

CATEGORIES: New York City Subway, Electric multiple units

The R160 is a class of New Technology subway cars built for the New York City Subway B Division. Entering service between 2006 and 2010, they replaced all R38, R40/A, and NYCT-operated R44 cars, and most R32 and R42 cars. The R160s are very similar to the R143s, but the two-car types cannot run together in the same train. The biggest difference between them is the FIND (Flexible Information and Notice Display) system on the R160s in place of static LED maps on the R143s.

[[The Odd Couple II]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 comedy movies, 1990s road movies, 1990s sequel movies, American comedy movies, American sequel movies, Movies directed by Howard Deutch

The Odd Couple II is a 1998 American comedy movie and the sequel to the 1968 movie The Odd Couple, directed by Howard Deutch and based on Neil Simon's play of the same name. It stars Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Richard Riehle, Jonathan Silverman, Jay O. Saunders, Jean Smart, Rex Linn, Alice Ghostley, Barnard Hughes and Rebecca Schull.

[[Buddy Buddy]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movie remakes, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Billy Wilder

Buddy Buddy is a 1981 American comedy movie based on Francis Veber's play and the final film directed by Billy Wilder. It stars Walter Matthau, Jack Lemmon and Paula Prentiss.

[[William Standish Knowles]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2012 deaths, American chemists, Scientists from Massachusetts

ChemistryWilliam Standish Knowles (June 1, 1917 – June 13, 2012) was an American chemist. He was born in Taunton, Massachusetts.  Knowles was one of the recipients of the 2001 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.  He split half the prize with Ryōji Noyori for their work in asymmetric synthesis, specifically for his work in hydrogenation reactions.  

The other half was awarded to K. Barry Sharpless for his work in oxidation reactions.

Knowles died on June 13, 2012 in Chesterfield, Missouri at the age of 95.

[[Ryōji Noyori]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Japanese chemists

ChemistryRyōji Noyori is a Japanese chemist. He won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2001, Noyori shared a half of the prize with William S. Knowles for the study of chirally catalyzed hydrogenations.

[[Karl Barry Sharpless]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, American chemists, Scientists from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

ChemistryKarl Barry Sharpless (born April 28, 1941) is an American chemist and Nobel Laureate. He is  known for his work on stereoselective reactions and click chemistry.

[[Dan Shechtman]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Israeli scientists, Chemists

ChemistryDan Shechtman (דן שכטמן; born January 24, 1941) is an Israeli chemist. He is the Philip Tobias Professor of Materials Science at the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology.

On April 8, 1982, while on sabbatical at the U.S. National Bureau of Standards in Washington, D.C., Shechtman discovered the icosahedral phase, which opened the new field of quasiperiodic crystals.  

Shechtman was awarded the 2011 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for the discovery of quasicrystals, making him one of six Israelis who have won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

[[John B. Fenn]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2010 deaths, American chemists, Scientists from New York City

ChemistryJohn Bennett Fenn (June 15, 1917spaced ndashDecember 10, 2010) was an American analytical chemist. He was awarded a share of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2002.  Fenn shared half of the award with Koichi Tanaka for their work in mass spectrometry.

[[Koichi Tanaka]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Japanese engineers, Japanese chemists

ChemistryKoichi Tanaka is a Japanese electrical engineer. He shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2002 for creating a method for mass spectrometric analyses of biological macromolecules with John Bennett Fenn and Kurt Wüthrich.

[[Kurt Wüthrich]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Swiss chemists, Physicists, Swiss biologists

ChemistryKurt Wüthrich (born 4 October 1938) is a Swiss chemist/biophysicist and Nobel Chemistry winner. He is known for developing nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods for studying biological macromolecules.

[[Peter Agre]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American physicians, American biologists, Scientists from Minnesota

ChemistryPeter Agre ˈ (born January 30, 1949) is an American physician and molecular biologist. He was a professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.

In 2003, Agre and Roderick MacKinnon shared the 2003 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for "discoveries concerning channels in cell membranes." A

In 2009, Agre was elected president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and became active in science diplomacy.

[[Aaron Ciechanover]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Israeli scientists, Biologists

ChemistryAaron Ciechanover (En-us-Aaron Ciechanover from Israel pronunciation (Voice of America).ogg AH; אהרן צ'חנובר; born October 1, 1947) is an Israeli biologist. He won the Nobel prize in Chemistry for characterizing the method that cells use to degrade and recycle proteins using ubiquitin.

[[Avram Hershko]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Hungarian scientists, Israeli scientists, Biologists

ChemistryAvram Hershko (אברהם הרשקו; born 31 December 1937) is a Hungarian-born  Israeli biochemist and Nobel laureate in Chemistry.

Along with Aaron Ciechanover and Irwin Rose, he was awarded the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for the discovery of ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation.

[[Michael Levitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, South African scientists, American biologists, American physicists, British biologists, British physicists, Israeli scientists, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom, Naturalized citizens of the United States

ChemistryMichael Levitt, GBR (מיכאל לויט; born 9 May 1947) is a South African-born biophysicist. He is a professor of structural biology at Stanford University, a position he has held since 1987. Levitt received the 2013 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. 

[[Arieh Warshel]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, American chemists, American biologists, American physicists, Israeli scientists

ChemistryArieh Warshel (אריה ורשל; born November 20, 1940) is an Israeli-American biochemist and biophysicist. He is  the Dana and David Dornsife Chair in Chemistry at the University of Southern California. He received the 2013 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, together with Michael Levitt and Martin Karplus for "the development of multiscale models for complex chemical systems".

[[Eric Betzig]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, American physicists, Scientists from Michigan, People from Ann Arbor, Michigan

ChemistryRobert Eric Betzig (born January 13, 1960) is an American physicist. He works as a Professor of Physics and Professor of Molecular and Cell biology at the University of California, Berkeley. He is also a Senior Fellow at the Janelia Farm Research Campus in Ashburn, Virginia.

Betzig has worked to develop the field of fluorescence microscopy and photoactivated localization microscopy.

He was awarded the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for "the development of super-resolved fluorescence microscopy" along with Stefan Hell and fellow Cornell alumnus William E. Moerner.

[[William E. Moerner]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, American chemists, American physicists, Scientists from California

ChemistryWilliam Esco Moerner (born June 24, 1953) is an American physical chemist and chemical physicist. 

He is known for his first optical detection and spectroscopy of a single molecule in condensed phases.  Optical study of single molecules has subsequently become a widely used single-molecule experiment in chemistry, physics and biology. 

In 2014, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

[[Jean-Pierre Sauvage]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, French chemists, Scientists from Paris

ChemistryJean-Pierre Sauvage (ʒãpjɛʁ sovaʒ; born 21 October 1944) is a French coordination chemist. He worked at Strasbourg University. He has specialized in supramolecular chemistry for which he has been awarded the 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry along with Sir J. Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L. Feringa.

[[Vincent & Theo]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s biographical movies, 1990 drama movies, Dutch drama movies, British biographical movies, British drama movies, French drama movies, German drama movies, Italian drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Argentine movies, Movies directed by Robert Altman

Vincent & Theo is a 1990 Dutch British French German Italian American Argentine biographical drama movie directed by Robert Altman and starring Tim Roth, Paul Rhys, Kitty Courbois, Johanna ter Steege, Wladimir Yordanoff, Hans Kesting, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Anne Canovas, Jean-Pierre Castaldi, Peter Tuinman.

[[Fraser Stoddart]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Scottish scientists, British chemists, People from Edinburgh

ChemistrySir James Fraser Stoddart GBR (born 24 May 1942) is a British chemist. He is Board of Trustees Professor of Chemistry and head of the Stoddart Mechanostereochemistry Group in the Department of Chemistry at Northwestern University in the United States. He shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry together with Ben Feringa and Jean-Pierre Sauvage in 2016 for the design and synthesis of molecular machines. He was born in Edinburgh.

[[Simon Gutman]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Polish Jews, French Jews, Holocaust survivors, People from Warsaw

Simon Gutman (20 July 1923 – 5 October 2020) was a Polish-born French Holocaust survivor. He was born in Warsaw. 

Gutman was deported in the 1st Convoy to Auschwitz on 27 March 1942. His mother, Cyma, and, probably, his sister, Bella, were deported to Sobibor extermination camp in March 1943, where they died. 

Gutman stayed at Birkenau until 26 October 1944, when he was transferred to multiple camps, including Natzweiler-Struthof concentration camp, Hailfingen, Dautmergen, and Altshausen. He escaped during a death march. On 5 April 1945, they met up with the French 2nd Armored Division in Baden-Württemberg and were liberated.

He died on 5 October 2020 at the age of 97.

[[Liberation of Paris]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s in France, 1944 in Europe, History of Paris, Battles involving France, European battles of World War II, Military of France, August events

The Liberation of Paris (Libération de Paris) was a military battle that took place during World War II from 19 August 1944 until the Germans surrendered the French capital on 25 August 1944. 

Paris had been ruled by Nazi Germany since the signing of the Second Compiègne Armistice on 22 June 1940, after which the Wehrmacht occupied northern and western France.

[[Fail-Safe (1964 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 thriller movies, 1960s war movies, American thriller movies, American war movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Sidney Lumet, Apocalyptic movies

Fail-Safe is a 1964 American Cold War thriller movie directed by Sidney Lumet and was based on the 1962 novel of the same name by Eugene Burdick and Harvey Wheeler. It stars Henry Fonda, Walter Matthau, Dan O'Herlihy, Frank Overton, Fritz Weaver, Edward Binns, Larry Hagman, Dom DeLuise and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Béatrice Arnac]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American composers, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, French composers, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French voice actors, Singers from Connecticut, Actors from Connecticut, People from Waterbury, Connecticut

Béatrice Arnac (23 April 1931 – 5 October 2020) was an American-born French actress, singer, and composer. She was born in Waterbury, Connecticut. 

Arnac was known for her roles in Mata Hari's Daughter (1955), Frou-Frou (1955), Lola Montès (1955), La Traversée de Paris (1956), Les Truands (1956), OSS 117 Is Not Dead (1957), Last Known Address (1970) and Good Little Girls (1971).

Arnac died in Castels et Bézenac, France on 5 October 2020 at the age of 89.

[[John Baring, 7th Baron Ashburton]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, British businesspeople, Bankers

John Francis Harcourt Baring, 7th Baron Ashburton, GBR (2 November 1928 – 6 October 2020), was a British merchant banker. He was chairman of British Petroleum (BP). Lord Ashburton also sat on the boards of Jaguar Cars, Dunlop Rubber and Royal Insurance.

Lord Ashburton died at his home on 6 October 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Lloyd D. George]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Idaho, Politicians from Las Vegas, Nevada, US Republican Party politicians

Lloyd Dee George (February 22, 1930 – October 7, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. He was born in Montpelier, Idaho. He was nominated to the United States District Court for the District of Nevada in 1984 by President Ronald Reagan. From 1992 to 1997, he was Chief Justice. 

George died on October 7, 2020 in Las Vegas, Nevada at the age of 90.

[[Alexander Alexeev (conductor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Russian conductors

Alexander Alexeev  (Aleksandr Vasil'yevich Alekseyev) (10 March 1938 – 7 October 2020) was a Russian conductor. He was a Honored Artist of the RSFSR. He was Music Director of the Kharkov Philharmonic Orchestra. Alexeev recorded with different orchestras in Russia for the label Melodya, including the Moscow Radio Symphony Orchestra.

Alexeev died in Saint Petersburg on October 7, 2020 at the age of 82.

[[Ray Pennington]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from fire, American country singers, American country guitarists, American drummers, American pianists, American singer-songwriters, Record producers, Singers from Kentucky, Musicians from Kentucky, Businesspeople from Kentucky, Singers from Nashville, Tennessee, Musicians from Nashville, Tennessee, Businesspeople from Tennessee

Ramon Daniel Pennington (December 22, 1933 – October 7, 2020) was an American country music singer-songwriter, musician and record producer. He was known for writing the Waylon Jennings and Montgomery Gentry song "I'm a Ramblin' Man", and for founding the independent Step One Records label. He was born in Clay County, Kentucky.

Pennington died in a house fire in Hendersonville, Tennessee on October 7, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Hendersonville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee

Hendersonville is the largest city in Sumner County, Tennessee, on Old Hickory Lake. The population was 51,372 at the 2010 census. 

[[Sumner County, Tennessee]]

Sumner County is a county located on the central northern border of the U.S. state of Tennessee, in what is called Middle Tennessee.

As of the 2010 census, the population was 160,645. Its county seat is Gallatin. Its  largest city is Hendersonville. The county is named for American Revolutionary War hero General Jethro Sumner.

[[A New Leaf]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 comedy movies, American black comedy movies, Movies based on short stories

A New Leaf is a 1971 American black comedy movie directed by Elaine May (who also stars) and was based on the short story The Green Heart by Jack Ritchie. It also stars Walter Matthau, Jack Weston, George Rose, James Coco, Doris Roberts, William Redfield and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Emancipation]]

CATEGORIES: Liberalism

Emancipation is any time when someone tries to have more economic and social rights, political rights or equality. This is usually for a group of people that feels disfranchised.

[[R46 (New York City Subway car)]]

The R46 is a New York City Subway car model that was built by the Pullman Standard Company from 1975 to 1978 for the IND/BMT B Division. They replaced all remaining Arnine cars and GE-powered R16s, and some R10s. The R46 order initially consisted of 754 single cars, each 75 feet (23 m) long, and was the largest single order of passenger cars in United States railroad history at the point of the fleet's completion. The R46 was the second order of 75-foot cars to be ordered for the New York City Subway, after the R44s.

[[Pete 'n' Tillie]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 comedy movies, 1970s LGBT movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Martin Ritt

Pete 'n' Tillie is a 1972 American comedy movie directed by Martin Ritt and was based on the 1968 novella Witch's Milk by Peter De Vries. It stars Walter Matthau, Geraldine Page, Carol Burnett, Barry Nelson, Lee H. Montgomery and was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1973. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Federation Council (Russia)]]

CATEGORIES: Russia

The Federation Council (Сове́т Федера́ции; Sovet Federatsii, common abbreviation: Совфед (Sovfed) or Senat) is the upper house of the Federal Assembly of Russia  (the parliament of the  Russian Federation), according to the 1993 Constitution of the Russian Federation. 

[[Federal Assembly (Russia)]]

CATEGORIES: Russia, Parliaments

The Federal Assembly (Federalnoye Sobraniye) is the national legislature of the Russian Federation, according to the Constitution of the Russian Federation (1993). It was preceded by the Supreme Soviet.

It is made up of the State Duma, which is the lower house, and the Federation Council, which is the upper house. Both houses are located in Moscow.

[[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]

CATEGORIES: Soviet Union

The Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (or Politburo, pəlʲɪtbʲʊˈro; abbreviated: Politbyuro TsK KPSS) was the highest policy-making authority within the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. 

It was founded in October 1917, and refounded in March 1919, at the 8th Congress of the Bolshevik Party. It was known as the Presidium from 1952 to 1966. The Politburo ended in 1991 when the Soviet Union broke-up.

[[Jan Szarek]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Polish people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Poland, Lutherans

Jan Szarek (13 February 1936 – 8 October 2020) was a Polish Lutheran minister. He was Bishop of Evangelical Church of the Augsburg Confession in Poland from 1991 to 2001 and Chairman of Polish Ecumenical Council from 1993 to 2001. Szarek was born in Bielsko, Poland.

Szarek died on 8 October 2020 in Cieszyn, Poland from COVID-19 at the age of 84.

[[Francesc Betriu]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish movie directors, Spanish screenwriters

Francesc "Paco" Betriu Cabeceran (18 January 1940 – 7 October 2020) was a Spanish movie director and screenwriter. He was born in Organyà, Spain. Betriu was known for directing and writing the screenplay for The Time of the Doves, Sinatra and  Monica del Raval.

Betriu died on 7 October 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Choi Yun-chil]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, South Korean sportspeople, Olympians, North Korean people

Choi Yun-chil (July 19, 1928 – October 8, 2020) was a South Korean long-distance runner. He was a two-time Olympian and a two-time national champion in the marathon. He competed in the 1948 Summer Olympics and at the 1952 Summer Olympics. He was born in Tanchon, present-day North Korea.

Choi died on October 8, 2020 in Seoul at the age of 92.

[[Anne Carson]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Canadian poets, Canadian educators, Essayists, Translators, Writers from Toronto

Anne Carson CAN (born June 21, 1950) is a Canadian poet, essayist, translator, classicist, and professor. She was born in Toronto.

Carson has taught classics, comparative literature, and creative writing at universities across the United States and Canada since 1979, including McGill, Michigan, NYU, and Princeton.

Publishing more than twenty books of writings and translations. She was appointed a Member of the Order of Canada in 2005 for her works to Canadian letters.

[[Annie Ernaux]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, French writers, People from Normandy

Annie Ernaux (born Annie Duschesne; 1 September 1940) is a French writer. She was born in Normandy, France. 

Her books A Woman's Story, A Man's Place, and Simple Passion were seen by the The New York Times Notable Books, and A Woman's Story was a Finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Prize. 

Shame was named a Publishers Weekly Best Book of 1998, I Remain in Darkness a Top Memoir of 1999 by The Washington Post, and The Possession was listed as a Top Ten Book of 2008 by More Magazine.

[[BelaPAN]]

CATEGORIES: Websites, Belarus, Censorship in Belarus, Free Media Award winners

The Belarusian Private News Agency (Беларускае прыватнае агенцтва навін) or shortly BelaPAN (БелаПАН) is a non-governmental news agency in Belarus. It is a big news agency in the country. BelaPAN makes news on politics, economy, and sports from Belarus in the Russian, Belarusian, and English languages. 

BelaPAN has the on-line newspaper Belorusskiye Novosti (naviny.by). Its site can't be opened in Belarus. It has been writing about the 2020 Belarusian protests and 2020 Belarusian presidential election.

On January 14, 2021, the office of BelaPAN was searched. Computers and part of the written by hand and printed papers were taken away. All that stopped the work of the news agency.

On August 18, 2021, the police searched the office of BelaPAN, houses of its journalists. The police took away computers, smartphones, and other things from there. A number of people who worked for BelaPAN were arrested, including editor-in-chief Iryna Levshyna. The websites of BelaPAN (belapan.by and belapan.com) has stopped working since August 18, 2021. Iryna Levshyna, past head Zmicier Navazhilau and accountant Katsyaryna Boeva became persons in a criminal case on organizing actions that attack public order. On August 19, 2021, ten organizations (the Viasna Human Rights Centre, the Belarusian Association of Journalists, the Belarusian Helsinki Committee and others) made a joint statement. It said that they are political prisoners.

[[29th Street (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 comedy-drama movies, 1990s biographical movies, American comedy-drama movies, Japanese movies, 20th Century Fox movies

29th Street is a 1991 American Japanese comedy drama movie directed by George Gallo and was based on the story by Frank Pesce (who also stars) and James Franciscus. It stars Danny Aiello, Anthony LaPaglia, Lainie Kazan, Robert Forster, Rick Aiello, Ron Karabatsos and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Darleane C. Hoffman]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, American chemists, American educators, Scientists from Iowa, Writers from Iowa

Darleane Christian Hoffman (born November 8, 1926) is an American nuclear chemist. He was among the researchers who found the existence of Seaborgium, element 106. 

She is a faculty senior scientist in the Nuclear Science Division of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and a professor in the graduate school at UC Berkeley. 

In 2002, she was named as one of the 50 most important women in science by Discover Magazine.

She is a member of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters.

[[Shlomo Gazit]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Turkish military people, Israeli educators, Israeli generals, People from Istanbul

Shlomo Gazit (שלמה גזית; 1926 – 8 October 2020) was a Turkish-born Israeli military officer and academic. He was a Major General in the Israel Defense Forces. He was in charge of Israel's Military Intelligence Directorate. He later was President of Ben-Gurion University and head of the Jewish Agency. He was born in Istanbul.

Gazit died on 8 October 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Laren]]

Laren is a municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. In 2019, 11,195 people lived there.

Oostzaan is a municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. In 2019, 9,757 people lived there.

[[Bennebroek]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Holland, Former municipalities of North Holland

Bennebroek is a former municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. Since 2009, it has been part of the municipality of Bloemendaal.

In 2007, 5,162 people lived there. It was the smallest municipality in the Netherlands, covering an area of only 1.75 km².

[[Obion County, Tennessee]]

Obion County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 31,807 people lived there. The county seat is Union City.

Overton County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 22,083 people lived there. The county seat is Livingston.

[[Jim Dwyer (journalist)]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in New York City, American columnists, Journalists from New York City

Jim Dwyer (March 4, 1957 – October 8, 2020) was an American journalist. He was a reporter and columnist with The New York Times, and the author or co-author of six non-fiction books. In 1992 and 1995, he won the Pulitzer Prize. 

Dwyer wrote columns for New York Newsday and the New York Daily News before joining the Times. He appeared in the 2012 documentary movie Central Park Five. He was born in New York City.

Dwyer died of lung cancer in New York City on October 8, 2020 at the age of 63.

[[Jim Dwyer]]

James Dwyer may refer to:

[[Fat-tailed dwarf lemur]]

CATEGORIES: Lemuriformes, Mammals of Africa

The fat-tailed dwarf lemur (Cheirogaleus medius), is a type of lemur. It is also called the lesser dwarf lemur, western fat-tailed dwarf lemur, or spiny forest dwarf lemur. It is only lives in Madagascar. It is nocturnal. It eats insects, other small animals, fruits and flowers. An adult weighs 160 grams.

[[Mohammad-Reza Shajarian]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Iranian singers, Iranian writers, Composers, Iranian educators, Songwriters, Deaths from kidney cancer

Mohammad-Reza Shajarian (محمدرضا شجريان; mohæmːæd ɾeˈzɒː ʃædʒæɾiˈɒːn, 23 September 1940 – 8 October 2020) was an Iranian classical singer-songwriter, composer and calligrapher. He was a Master (master) of Persian traditional music. His best known single was "Night, Silence, Desert" (2000).

In 2017, Los Angeles Times called him as the "greatest living maestro of Persian classical music." He was born in Mashhad, Iran.

He supported the 2009 protests in Iran and was a critic of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

In 2001, Shajarian was diagnosed with kidney cancer. In January 2020, he was hospitalized in Tehran and had surgery.

Shajarian died on 8 October 2020 in Tehran at the age of 80.

[[Ali Khalif Galaydh]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of Somalia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Ali Khalif Galaydh (Cali Khalif Galaydh, علي خليف غلير) (October 14, 1941 – October 8, 2020) was a Somali politician. He was the Prime Minister of Somalia from October 8, 2000 to October 28, 2001. He was a member of the Federal Parliament of Somalia from 2012 until his death. He was also President of the Khatumo State between 2014 until his death. Galaydh was born in Las Anod, Somalia.

Galaydh died on October 8, 2020 at a hospital in Jigjiga, Ethiopia from COVID-19 at the age of 78.

[[Jim Dwyer (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Baltimore Orioles players, Boston Red Sox players, Minnesota Twins players, Montreal Expos players, New York Mets players, People from Evergreen Park, Illinois, San Francisco Giants players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Sportspeople from Chicago

James Edward Dwyer (born January 3, 1950) is an American MLB outfielder. He enjoyed an eighteen-year major league career for seven different teams between 1973 and 1990. He was born in Evergreen Park, Illinois. His career lasted between 1973 to 1990.

He played for the St. Louis Cardinals, Montreal Expos, New York Mets, San Francisco Giants, Boston Red Sox, Baltimore Orioles and the Minnesota Twins. In 1983, he won the World Series.

Livingston is a town in Tennessee in the United States. It is the county seat of Overton County.

South Haven is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan. Most of the city is in Van Buren County, although a small part of it goes into Allegan County. The population was 4,403 at the 2010 census.

Idiotville is a ghost town in Tillamook County, Oregon, United States. It is near the mouth of Idiot Creek on the Wilson River.

[[Reddish-gray mouse lemur]]

CATEGORIES: Lemuriformes, Mammals of Africa

The reddish-gray mouse lemur (Microcebus griseorufus) is a type of lemur. It is called the gray-brown mouse lemur or rufous-gray mouse lemur. It is found in Western Madagascar in the region around Beza Mahafaly Reserve, north to Lamboharana.

Purmerend is a municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. In 2019, 80,117 people lived there.

[[Muiden]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Netherlands, Settlements in North Holland, Former municipalities of North Holland, Gooise Meren

Muiden is a former municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. Since 2016, it has been part of the new municipality of Gooise Meren.

It is known for its castle-museum Muiderslot and consists of two villages: Muiden and Muiderberg.

[[Muiderberg]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Holland

Muiderberg is a village in the municipality of Gooise Meren (formerly 

Muiden), Province of North Holland, the Netherlands.

In 2012, 3,070 people lived there.

[[Phillip Parker King]]

CATEGORIES: 1791 births, 1856 deaths, Australian explorers, Exploration of Australia, Norfolk Island, Politicians from New South Wales, Royal Navy officers, Fellows of the Royal Society

Phillip Parker King FRS RN (13 December 1791 – 26 February 1856) was an explorer, Royal Navy officer and politician from the colony of New South Wales. He is known as an early explorer of the Australian coastline. He also took part in the survey of Patagonian coasts. He served as a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council. In 1855, he was named as a rear admiral on the retired list. He was also a member of the Royal Society.

King was born on Norfolk Island. He was the son of Anna Josepha (née Coombe) and Philip Gidley King. He was named after his father's mentor, Arthur Phillip, the first governor of New South Wales and founder of the British penal colony which later became the city of Sydney. This explains the difference in spelling of his and his father's first names.

King married Harriet Lethbridge in 1817. The couple had eight children. Two of his sons, Philip Gidley (named after his grandfather) and John, were both pastoralists and politicians. King died in North Sydney on 26 February 1856 at the age of 64.

There are many instances of things named after King. King Sound of the Kimberley in Western Australia is named after him. There are also six reptile species named after King: Amphisbaena kingii, Chlamydosaurus kingii, Egernia kingii, Elgaria kingii, Hydrophis kingii and Liolaemus kingii.

[[1991 DFB-Supercup]]

CATEGORIES: DFL-Supercup, 1991 in sports

The 1991 DFB-Supercup was the fifth season of the DFB-Supercup. This was the only season where 4 teams participated, because of German reunification in 1990. The 4 teams were the 1990-91 Bundesliga winners 1. FC Kaiserslautern, 1990-91 DFB-Pokal winner Werder Bremen, 1990-91 NOFV-Oberliga and 1990-91 NOFV-Pokal winners Hansa Rostock and 1990-91 NOFV-Pokal runner-up Stahl Eisenhüttenstadt.

Kaiserslautern would win the DFB-Supercup, after beating Werder Bremen 3–1 in Hanover.

[[Philip King (Australian politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1817 births, 1904 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in New South Wales, Mayors, Politicians from Sydney

Philip Gidley King (31 October 1817 – 5 August 1904) was an Australian pastoralist and politician from the colony of New South Wales. He served as a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council from 1880 until his death in 1904. He was also the first mayor of Tamworth from 1876 to 1880.

King was born in Parramatta, New South Wales. His parents were Harriet (née Lethbridge) and Phillip Parker King. His father was an explorer, Royal Navy officer and politician. He was named after his grandfather, also Philip Gidley King, the third governor of New South Wales.

King married Elizabeth Macarthur in 1843. The couple had four children. He died of heart disease in Double Bay, Sydney, on 5 August 1904. He was 86.

[[Eisenhüttenstädter FC Stahl]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 establishments in Germany, 2010s disestablishments in Germany, 2016 disestablishments in Europe, German football clubs, Brandenburg

Eisenhüttenstädter FC Stahl was a German association football team, based in Eisenhüttenstadt, Brandenburg.

[[Philip Fysh]]

CATEGORIES: 1835 births, 1919 deaths, Members of the Australian House of Representatives, Politicians from London, Politicians from Tasmania, Premiers of Tasmania, Knights Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George

Sir Philip Oakley Fysh AUS (1 March 1835 – 20 December 1919) was an Australian politician and merchant. He arrived in the colony of Tasmania in 1859. He later became a key merchant in Hobart. He served two terms as premier of Tasmania (1877–1878, 1887–1892). He became a leader of the colony's federation movement. He later won election to the new federal House of Representatives (1901–1910). He was also chosen to represent Tasmania in the first federal ministry under Edmund Barton. He was minister without portfolio (1901–1903) and Postmaster-General (1903–1904).

Fysh was born in Highbury, London. His wife died in 1912. The couple had at least nine children. Fysh died on 20 December 1919 in Sandy Bay, Hobart, at the age of 84. The Canberra suburb of Fyshwick is named in honour of him.

[[Loris Karius]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, German footballers, Sportspeople from Baden-Württemberg, Living people, Manchester City F.C. players, Liverpool F.C. players, Premier League players

Loris Sven Karius (born 22 June 1993) is a German football player. He plays as a goalkeeper for Bundesliga club Union Berlin, on loan from Premier League club Liverpool.

[[Alice Ross-King]]

CATEGORIES: 1887 births, 1968 deaths, Australian military people, Australian nurses, Military personnel of World War I, Military personnel of World War II, People from Ballarat

Alys Ross King AUS (5 August 1887 – 17 August 1968), known as Alice Ross-King (later Alice Appleford), was an Australian nurse who served during both World Wars. During World War I, she served in hospitals in Egypt and France. She was one of only seven Australian nurses awarded with the Military Medal for gallantry (military courage). She also held a senior post within the Australian Army Medical Women's Service during World War II. In 1949, she was awarded the Florence Nightingale Medal, the highest award made by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Ross-King was born in Ballarat, Victoria. At a young age, she moved with her family to Perth, Western Australia. Her father, Archibald Ross King, and two brothers died after drowning in Swan River. After the accident, her mother, Henrietta King, moved to Melbourne with Alys. After joining the Australian Army Nursing Service, she started using the spelling "Alice" and added a hyphen to her surname.

Ross-King was engaged to Harry Moffitt during World War I. He died during the Battle of Fromelles in 1916. After the war, she married Sydney Theordore Appleford. The couple had four children. Her husband died in 1958. Ross-King died in Cronulla, Sydney, on 17 August 1968. She was 81.

[[Rove McManus]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Australian comedians, Australian radio personalities, Australian television presenters, Entertainers from Perth, Western Australia

John Henry Michael "Rove" McManus (born 21 January 1974) is an Australian comedian, television and radio presenter. He is best known as the host of variety show Rove from 1999 to 2009. He was awarded the Gold Logie Award for Most Popular Personality on Australian Television in 2003, 2004 and 2005. Other projects include hosting Rove LA and Whovians. He has also appeared in Good Morning Australia, John Safran vs God, Pulp Sport, The Living Room, The Project, Studio 10, Celebrity Name Game, Have You Been Paying Attention New Zealand? and Hughesy, We Have a Problem.

McManus was born in Perth, Western Australia. He married actress Belinda Emmett in 2005. She died of breast cancer in 2006. He later married actress Tasma Walton. The couple have one child. His first cousin is Australian rules footballer Shaun McManus.

[[Steven Miles (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Australian Labor Party politicians, Politicians from Brisbane

Steven John Miles (born 15 November 1977) is an Australian politician for the Labor Party. He is the current Deputy Premier of Queensland, serving since May 2020. He has been the member for Murrumba in the Queensland Legislative Assembly since 2017, and formerly represented Mount Coot-tha from 2015 to 2017. He has also served as Queensland's Minister for Health and Ambulance Services since 2017.

Miles was born in Brisbane, Queensland. He is married to Kim and has three children. As of 2018, he lives in the Moreton Bay Region suburb of Mango Hill.

[[Gray mouse lemur]]

CATEGORIES: Lemuriformes, Mammals of Africa

The gray mouse lemur (Microcebus murinus), is a type of lemur. It is only found on the island of Madagascar. It is also called the grey mouse lemur or lesser mouse lemur. It weighs 58 to 67 grams (2.0 to 2.4 oz). It is the largest mouse lemur.

[[Phillip Island]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Victoria, Australia, Islands of Australia

Phillip Island (Boonwurrung: Corriong or Millowl) is an island about 140 south-southeast of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. The island is named after Arthur Phillip, the first governor of New South Wales, by explorer and seaman George Bass. As of the 2016 census, 10,387 people live on the island.

Phillip Island is 26 long and 9 wide, with an area of about 100. It has 97 of coastline and is part of the Bass Coast Shire.

A 640 concrete bridge (formerly a wooden bridge) connects the mainland town San Remo with the island town Newhaven.

[[Schagen]]

CATEGORIES: Schagen, Cities in the Netherlands, Settlements in North Holland

Schagen is a municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. In 2019, 46,553 people lived there.

The city is between Alkmaar and Den Helder. It received city rights in 1415.

Since 2013, Harenkarspel and Zijpe have been part of the municipality of Schagen.

[[The Front Page (1974 movie)]]

The Front Page is a 1974 American black comedy movie directed by Billy Wilder and was the third adaptation of Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur's 1928 play of the same name. It stars Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Susan Sarandon, Vincent Gardenia, David Wayne, Carol Burnett, Allen Garfield, Charles Durning, Allen Jenkins and Martin Gabel.

[[Up the Down Staircase (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Robert Mulligan

Up the Down Staircase is a 1967 American drama movie directed by Robert Mulligan and was based on the 1964 novel of the same name by Bel Kaufman. It stars Sandy Dennis, Patrick Bedford, Eileen Heckart, Ruth White, Jean Stapleton, Sorrell Brooke, Florence Stanley, Vinnette Carroll and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[IPhone 12]]

CATEGORIES: iPhone, Mobile phones with multiple rear cameras, Mobile phones with 4K video recording, IPhones released in 2020

Lowercase title

The iPhone 12 is a smartphone made by Apple Inc. released on October 13, 2020. Succeeding the iPhone 11, it has an identical 6.1-inch screen size to its predecessor but also comes in a smaller variant called the iPhone 12 mini, which has a 5.4-inch screen. Both models have dual rear camera lenses and come in storage options of 64 GB, 128 GB, and 256 GB. It is equipped with the Apple A14 Bionic System-on-Chip (SoC). The iPhone 12 mini starts at US $649, and iPhone 12 starts at US $799. 

The iPhone 12 and 12 mini both include OLED displays. They include USB-C–to–Lightning cables but no power adapter. Apple included MagSafe in the iPhone 12 family, a magnetic back of the device which allows for magnetic wireless charging and mounting accessories such as a wallet to the back of the phone.

The iPhone 12 family is the first series of iPhones to have 5G connectivity. The iPhone 12 and 12 mini are available in white, black, green, blue, and (PRODUCT)RED finishes. The iPhone 12 marks a return to flat edges for the iPhone, first introduced in 2010 with the iPhone 4 until the iPhone 5S (2013), with an exception for the first-generation iPhone SE (2016).

[[An American Tail]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy-drama movies, 1980s musical movies, American animated movies, American comedy-drama movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by Don Bluth

An American Tail is a 1986 American animated musical comedy-drama movie directed by Don Bluth. It was the first animated movie that was presented by Steven Spielberg.

[[Rock-a-Doodle]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 comedy movies, 1990s animated movies, 1990s musical movies, 1990s fantasy-comedy movies, American animated movies, American musical fantasy movies, American musical comedy movies, American fantasy-comedy movies, British animated movies, British musical movies, British fantasy movies, British comedy movies, Irish movies, Movies directed by Don Bluth

Rock-a-Doodle is a 1991 Irish/British/American live-action/animated musical comedy adventure movie. It was produced by Sullivan Bluth Studios and Goldcrest Films. It is loosely based on Edmond Rostand's comedy Chantecler. Rock-a-Doodle was directed by Don Bluth and written by David N. Weiss. The movie has the voices of Glen Campbell, Christopher Plummer, Phil Harris (in his last movie role before his retirement and death), Charles Nelson Reilly, Sorrell Booke, Sandy Duncan, Eddie Deezen, Ellen Greene, and Toby Scott Ganger in his movie debut. The movie was released in the United Kingdom on 2 August 1991 and in the United States and Canada on 3 April 1992.

[[Gabo Ferro]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Argentina, Argentine singers, Argentine poets, Argentine educators, Songwriters, Writers from Buenos Aires

Fernando Gabriel "Gabo" Ferro (6 November 1965 – 8 October 2020) was an Argentine singer-songwriter, poet and historian. Ferro was born in Buenos Aires. 

His career began in 1994. His solo career began in 2004. He played the guitar and most of his songs were rock. Many of his songs were made by Azione artigianale record label. His best known albums were Canciones que un hombre no debería cantar (2005) and Mañana no debe seguir siendo esto (2007).

Ferro died on 8 October 2020 in Buenos Aires from cancer at the age of 54.

[[Günter de Bruyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Writers from Berlin

Günter de Bruyn (də bʀɔʏn; 1 November 1926 – 4 October 2020) was a German author. He was born in Berlin. 

He trained as a librarian and worked at the Zentralinstitut für Bibliothekswesen (Central Institute for Library Knowledge) in East Berlin from 1953 to 1961. From 1965 to 1978, he was a member of the Zentralvorstandes des Schriftstellerverbandes der DDR (Central Executive Committee of the Literary Association of East Germany).

He was a member of the presidency of the PEN Centre of East Germany from 1974 to 1982.

In October 1989, Günter de Bruyn declined to accept the National Prize of East Germany.

Bryn died in Berlin on 4 October 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Dirk Bootsma]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch academics, Dutch scientists, Geneticists

Dirk Bootsma (23 May 1936 – 5 October 2020) was a Dutch geneticist. He was a professor at the Erasmus University Rotterdam between 1969 and 2002. He and his research group discovered the cause of chronic myelogenous leukemia and pushed for the understanding of the nucleotide excision repair.

Bootsma was elected a member of the European Molecular Biology Organization in 1976. He was elected a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1983. Bootsma was elected a member of the Academia Europaea in 1991.

[[Monica Roberts]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pulmonary embolism, American LGBT rights activists, Bloggers, Journalists from Texas, Writers from Houston, Texas, American bloggers

Monica Roberts (May 4, 1962 – October 5, 2020) was an African-American blogger, writer, and transgender rights activist. She was the founding editor of TransGriot, a blog focusing on issues about to trans women, many of which minorities. She was born in Houston, Texas.

Roberts died on October 5, 2020 in Houston from a pulmonary embolism at the age of 58.

[[Tommy Rall]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Deaths from surgical complications, Actors from Kansas City, Missouri, American dancers, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, Singers from Kansas City, Missouri

Thomas Edward "Tommy" Rall (December 27, 1929 – October 6, 2020) was an American actor and dancer. Rall was born in Kansas City, Missouri. His career lasted from 1942 to 1988. 

Rall was known for his roles in Kiss Me, Kate as "Bill" (1953), Seven Brides for Seven Brothers as "Frank" (1954), Invitation to the Dance (1956),

Merry Andrew as "Giacomo Gallini" (1958), and My Sister Eileen as "Chick" (1955).

Rall died on October 6, 2020 from congestive heart failure caused by heart surgery in Santa Monica, California at the age of 90.

[[Fred Wenz]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Red Sox players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Sportspeople from New Jersey

Frederick Charles "Fireball" Wenz (August 26, 1941 – October 6, 2020) was an American middle relief pitcher in Major League Baseball. He played from 1968 through 1970 for the Boston Red Sox (1968–69) and Philadelphia Phillies (1970). He was born in Bound Brook, New Jersey.

Wenz died on October 6, 2020 in Branchburg, New Jersey at the age of 79.

[[Kim Batiste]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Philadelphia Phillies players, San Francisco Giants players, Deaths from surgical complications, Deaths from kidney disease, Sportspeople from New Orleans, Louisiana

Kimothy Emil Batiste (March 15, 1968 – October 7, 2020) was an American Major League Baseball infielder for the Philadelphia Phillies from 1991 to 1994 and San Francisco Giants in 1996, both of the National League. He was born in New Orleans, Louisiana.

Batiste died on October 7, 2020 in New Orleans from problems caused by kidney surgery at the age of 52.

[[Nabil Bechaouch]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Tunisian footballers, Deaths from myocardial infarction, People from Tunis

Nabil Bechaouch (1970 – 7 October 2020) was a Tunisian footballer. He was born in Aryanah, Tunisia. Bechaouch played for the national team from 1993 to 1995. He played from Olympique Béja, CS Sfaxien and Stade Tunisien. 

Bechaouch died on 7 October 2020 of a heart attack in Béja, Tunisia.

[[Weekend at Dunkirk]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 drama movies, 1960s war movies, French drama movies, Italian drama movies, World War II movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henri Verneuil

Weekend at Dunkirk (Week-end à Zuydcoote) is a 1964 French Italian World War II drama movie directed by Henri Verneuil and was based on the 1949 novel Week-end at Zuydcoote (Week-end à Zuydcoote) by Robert Merle. It stars Jean-Paul Belmondo, Catherine Spaak, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Pierre Vernier, Paul Préboist and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Manuel Guerra (swimmer)]]

Manuel Guerra (18 July 1928 – 7 October 2020) was a Spanish swimmer. He competed in three events at the 1948 Summer Olympics.

Guerra died on 7 October 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Sam Burton]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Cancer deaths in the United Kingdom, English footballers, People from Wiltshire

Samuel Burton (10 November 1926 – 8 October 2020) was an English professional footballer. He played his entire career as a goalkeeper for Swindon Town, making 463 appearances in the Football League and 509 in all first-team competitions. Only John Trollope, Maurice Owen and Fraser Digby played more times for the club. He was born in Swindon, Wiltshire.

Burton died on 8 October 2020 from dementia-related problems and cancer at the age of 93.

[[David Ipp]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, South African politicians, Australian judges, Australian lawyers, Naturalised citizens of Australia, Politicians from New South Wales, People from Johannesburg

David Andrew Ipp AO QC (1938 – 8 October 2020) was a South African-born Australian lawyer and politician. He was the Commissioner of the NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption between 2009 and 2014. Between 1989 to 2002, he was a judge of the Supreme Court of Western Australia. Ipp was born in Johannesburg.

Ipp died in Sydney on 8 October 2020 at the age of 82.

[[California Suite]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, 1970s LGBT movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Herbert Ross

California Suite is a 1978 American comedy movie directed by Herbert Ross and was based on the play of the same name by Neil Simon. It stars Maggie Smith, Alan Alda, Walter Matthau, Michael Caine, Jane Fonda, Elaine May, Richard Pryor, Dana Plato, Bill Cosby and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 3 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1979.

[[Brian Locking]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from bladder cancer, English rock musicians, English pianists, English guitarists, English songwriters, Writers from Warwickshire

Brian "Licorice" Locking (22 December 1938 – 8 October 2020) was an English rock pianist and songwriter. He was briefly the bass guitarist with The Shadows, between 1962 and 1963. During his tenure with the band he appeared  with Sir Cliff Richard in the movie Summer Holiday. Locking was born in Bedworth, Warwickshire.

Locking died on 8 October 2020 from bladder cancer in Wales, aged 81.

Marty Wilde, GBR (born Reginald Leonard Smith; 15 April 1939) is an English rock pop singer-songwriter. He is the father of pop singers Ricky, Kim and Roxanne Wilde. Wilde was born in London. His career began in 1957.

[[Tom O'Donnell]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Irish politicians, Former MEPs, People from County Cork

Thomas G. O'Donnell (30 August 1926 – 8 October 2020) was an Irish Fine Gael politician. He was born in Charleville, County Cork.

O'Donnell was Minister for the Gaeltacht from 1973 to 1977. He was a Teachta Dála (TD) for the Limerick East from 1961 to 1987. He also was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the Munster constituency from 1979 to 1984.

O'Donnell died on 8 October 2020 in County Limerick at the age of 94.

[[Ram Vilas Paswan]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Indian politicians

Ram Vilas Paswan (5 July 1946 – 8 October 2020) was an Indian politician. He was born in Khagaria, Bihar. 

He was a member of the Janata Party. He was a member of the Lok Sabha between 1977 to 1984, 1989 to 1991, 1991 to 1996, 1996 to 2009 and from 2014 to 2019. He was also a member of the Rajya Sabha between 2010 to 2014 and from 2019 until his death.

Paswan was Minister of Labour between 1989 to 1990. From 1996 to 1998, he was Minister of Railways. He was Minister of Communications and Information Technology between 1999 to 2001. 

He was Minister of Mines between 2001 to 2002. He was Minister of Chemicals and Fertilizers between 2004 to 2009. He also was Minister of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution between 2014 to 2020.

Paswan died on 8 October 2020 in New Delhi from problems caused by heart surgery, aged 74.

Wormerland is a municipality in the Dutch province of North Holland. In 2019, 16,329 people lived there.

[[Tommy Robson]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Tyne and Wear, English footballers, Deaths from motor neurone disease

Thomas Henry Robson (31 July 1944 – 8 October 2020) was an English footballer. He made more than 600 appearances in the Football League playing as a left winger. Robson was born in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear. 

Robson's career lasted from the 1950s to 1980s. He played for Northampton Town, Chelsea, Newcastle United, Peterborough United, Nuneaton Borough and Stamford.

In September 2019, Robson was diagnosed with motor neurone disease. He died on 8 October 2020 at the age of 76.

[[IPhone (1st generation)]]

CATEGORIES: iPhone, Mobile phones released in 2000s

The iPhone (also called the first-generation iPhone, iPhone (original), iPhone 2G, and iPhone 1) was the first smartphone made by Apple, Inc. It was announced on January 9, 2007, and released on June 29, 2007. It changed the mobile phone industry, being the first phone to have a multi-touch screen. It succeeded the Newton line of touchscreen phones by Apple.

[[Ràdio i Televisió d'Andorra]]

Ràdio i Televisió d'Andorra, S.A. (RTVA) (ˈraði.u j tələβiziˈo ðənˈdorə; "Radio and Television of Andorra PLC") is the state-owned public television and radio broadcaster in the Principality of Andorra. It works as a television channel, ATV, and a radio station, RNA, both of which broadcast in Catalan.

[[Folker Bohnet]]

Folker Bohnet (7 August 1937 – 6 October 2020) was a German actor and theatre director. He was born in Berlin. He was known for his role as Hans in Die Brücke (1959) and as Josef Kainz in ''Ludwig (1973).

Bohnet died on 6 October 2020 in Berlin at the age of 83.

[[Josef Kainz]]

CATEGORIES: 1858 births, 1910 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Austrian stage actors, Actors from Vienna

Josef Gottfried Ignaz Kainz (2 January 1858 – 20 September 1910) was an Austrian actor. He was one of the greatest actors of the German-speaking theatre. He was known for his works in Hamlet, Richard II, Schiller's Don Carlos and as Franz Moor in The Robbers.
