[[Out to Sea]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 comedy movies, 1997 romance movies, 1990s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies

Out to Sea is a 1997 American romantic comedy movie directed by Martha Coolidge and starring Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Dyan Cannon, Gloria DeHaven, Donald O'Connor, Rue McClanahan, Edward Mulhare, Estelle Harris. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Fred Dean]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, American football defensive ends, American football linebackers, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, San Diego Chargers players, San Francisco 49ers players, Sportspeople from Louisiana

Frederick Rudolph Dean (February 24, 1952 – October 14, 2020) was an American former professional football player. He was a defensive end in the National Football League (NFL). He was a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame. 

His career started with the San Diego Chargers in 1975 and ended with the San Francisco 49ers after the 1985 season. A two-time first-team All-Pro and a four-time Pro Bowler, he won two Super Bowls with the 49ers.

On October 8, 2020, Dean was diagnosed with COVID-19 and hospitalized in West Monroe, Louisiana. He died a few days later on October 14 while being airlifted from West Monroe to Jackson, Mississippi at the age of 68.

[[Appingedam]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Netherlands, Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Eemsdelta

Appingedam is both a small city and a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. In 2019, 11,721 people lived there. Since 2021, it has been part of the new municipality of Eemsdelta.

[[David Refael ben Ami]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Israel, Israeli singers

David Refael ben-Ami (8 October 1950 – 9 October 2020) was an Israeli singer. He was born in Nahalal, Israel. He was known for his 1970 single "Desdemona". Most of his works are written by Matti Caspi. In 2006, he released his album We are for God and our eyes are to God. Many of his songs were political, mainly pro-Israel.

Ben Ami died of COVID-19 on 9 October 2020 at a hospital in Jerusalem, aged 70.

[[World Food Programme]]

CATEGORIES: United Nations

PeaceThe World Food Programme (WFP) is the food-assistance branch of the United Nations and the world's largest humanitarian organization. It was founded by Food and Agriculture Organization in 1961. Its mission is to end hunger and helping giving people food. 

According to the WFP, it gives food assistance to an average of 91.4 million people in 83 countries each year. From its headquarters in Rome and from more than 80 country offices around the world, the WFP works to help people who cannot make or get enough food for themselves and their families. 

It is a member of the United Nations Development Group and part of its executive committee. 

It was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2020.

[[Mondaire Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, African American politicians, African American lawyers, American political activists, United States representatives from New York, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians, LGBT people from New York City, Gay men, LGBT politicians

Mondaire Jones (born May 18, 1987) is an American attorney and politician. He is a member of the Democratic Party. He is the U.S. Representative for NY since 2021. 

He and Ritchie Torres were the first openly gay black members of Congress.

He was the Democratic nominee for NY in the 2020 election. He won the election in November 2020.

[[Uncommon Valor]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 action movies, 1980s war movies, American action movies, Vietnam War movies, Movies directed by Ted Kotcheff

Uncommon Valor is a 1983 American action movie directed by Ted Kotcheff and starring Gene Hackman, Patrick Swayze, Robert Stack, Fred Ward, Tim Thomerson, Reb Brown, Randall "Tex" Cobb, Gail Strickland, Jane Kaczmarek, Michael Dudikoff. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Orangetown, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Orangetown is a town in Rockland County, New York, United States. It is northwest of New York City, north of New Jersey, east of the town of Ramapo, south of the town of Clarkstown, and west of the Hudson River. The population was 49,212 at the 2010 census.

[[Orange, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Orange is a town in Schuyler County, New York, United States.  The population was 1,752 at the 2000 census.

The Town of Orange is in the southwest part of the county and is east of Bath, New York.

[[Orangeburg, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Orangeburg is a hamlet and census-designated place, in the town of Orangetown, Rockland County, New York, United States. It is located north of Tappan, south of Blauvelt, east of Pearl River and west of Piermont. The population was 4,568 at the 2010 census.

[[Tappan, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Tappan (t, TUH-pan) from the Lenape word "tuphanne" thought to mean "cold water," is a hamlet and census-designated place in the town of Orangetown, Rockland County, New York, United States. The population was 6,613 at the 2010 census.

[[Blauvelt, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Blauvelt is a hamlet and census-designated place, formerly known as Greenbush and then Blauveltville, in the town of Orangetown, Rockland County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census, the CDP had a population of 5,689.

[[Pearl River, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Pearl River is a hamlet and census-designated place in the town of Orangetown, Rockland County, New York, United States. The population was 15,876 at the 2010 census.

[[Piermont, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Piermont is a village in Rockland County, New York, United States. Piermont is in the town of Orangetown. The population was 2,510 at the 2010 census. 

[[Haren, Groningen]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Groningen (city)

Haren is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the municipality of Groningen.

[[I'm Not Rappaport]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on plays

I'm Not Rappaport is a 1996 American comedy-drama movie directed by and based on the play of the same name by Herb Gardener. It stars Walter Matthau, Ossie Davis, Amy Irving, Craig T. Nelson, Martha Plimpton, Boyd Gaines, Ron Rifkin and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Ten Boer]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Groningen (city)

Ten Boer is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the municipality of Groningen.

[[Nine Hours to Rama]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 drama movies, British drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Mark Robson, 20th Century Fox movies

Nine Hours to Rama is a 1963 British American drama movie directed by Mark Robson and is based on the 1962 novel of the same name by Stanley Wolpert. It stars Horst Buchholz, Diane Baker, Jose Ferrer, Robert Morley and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Les Misérables (1952 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 drama movies, 1950s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Lewis Milestone, 20th Century Fox movies

Les Misérables is a 1952 American romantic drama movie directed by Lewis Milestone and is based on the 1862 novel of the same name by Victor Hugo. It stars Michael Rennie, Debra Paget, Robert Newton, Sylvia Sidney, Edmund Gwenn and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Reiderland]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Oldambt

Reiderland is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2010, it has been a part of the municipality of Oldambt.

[[Bellingwedde]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s establishments in the Netherlands, 1968 establishments in Europe, Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Westerwolde

Bellingwedde is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands.

[[Vlagtwedde]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Westerwolde

Vlagtwedde is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2018, it has been part of the new municipality of Westerwolde.

[[Het Hogeland]]

CATEGORIES: Het Hogeland, 2019 establishments in the Netherlands

Het Hogeland is a municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. In 2019, 49,479 people lived there.

It was created on 1 January 2019 from the former municipalities of Bedum, De Marne, Eemsmond and Winsum.

[[Briaroaks, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Briaroaks is a town in the U.S. state of Texas. 

[[War of God (1976 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 movies, 1970s adventure movies, Taiwanese movies, Monster movies

War of God or Hong Kong Calamity is an 1976 Taiwanese-Hong Kong movie.  It is science fiction, fantasy, and action movie. Chun Hongmyin directed it.  It was produced by Hsing Hua Film Production Company. War of God was released in Taiwanese by July 24, 1976. Koichi Takano built the special effects.

[[Sadyr Japarov]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, Presidents of Kyrgyzstan, Prime Ministers of Kyrgyzstan, Current national leaders

Sadyr Nurgozhoevich Japarov (Садыр Нургожоевич Жапаров; born 6 December 1968, surname sometimes romanized as Zhaparov) is a Kyrgyz politician. He is the Prime Minister of Kyrgyzstan since 6 October 2020. On 15 October 2020, he became Acting President of Kyrgyzstan.

[[SpaceX Crew-1]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in the United States, Spaceflight, Future events, October 2020 events, November 2020 events

SpaceX Crew-1 (also known as USCV-1 or simply Crew-1) is the first crewed operational flight of a Crew Dragon spacecraft. 

The Crew Dragon spacecraft Resilience was expected to launch on 31 October 2020 on a Falcon 9 from the Kennedy Space Center, LC-39A. The launch was postponed due to bad weather and was eventually launched on 15 November. 

It carried NASA astronauts Michael Hopkins, Victor Glover and Shannon Walker along with JAXA astronaut Soichi Noguchi, all members of the Expedition 64 crew. The mission is the second overall crewed orbital flight of the Crew Dragon, pending the certification of the vehicle.

[[Michael S. Hopkins]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, Engineers from Missouri, American astronauts, Scientists from Missouri

Michael Scott “Mike” Hopkins (born December 28, 1968) is a Colonel in the United States Space Force, and a current NASA astronaut. 

Hopkins was selected in June 2009 as a member of the NASA Astronaut Group 20. He made his first spaceflight as a Flight Engineer on Soyuz TMA-10M/Expedition 37/Expedition 38, from September 2013 until March 2014. 

He was the first member of his astronaut class to fly in space.

[[Lebanon, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Lebanon is a city in Laclede County, Missouri, United States. The population was 14,474 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Laclede County.

[[Victor J. Glover]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American astronauts, American aviators, Engineers from California, Scientists from California

Victor Jerome Glover (born April 30, 1976) is a NASA astronaut of the class of 2013 and Pilot on the first operational flight of the SpaceX Crew Dragon to the International Space Station. 

Glover is a commander in the U.S. Navy. He was born in Pomona, California. He is an F/A-18 pilot and graduate of the U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School.

[[Shannon Walker]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, American astronauts, American physicists, Scientists from Houston, Texas

Shannon Walker (born June 4, 1965) is an American physicist and a NASA astronaut since 2004. She launched on her first mission into space on 25 June 2010 onboard Soyuz TMA-19 and has currently been 163 days in space over one long-duration mission to the International Space Station (ISS).

[[Hyla]]

CATEGORIES: Hyla, Frogs, Animals of Asia

Hyla is a genus of tree frogs in the family Hylidae. Over the years, scientists have changed their minds about which frog species should be in Hyla and which should be in Litoria, Ranoidea or other genera.  At one time, Hyla had more than 300 species from Europe, Asia, Africa, and across the Americas. Now, Hyla has only 17 extant (living) species. They are from Europe, northern Africa and Asia. The earliest known fossil from a Hyla frog is †Hyla swanstoni from the Eocene.  The fossil was found in Saskatchewan, Canada, but it is not clear whether we would consider swanstoni a Hyla frog today.

Josephus Nicolaus Laurenti made the genus in 1768. He named it after Hylas from Greek mythology.  Hylas was a friend of Hercules. Even though the mythological person Hylas was male, the name Hyla is given the feminine grammatical gender.

Some people say this word comes from the Greek word ὕλη (grc, "forest" or "wood"), but it does not.

[[Pomilio PE]]

CATEGORIES: World War I aircraft, Italian military aircraft

The Pomilio PE is an Italian reconnaissance biplane aircraft. It flew for the World War I and was built as at least 985 planes.

[[Soichi Noguchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, Astronauts, Japanese engineers, Japanese scientists

Soichi Noguchi is a Japanese aeronautical engineer and JAXA astronaut. 

His first spaceflight was as a Mission Specialist aboard STS-114 on 26 July 2005 for NASA's first "return to flight" Space Shuttle mission after the Columbia disaster. 

He was most recently in space as part of the Soyuz TMA-17 crew and Expedition 22 to the International Space Station (ISS), returning to Earth on 2 June 2010. 

He is the fifth Japanese astronaut to fly in space and the fourth to fly on the space shuttle.

[[New Administrative Capital]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Egypt

The New Administrative Capital (NAC) (العاصمة الإدارية الجديدة) is a large-scale project in Egypt that has been under construction since 2015.

It was announced by then-Egyptian housing minister Moustafa Madbouly at the Egypt Economic Development Conference on 13 March 2015. The city will reportedly be named Wedian, the Egyptian Arabic plural for "Wadi". 

[[Great conjunction]]

CATEGORIES: Jupiter, Saturn

A great conjunction is a conjunction of the planets Jupiter and Saturn. Great conjunctions occur regularly (every 19.6 years, on average) due to the combined effect of Jupiter's about 11.86-year orbital period and Saturn's 29.5-year orbital period. The last great conjunction happened on 21 December 2020. It was the closest great conjunction since 1623.

[[2020 Moldovan presidential election]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections in Europe, Moldova, November 2020 events

The 2020 Moldovan presidential election took place on Sunday, 1 November 2020. It was the 4th presidential election since the nation's declaration of independence. Voters elected former Prime Minister Maia Sandu as the new president in the second-round of the election on 15 November.

[[Dassault Aviation Falcon 7X]]

CATEGORIES: Aviation in France, Dassault Aviation

The Dassault Aviation Falcon 7X is a tri-jet business aircraft built in France.

[[2020 Venezuelan parliamentary election]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections, December 2020 events, History of Venezuela

Parliamentary elections were held in Venezuela on 6 December 2020. Aside from the 167 deputies of the National Assembly who are eligible to be re-elected, the new National Electoral Council president announced that the assembly would increase by 93 seats, for a total of 277 deputies to be elected.

Many saw the election was unfair saying that there were many illegal votes and it was rigged.

[[Solar eclipse of December 14, 2020]]

CATEGORIES: December 2020 events, Eclipses

A total solar eclipse occurred on Monday, December 14, 2020. A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between Earth and the Sun, which will cover the image of the Sun for a viewer on Earth. 

A total solar eclipse happens when the Moon's apparent diameter is larger than the Sun's, blocking all direct sunlight, turning day into darkness. Totality happens in a narrow path across Earth's surface, with the partial solar eclipse visible over a surrounding region thousands of kilometres wide. 

The Moon’s apparent diameter was larger because the eclipse occurred only 1.8 days after perigee, the point at which the Moon is closest to the Earth (on December 12, 2020).

It was visible from Chile and Argentina. There was also a partial solar eclipse in Bolivia, Brazil, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay.

[[Baalveer Returns]]

CATEGORIES: Children's television series, Action television series, Superhero television shows, Fantasy television series, Indian television series

Baalveer Returns is an Indian fantasy television series. It premiered on 10 September 2019 on SAB TV, and stars Dev Joshi, and Vansh Sayani in the titular lead role. It is a sequel of Baal Veer, which ran from 2012 to 2016.  It is produced by Optimystix Entertainment with screenplay by Manoj Tripathi.

[[Prince Charles of Luxembourg (born 2020)]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Prince Charles of Luxembourg (born Charles Jean Philippe Joseph Marie Guillaume; born 10 May 2020) is the only child of Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume and Hereditary Grand Duchess Stéphanie. He was born at Grand Duchess Charlotte Maternity Hospital in Luxembourg City. 

He is second in the line of succession to the throne of Luxembourg. 

His birth was celebrated by a 21-gun salute at Fort Thungen in Kirchberg.

On 19 September 2020, Prince Charles was baptised at the Abbey of St. Maurice and St. Maurus of Clervaux in Luxembourg.

[[Prince Charles of Luxembourg (1927–1977)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 1977 deaths, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian politicians

Prince Charles of Luxembourg, Prince of Bourbon-Parma and Nassau (born Charles Frédéric Louis Guillaume Marie; 7 August 1927 – 26 July 1977), was a younger son of Grand Duchess Charlotte and Prince Felix of Bourbon-Parma.

[[Hairy-eared dwarf lemur]]

CATEGORIES: Lemuriformes, Mammals of Africa

The hairy-eared dwarf lemur (Allocebus trichotis), is a type of lemur. It is also called the hairy-eared mouse lemur. It is a nocturnal animal. It only lives in Madagascar. It is the only member of the genus Allocebus.

[[Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Prince Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg (Guillaume Jean Joseph Marie; born 11 November 1981), is the heir apparent to the crown of Luxembourg since his father's became grand duke in 2000.

His style and title in full is: His Royal Highness Prince Guillaume Jean Joseph Marie, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, Hereditary Prince of Nassau, Prince of Bourbon-Parma.

On 26 April 2012, the court announced the engagement of the Hereditary Grand Duke to the Belgian Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy. They were married on 19 October 2012.

Guillaume and Stéphanie have a son, named Prince Charles, born on 10 May 2020.

[[Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Princess Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg (born Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy on 18 February 1984), is the wife of Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume, heir apparent to the throne of Luxembourg. 

She became engaged to the Hereditary Grand Duke on 26 April 2012 and married him, in a civil ceremony, on 19 October 2012, followed by a religious service the next day. The couple have a son, Prince Charles.

[[Maria Teresa, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, People from Havana, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Maria Teresa (born María Teresa Mestre y Batista; 22 March 1956) is the spouse of Grand Duke Henri, who acceded to the throne in 2000. She was born in Cuba.

Maria Teresa married Prince Henri of Luxembourg in a civil ceremony on 4 February 1981 and a religious ceremony on 14 February 1981. She received a bouquet of red roses as a wedding gift from the then Cuban dictator Fidel Castro.

The couple has five children: Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, Prince Félix of Luxembourg, Prince Louis of Luxembourg, Princess Alexandra of Luxembourg, and Prince Sébastien of Luxembourg.

[[List of monarchs of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: Grand Dukes of Luxembourg

The territory of Luxembourg has been ruled successively by counts, dukes and grand dukes.  It was part of the medieval Kingdom of Germany, and later the Holy Roman Empire until it became a sovereign state in 1815.

[[William I of the Netherlands]]

CATEGORIES: 1772 births, 1843 deaths, Grand Dukes of Luxembourg, Kings and Queens of the Netherlands

William I (Willem Frederik, Prince of Orange-Nassau; 24 August 1772 – 12 December 1843) was a Prince of Orange, the King of the Netherlands and Grand Duke of Luxembourg.

[[Adolphe, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: 1817 births, 1905 deaths, Grand Dukes of Luxembourg

Adolphe (Adolf Wilhelm August Karl Friedrich; 24 July 1817 – 17 November 1905) was the last sovereign Duke of Nassau, reigning from 20 August 1839 until the duchy's annexation to Kingdom of Prussia in 1866. 

In 1890, he became Grand Duke of Luxembourg following the death of King William III of the Netherlands, ending the personal relationship between the Netherlands and Luxembourg, until his own death in 1905. 

He was the first monarch of Luxembourg from the House of Nassau-Weilburg.

[[William IV, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: Grand Dukes of Luxembourg, 1852 births, 1912 deaths

William IV (William Alexander; French: Guillaume Alexandre; 22 April 1852 – 25 February 1912) reigned as the Grand Duke of Luxembourg from 17 November 1905 until his death. He succeeded his father, Adolphe.

Currently, William is the last monarch of Luxembourg to die while still on the throne.

[[Marie-Adélaïde, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: Grand Dukes of Luxembourg, 1894 births, 1924 deaths

Marie-Adélaïde (Marie Adelheid Thérèse Hilda Wilhelmine; 14 June 1894 – 24 January 1924), reigned as Grand Duchess of Luxembourg from 1912 until she left the throne in 1919. 

She was the first Grand Duchess regnant of Luxembourg (after five grand dukes), its first female monarch since Duchess Maria Theresa (1740–1780, who was also Austrian Archduchess and Holy Roman Empress) and the first Luxembourgish monarch to be born within the territory since Count John the Blind (1296–1346).

[[Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: 1896 births, 1985 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Grand Dukes of Luxembourg

Charlotte (Charlotte Adelgonde Élise/Elisabeth Marie Wilhelmine; 23 January 1896 – 9 July 1985) was the Grand Duchess of Luxembourg from 1919 until her abdication in 1964.

She became grand duchess on 14 January 1919 following the abdication of her sister, Marie-Adélaïde, due to political pressure.

She married Prince Felix of Bourbon-Parma on 6 November 1919. They had six children. Following the 1940 German invasion of Luxembourg during World War II, Charlotte went into exile: first in France, then Portugal, Great Britain, and North America. While in Britain, she made broadcasts to the people of Luxembourg. She returned to Luxembourg in April 1945.

She abdicated in 1964, and was replaced by her son Jean. 

[[Prince Felix of Bourbon-Parma]]

CATEGORIES: 1893 births, 1970 deaths, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Prince Félix of Bourbon-Parma (Félix Marie Vincent; 28 September 1893 – 8 April 1970), later Prince Félix of Luxembourg, was the husband of Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg and the father of her six children, including her replacement: Grand Duke Jean. He was the longest serving consort of Luxembourg.

[[Princess Joséphine Charlotte of Belgium]]

CATEGORIES: Princes and princesses, Deaths from lung cancer, People from Brussels, Luxembourgian people, 1927 births, 2005 deaths

Joséphine-Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg (born Princess Joséphine-Charlotte of Belgium; 11 October 1927 – 10 January 2005), was the Grand Duchess consort of Luxembourg as the wife of Grand Duke Jean. 

She was the first child of King Leopold III of Belgium, and sister of the late King Baudouin and former King Albert II and aunt of King Philippe. 

She was also the first cousin of King Harald V of Norway.

Joséphine died of lung cancer on 10 January 2005 at Fischbach Castle in Luxembourg at the age of 77.

[[Anne of Austria, Landgravine of Thuringia]]

CATEGORIES: 1432 births, 1462 deaths, People from Vienna, Princes and princesses

Anne of Bohemia and Austria (12 April 1432 – 13 November 1462) was a Duchess of Luxembourg in her own right and, as a consort, Landgravine of Thuringia and of Saxony.

She was the eldest daughter of Albert of Austria.

On 2 June 1446 the young Anne was married to William "the Brave" of Saxony (1425–82), Landgrave of Thuringia, a younger son of Frederick I "the Warlike" of Saxony.

[[William III, Landgrave of Thuringia]]

CATEGORIES: 1420s births, 1482 deaths, Grand Dukes of Luxembourg

William III (30 April 1425 – 17 September 1482), called the Brave (in German Wilhelm der Tapfere), was landgrave of Thuringia (from 1445) and claimant duke of Luxemburg (from 1457).  He is actually the second William to rule Thuringia, and in Luxembourg; he was the third Margrave of Meissen named William.

[[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]]

CATEGORIES: Cathedrals, Luxembourg, Buildings and structures in Europe

Notre-Dame Cathedral (Kathedral Notre-Dame, Cathédrale Notre-Dame, Kathedrale unserer lieben Frau) is the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Luxembourg City, in southern Luxembourg. 

It was originally a Jesuit church, and its cornerstone was laid in 1613. It is the only cathedral in Luxembourg.

Many Grand Dukes are buried here.

[[Cream (colour)]]

CATEGORIES: Shades of white, Shades of yellow

Cream is a yellowish-white color.

[[Infanta Marie Anne of Portugal]]

CATEGORIES: 1861 births, 1942 deaths, Princes and princesses, Luxembourgian people

Infanta Marie Anne of Portugal (Maria Ana; 13 July 1861 – 31 July 1942) was Grand Duchess of Luxembourg as the wife of Grand Duke Guillaume IV.

She was the country's regent in the name of their daughter, Grand Duchess Marie-Adélaïde. She was a member of the House of Braganza.

[[Russet (color)]]

CATEGORIES: Shades of brown, Shades of red

Russet is a reddish-brown color.

[[Tawny (color)]]

CATEGORIES: Shades of brown, Shades of orange

Tawny is a brownish-orange color or brownish-yellow color.

[[Buff (colour)]]

CATEGORIES: Shades of brown, Shades of yellow, Shades of orange

Buff is a light brownish-yellow color.

[[Pierre Kezdy]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Illinois, American rock musicians, American punk musicians, Musicians from Chicago

Pierre Kezdy (January 4, 1962 – October 9, 2020) was an American bass player. He was born in Chicago. Kezdy was known for playing with many  Chicago punk bands, including Naked Raygun, Pegboy, Strike Under, Arsenal, and Trial By Fire.

Kezdy died of cancer on October 9, 2020 while under hospice care in Glenview, Illinois at the age of 58.

[[J. Russell Capps]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1931 births, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from North Carolina, People from Raleigh, North Carolina, US Republican Party politicians

James Russell Capps (February 26, 1931 – October 6, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the North Carolina General Assembly from 1994 to 2006. He was born in Raleigh, North Carolina. He lost his re-election campaign in 2006. He unsuccessfully ran again in 2012.

Capps died on October 6, 2020 in Raleigh at the age of 89.

[[Alas (geography)]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms, Geography of Russia

Alas is a landform that is a little bit lower than the surface around it. It mainly occurs in Yakutia. An alas first develops as a shallow lake. The lake eventually dries out and is replaced by grass and other plants.

Alases are often used as a pasture for horses. They are common in the Central Yakutian Lowland. The largest alas in the world is Myuryu, found in Ust-Aldan District.

[[Thiago Alcântara]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Spanish footballers, Association football midfielders, Liverpool F.C. players, Premier League players, UEFA Euro 2016 players, 2018 FIFA World Cup players

Thiago Alcântara do Nascimento (born 11 April 1991), commonly known as Thiago Alcântara, or simply Thiago is a Spanish professional footballer. He plays as a central midfielder for Premier League club Liverpool, and the Spain national team. He is the son of former Brazilian player Mazinho. Thiago is considered as one of the best midfielders of all time.

[[Loppersum]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Eemsdelta

Loppersum is a village and former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. In 2019, 9,614 people lived there. Since 2021, it has been part of the new municipality of Eemsdelta.

[[Lemsterland]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Friesland, De Fryske Marren

Lemsterland (Lemsterlân) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. Since 2014, it has been part of the new municipality of De Fryske Marren.

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Friesland, De Fryske Marren

Skarsterlân (Scharsterland) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. Since 2014, it has been part of the new municipality of De Fryske Marren.

[[Gaasterlân-Sleat]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Friesland, De Fryske Marren

Gaasterlân-Sleat (Gaasterland-Sloten) is a former municipality in the Dutch province of Friesland. Since 2014, it has been part of the new municipality of De Fryske Marren.

[[De Marne]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Het Hogeland

De Marne is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the new municipality of Het Hogeland.

[[Kostas Tsimikas]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Greek footballers, Association football defenders, Association football full-backs, Liverpool F.C. players, Living people

Konstantinos "Kostas" Tsimikas (Κωνσταντίνος "Κώστας" Τσιμίκας, born 12 May 1996) is a Greek football player. He plays as a left-back for Premier League club Liverpool and the Greece national team.

[[Bedum]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Het Hogeland

Bedum is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the new municipality of Het Hogeland.

[[Eemsmond]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Het Hogeland

Eemsmond is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the new municipality of Het Hogeland.

[[Winsum]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Former municipalities of Groningen (province), Het Hogeland, Westerkwartier

Winsum is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2019, it has been part of the new municipality of Het Hogeland and has also been part of the new municipality of Westerkwartier.

Hoogezand-Sappemeer is a former municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. Since 2018, it has been part of the new municipality of Midden-Groningen.

[[Ronnie Whelan]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Irish footballers, Irish football managers, 1990 FIFA World Cup players, 1994 FIFA World Cup players, Association football midfielders, Liverpool F.C. players, Premier League players, Sportspeople from Dublin, Living people

Ronald Andrew Whelan (born 25 September 1961) is a former Irish football player. During his playing career, he played as a midfielder and sometimes as a defender. He was a part of a dominant Liverpool side that won a many titles in the 1980s.

[[Rudolph B. Davila]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2002 deaths, American people of World War II, United States Army Medal of Honor recipients, People from El Paso, Texas

Rudolph B. Davila (April 27, 1916 – January 26, 2002) was an Asian American who recevied the Medal of Honor during World War II.  He was the only person of Filipino ancestry to receive the medal.

[[Native Hawaiians]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in Oceania, Ethnic groups in the United States, Polynesia, Native Hawaiians

Native Hawaiians are the native people of Hawaii. They are a Polynesian group whose ancestors came from what is now French Polynesia. Hawaiians make up 21% of Hawaii’s total population, though most are mixed. Their original language is the Hawaiian language, but Hawaiian Pidgin or English is more common.

[[Glen]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys

A glen is a valley, that has slopes that are not steep. It is usually long. It is found in the Northern Hemisphere.

[[Windward slope]]

CATEGORIES: Geography, Weather

The windward slope is the side of a mountain, island or other tall thing that the wind hits.  The windward direction is the direction upwind from the point of reference.  That means windward is the direction from which the wind is coming.  If the wind is moving from north to south, then the windward slope is the north side of the hill or mountain.  Leeward is the direction downwind from the point of reference.  The leeward side of a mountain is usually drier than the windward side.

[[Ridge]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms

A ridge or a mountain ridge is a landform that consists of a chain of mountains or hills that form lots of peaks for a distance. Ridges are usually called hills or mountains as well.

[[Lake Success, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Lake Success is a village and a capital of the Great Neck School District in Nassau County, New York in the United States. The population was 2,934 at the 2010 census.

[[Joseph Pérez]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, French historians

Joseph Pérez (14 January 1931 &ndashl 8 October 2020) was a French historian. His works focused in Spanish history. 

Pérez's worked in the births of the modern Spanish state and the Latin American nations.  

Among his books, he examined the independence movements of Latin America; Ferdinand and Isabella, the Catholic Monarchs; Holy Roman Emperor Charles V, and Philip II of Spain.

[[Frido Croes]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Aruba, South American politicians

Francisco Walfrido "Frido" Croes (3 December 1957 – 9 October 2020) was an Aruban politician and schoolteacher. He held the office of Minister Plenipotentiary of Aruba from 2005 to 2009. Prior to that, he was a member of parliament from 1989 to 1994, and as its chairman from 2001 to 2004. He also served as minister of education from 2004 to 2005.

Croes died on 9 October 2020 at the age of 62.

[[Estates of Aruba]]

CATEGORIES: Aruba

The Estates of Aruba (Staten van Aruba) are the unicameral legislature or parliament of Aruba. The Estates have 21 members, elected for a four-year term by proportional representation. 

Each member holds their seats until Parliament is dissolved which is every four years by a general election. The leader of the party who gains majority usually becomes the Prime Minister.

[[Ekow Hayford]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Ghanaian politicians, Murders by firearm, Assassinated people

Ekow Hayford (24 December 1970 – 9 October 2020) was a Ghanaian politician. He was a member of the Seventh Parliament of the Fourth Republic of Ghana representing the Mfantseman Constituency in the Central Region. He was a member of the New Patriotic Party. Hayford was born in Mankessim, Ghana.

On 9 October 2020, while returning from a campaign tour, he was shot dead by unknown persons at the age of 49.

[[Converse (logic)]]

CATEGORIES: Logical connectives

While a converse is similar to its originating implication, they are not logically equivalent. This means that the truth of an implication does not guarantee the truth of its converse (and vice versa).

Scappoose s is a city in Columbia County, Oregon,  United States. It was named for a nearby stream, which drains the southern part of the county.  The population was 6,592 at the 2010 census.

[[Logical equivalence]]

CATEGORIES: Logic

For example, the statements "A and B" and "B and A" are logically equivalent. If P and Q are logically equivalent, then the statement "P if and only if Q" is a tautology.

[[Bitme (Mexican TV channel)]]

[[Carter Catlett Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Gerontology, American activists, People from Texas

Carter Catlett Williams was a social worker. She worked to change nursing homes so that older people living in them had more freedom. She started the Pioneer Network. It is a not-for-profit organization that works to make nursing homes better. She was a leader in creating the Nursing Home Reform Act in 1987. The University of Rochester Medical Center keeps her papers.

Williams was born on September 2, 1923 in Texas and died on September 8, 2020 in Gloucester, Virginia. She was 97 years old.

[[Jimmie Lee Solomon]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Houston, Texas

Jimmie Lee Solomon (March 11, 1956spndOctober 9, 2020) was an American lawyer and Major League Baseball executive. He was born in Trinity County, Texas. He was the Executive Vice President of Baseball Operations from 2005 to 2010. He later was the Executive Vice President for Baseball Development from 2010 to 2012.

Solomon was found dead on October 9, 2020 at his home in Houston, aged 64. The cause of death is unknown.

[[Cat Bordhi]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Textile artists, American novelists, Writers from San Francisco

Cat Bordhi was a teacher, author, and knitting expert. She changed how people knit socks and scarves. She was very influential in the knitting community. She self-published books that opened up a very closed and tightly controlled knitting publishing industry.

She also wrote a novel called Treasure Forest. It was a Nautilus Book Award winner in 2004.

She was born 2 March 1951 in San Francisco, California. She died 19 September 2020 at home in Friday Harbor, Washington. She was 69 years old.

[[Nautilus Book Awards]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 establishments in the United States, American literature, American culture, Literary awards

Nautilus Book Awards is a prize for books about social and environmental justice. It started in the United States in 1998. There is prize money. The award is to recognize books that "make a difference and inspire." The award is named for the nautilus shell, as a symbol of wisdom and growth.

[[Antarctic plate]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Antarctica, Tectonic plates

The Antarctic plate is tectonic region that located in Antarctica, south pole. The Antarctic plate surrounded spreading centers at the oceanic edges of large neighboring plates. These include the Pacific, Nazca, South American, African, and Australian plates. The smaller scotia, South Sandwich, and Shetland Plates are considered to be part of Antarctic region and one of the Earth's seven major tectonics plate. It is moving at speeds varying from 4 to 20 mm/year. The Antartic plate includes continental crust making up Antarctica and its continental shelf, along with oceanic crust beneath the seas surrounding of Antarctica.

[[Christopher Poole]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s births, Living people, Businesspeople from New York City, Google people, American Internet celebrities

Christopher Poole (born 1988), known online as moot,  is an American Internet entrepreneur. He was born in New York City. He is best known for founding the anonymous English-language imageboard 4chan in October 2003. He served as the site's head administrator for more than 11 years before stepping down in January 2015. In 2016, he began working for Google. As of 2018, he works in the company's Google Maps division, based in Tokyo.

[[The Grass Harp (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on books

The Grass Harp is a 1995 American comedy-drama movie directed by Charles Matthau and was based on the 1951 novel of the same name by Truman Capote. It stars Piper Laurie, Sissy Spacek, Walter Matthau, Jack Lemmon, Edward Furlong, Nell Carter, Roddy McDowall, Mary Steenburgen, Charles Durning, Doris Roberts, Scott Wilson and was distributed by Fine Line Pictures.

[[Touch-Tone Terrorists]]

CATEGORIES: American comedians

The Touch-Tone Terrorists is a series of prank phone calls comedy CDs. The Touch-Tone Terrorists are actually one man named Pete Dzoghi who also goes by the name of "RePete". He purchased a series of 1-800 numbers, including ones that were one digit different than actual customer service numbers for companies such as (apparently) UPS, an oil change business, an auto insurance "claims support line", a psychic hotline, a pen manufacturer, a bank, department store, phone company, and others. Using a Gentner SPH-3A telephone hybrid and a Yamaha SPX-90 electronic pitch transposer to alter his voice over the phone, he would take incoming calls from people who had misdialed the number and were under the assumption that they had dialed the right number.  He created a series of ridiculous exaggerated characters, all of which were voiced by him.

[[Rock shelter]]

CATEGORIES: Caves

A rock shelter is a shallow cave-like opening at the bottom of a cliff. Rock shelters form because a rock stratum that does not erode has formed a cliff. But a weaker stratum, that erodes a lot is under the resistant stratum. As it erodes it creates an opening at the bottom of the cliff.

[[Charles Moore (athlete)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, American track and field athletes, American Olympic gold medalists, American Olympic silver medalists, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from Pennsylvania, Sportspeople from Pennsylvania

Charles Hewes Moore Jr. (August 12, 1929 – October 8, 2020) was an American track and field athlete. Moore won a gold medal and a silver medalist in the 400 metre hurdles in the 1952 Summer Olympics with a time of 50.8 seconds. In 1999, he was added into the United States National Track and Field Hall of Fame. Moore was born in Coatesville, Pennsylvania.

Moore died on October 8, 2020 in Laporte, Pennsylvania at the age of 91.

[[Laporte, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania, County seats in Pennsylvania

Laporte is a borough in Sullivan County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 316 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Sullivan County.

[[Coatesville, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Pennsylvania

Coatesville is a city in Chester County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 13,100 at the 2010 census. Coatesville is about 39 miles west of Philadelphia.

[[Two Gentlemen Sharing]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 drama movies, British drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Ted Kotcheff

Two Gentlemen Sharing is a 1969 British drama movie directed by Ted Kotcheff and was based on the novel of the same name by David Stuart Leslie. It stars Rob Phillips, Judy Geeson, Norman Rossington, Rachel Kempson, Hilary Dwyer, Ram John Holder, Philip Stone, David Markham.

[[George Rhoden]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, Jamaican sportspeople, Competitors in athletics, People from Kingston, Jamaica, Olympic gold medalists

George Vincent Rhoden (born 13 December 1926) is a former Jamaican athlete. He is the winner of two Olympic gold medals in 1952. He was born in Kingston.

[[Leslie Laing]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2021 deaths, Jamaican sportspeople, Male athletes, Olympic gold medalists, Sprinters

Leslie Alphonso "Les" Laing (19 February 1925 – 7 February 2021) was a Jamaican athlete. He was a winner of gold medal in 4 × 400 m relay at the 1952 Summer Olympics. He was born in Linstead, Jamaica. At the Helsinki Olympics, Laing was fifth in the 200 m. He ran the second leg in the Jamaican 4 × 400 m relay team, which won the gold medal with a new world record of 3:03.9.

Laing died on 7 February 2021 at the age of 95.

[[John Webster (Royal Navy officer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, British military people

Vice Admiral Sir John Morrison Webster KCB (3 November 1932 – 5 October 2020) was a Royal Navy officer. He became the Flag Officer Plymouth and Port Admiral, Devonport in 1987. He left the position in 1990.

He was appointed Director of Naval Warfare at the Ministry of Defence in 1980, Flag Officer Sea Training in 1982 and Chief of Staff to the Commander-in-Chief Fleet in 1984.

He died on 5 October 2020 at the age of 87.

[[2020 Kyrgyzstani protests]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 protests in Asia, 2020s in Kyrgyzstan, October 2020 events

The 2020 Kyrgyzstan protests began on 5 October 2020 in response to the 2020 parliamentary election that were perceived by protestors as unfair. The results of the election were annulled on 6 October 2020.

[[2020 Kyrgyz parliamentary election]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections in Asia, 2020s in Kyrgyzstan, October 2020 events

Parliamentary elections were held in Kyrgyzstan on 4 October 2020. 

The results showed that pro-government parties had won a supermajority of seats. The election was annulled by the Central Election Commission during the 2020 Kyrgyzstan protests.

[[Supreme Council (Kyrgyzstan)]]

CATEGORIES: Kyrgyzstan

The Supreme Council (Жогорку Кеңеш, Joğorku Keñeş, جوعورقۇ كەڭەش; Верховный Совет, Verkhovnyy Sovet) is the unicameral Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic. It  was known as the Supreme Soviet of the Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic until 1991.

The parliament has 120 seats with members elected for a five-year term by party-list proportional voting.

[[Vasili Kulkov]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Russian footballers, Football managers, Sportspeople from Moscow

Vassily Sergeyevich Kulkov (no; 11 June 1966 – 10 October 2020) was a Russian footballer, and manager. He was born in Moscow.

He was a central defender and defensive midfielder. He was best known for his spells at Spartak Moscow and Benfica. He also played for the Russian national team from 1992 to 1995.

Kulkov died of brain cancer on 10 October 2020 in Moscow, aged 54.

[[Megalopyge opercularis]]

CATEGORIES: Lepidoptera

The Megalopyge opercularis is a moth of the family Megalopygidae. It has a number of common names, like asp caterpillar, puss caterpillar, woolly slug and puss moth. 

This caterpillar is highly dangerous due to its venomous spines. Exposure to this caterpillar's fur-like spines leads to an immediate skin irritation. The pain is similar to bee, wasp or hornet stings. The reactions are often localized to the affected area. However, the reactions are usually severe. The reaction causes burning, nausea, headache, rashes, vomiting and blisters.

These caterpillars are seen from southeast Virginia to Florida and as far west as Missouri and Texas. They are also in Mexico and Central America.

If you are stung by a puss moth, asp caterpillar or puss caterpillar, get first aid right away. The spines need to be removed using cellophane tape. You can also use baking soda, ice packs or calamine lotion for the sting.

[[Mary Berry]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, British television presenters, British chefs, Writers from Somerset, People from Bath, Somerset

Dame Mary Rosa Alleyne Hunnings GBR (Berry; born 24 March 1935), known professionally as Mary Berry, is a British food writer, chef and television presenter. She was born in Bath, Somerset.

She has published more than 75 cookery books, including her best-selling Baking Bible in 2009. Her first book was The Hamlyn All Colour Cookbook in 1970. 

She hosted several television series for the BBC and Thames Television. Berry has appeared on Woman's Hour and Saturday Kitchen. She was a judge on the BBC One (originally BBC Two) television programme The Great British Bake Off from 2010 until 2016.

In 2020, Berry was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire.

[[Paul Smith (fashion designer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, British fashion designers, Businesspeople from London, People from Nottinghamshire

Sir Paul Smith GBR (born 5 July 1946) is a British fashion designer. He is known for his designs for men's clothing.

Smith was made a Royal Designer for Industry in 1991 and was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in the 2000 Queen's Birthday Honours List.

[[Tommy Steele]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, English rock singers, English rock guitarists, English movie actors, English television actors, Actors from London, Musicians from London, Singers from London

Sir Thomas Hicks, GBR (born 17 December 1936), known professionally as Tommy Steele, is an English rock singer, guitarist and actor. He was born in London. He reached number one with "Singing the Blues" in 1957.

[[Brendan Foster]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, British Olympic bronze medalists, British athletes, Olympic Games broadcasters, Commanders of the Order of the British Empire, Sportspeople from Tyne and Wear

Sir Brendan Foster GBR (born 12 January 1948) is a British former long-distance runner, athletics commentator and road race organiser.

He founded the Great North Run, one of the sport's most high profile half-marathon races. Foster was born in Hebburn, South Tyneside.

As an athlete, he won the bronze medal in the 10,000 metres at the 1976 Summer Olympics, and the gold medal in the 5,000 metres at the 1974 European Championships and the 10,000 metres at the 1978 Commonwealth Games. 

[[Louie Gohmert]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, United States representatives from Texas, American judges, American lawyers, US Republican Party politicians, Businesspeople from Texas

Louis Buller Gohmert Jr. (ˈ; born August 18, 1953) is an American attorney and former judge. He is a member of the U.S. Representative from Texas's 1st congressional district since 2005. Gohmert is a member of the  Republican Party and is part of the Tea Party movement.

In January 2015, he unsuccessfully ran against John Boehner for the position of Speaker of the House of Representatives.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, he became known for his criticism of wearing surgical masks to prevent the spread of COVID-19. In July 2020, Gohmert tested positive for the disease.

In July 2020, Gohmert proposed to ban the Democratic Party over their past support for slavery during the Civil War era.

[[Pete Aguilar]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, United States representatives from California, American mayors, US Democratic Party politicians

Peter Rey Aguilar ˈ (born June 19, 1979) is a Mexican-American politician. He is the U.S. Representative from California's 31st congressional district. He is a member of the Democrat. He was Mayor of Redlands, California from 2010 to 2014.

Aguilar is a Chief Deputy Whip in the House Democratic Caucus and Whip of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus.

[[Jay Kim]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, United States representatives from California, South Korean politicians, People from Seoul, People from Riverside, California

Jay Chang Joon Kim (김창준; born March 27, 1939) is a Korean-American politician. He was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from California between 1993 to 1999. He was the first Korean American to be elected to the United States Congress. Kim was born in present-day Seoul.

[[Russell's teapot]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophical concepts

Russell's teapot is an analogy by the philosopher Bertrand Russell (1872–1970), to show that the philosophic burden of proof has on a person making a claim that cannot be proven false.  

Russell used his analogy in for religion. He wrote that if he were to say without proof, that a teapot, too small to be seen by telescopes, orbits the Sun somewhere in space between the Earth and Mars, he could not expect anyone to believe him because his claim could not be proven wrong.

Russell's teapot is still used to talk about the existence of God.

[[Veendam]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Groningen (province), Municipalities of Groningen (province)

Veendam is a municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. In 2019, 27,491 people lived there.

[[Burden of proof (philosophy)]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophical concepts

The burden of proof (Latin: onus probandi) is the job of a person who is involved in a debate to show proof for their claim. 

When people are in a discussion and one makes a claim that the other one does not agree with, the one who makes the claim has the  burden of proof. It means he must show proof of that claim, especially when it is controversial. 

Carl Sagan said that: "extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence" – which is known as the Sagan standard.

Often these philosophical debates moved from what the claim was to debating who has the "burden of proof" or the best proof for their claim.

[[Lexicology]]

CATEGORIES: Linguistics

Lexicology is the science of words and their meanings.

The word "lexicology" is a combination of Greek λεξικόν lexicon, which means "of" or "for words", and Greek -λογία -logia, "the study of".

[[Abyssal fan]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms

Abyssal fans are underwater geological formations formed by turbidity currents. It is also called deep-sea fans, underwater deltas, and submarine fans. They can be several kilometres long to several thousands of kilometres long. The largest abyssal fan is the Bengal Fan.

[[Abyssal plain]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms

An abyssal plain is an underwater plain on the deep ocean floor. It is usually found 3,000 metres (9,800 ft) and 6,000 metres (20,000 ft) below the surface of the water. Abyssal plains cover more than 50% of the Earth's surface. They are among the flattest and smoothest places on Earth.

Abyssal plains are believed to have lots of biodiversity. They are also play an important role in ocean carbon cycling, dissolution of calcium carbonate, and atmospheric CO2 concentrations over hundreds or thousand years. Abyssal plains also have hydrothermal vents and cold seeps.

[[Daredevil (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 movies, 2003 crime movies, American crime movies, English-language movies, 2000s superhero movies, Daredevil (movie series), Film noir, Movies directed by Mark Steven Johnson, Movies produced by Avi Arad, Movies set in New York, Screenplays by Mark Steven Johnson, Superhero drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, American superhero movies

Daredevil is a 2003 American superhero movie directed and written by Mark Steven Johnson. It was based on the Marvel character Daredevil by Stan Lee. Daredevil's main actors are Ben Affleck, Jennifer Garner, Michael Clarke Duncan, and Collin Farrell.

[[Fantastic Four (2015 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 movies, 2010s superhero movies, American action movies, American fantasy movies, American science fiction movies, English-language movies, Movies based on comic book characters, Movies produced by Simon Kinberg, Movies set in the 2000s, Screenplays by Simon Kinberg, Superhero drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Fantastic Four movies, Reboot movies

Fantastic Four is a 2015 American superhero movie based on the Marvel Comics comic Fantastic Four.  The movie was released in the United States on August 7, 2015.

It was very poorly received by audiences and critics.

[[Natural arch]]

CATEGORIES: Rocks, Landforms

A natural arch is a natural rock formation where an arch has formed with an opening under the arch. It is also called a natural bridge, or (less commonly) rock arch. Natural arches commonly form where inland cliffs, coastal cliffs, fins or stacks are eroded by the sea, rivers or weathering.

Most natural arches are formed from narrow fins and sea stacks that is made up of sandstone or limestone.

[[Mortal Kombat 11]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 video games, Crossover video games, Mortal Kombat series, Nintendo Switch games, PlayStation 4 games, PlayStation 5 games, Windows games, Xbox One games, Xbox Series X and Series S games

Mortal Kombat 11 is a fighting video game. It was developed by NetherRealm Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. It is the eleventh main game in the Mortal Kombat series.

[[Richard Epcar]]

Richard Michael Epcar (born April 29, 1955) is an American movie, television and voice actor. He is the voice of Raiden in Mortal Kombat, of The Joker in Injustice and of Ansem in Kingdom Hearts.

[[Linked list]]

CATEGORIES: Data structures

In computer science, a linked list is a data structure that is a linear collection of items whose order is not given by their physical placement in memory. Instead, each item links to the next item. The last item links to a terminator used to mark the end of the list.

[[Injustice 2]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 video games, Crossover video games, Fighting games, NetherRealm Studios games, PlayStation 4 games, Windows games, Video games based on DC Comics, Xbox One games

Injustice 2 is a fighting video game. It was developed by NetherRealm Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. It is the second main game in the Injustice series based on characters from DC Comics.

[[Spawn (comics)]]

CATEGORIES: Comic books, Fictional African-American people, Fictional characters introduced in 1992, Fictional demons and devils, Mortal Kombat guest characters, Fictional war veterans, Soulcalibur series guest characters, Spawn (comics), Superheroes, Superhero movie characters

Spawn is a fictional character, a comic book superhero published by Image Comics. He was created by Todd McFarlane. He appears as a playable guest character in both Soulcalibur II and Mortal Kombat 11.

[[Tree (data structure)]]

CATEGORIES: Data structures

In computer science, a tree is a graph data structure composed of items that have child items. Trees have an item called a root. No item has the root as a child. Trees may not have cycles. Items may contain a reference to their parent. An item is a leaf if it has no children. The height of an item is the length of the longest downward path to a leaf from that item. The height of the root is the height of the tree. The depth of an item is the length of the path to the tree's root.

[[Binary tree]]

CATEGORIES: Data structures

In computer science, a binary tree is a type of tree (data structure) where each item 

within the tree has at most two children.

[[New Democracy (Greece)]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Greece, 1974 establishments in Europe, Conservative parties, Liberal parties, Political parties in Greece

New Democracy (ND; Νέα Δημοκρατία, Nea Dimokratia) is a liberal-conservative political party in Greece. Konstantinos Karamanlis founded the party in 1974. It is a far-right party, with many liberal ideas. Its main rival is the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, commonly known as PASOK.

Sequeira (born 10 November 1999) is a Portuguese professional footballer. He plays as a forward for La Liga club Atlético Madrid and the Portugal national team. At 18, he became the youngest ever player to score a hat-trick in the UEFA Europa League.

[[Breadth-first search]]

CATEGORIES: Searching and sorting algorithms

In computer science, breadth-first search (BFS) is a method used for traversing a graph. It starts at any item you want to use as a starting position in a graph, and explores all of the neighbor items at the present depth before to moving on to the items at the next depth level. A breadth-first search done on a tree (data structure) is called a level-order traversal.

[[The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 thriller movies, 1970s action movies, American action movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Joseph Sargent

The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (also known as The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3) is a 1974 American action thriller movie directed by Joseph Sargent and was based on the 1973 novel of the same name by Morton Freedgood. It stars Walter Matthau, Robert Shaw, Hector Elizondo, Martin Balsam, James Broderick, Earl Hindman, Jerry Stiller, Doris Roberts, Lee Wallace, Dick O'Neill and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Depth-first search]]

CATEGORIES: Searching and sorting algorithms

In computer science, depth-first search (DFS) is a method used for traversing a graph. It starts at an arbitrary item of a graph and explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.

[[Tracy Reiner]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American movie producers, American adoptees, Actors from Albuquerque, New Mexico

Tracy Reiner (born Tracy Henry; July 7, 1964) is an American actress, known for her roles in When Harry Met Sally..., Masque of the Red Death, A League of Their Own, and Apollo 13.

Reiner was born Tracy Henry in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the daughter of Penny Marshall and Michael Henry. She is filmmaker Garry Marshall's niece. Her mother was married for 10 years to Rob Reiner, who adopted her and raised her as his own. Her mother is of Italian, English, German and Scottish descent.January 2015 Reiner's adoptive paternal grandparents are Carl Reiner (1922–2020) and Estelle Reiner (1914–2008). Growing up, 15 of Reiner's relatives were employed at labs run by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Reiner is married and has five children.

[[Bidirectional search]]

CATEGORIES: Searching and sorting algorithms

In computer science, bidirectional search is a method used for finding the shortest path between two items in a graph. It runs two simultaneous searches starting from the two items.

[[Heap (data structure)]]

CATEGORIES: Data structures

In computer science, a heap is a type of tree (data structure) that satisfies the heap property. Heaps are useful when you need to remove the item with the highest (or lowest) value. A common implementation of a heap is the binary heap in which the tree is a complete binary tree.

[[Certificate of origin]]

CATEGORIES: Commerce, Documents

Certificate of Origin (abbreviated as C/O or CO) is a document used in trade between countries. Certificate of Origin gives information about the manufacturing country and required by the Customs department of the importing country to clear the items upon arrival. It is issued by the Chamber of Commerce of the exporting country.

[[Tots TV]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s British television series, 1993 British television series debuts, PBS Kids shows, English-language television programs

Tots TV is a British children's television programme, produced by Ragdoll Productions and Central.

The programme features three ragdoll friends: Tilly, a French girl, with red hair and white skin, who speaks in basic French (changed to English in French broadcasts, and changed to Spanish in the American version), Tom, a blue-haired boy with dark skin and glasses, and Tiny, the youngest Tot, who is smaller than the others and has green hair and white skin. It also featured their pet Donkey who lived in a stable next to the tots' secret house and a mischievous little dog named Furryboo that the tots never knew about.

Tots TV was written by two of its puppeteers Robin Stevens (Tom) and Andrew Davenport (Tiny). Tilly was played by three actresses – initially Véronique Deroulede, then Claire Carre and Alexandra Hogg. The series won two BAFTA awards for its producer Anne Wood and director Vic Finch. Originally broadcast in the UK on the ITV network (as part of CITV), CBeebies, the BBC's television channel for young children, picked up the series from 2004, where it first aired on the BBC Two block as well as the CBeebies channel, on the 19 April.

The series was also broadcast in the United States on the PBS network from 1996 to 2002 with Tilly speaking Spanish, instead of French. In 2000 Discovery Kids broadcast the series throughout Central and South America, the Caribbean and the Falkland Islands.

[[Game Over]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s American sitcoms, 2004 American television series debuts, 2004 American television series endings, English-language television programs

This is about a series. For the video game Game Over, see Game over(video game).

Game Over is a 2004 American adult computer-animated sitcom created by David Sacks (who would later become president of Nickelodeon Animation Studio), produced by Carsey-Werner Productions and broadcast on UPN in 2004. It was cancelled after five episodes.

Game Over (the title was inspired by the phrase "game over" that commonly concludes video games) focused on what happens to video game characters after the game ends. The show recounted the lives of the Smashenburns, a far-from-ordinary suburban family that lives in an alternate video game universe.

The show made numerous references to video games and even featured certain game characters as cameos. For example, Crash Bandicoot appears on a Got Milk? billboard whilst creatures from Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee appear in one of the episodes.

Marisa Tomei voiced Raquel Smashenburn in the series' unaired pilot episode, but scheduling problems made Lucy Liu take over the role for the actual series.

Game Over was heavily hyped by UPN before its debut. The series generally received positive press upon its airing. Despite this, only six episodes were made, which aired on a variety of different days – the fourth and fifth episodes were broadcast on April 2, 2004 and the sixth episode ("Monkey Dearest") was not aired.

[[Zhabinka]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Belarus

Zhabinka (Жабінка, ˈʐabʲinka; Жабинка; זשאבינקע Zhabinke, Żabinka) is a city of Brest Region. It is placed in the southwest of Belarus, near Brest. It is the administrative center of the Zhabinka District. In 2019, 14,577 people lived there.

[[Camillo Bazzoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Cinematographers, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters

Camillo Bazzoni (29 December 1934 – 8 October 2020) was an Italian cinematographer and movie director. He was born in Salsomaggiore Terme, Italy. His career began in 1960. From 1967 he worked as cinematographer with Lina Wertmüller, Mario Monicelli, Salvatore Samperi, Massimo Troisi, Franco Rossi. 

His first movie as a director was Suicide Commando, and a spaghetti western, A Long Ride from Hell.

Bazzoni died on 8 October 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Miguel Giubergia]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina, Argentine politicians

Miguel Giubergia (17 April 1953 – 8 October 2020) was a Argentine politician. He was a Deputy from 1999 to 2011. Giubergia was a member of the Radical Civic Union. He was born in Jujuy Province, Argentina.

Giubergia died on 8 October 2020 from COVID-19 in Jujuy Province at the age of 67.

[[Len Rossi]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from New York, Sportspeople from Tennessee, People from Utica, New York

Len Rossi (born Len Rositano; September 24, 1929 – October 9, 2020) was an American professional wrestler. He competed throughout the National Wrestling Alliance from 1958 to 1972. 

Rossi was also a member of both the NWA Hall of Fame in 2016 and the Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame in 2004. He was born in Utica, New York.

Rossi died on October 9, 2020 from cancer in Nolensville, Tennessee at the age of 91.

[[Nolensville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Tennessee

Nolensville is a town in Williamson County, Tennessee. The population was 5,861 at the 2010 census.

[[Vijay (director)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian screenwriters, Indian movie directors

Vijay Reddy (1936 – 9 October 2020) was an Indian movie director and screenwriter. He was born in Tadepalligudem, Andhra Pradesh. His career began in 1970 and he retired in 2003. He directed Gandhada Gudi, Mayura and Mojugara Sogasugara. His first movie was Rangamahal Rahasya and his last was Hrudayanjali.

Vijay died at a hospital in Chennai on 9 October 2020 from cardiac arrest at the age of 84.

[[Cecil Thiré]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors, Brazilian stage actors, Brazilian theatre directors, People from Rio de Janeiro

Cecil Aldary Portocarrero Thiré (May 28, 1943 – October 9, 2020) was a Brazilian actor and director. He was born in Rio de Janeiro. His career began in 1962. He was known for his works in The Guns, A Padroeira and Celebridade.

Thiré died on October 9, 2020 from Parkinson's disease-related problems in Rio de Janeiro, aged 77.

[[Kerry Roberts]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Year of birth missing (living people), State legislators of the United States, American radio personalities, Entertainers from Tennessee, Entertainers from Indiana, Politicians from Tennessee, Politicians from Indiana, US Republican Party politicians

Kerry E. Roberts is a Republican politician and radio personality. He is a member of the Tennessee Senate for the 25th district since 2015. From 2011 to 2013, he represented the 18th district.

In January 2020, Roberts left his weekly radio show on Springfield's WDBL and moved to Nashville's WLAC. He was born in Bedford, Indiana.

Roberts was hospitalized in October 2020 in Nashville, Tennessee after having an aneurysm.

[[Dune (2021 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 movies, 2020s science fiction movies, Upcoming movies, Movies based on books, American science fiction movies, American epic movies, Canadian movies, Hungarian movies, Movies directed by Denis Villeneuve, Movies set in deserts, Movies set on fictional planets

Dune is an upcoming epic science fiction movie directed by Denis Villeneuve. It is the first of a planned two-part adaptation of the 1965 novel of the same name by Frank Herbert.

It stars Timothée Chalamet, Rebecca Ferguson, Oscar Isaac, Josh Brolin, Stellan Skarsgård, Dave Bautista, Stephen McKinley Henderson, Zendaya, David Dastmalchian, Chang Chen, Sharon Duncan-Brewster, Charlotte Rampling, Jason Momoa and Javier Bardem.

Dune is scheduled to be released theatrically in the United States in IMAX and 3D on October 22, 2021, by Warner Bros. Pictures.

[[Timothée Chalamet]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Living people, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American child actors, Actors from New York City

Timothée Hal Chalamet (born December 27, 1995) is an American actor. He starred in Christopher Nolan's science-fiction movie Interstellar. Chalamet was born in New York City.

In 2017, Chalamet starred in the romantic drama Call Me by Your Name. He also starred in Hot Summer Nights and Lady Bird.

He starred as a drug-addicted teenager in the drama Beautiful Boy (2018), for which he was nominated for the BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role. In 2019, Chalamet starred in The King and Little Women.

[[Frank Herbert]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 1986 deaths, Deaths from pulmonary embolism, Deaths from surgical complications, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American novelists, American science fiction writers, People from Tacoma, Washington, Writers from Washington, Writers from Oregon, People from Salem, Oregon

Franklin Patrick Herbert Jr. (October 8, 1920 – February 11, 1986) was an American science-fiction author best known for the 1965 novel Dune and its five sequels.

Herbert died of a pulmonary embolism while recovering from pancreatic cancer surgery on February 11, 1986.

[[Josh Cooley]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, American animators, American voice actors, Movie directors from California, Screenwriters from California, Actors from Berkeley, California, Writers from Berkeley, California

Joshua Cooley (born May 23, 1980) is an American animator, screenwriter, director and voice actor. He is best known for working on the 2015 Pixar animated movie Inside Out and directing the short movie Riley's First Date?. He directed Toy Story 4.

[[Little Miss Marker (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, American movie remakes, Movies based on short stories

Little Miss Marker is a 1980 American comedy-drama movie directed by Walter Bernstein and was based on the short story by Damon Runyon. It stars Walter Matthau, Tony Curtis, Julie Andrews, Bob Newhart, Brian Dennehy, Lee Grant and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It is the fourth version of the 1934 movie Little Miss Marker.

[[Kingdom Hearts Birth by Sleep]]

Kingdom Hearts Birth by Sleep is a PlayStation Portable video game from the Kingdom Hearts series. It has the characters of the Final Fantasy series and Walt Disney characters; for example Donald Duck, Goofy and Mickey Mouse. The game is set ten years before Sora begins his journey. It was released in Japan on January 9, 2010, in North America on September 7, 2010, and in Europe on September 10, 2010. The player controls Terra, Aqua and Ventus in a storyline.

[[Onitsha]]

Onitsha (Ọ̀nị̀chà Mmílí or just Ọ̀nị̀chà) is a city on the east side of the Nigeria River, in Nigeria's Anambra State. It has a river port. In 2006, around 260,000 people lived there.

[[The Boss Baby]]

The Boss Baby  was released digitally on March 12, 2017, and was released on March 31.

[[Barrier island]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms

Barrier islands are landforms which are flat or lumpy areas of sand. It is formed by waves and tides. They usually occur in chains. It can consist from a few islands to more than a dozen. They can change during storms and other actions. The longest and widest barrier island is Padre Island of Texas.

[[Jorge Garcia]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Omaha, Nebraska, American bloggers

Jorge Garcia (born April 28, 1973) is an American movie, television and voice actor. He is known for his roles as Germur on Rock Dog and as Rodrigo on Phineas and Ferb. He also appeared in BoJack Horseman. He starred on Lost from 2004 to 2010.

[[Baymouth bar]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms

A baymouth bar is a landform that forms because of longshore drift. It is a sandbank that partially or completely closes a bay. They are usually made up of gravel and sand.

[[Getafe CF]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s establishments in Spain, 1983 establishments in Europe, Spanish football clubs, Community of Madrid

Getafe Club de Fútbol, or simply Getafe, is a Spanish football club based in Getafe, a city in the south of the Community of Madrid. The team competes in La Liga, the highest tier of the Spanish football system. The club's home stadium is Coliseum Alfonso Pérez which was opened in 1998 and has a capacity of 17,393. The club was founded in 1946 and refounded in 1983. Their main rival is CD Leganés, while they have a friendly rivalry against Atlético Madrid and Real Madrid.

It was nominated for 6 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1975.

[[Wandolleck's white-lipped tree frog]]

Wandolleck's white-lipped tree frog (Litoria albolabris) is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists have only seen it in West Sepik Province on the northern coast of the island.

[[DiGeorge syndrome]]

CATEGORIES: genetic disorders, Syndromes

DiGeorge syndrome, or 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a syndrome caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22. The symptoms are caused by the lack of those genes.  

The symptoms often include congenital heart problems, facial features,  infections, developmental delay, learning problems and cleft palate. Other conditions include kidney problems, hearing loss and autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis or Graves disease.

DiGeorge syndrome is due to the deletion of 30 to 40 genes in the middle of chromosome 22 at a location known as 22q11.2. About 90% of cases occur due to a new mutation during early development, while 10% are inherited from a person's parents. 

The condition is autosomal dominant: only one affected chromosome is needed for the condition to occur. Diagnosis is suspected based on the symptoms and confirmed by genetic testing.

Although there is no cure, treatment can improve symptoms. This often includes efforts to improve the function of the many organ systems involved. Long-term outcomes depend on the symptoms present and the severity of the heart and immune system problems. With treatment, life expectancy may be normal.

DiGeorge syndrome occurs in about 1 in 4,000 people. The syndrome was first described in 1968 by American physician Angelo DiGeorge. In late 1981, the underlying genetics were determined.

[[Tag out]]

CATEGORIES: Baseball rules, Sports words

In baseball, a player from the batting team is out when a fielder touches them with the ball while they are not standing on a base.

[[Elektryon]]

CATEGORIES: Greek mythology

Elektryon was a king in ancient Greek mythology. He was king a small fishing town in Mycenae.  Mycenae was part of Ancient Greece. He was the grandfather of the demigod Hercules.  Elektryon's daughter Alcmene was Hercules' human mother and the god Zeus was Hercules' father.  Elektryon became very sad when he found out his daughter Alcmene had had sexual intercourse with Zeus.  He told Alcmene to leave, so she went to a farming region.

[[Thing (comics)]]

CATEGORIES: Characters created by Stan Lee, Fantastic Four, Fictional characters introduced in 1961, Marvel Comics characters, Marvel Comics mutates

Benjamin Joseph Grimm (also known as The Thing) is a fictional character, a Marvel Comics superhero created by writer Stan Lee and artist/co-writer Jack Kirby. The character first appeared in Fantastic Four #1 in November 1961. Like the other founding members of the Fantastic Four, Ben received his powers after being exposed to a cosmic storm. His primary power is to clobber enemies. He has been adapted into motion pictures and is played by Michael Chiklis and Jamie Bell.

Doctor Doom is the archenemy of the Fantastic Four. He first appeared in Fantastic Four #5 (July 1962), created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby. He is the ruler of Latveria and CEO of Von Doom Industries.
