[[Andrew of Wyntoun]]

CATEGORIES: 14th century births, 15th century deaths, Scottish poets, Historians

Andrew of Wyntoun (also known as Andrew de Wyntoun  and Andrew Wyntoun) (1350), was a Scottish poet, a canon of St. Andrew's and a prior (higher-up within the Church) of St. Serf's Inch in Loch Leven. Wyntoun and John Barbour (The Brus, 1375) were the first people to write about history in the Scots language.

He wrote a long poetic history of Scotland, called the Orygynale Cronykil of Scotland, which included Scotland's mythical pre-history and finished when King James I came to power.

[[Arctic ice pack]]

CATEGORIES: Climate change

The Arctic ice pack or arctic ice cap is an ice shield covering the Arctic Ocean. It changes during the year. Usually, the ice melts in spring and summer, and increases during autumn and winter. The minimum cover is around mid-September.  Summer ice cover in the Arctic is about half of winter cover.  Some of the ice survives from one year to the next. Currently, 28% of Arctic basin sea ice is multi-year ice. Multi-year ice is thicker than seasonal ice: up to 3 thick over large areas, with ridges up to 20 thick.  As well as the regular seasonal cycle there has been an underlying trend of declining sea ice in the Arctic in recent decades.

[[Same Time, Next Year (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, 1978 drama movies, 1970s comedy-drama movies, 1970s romantic drama movies, American romantic comedy movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Robert Mulligan

Same Time, Next Year is a 1978 American romantic comedy-drama movie directed by Robert Mulligan and was based on the 1975 play of the same name by Bernard Slade. It stars Alan Alda, Ellen Burstyn, Ivan Bonar and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 4 Academy Awards in 1979.

[[Tom Parker (singer)]]

Thomas Anthony Parker (born yes) is an English singer, record producer and sound engineer. He is best known for being a member of the British-Irish boy band The Wanted. He was born in Bolton, Greater Manchester.

In October 2020, Parker was diagnosed with a terminal brain tumour.

[[Yanni]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Greek writers, Composers, Keyboardists, European pianists, Record producers, Greek businesspeople

Yiannis Chryssomallis (Γιάννης Χρυσομάλλης, born November 14, 1954), known professionally as Yanni (Yanni (spoken word).ogg ˈ), is a Greek composer, keyboardist, pianist, and music producer. He was born in Kalamata, Greece.

At least sixteen of Yanni's albums have peaked at No. 1 in Billboard's "Top New Age Album" category, and two albums (Dare to Dream and In My Time) received Grammy Award nominations. His career began in 1980.

[[John Derek]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, Cardiovascular disease deaths in California, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American photographers, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Movie directors from Los Angeles, California, Movie producers from Los Angeles, California, Screenwriters from Los Angeles, California

John Derek (born Derek Delevan Harris; August 12, 1926 – May 22, 1998) was an American actor, director, screenwriter, producer and photographer. He appeared in many movies such as Knock on Any Door, All the King's Men (both 1949), and Rogues of Sherwood Forest (1950). 

He was known for his marriage with Bo Derek, which lasted from 1976 until his death in 1998. He was born in Los Angeles.

Derek died on May 22, 1998 from heart disease in Santa Maria, California at the age of 71.

[[Margaret Nolan]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in London, English models, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, People from Hampstead, Actors from Somerset, Actors from London, Actors who played in James Bond movies

Margaret A. Nolan (29 October 1943 – 5 October 2020) was an English visual artist, actress and model. She was best known for her appearances in the 1964 movies Goldfinger and A Hard Day's Night. Nolan was born in Norton Radstock, Somerset. Her career lasted from 1964 to 2019.

Nolan died on 5 October 2020 in London from cancer at the age of 76.

[[Jean Martin (pianist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, French pianists, People from Lyon

Jean Martin (7 November 1927 – 7 October 2020) was a French pianist. He was born in Lyon, France.

Martin began a teaching career, starting in Grenoble in 1953. He recorded two albums dedicated to the works of Carl Maria von Weber, five dedicated to Robert Schumann, two to Stephen Heller and Gabriel Fauré. In 1970, he played with the Trio Delta with violinist Flora Elphège and cellist Claude Burgos.

Martin died on 7 October 2020 in Paris, aged 92.

[[Stephen Heller]]

Stephen Heller (Heller István) (15 May 1815spaced ndash14 January 1888) was a Hungarian pianist, teacher and composer. Heller was an important figure for later Romantic composers.

John Wilson Sutherland NZL (1927 – 8 October 2020) was a New Zealand sprinter. He won a bronze medal representing his country at the 1950 British Empire Games. He was born in Oamaru, New Zealand.

Sutherland died on 8 October 2020 in Oamaru at the age of 93.

[[Carlton Chapman]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2020 deaths, Indian footballers, Football managers, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Carlton Anthony Chapman (13 April 1971 – 12 October 2020) was an Indian professional footballer.

Chapman played as midfielder for the Indian national team between 1995 and 2001 and also captained the team. He played with East Bengal and JCT Mills.

As coach, Chapman had a six-year career with I-League 2nd Division club Tata Football Academy from 2002 to 2008, followed by Royal Wahingdoh FC and Students Union of the Bangalore Super Division.

Chapman died in Bangalore from a heart attack on 12 October 2020, aged 49.

[[Hugo Arana]]

Hugo Arana (July 23, 1943 – October 11, 2020) was an Argentine actor and comedian. He was born in Monte Grande, Argentina. His career began in 1970. His best known roles were in El Santo de la Espada, The Truce and Los exitosos Pells.

Arana died at a Buenos Aires hospital from COVID-19 on October 11, 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Boro Drljača]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Serbian singers, Television personalities, Folk singers

Borislav Drljača (Serbian Cyrillic: Борислав Дрљача; 29 August 1941 – 11 October 2020), better known as Bora Drljača, was a Serbian folk singer. 

Drljača recorded over four hundred songs including "Stari vuk" (Old Wolf), "Ne namiguj na me tuđa ženo" (Don't Wink at Me, Someone Else's Wife), and "Plači, mala, plači" (Cry, Baby, Cry).

Drljača also appeared on reality shows Veliki Brat VIP 4 (2010) and Parovi 4 (2015). 

Drljača died of colon cancer on 11 October 2020 in Belgrade, aged 79.

[[Ângelo Martins]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Portuguese footballers

Ângelo Gaspar Martins (19 April 1930 – 11 October 2020), simply known as Ângelo, was a Portuguese footballer. He played as a defender for Benfica and the Portugal national team. His career lasted from 1945 to 1962. He was born in Porto, Portugal.

Martins died on 11 October 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Jamie Raskin]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, United States representatives from Maryland, American educators, American political writers, Politicians from Washington, D.C., US Democratic Party politicians

Jamin Ben "Jamie" Raskin (born December 13, 1962) is a Jewish politician. He was the U.S. Representative for Maryland's 8th congressional district since 2017. He is a Democrat. He was a member of the Maryland State Senate from 2007 to 2016.

Raskin supports banning discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity. In 2019, he voted in favor of the Equality Act and urged Congress members to do the same. 

[[Marcus Raskin]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2017 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Washington, D.C., American political activists, American political writers, American philosophers, American critics, American progressives, Writers from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Writers from Washington, D.C.

Marcus Goodman Raskin (April 30, 1934 – December 24, 2017) was an American social critic, political activist, author, and philosopher. He worked for progressive social change in the United States.

He was the co-founder, with Richard Barnet, of the progressive think tank, the Institute for Policy Studies in Washington, DC.  He was also a professor of public policy at George Washington University’s School of Public Policy and Public Administration.

Raskin died of heart disease on December 24, 2017 in Washington, D.C. at the age of 83.

[[Terry McBrayer]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American lawyers, American lobbyists, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Kentucky, Politicians from Ohio, People from Lexington, Kentucky, US Democratic Party politicians

W. Terry McBrayer (September 1, 1937 – October 11, 2020) was an American lobbyist, attorney, and Democratic politician. He was born in Ironton, Ohio. He was a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives between 1966 until his retirement in 1976. 

McBrayer died on October 11, 2020 in Lexington, Kentucky from cancer, aged 83.

[[Bette Greene]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, American novelists, Deaths from heart failure, Writers from Memphis, Tennessee

Bette Greene (June 28, 1934 – October 2, 2020) was an American author of many books for children and young adults. Some of her best known works were Summer of My German Soldier, The Drowning of Stephan Jones, and the Newbery Honor book Philip Hall Likes Me, I Reckon Maybe. She was born in Memphis, Tennessee.

Greene died of heart failure on October 2, 2020 at her home in Lakewood Ranch, Florida at the age of 86.

[[Lakewood Ranch, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Florida

Lakewood Ranch is a planned community located in southeastern Manatee County and northeastern Sarasota County, Florida, United States. It is about 31000.

It is part of the North Port-Bradenton-Sarasota, Florida Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[C. M. Chang]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

C. M. Chang (born Chongshen Mongkosungkum Chang; 1 April 1942 – 12 October 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Nationalist Democratic Progressive Party. He was born in Tuensang, Nagaland. He was a member of the Lok Sabha between 2009 to 2014. He also was a member of the Nagaland Legislative Assembly between 2013 until his death.

Chang died on 12 October 2020 at a hospital in Kohima, Nagaland from COVID-19 at the age of 78.

[[Yehoshua Kenaz]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli writers, Translators, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Israel

Yehoshua Kenaz (יהושע קנז) ( 2 March 1937 – 12 October 2020) was an Israeli novelist. He was born in Petah Tikva, in the British Mandate of Palestine.

He translated many French classics into Hebrew, and worked on the editorial staff of the Ha'aretz newspaper. 

He was awarded the Alterman Prize in 1991, the Newman Prize in 1992, the Agnon Prize (1993), the ACUM Prize (1994) and the Bialik Prize (1995).

In 2007, Infiltration was named one of the ten most important books in Israeli history.

Kenaz died on 12 October 2020 in Jerusalem from COVID-19 at the age of 83.

[[Ilya Moiseev]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Russian chemists, People from Moscow

Ilya Iosifovich Moiseev (Илья Иосифович Моисеев; 15 March 1929 – 11 October 2020) was a Russian chemist. He was an expert in both kinetics and the coordination chemistry of transition metals. He was known for his works in metal-complex catalysis. In 1992, he was elected to the Russian Academy of Sciences. Moiseev was born in Moscow.

Moiseev died on 11 October 2020 in Moscow, aged 91.

[[The Mummy Returns]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 movies, 2000s adventure movies, 2000s fantasy movies, 2000s horror movies, American adventure movies, American fantasy movies, American horror movies, Movies directed by Stephen Sommers, Movies set in Egypt, Movies set in the 1930s, Multilingual movies, The Mummy, Universal Pictures movies, Screenplays by Stephen Sommers

The Mummy Returns is a 2001 American fantasy adventure horror movie. It is a sequel to 1999's The Mummy.

[[John A. Ruthven]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American painters, People from Cincinnati, Ohio

John Aldrich Ruthven (November 12, 1924 – October 11, 2020) was an American artist best known for his paintings of wildlife. He was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. In 2004, President George W. Bush honored him with the National Medal of Arts. Ruthven's wildlife paintings are on display at many museums including the Smithsonian Institution.

Ruthven died at his home in Georgetown, Ohio on October 11, 2020 at the age of 95.

[[Paul Milgrom]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, American economists, American educators, American Nobel Prize winners, Jewish American academics, Jewish American scientists, Jewish Nobel Prize winners, Scientists from Detroit, Michigan, Stanford University alumni, Stanford University faculty, Writers from Detroit, Michigan, Yale University faculty

EconomicsPaul Robert Milgrom (born April 20, 1948) is an American economist. 

He is the Shirley and Leonard Ely Professor of Humanities and Sciences at Stanford University.

Milgrom is an expert in game theory, mainly auction theory and pricing strategies. He is the winner of the 2020 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, together with Robert B. Wilson, "for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats."

[[Human Torch]]

CATEGORIES: Characters created by Stan Lee, Fantastic Four, Fictional characters introduced in 1961, Fictional characters with fire or heat abilities, Marvel Comics characters, Marvel Comics mutates

Johnny Storm (also known as Human Torch) is a fictional character, a Marvel Comics superhero created by writer Stan Lee and artist/co-writer Jack Kirby. The character first appeared in Fantastic Four #1 in November 1961. Like the other founding members of the Fantastic Four, Johnny received his powers after being exposed to a cosmic storm. His primary power is to use fire and fly while on fire. He is also the Invisible Woman's brother. He has been adapted into motion pictures and is played by Chris Evans and Michael B. Jordan.

[[Kimberly rocket frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The Kimberly rocket frog (Litoria axillaris) is a frog from Australia.  It lives in the Kimberly region in Western Australia.

This frog is about 2.6 cm long.  It has a triangular head and long front and hind legs.  It is brown or gray in color with dark stripes down its sides and other stripes on its back.  It has climbing discs on its toes but they are not very large.  Its front feet have some webbing but are not webbed all the way to the ends of the toes.  Scientists have only seen this frog on rock platforms made of sandstone.

This frog is called axillaris in Latin because of the stripes on its sides.

[[The Scorpion King]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 movies, 2000s adventure movies, 2000s fantasy movies, American adventure movies, American fantasy movies, English-language movies, Movies directed by Chuck Russell, Movies set in prehistory, Movie spin-offs, Prequel movies, The Mummy, The Scorpion King (movie series), Universal Pictures movies, Screenplays by Stephen Sommers, Period action movies

The Scorpion King is a 2002 American fantasy adventure movie. It is a spin-off/prequel to 1999's The Mummy. It has Dwayne Johnson's first lead role in a movie.

[[1935 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Weather

The 1935 Atlantic Hurricane Season had eight storms, with five hurricanes and three major hurricanes. It lasted from May 15, to November 14. The season included the Labor Day Hurricane.

[[Native element mineral]]

CATEGORIES: Minerals

A native element mineral or native metal is any element that is found as a pure metal in nature. 

The list of metals include aluminium, antimony, arsenic, bismuth, cadmium, chromium, cobalt, indium, iron, manganese, molybdenum, nickel, niobium, rhenium, selenium, tantalum, tellurium, tin, titanium, tungsten, vanadium, zinc, gold, copper, lead, mercury, silver, platinum, iridium, osmium, palladium, rhodium and ruthenium.

[[Passivation (chemistry)]]

CATEGORIES: Metallurgy

In physical chemistry and engineering, passivation, refers to a material that becomes less affected by corrosion. Passivation involves making an outer layer out of a material that is less affected by corrosion. The material is put on as a microcoating. Passivation can only occur in certain conditions. It is used in microelectronics.

[[Glossary of astronomy]]

CATEGORIES: Astronomy lists, Glossaries

This glossary of astronomy is a list of terms and concepts of astronomy and cosmology and their sub-disciplines.

[[Orgazmo]]

CATEGORIES: NC-17 rated movies, American comedy movies, 1997 comedy movies, American superhero movies

Orgazmo is a 1997 American sex comedy and superhero movie. It was written, directed by and stars Trey Parker. Matt Stone co-directed the movie. He also stars in it.

[[Musi-Video]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian television series, 1980s television series, 1980s Canadian television series

Musi-Video was a music video series that was shown in Canada from 1980 and 1984. It was syndicated to community channels all around Canada. It was a very early example of the format that was later used by MTV and MuchMusic.

The series was made by Marc Fontaine, who was part of the new wave pop group Nudimension. The series was produced in Montreal, and featured early 1980s music artists playing live in a studio, and early music videos.

In 2008 the Musi-Video brand was revived as a music publishing label by Marc Fontaine.

[[Terminator (character)]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 1984, Mortal Kombat guest characters, Science fiction movie characters, Terminator (franchise)

The Terminator is a fictional character from The Terminator. He first appeared in the 1984 movie The Terminator before becoming a protagonist starting with Terminator 2: Judgment Day.

[[Yautja]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 1987, Mortal Kombat guest characters

Yautja are fictional aliens created by James Cameron made for the Predator franchise starting in 1987.

[[Ahsoka Tano]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 2008, Fictional war veterans, Star Wars characters

Ahsoka Tano is a fictional character and a heroine in the Star Wars series.

[[Enter the Matrix]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 video games, Atari video games, Matrix series, Nintendo GameCube games, PlayStation 2 games, Xbox games

Enter the Matrix is a 2003 action-adventure video game based on The Matrix and its sequels. It was written and directed by The Wachowskis. It notably has an hour of movie footage made just for the game with the actors intact.

[[Spawn (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 action movies, 1990s superhero movies, African-American superhero movies, American action movies, English-language movies, New Line Cinema movies, Spawn (comics), Movies set in North Korea, American superhero movies

Spawn is an 1997 superhero movie that was based on the 1990s superhero character of the same name created by Todd McFarlane.

[[Fantastic Four (2005 video game)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 video games, Fantastic Four (movie series), Fantastic Four video games, Game Boy Advance games, Nintendo GameCube games, PlayStation 2 games, Superhero video games, Xbox games

Fantastic Four is an action-adventure video game made by Vicarious Visions. It can be played on the PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube, Game Boy Advance and Xbox. The game is based on the Marvel Comics superhero team The Fantastic Four and is also based on the 2005 movie. It has Ioan Gruffudd, Jessica Alba, Michael Chiklis, Chris Evans and Julian McMahon returning from the movie into voicing the characters.

[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (2014 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 action movies, 2010s superhero movies, Paramount movies, Platinum Dunes movies, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movies, Reboot movies

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is a fantasy action movie. It was made in the United States and released in 2014. It is part of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (TMNT) series. The movie is the first in the rebooted TMNT movie series. It is the first TMNT movie to use motion capture for the turtles.

The movie was financially successful and got a sequel in 2016 but had bad reviews.

[[Mononuclidic element]]

CATEGORIES: Isotopes, Chemical elements

A mononuclidic element or monotopic element is a chemical elements that is found naturally on Earth as only one nuclide. Most elements have many nuclides, that is their nuclei may have various numbers of neutrons. The single nuclide of a mononuclidic element may, or may not, be a stable one. There are 21 mononuclidic elements.

[[Notes on Nationalism]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 works, Essays, Nationalism

Notes on Nationalism is a well-known essay written by George Orwell. Orwell wrote the essay in May 1945, in a journal called Polemic, after the Second World War had ended. In the essay, Orwell describes his idea of nationalism as:

Here, he links nationalism to political power, influence and factionalism. He says nationalism is not the same as patriotism, as patriotism "is of its nature defensive.... Nationalism, on the other hand, is inseparable (hard to separate) from the desire for power."

He says that it can be positive, i.e. for something, such as one's country. Orwell says Celtic nationalism and Zionism are examples of this sort of nationalism. On the other hand, it can be negative, i.e. against something, such as another group. Orwell says Anti-Soviet Trotskyism ans Antisemitism are examples of this sort.

Transferred nationalism is a third kind. This is identification and promotion of a different race, social class, or country to your own.

[[Grim & Evil]]

CATEGORIES: Cartoon Network series, The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy, 2001 American television series debuts, 2003 American television series endings, English-language television programs

Grim & Evil is an American animated television series. It was created by Maxwell Atoms. It was originally shown on the Cartoon Network. It began on August 24, 2001 and ended on 2003. There are two segments shown in the show that became their solo shows in 2003: The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy and Evil Con Carne. Grim focuses on two kids who become friends with the Grim Reaper. Evil focuses on the brain of a Mexican playboy who wants to collect the rest of his organs for world domination.

The series is targeted at 9–14 year olds.

The directors of episodes included Juli Murphy, Robert Alvarez, Brain Sheesley, Shaun Cashman, Eddy Houchins, Sue Perrotto, Randy Myers, John McIntyre, Phil Cummings, Matt Engstrom, Kris Sherwood, and Russell Calabrese.

Writers for the series were Maxwell Atoms, Gord Zajac and Chris Reccardi.

== Cast == 

[[Harold Betters]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, American trombonists, Musicians from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Harold Betters (March 21, 1928 – October 11, 2020) was an American jazz trombone player. His career was based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Betters released nine LPs on Gateway Records, and three LPs for Reprise. He was born in Connellsville, Pennsylvania. In the 1950s he made a tour with the Ray Charles big band, playing at the Apollo Theatre.

Betters died on October 11, 2020 in Pittsburgh at the age of 92.

[[Telehit Música (Mexican TV channel)]]

Telehit Música its programming is filmed in the case mexican of the list in the Mexican channel.

[[Gary F. Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from California, People from Long Beach, California

Gary F. Jones (June 16, 1944 – October 11, 2020) was an American trainer of Thoroughbred racehorses. His career began in 1974 and ended with his retirement at the end of July, 1996. He won 1,465 races including 102 graded stakes. Jones was elected to the United States Racing Hall of Fame in 2014. He was born in Long Beach, California.

Jones died on October 11, 2020 in Del Mar, California at the age of 76.

[[The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy (video game)]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 video games, Fighting games, Game Boy Advance games, The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy, Nintendo GameCube games, PlayStation 2 games, Wii games

The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy is a fighting video game made by High Voltage Software. It can be played on the PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube, Game Boy Advance and Nintendo Wii. The game is based on the Cartoon Network show The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy.

[[Del Mar, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in San Diego County, California

Del Mar is a beach city in San Diego County, California, United States. The population was at 4,347 in 2018.

[[Joe Morgan]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from neurodegenerative disease, Cincinnati Reds players, Houston Astros players, San Francisco Giants players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Oakland Athletics players, Deaths from myelodysplastic syndrome

Joe Leonard Morgan (September 19, 1943 – October 11, 2020) was an American professional baseball second baseman. He played Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Houston Astros, Cincinnati Reds, San Francisco Giants, Philadelphia Phillies, and Oakland Athletics from 1963 to 1984. He won two World Series championships with the Reds in 1975 and 1976 and was also named the National League Most Valuable Player (MVP) in each of those years. 

Morgan was honored into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1990.

Morgan was born in Bonham, Texas. In 2015, Morgan was diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome and leukemia. He died on October 11, 2020 from polyneuropathy, at his home in Danville, California at the age of 77.

[[Danville, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Contra Costa County, California, Cities in the San Francisco Bay Area

The Town of Danville is located in the San Ramon Valley in Contra Costa County, California. The population was 42,039 at the 2010 census. 

In 2020, Danville was named "the safest town in California". 

[[Sarat Kumar Kar]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian writers

Sarat Kumar Kar (5 September 1939 – 12 October 2020) was an Indian politician and writer. He was a member of the Biju Janata Dal (BJD) political party. He was born in Cuttack, India. He was a member of the Odisha Legislative Assembly (OLA) from 1971 to 1974, 1990 to 1995 and 2000 to 2004. From 2000 to 2004, he was the Speaker of the OLA. He was a member of Lok Sabha from 1977 to 1980.

Kar died on 12 October 2020 from COVID-19, aged 81.

[[Éric Assous]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, French movie directors, French screenwriters, Tunisian writers, People from Tunis

Éric Assous (30 March 1956 – 12 October 2020) was a Tunisian-born French director, screenwriter and dramatist. He was born in Tunis, Tunisia. Assous was known for directing and writing The Banned Woman, The Girl from Paris and 22 Bullets.

Assous died on 12 October 2020 in Paris at the age of 64.

[[Samuel Brittan]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Journalists from London

Sir Samuel Brittan (29 December 1933 – 12 October 2020) was an English journalist and author. He was the first economics correspondent for the Financial Times. He was a member of the Academic Advisory Council of the Global Warming Policy Foundation. He was born in London. In 1961, Brittan was appointed economics editor at The Observer until 1964 and in 1965 was appointed as an advisor at the Department of Economic Affairs.

Brittan died on 12 October 2020 in London at the age of 86.

[[Richie Barker (footballer, born 1939)]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from Leicestershire

Richie Joseph Barker (23 November 1939 – 11 October 2020) was an English footballer and manager. He played in the Football League for Derby County, Notts County and Peterborough United. He was also manager of Shrewsbury Town, Stoke City, Notts County, Ethnikos Piraeus (Greece), Zamalek (Egypt) and West Bromwich Albion.

[[Barry Keoghan]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Irish movie actors, Irish television actors, Irish voice actors, Actors from Dublin

Barry Keoghan (k; born 18 October 1992) is an Irish actor. He has appeared in the movies Dunkirk, The Killing of a Sacred Deer, for which he won an Irish Film and Television Award for Best Supporting Actor; and Trespass Against Us.

[[Lyuben Gotsev]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Bulgarian politicians, People from Sofia

Lyuben Gotsev Stoyanov (3 March 1930 – 7 October 2020) was a Bulgarian politician. He was born in Sofia, Bulgaria. He was a member of the Bulgarian Communist Party and Bulgarian Socialist Party. During the Andrey Lukanov cabinet, he was the Minister of Foreign Affairs between 22 September 1990 to 20 December 1990. 

Gotsev died on 7 October 2020 in Sofia at the age of 90.

[[Highspire, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Highspire is a borough in Dauphin County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 2,399 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Harrisburg–Carlisle Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania, County seats in Pennsylvania

Carlisle is a borough in and the county seat of Cumberland County, Pennsylvania, United States. As of the 2010 census, the borough population was 18,682. 

[[Polyneuropathy]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Polyneuropathy (poly- + neuro- + -pathy) is damage or disease affecting peripheral nerves (peripheral neuropathy) in roughly the same areas on both sides of the body, featuring weakness, numbness, and burning pain. 

It usually begins in the hands and feet and may progress to the arms and legs and sometimes to other parts of the body where it may affect the autonomic nervous system. 

Diabetes and some types of Guillain–Barré syndrome can cause this disease.

[[Deedee Magno Hall]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American pop singers, American stage actors, Actors from Virginia, Singers from Virginia, People from Portsmouth, Virginia

Deedee Lynn Magno Hall (born April 2, 1975)  is an American actress and singer. She is best known for her work in the pop group The Party, and as the voice of Pearl and other characters in the animated series Steven Universe and its sequel series Steven Universe Future. Hall was born in Portsmouth, Virginia.

[[Mister Fantastic]]

CATEGORIES: Characters created by Stan Lee, Fantastic Four, Fictional characters introduced in 1961, Marvel Comics characters, Marvel Comics mutates

Reed Richards (also known as Mister Fantastic) is a fictional character, a Marvel Comics superhero created by writer Stan Lee and artist/co-writer Jack Kirby. The character first appeared in Fantastic Four #1 in November 1961. Like the other founding members of the Fantastic Four, Reed received his powers after being exposed to a cosmic storm. His primary power is to stretch his body to lengths. He is also the Invisible Woman's husband. He has been adapted into motion pictures and is played by Ioan Gruffudd and Miles Teller.

[[Hellboy (2004 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: American fantasy movies, 2004 movies, 2000s fantasy movies, German movies, Hellboy movies, Hungarian movies, English-language movies, Movies directed by Guillermo del Toro, Movies set in the 1940s, Movies set in 2004, Apocalyptic movies, American superhero movies

Hellboy is a 2004 movie. It was directed by Guillermo del Toro and stars Ron Perlman. It is based on the Dark Horse Comics character of the same name.

It had a 2008 sequel made by Universal called Hellboy II: The Golden Army.

[[Hellboy (2019 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: American fantasy movies, Arthurian movies, 2019 movies, 2010s fantasy movies, English-language movies, Hellboy movies, Lionsgate movies, Reboot movies, American superhero movies, 2010s superhero movies, Movies about giants

Hellboy is a 2019 movie and a reboot to the 2000s movies. It is based on the Dark Horse Comics character of the same name.

Unlike the 2000s movies, many fans and critics didn't like it and it was a box office bomb.

[[Batman Begins (video game)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 video games, Batman video games, Electronic Arts video games, Game Boy Advance games, Nintendo GameCube games, PlayStation 2 games, Superhero video games, The Dark Knight Trilogy, Xbox games

Batman Begins is a 2005 stealth/action-adventure video game based on the 2005 movie Batman Begins. It has all of the cast returning except Gary Oldman. It was also going to be released for the PlayStation Portable but got cancelled.

[[Spider-Man 3 (video game)]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 video games, Game Boy Advance games, Nintendo DS games, Wii games, Xbox 360 games, PlayStation 2 games, PlayStation 3 games, Windows games, Spider-Man (2002 movie series), Spider-Man video games, Video games based on Spider-Man movies

Spider-Man 3 is a 2007 action-adventure video game based on the 2007 movie Spider-Man 3 released for Game Boy Advance, Microsoft Windows, Nintendo DS, PlayStation 2, Wii, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3. A GameCube version was also planned, but was canceled. Tobey Maguire and several other cast members including Topher Grace, James Franco, and Thomas Haden Church return to voice in the game, with Bruce Campbell as the narrator.

[[Aldridge Bousfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American mathematicians, Scientists from Boston, Massachusetts

Aldridge Knight Bousfield (5 April 1941 – 4 October 2020), known as Pete, was an American mathematician. He was known for his works in Algebraic Topology and for the idea of Bousfield localization. Bousfield was born in Boston, Massachusetts. He was a Fellow of the American Mathematical Society,

Bousfield died on 4 October 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Telestrations]]

CATEGORIES: Games

Telestrations is a party game in which players must draw an object listed on a card, then guess what the other players have drawn. USAopoly makes the game.

[[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen]]

CATEGORIES: 1792 births, 1849 deaths, Kings and Queens consort of the United Kingdom, House of Hanover

Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen (13 August 1792 – 2 December 1849) was the wife of King William IV of the United Kingdom. She was the daughter of George I, Duke of Saxe-Meiningen, and Luise Eleonore of Hohenlohe-Langenburg.

[[Grand Canyon (1991 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Lawrence Kasdan

Grand Canyon is a 1991 American drama movie directed by Lawrence Kasdan and stars Danny Glover, Kevin Kline, Steve Martin, Alfre Woodward, Mary McDonnell, Mary-Louise Parker, Tina Lifford. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was a minor box office failure. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1992.

[[Izumi Matsumoto]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese manga artists

Kazuya Terashima was a Japanese manga artist. He was best known for Kimagure Orange Road. His career started in 1982. Some of his works were on Weekly Shōnen Jump. He was born in Takaoka, Toyama.

In November 2019, Terashima revealed that he had been diagnosed with spinal stenosis. Matsumoto died at 61 on October 6, 2020.

[[Spinal stenosis]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal or neural foramen. It can cause pressure on the spinal cord or nerve roots. 

Symptoms may include pain, numbness, or weakness in the arms or legs.

Symptoms usually get worse over time. Severe symptoms may include bladder and bowel problems or sexual dysfunction.

[[Sexual dysfunction]]

CATEGORIES: Medical signs

Sexual dysfunction is a medical problem in which a person or a couple have problems during any stage of sex and can make it hard for them to have an arousal or orgasm. 

Sexual dysfunction happens when a person feels extremely uncomfortable for a minimum of six months. Sexual dysfunctions can have a profound impact on an individual's perceived quality of sexual life. 

[[Pat Hooper]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Competitors in athletics, Irish Olympians, Sportspeople from Dublin

Patrick Hooper (12 May 1952 – 9 October 2020) was an Irish Olympian and long-distance runner. He was born in Dublin. He represented Ireland in the marathon at European and Olympic level. His marathon personal best time was 2:17:46. He participated in the 1980 Summer Olympics coming in 40th place.

He was the older brother of three-time Olympian and marathoner Dick Hooper.

Hooper died on 9 October 2020 in Dublin, aged 68.

[[Edward Nabunone]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian people, Olympians, Competitors in athletics

Anderias Hiler Eduardus "Edward" Nabunone (21 April 1968 – 12 October 2020) was an Indonesian long-distance runner. He competed in the men's 5000 metres and the 10,000 metres  at the 1988 Summer Olympics.

Nabunone died on 12 October 2020 at the age of 52.

[[Rashid Haider]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1941 births, Bangladeshi writers, Deaths from stroke, Novelists

Rashid Haider (15 July 1941 – 13 October 2020) was a Bangladeshi writer. His novels include Khancay (1975), Nashta Josnay Ekon Aranya (1982), Sadh Ahlad (1985), Andha Kathamala (1987), Asamabriksha (1987) and Mabuhai (1988). He was awarded Ekushey Padak in 2014 by the government of Bangladesh. He was born in Pabna.

In February 2020, Haider had a stroke. He died later that year, on 13 October, at the age of 79.

[[Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Serbia, 1992 establishments in Europe, Airports in Europe, Buildings and structures in Serbia, Belgrade

Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport (Aerodrom Nikola Tesla Beograd) or Belgrade Airport (Aerodrom Beograd) BEG is an airport in Belgrade, Serbia. It is run by the French company Vinci Airports. The Serbian national plane company uses Belgrade Nikola Tesla as their hub. It was founded on 13 March 1992; 28 years ago. In 2019 it had seen 6,159,000 passengers and 20,064 tons of cargo pass through it.

[[Jack Skellington]]

CATEGORIES: Disney characters, Fictional characters introduced in 1993, Kingdom Hearts characters, The Nightmare Before Christmas

Jack Skellington is the main character of the 1993 movie The Nightmare Before Christmas. Jack is the "Pumpkin King" of Halloween Town, a world based on Halloween. Jack is voiced by Chris Sarandon. Danny Elfman provided Jack's singing voice. The character is shown on various merchandise.

[[Rocky III]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s sports movies, 1982 drama movies, Movies set in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Movies directed by Sylvester Stallone, Screenplays by Sylvester Stallone, Rocky movies

Rocky III is a 1982 American sports drama movie. It was directed, written by, and starred, Sylvester Stallone. The movie is a famed boxer fighting against Clubber Lang.

It was followed by Rocky IV in 1985.
